webTitle: Small press corner: Charles, Diana and Me

fields.headline: Small press corner
fields.trailText: This is one of five slim books by Libya's greatest living writer, published by Kegan Paul.
fields.body:
Charles, Diana and Me and Other Stories
Ahmed Fagih
(Kegan Paul, £19.95)

This is one of five slim books by Libya's greatest living writer, published by Kegan Paul - a distinguished imprint for more than 100 years, but now rather caught in the interstices of international publishing. There's real literary quality in the tales themselves, the title one about Diana (written before her death) being the ironical address of an obsessive to the princess. The effect is rather as if a British writer had written a similar story about Colonel Gadafy.

The other books in the series are: Valley of the Ashes (a coming-of-age novella), Who's Afraid of Agatha Christie? (more short stories), Gazelles (plays) and Libyan Stories , a collection of the work of others edited by Fagih.

Fagih is clearly quite brilliant, but the translation feels bad: it is a further mark of Fagih's abilities that his merit shines through nonetheless. In other words, you get a sense of genius brought low. And by itself, too: Fagih reportedly translated the works himself with the help of friends.

Nor, alas, have the books been packaged in a very attractive way - it doesn't inspire confidence that the publisher misspells its own name on the cover of Libyan Stories. But Kegan/Keegan Paul is to be congratulated for bringing Fagih's intriguing work to Britain.

fields.headline: Dead bodies in suburbia
fields.standfirst: Robert Cormier tells Lyn Gardner why teenage readers are so demanding
fields.trailText: Robert Cormier tells Lyn Gardner why teenage readers are so demanding
fields.body:
"There are no taboos. Every topic is open, however shocking. It is the way that the topics are handled that's important, and that applies whether it is a 15-year-old who is reading your book or someone who is 55," says US novelist Robert Cormier, whose 13th book for teenagers, Frenchtown Summer, has just been published.

Since The Chocolate War, a coruscating attack on intimidation and corruption in a private American Catholic academy, was published in 1974, Cormier has been pushing hard at the boundaries of young adult fiction. This is no mean feat in a country where Harry Potter has been accused of encouraging Satanism and there have been calls to ban Goldilocks and the Three Bears because of her propensity for breaking and entering.

Yet Cormier has continued to create work that writes up to his audience, not down to them. In Tenderness, he charted a promiscuous young girl's fixation with a serial killer; The Bumblebee Flies Anyway, set among the terminally ill teenage inmates of an experimental medical institution, was an extraordinary study of tiny moments of hope amid black despair; while his psychological thrillers, such as We All Fall Down and I Am Cheese, don't for a moment shirk the cruelties that humans inflict upon each other.

So Frenchtown Summer, an elegiac account of a young paperboy's journey to self-awareness as he walks the streets of his hometown more than 50 years ago, is something of a surprise. Not least because it is written in the form of a prose poem, and because the writing swells with tenderness.

Not, of course, that Cormier neglects to tell it how it really is. There are bullies on the street corner, and the mysteries of incipient adulthood meld into darker mysteries that lurk behind the town's sunlit streets. As Cormier's editor noted, the book might be hauntingly beautiful, but Cormier still managed to get a dead body into it.

That is because there really was one. Frenchtown Summer is set in the same small American town that features in almost all of Cormier's work, the one where he grew up and has lived almost all his life. And as a child, he was haunted by an unsolved murder that had taken place long before he was born.

Cormier still lives just three miles from the house where he was born. For 30 years he worked as a journalist on the local paper, covering everything from the police news to the births, deaths and weddings.

All this has fed into his novels, which create a fascinating portrait of suburban American life seen through the eyes of children. There is a wonderful chapter in The Chocolate War when Jerry's doubts about his father, and his fear of growing up to become his father, are represented by that most homely of American suppers - the tuna casserole.

Even The Chocolate War was inspired by a real-life incident: back in the early 1970s, Cormier's then teenage son refused to take part in the annual school fund-raising sale as a matter of principle. The worst Cormier's son endured was some joshing and bad-mouthing, but in The Chocolate War it is magnified into an almost life-and-death struggle, as Jerry's refusal to sell 50 boxes of chocolates for the school pits him against the corruption of both his teachers and the school's home-grown student Mafia.

Cormier was surprised when his agent informed him that he had written a book for teenagers. "I wrote the book entirely innocent that there were such things as young adult novels. I thought I was just writing a novel," he says. The subject matter, the number of characters and the lack of an optimistic ending made publishers nervous: there were seven rejections before the book was finally accepted.

A glowing front-page review in the literary section of the New York Times gave the book the status of an instant children's classic, although like almost all of Cormier's books, it has been subject to frequent campaigns by those who believe it is unsuitable for young people.

"I am so weary of it," says Cormier. "I never come to the defence of one of my books. But if a teacher or librarian is under threat then I feel that I must, and I do. The problem is that so often the people who want to censor haven't read the book they want banned."

Frenchtown Summer is unlikely to upset anyone, unless they have an objection to good writing. The very thing that Cormier identifies as his weakness - an inability to write description, that he disguises by use of simile and metaphor - is a real strength here.

Tiny phrases conjure an entire town: the whist-playing uncles and aunts who come and go "like gaudy ghosts"; the failed suicide who falls back from the railing "like a balloon deflated"; the white bouquet on the hall table with its scent of death; and most of all, Eugene's relationship with his distant father. He is "as unknown as a foreign language", but at the crucial moment he manages to affirm his love for his son in the tiniest of gestures.

Like many authors whose books are marketed for teenagers, Cormier has had times when he wishes that his work was held in higher esteem, but he is quick to point out: "I've had such success it would be a betrayal of my readers to say the Young Adult label has been detrimental. It is the most demanding, most critical audience in the world. Though I'm always puzzled how anyone can set out to write for a 14-year-old. With my books it just happens that's who they end up for. I simply write with an intelligent reader in mind." He pauses: "But then I've always maintained that I am just an arrested adolescent myself."

webTitle: Guardian review: Please Don't Call Me Human by Wang Shuo

fields.headline: Boxing clever
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Lezard enjoys Wang Shuo's raucous Chinese satire, Please Don't Call Me Human
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard enjoys Wang Shuo's raucous Chinese satire, Please Don't Call Me Human
fields.body:
Please Don't Call Me Human
Wang Shuo, trans Howard Goldblatt
(No Exit Press, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

The front cover shows a face obscured by a red star; that and the title suggest a novel dealing with human rights, freedom of expression, the yearning for liberation, that kind of thing... Well, it's a lot more interesting than that.

A little context. Wang Shuo is China's most popular author, in the teeth of great government disapproval. The powers that be call him a "spiritual pollutant", yet his 20 novels have sold around 10 million copies. Even allowing for China's population, that's quite a hefty total.

And can there be any writer in this country, apart from AS Byatt and Andrew Motion, of course, who doesn't yearn to be denounced by Tony Blair as a spiritual pollutant? What a shame that we have such a weedy tradition of free speech, coupled with a government philistinism that is so pervasive and entrenched that it may actually be functional illiteracy. In China they take these things more seriously.

Please Don't Call Me Human is a raucous, surreal satire on what it means to be Chinese at the moment, as revolutionary Communist rhetoric joins forces with materialist capitalism. A satirist, you feel, would find rich pickings under such circumstances, and indeed Wang Shuo does just that.

The Chinese and Foreign Free-style Elimination Wrestling Competition Organizing Committee watches a video of a foreign (ie Caucasian) wrestler beating the crap out of several Asian competitors. What can the nation do, asks the Committee, to save face?

First it changes its name (naturally) to MobCom (mobilization committee - one of the translator's neater touches), and then it starts looking for a hero, a Dream Boxer, a reincarnation of the heroes of the Boxer uprising. The result is a harum-scarum tearing-down of everything you feel the Chinese hold sacred, as Wang Shuo plays off the varying kinds of vacuous rhetoric with which the nation has been browbeaten for generations.

"I seem to recall lining up like this once before, a long time ago," says someone forced to celebrate publicly when a hero is found, "waving little flags and mumbling things to someone passing by." "It must have been 1949." "No, earlier than that." "Then it must have been 1937."

Now, I imagine you are well-educated enough to know the significance of 1949 to the Chinese, but 1937 might stump you (the Kuomintang-Communist pact and the start of the Sino-Japanese war); and that is a bit of a problem with this book. It is crammed with allusions which Chinese would get at once, but which are pretty much lost to us; the translator has "chosen not to clutter the text with explanatory notes or other devices that would ultimately contribute little to an appreciation of the novel".

Well, if it's all the same to you, we would rather be the judges of that. This laziness (there's no other word; except, perhaps, "cheeseparing"), along with that American translators' trait of using a slang that no one ever spoke (imaginary 1920s gangster-speak with up-to-date swear-words) can make the book a bit grim to read at times, but stick with it: Wang Shuo is the real thing, and the stuff that comes out of his head is the stuff of true satire. Buy enough copies of this book, and No Exit will be able to afford a translation of their own.

As for the blurb, do not read it. It gives away the ending, by which I mean what happens on the penultimate page. This is a crime against fiction that cries to heaven for justice. Still, better the book is out in English than not at all.

fields.headline: Entertainment and humour
fields.trailText: If the Simpsons are in second and sixth place and Buffy is in fourth and fifth, who's the most popular kid on the block?
fields.body:
If the Simpsons are in second and sixth place and Buffy is in fourth and fifth, who's the most popular kid on the block? It's the sort of tie-breaker that could drive the UK's struggling humorists to mass suicide, seeing as how both are imports and, what's worse, TV spin-offs.

Still, there's a lot to be said for the success of America's most dysfunctional family and its most vampiricidal nymphette. At least they're not dumb, like most native residents of pre-watershed TV these days. At least their fans can read!

Good old Auntie Beeb, meanwhile, can bask in the golden glow that The Last of the Summer Wine is still casting over thousands of birthdays in shire towns across the land. Which brings us nicely to Now We Are Sixty, Christopher Matthew's shrewd and endearing reworking of A A Milne's children's classic as songs not of innocence, but of experience. Buffy the Grandchild Slayer - now there's a tip for the future.

fields.headline: Fiction
fields.trailText: A flawlessly constructed story of working-class America, plus Inishowen, James Miranda Barry, The Silver Dove and Making Do
fields.body:
Tony Luongo
Joseph Torra
(Gollancz, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

The second part of Torra's American trilogy is every bit as good as the first. As in Gas Station, Tony Luongo hymns the ordinary experiences of a working-class man. In an unbroken monologue, Tony Luongo tells his life story: from Marine corps service in Korea to life as a salesman in a Boston department store, chasing chicks, getting married and growing older.

Luongo's life is full of incident but no great drama. He gets angry with his wife, loves his mother, works hard. The years pass; he loses his hair, gains weight. Told in a flawlessly constructed, unpunctuated stream of consciousness, the novel pulls the reader effortlessly into a world of small achievements and slight contentments.

Inishowen
Joseph O'Connor
(Secker & Warburg, £10)
Buy it at BOL

It takes 10 days and coming on for 500 pages for O'Connor to get his three central characters up to Inishowen, a peninsula in north-west Ireland. On the journey, as is the way of these things, Ellen, Martin and Amery make discoveries that change their lives. Ellen has escaped Christmas in Scarsdale to come to terms with cancer and to find her mother; Martin is escaping Christmas alone and his grief for his dead son; Amery has flown in to get Ellen back to Scarsdale and their marriage. O'Connor weaves a dense plot featuring old-fashioned mystery, farce and a love affair, but the characters are types and the narrative is waylaid by too many comic asides.

James Miranda Barry
Patricia Duncker
(Picador, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

As visitors to London's Kensal Green Cemetery know, under the gravestone of military surgeon James Miranda Barry lies the body of a woman. There is little mystery as to why an intelligent girl might want to pass as a man in 19th-century England, but the how of it has long intrigued. With Duncker's fictional account we follow Barry from tomboy to Edinburgh student, colonial doctor and heart-throb. Duncker turns the story into a quest for the identity of Barry's natural father, which gives the novel the unexpected edge of a Victorian detective story. But her refusal to probe the depths of Barry's gender seems like an opportunity missed.

The Silver Dove
Andrey Bely
(Angel Classics, £10.95)
Buy it at BOL

The Silver Dove, written in the decade before the Russian revolution, was a pioneering antithesis to the realist tradition of Dostoevsky, Tolstoy and Chekhov. The story of Daryalsky, a Moscow intellectual, and his involvement with a sect led by a peasant carpenter echoes the spiritual and political chaos of Russia on the verge of collapse, but follows the tradition of Gogol and the fantastic. With notes and a scholarly introduction, The Silver Dove is perhaps not meant to be read entirely for enjoyment, but Bely depicts a world which is fascinating, full of strange imagery and tormented by passions. It is less stylised and more accessible than his better-known Petersburg.

Making Do
Catherine Feeny
(Flame, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

Mark Upshaw is upper-class and on his uppers when he moves into a rented room in Soho. His landlady, Clara, is different from any woman he has met before, and it wouldn't be spoiling the plot to let on that there is a happy-ever-after. Making Do is an urban fairy-tale with plenty of clichéd characters and improbable scenarios, but Feeny's low-key pre-Thatcher political message gives it charm. Upshaw throws off his public-school ethos, learns to love Clara's and her lodgers' eccentricities, and understands how to get by without his birthright silver spoon. Readable stuff: Feeny's touches of class-consciousness and his love of old Soho raise it above the mundane.

Readable stuff: Feeny's touches of class-consciousness and his love of old Soho raise it above the mundane.

webTitle: Guardian review: Tree of Pearls by Louisa Young

fields.headline: Loving the alien
fields.standfirst: Carol Birch  on Louisa Young's eastern romance, Tree of Pearls
fields.trailText: Carol Birch on Louisa Young's eastern romance, Tree of Pearls
fields.body:
Tree of Pearls
Louisa Young Flamingo, £7.99, 224pp
Buy it at BOL

This is the third in a trilogy, following on from Baby Love and Desiring Cairo, that follows the fortunes of Angeline Gower, a blonde belly-dancing Egyptophile caught up in the fringes of the international criminal underworld. The first 30 pages bring the reader rapidly up to date on a particularly racy soap opera, full of kidnappings, sudden death, bent cops, psychos and gorgeous Nile boatmen. Deep passions are sketched: "She's jealous because Sa'id loved me and didn't want to love her. And because I told him he had to, because she's his mother, she resents me."

But Young fills in too much. All you need to know is that Angeline lived and danced in Cairo, that she's now bringing up her dead sister's child in London, and that in the past she attracted the attentions of a mad stalker drugs baron called Eddie Bates.

"I am so accustomed to melodramatic absurdity by now," she says, "that I forget how strange it must sound to other people." Quite. The plot creaks alarmingly at times, unless you accept that its narrator heroine is to some extent fooling herself. She keeps stressing she doesn't want trouble, but it's quite obvious that she courts it.

Thus, dispatched to Egypt by the police to make discreet inquiries into the whereabouts of Eddie, she takes along with her his wife Chrissie, a recovering alcoholic "only very precariously attached to her rocker". In Luxor, Angeline quickly re-establishes contact with Sa'id, the man she loved and recently left, and by whom she has recently discovered she is pregnant. As her mother says: "You do like things complicated."

Although there's a surfeit of it, however, plot is not really important here. Young's talent lies in characterisation, and her great success is in the depiction of the central triangle of Angeline, Sa'id and her old flame and best friend, Harry. These three come alive, particularly Angeline herself. Generous, humorous, a fascinating raconteur about all things Egyptian, she is also disarmingly transparent.

She never admits to not being 100 per cent PC and covers herself with guilty little disclaimers: "No judgement - no judgement - on a woman who needs to do that, but..." (talking of abortion). Or, "I'm not being fattist here", before embarking on a scathing description of an obese American tourist. She's confused. When she banters with the boatmen and flirts with the felafel-sellers of Luxor, she is desperate to prove her credentials, to prove that she's not a tourist. "I speak Arabic. I understand Ramadan. I belong."

At the heart of the book is the issue of multiculturalism, "a Western idea", according to Sa'id. How much of Angeline's love for him is love of "otherness"? How far is it tied in with her love of Egypt? In describing this land she becomes a poet: "In Upper Egypt the trees are full of egrets, who hang at dusk like handkerchiefs, and say buggle buggle da, buggle da, burbling like shishas. Written down the words even look like Arabic. And the sky is striped, green and rose and gold, the colours of alabaster, and the moon lies on its back."

This is also an honest look at the dilemma of loving two men, both of them good and worthy. Young makes decency interesting, and this is no mean feat. She writes swooningly about love of all kinds, reaching at last a mature conclusion: "The idea of a man and woman living together seemed to me charming, practical, full of possibilities." After the drama looms the possibility of peace, exciting as exotica.

webTitle: Guardian review: The Book of the Heathen by Robert Edric

fields.headline: Fake mastery
fields.standfirst: Sukhdev Sandhu  admires Robert Edric's novel of Congo colonists, The Book of the Heathen
fields.trailText: Sukhdev Sandhu admires Robert Edric's novel of Congo colonists, The Book of the Heathen
fields.body:
The Book of the Heathen
Robert Edric
Anchor, £9.99, 351pp
Buy it at BOL

"The horror! The horror!" Since the publication of Heart of Darkness in 1899, Kurtz's ghastly ululation has become the literary equivalent of Edvard Munch's The Scream. It anticipates the psycho-social disintegration and moral infernos about which Eliot and Adorno later wrote. Staled by repetition, it's also a melodramatic catchphrase for when you ladder your tights or spill latte on your lap.

Some critics have taken issue with Conrad's depiction of the Congo as a malevolent black hole sucking out European vitality, a diseased abyss bereft of joy or humanity whose inhabitants march to the beat of a frenzied tom-tom. Yet the imaginative territory that it represents has lured generations of writers from Naipaul and Mailer to William Boyd and Ronan Bennett. Querry, the jaded church architect in Graham Greene's A Burnt-Out Case, goes there because he craves "an empty place", one where he can abandon his self. In the travelogues of Redmond O'Hanlon, by contrast, self and epic masculinity are flexed against tropical swelter and discomfort.

The Congo, it seems, offers authors many attractions: a vivid topography, a literary genealogy, a fascinating history (much of it pocked by imperialist rapacity), a crucible for the West in its encounters with "otherness", a poetics of extinction.

Many of these themes crop up in Robert Edric's The Book of the Heathen. The novel tells the story of James Frasier, a young man educated at Oxford and Sandhurst who is appointed map-maker and technical overseer for a company trading in the Congo at the end of the 19th century. He is accompanied by Nicholas Frere, who has been courting his sister and whose intrepid, free-spirited demeanour he envies.

They arrive to find a claustrophobic dread hanging over their station. Colleagues are glowering and unhelpful, business is waning fast, a local potentate traffics in slaves, and the nearby mission school is run by a vicious demagogue, Father Klein. They've travelled thousands of miles and found not the adventure playground they had hoped for, but a putrescent graveyard.

They begin to wander further afield in search of newness - and, in Frere's case, cannibalistic ceremonies that no Westerner has previously witnessed. One day, though, Frere is charged with killing a native girl. Frasier's attempts to piece together what really happened form the backbone of the novel.

The Book of the Heathen begins with an epigraph from the diary of Roger Casement asking us to consider what the consequences would be if Congolese tribesmen were to pen their own accounts "of these terrible events, of this shameful history told only once". Edric doesn't presume to offer that alternative narrative. Like many contemporary novelists, he shows the limitations of European cartography in offering credible representations of the colonial world. At its best, plotting new map coordinates serves merely venal ends - at its worst, it induces a fake sense of mastery over a terrain and a civilisation that will eventually destroy you.

Edric is a prolific and highly talented writer whose books - most recently In Desolate Heaven and The Sword Cabinet - give historical fiction a good name. They are distinguished not only by their formal skill and wide-ranging subject matters, but by their hairless, unshowy prose. In The Book of the Heathen, he uses suspense and thriller techniques to telling effect. His linguistic minimalism can also be effective - his low-key description of a hanging is quite the most harrowing I've ever read.

At times, though, the fastidiousness of his writing denies us that woozily hallucinogenic sense of colonial place that we find in European authors such as Ryszard Kapuscinski or Sven Lindqvist. One finishes the novel thinking not "The horror! The horror!", but "The unseemliness! The unseemliness!"

fields.headline: The List
fields.trailText: A look ahead into the distant future of the universe, plus The Cunning of Unreason
fields.body:
The Five Ages of the Universe
Fred Adams and Greg Laughlin
(Touchstone, £9.99)
Buy it at BOL

In which our authors quixotically attempt to chart the likely course of creation over the next 10 to the 100 years. The period between the birth of our solar system and the future death of the sun, which will wipe out life on Earth for ever, is only a miserable 12 and a half billion years, an unimaginably minuscule moment. If God were to blink, he'd miss us altogether. And even if we were to build spaceships to get out of here before the sun blows, could we then survive when the very fabric of matter started to fall apart?

Adams and Laughlin have magically woven a fascinating narrative - not, as is usual with pop-science books, by cleaving to the "human" stories of scientific visionaries, as if that were all anyone could relate to; but by carefully explaining the facts and engaging in mind-expanding speculation. We are currently, by the way, in the second age of the universe, the Stelliferous: a poetic denotation meaning "filled with stars". The next age will be the Degenerate, natch: as on earth, so it is in heaven.

The Cunning of Unreason
John Dunn
(HarperCollins, £16.99)
Buy it at BOL

Politics, eh? What's it for? Where did it come from? In his charming and refreshingly dogged philosophical analysis, Dunn adopts a bracing tone from the off: politics today is "vaguely degrading" and "certainly not fit for gentlemen". He seeks to define key terms in the understanding of politics, such as "popular consent", "state authority" and "judgment", peering at specimen views from Plato and Aristotle, through Machiavelli, Rousseau and Hobbes, to Marx, Keynes and Hayek. In the second half he attempts an explanation of just why Britain's economy, society and politics underwent such an upheaval through the Tory years of 1979 to 1997. A serious jewel amid the foul slurry of New Labour gossipmongering.

fields.headline: Non-fiction
fields.trailText: An album of portraits of one of the last of the windjammers, plus Sir Francis Drake and Shackleton
fields.body:
Learning the Ropes
Eric Newby
(John Murray, £14.99)
Buy it at BOL

It is 1938, aboard the Moshulu, a fourmasted square-rigged steel barque out of the Baltic by way of Belfast: one of a dozen then still speedily freighting wheat from South Australia to Europe. She was built in 1904, she carried 31 sails (from main course to jigger topgallant), 5,000 tons of grain and two ships' pigs: Fabian and Filimon.

Newby was 18, an apprentice who had never climbed rigging before - but he did have a camera, and this is an album of portraits of his first love and her other boatswains (they made small votive models of her, and trapped her an albatross). She's demanding and so beautiful, bow up to the swell as she rides a storm in the Southern Ocean.

Sir Francis Drake
Harry Kelsey
(Yale, £11.99)
Buy it at BOL

Tersely apt about the Devonian pirate who failed to make a fortune importing "currants and sweet oyle" from Zante in the Ionian Sea (his salad days), but prospered wickedly as Gloriana's licensed equivalent of a Great Train Robber in Spanish America. He thieved gold from those who had extorted it from the natives, ordered the ship's surgeon to autopsy a hand dead of yellow fever (the doctor died of the resultant infection), and had a friend beheaded for questioning his authority. But the book is heedless of the ships: even the Pelican, Drake's own craft, gets no more than her mean dimensions specified, though she circled the earth with him, and he was dubbed knight aboard her.

Shackleton
Roland Huntford
(Abacus, £12.99)

Huntford, on the other hand, feels for Shackleton's ships as much as for the true-hearted Antarctic explorer. Maybe more so, since a ship is the innocent victim both to the ambitions of those aboard her and to the pitiless sea, and the last agony of Shackleton's vessel, Endurance, was cruel. She was the wrong build to be caught helpless in the frozen Wedell sea, not egg-shaped enough to slip above the ice when the pressure waves rippled through it like solid surf. She was twisted, the keel torn out of her. They abandoned her pumps. Eight Emperor penguins sang her dirge, and all hands had one last supper in her wardroom, silent but for the clock ticking.

webTitle: A pain in the neck for Murdoch?

fields.headline: A pain in the neck for Murdoch?
fields.trailText: Simon & Schuster look to Michael Crick's biography of Rupert Murdoch to boost sales, plus a late night invitation and the quick route to publication
fields.body:
 Simon & Schuster are looking to Michael Crick to help them to boost sales, having picked up his Rupert Murdoch biography after Fourth Estate, now part of the NewsCorp empire, found it impolitic to proceed. Crick promises analysis of Murdoch's role in world affairs over the last decade, which should get the punters going. S&S UK's turnover is up for the first half of the year, unlike that of its parent company, and their finance director has his own ideas as to why business is slow. "Some of the product we've launched," he muses, "has not sparkled quite as it would have done in a better publishing environment." So now you know: it's your fault.

 Radishes are the new rock'n'roll, apparently, and chef Anthony Bourdain continues to beguile the media with his memoir Kitchen Confidential. The Loafer was therefore delighted to receive an invitation to his party this coming week, although slightly terrified by the news that it doesn't begin until midnight. After the kitchen closes, of course.

 If you want to get your book out there double-quick, shuffling off this mortal coil isn't a bad option. Penguin are bringing forward the paperback of Alec Guinness's A Positively Final Appearance by a month, while Macmillan are reprinting Robin Day's Grand Inquisitor to hit the shops as soon as possible. Meanwhile, Weidenfeld's Ion Trewin has finally finished editing Alan Clark's Diaries (enlarging them from A4 to A3 and then using a magnifying glass) in time for October, and Anthony Powell's A Writer's Notebook will appear from Heinemann in November.

 Christmas is already upon us book folk, as all and sundry are pimping their would-be big-sellers for the end of the year. The Loafer was intrigued to see that Doris Lessing has entered the fray with a book entitled The Old Age of El Magnifico. Trade magazine The Bookseller describes it thus: "This poignant little story about an old friend suddenly deprived of a leg will have resonance for all cat owners. The perfect Christmas gift." That's the sentimentalist amputee moggy brigade sewn up, then.

webTitle: Guardian review: How to Read and Why by Harold Bloom

fields.headline: Why read this?
fields.standfirst: Harold Bloom sticks up for the examined life in How to Read and Why
fields.trailText: Harold Bloom sticks up for the examined life in How to Read and Why
fields.body:
How to Read and Why
Harold Bloom
Fourth Estate, £15.99, 283pp
Buy it at BOL

At the age of eight, Harold Bloom used to wander around chanting the verses of Blake and Housman. It's a disturbing image, particularly when you consider what the little fellow would have been singing:

"O rose, thou art sick!

The invisible worm

That flies in the night

In the howling storm

Has found out thy bed

Of crimson joy,

And his dark secret love

Does thy life destroy."

And yet these lyrics were (and are) a wonderful introduction to poetry, even for an eight-year-old. Beneath their simplicity are depths explored with extraordinary economy. But to read them is to cast aside childish things: "the invisible worm" has its intimations of venereal disease; "an air that kills", as Bloom points out, is a superb irony in that the "breath paradoxically slays, precisely where it should enhance life". What a precocious little horror Harold must have been.

At the age of 70, Bloom hasn't changed much. He still chants. He's still showy and precocious. Above all, he still reads seriously and wears his learning heavily. But you can forgive him the latter because the former is so important in this age.

Bloom's iconoclasm is great fun. He laments the death of memorised verse, since that now-dead culture of learning encouraged many people to read great poetry with the requisite attention. For heaven's sake, try harder. Learn more. Read better. Such is his bracing tone.

Not surprisingly, Bloom loves the poetry of those 19th-century Englishmen who despaired of everything but the strong self and its powers of endurance. Bloom despairs of computers, television, and much more besides.

His judgments seem to swoop down from Olympus. Poe is widely popular, Bloom notes, but, really, he wrote atrociously. He reproves Maupassant for wearing Schopenhauerian goggles: the result was that his short stories distorted the vagaries of human desire.

Ultimately, though, isn't this just another of Bloom's greatest literary hits, another stroll through the texts of his western canon? Through the Victorian poetry course he taught at NYU; through his favourite American fiction (step forward, neglected Eudora Welty); another climb to the summit of literature that he wrote about so impressively in last year's Shakespeare: The Invention of the Human ?

Well, yes, it is all that. But where The Western Canon 's taxonomy became suffocating and joyless, here Bloom's love of great literature is contagious. It sent me off anew to Proust, to Flannery O'Connor, to Italo Calvino; and for the first time to many others - to Cormac McCarthy, to Welty and (to my shame) to Robert Browning. True, sometimes Bloom's readings are too perfunctory to be useful, but all of them are buoyed up by a serious, corrective spirit in an age of too many things that don't matter. "Information is endlessly available to us; where shall wisdom be found?" asks Bloom rhetorically. In the books he hails, for sure. And, frequently, in this book too.

Bloom reckons How to Read is not a polemical book, though American academics - and indeed anybody who reads him as seriously as the professor recommends - might disagree. For Bloom, US universities "have empowered such covens as 'gender and sexuality' and 'multiculturalism' ". Bloom adds angrily: "A university culture where the appreciation of Victorian women's underwear replaces the appreciation of Charles Dickens and Robert Browning sounds like the outrageousness of a new Nathanael West, but is merely the norm... The poems of our climate have been replaced by the body stockings of our culture." Covens? Body stockings? If this isn't a polemic, it certainly is name-calling.

These broadsides are refreshing, though when some of Bloom's assertions don't much bear much reflection. "If you wish to maintain," he sniffs rhetorically, "that Shakespeare's ascendancy was a product of colonialism, then who will bother to confute you?" But one could easily maintain this view of the ascendancy of Shakespeare without implying that the playwright's literary merit is undermined by as a result. He should read Edward Said's Culture and Imperialism: yes, some great literary works are unthinkable without a thriving empire (think of the plantations that paid for the moneyed ease of Mansfield Park). But that says nothing about their shortcomings or otherwise as works of art.

Against the collectivist, materialist demons who have seized control of American universities, Bloom champions the solitary praxis of the individual reader, and summons Emerson, Dr Johnson and Francis Bacon in support. The best advice is from Bacon: "Read not to contradict and confute, nor to believe and take for granted, nor to find talk and discourse, but to weigh and consider."

But perhaps most suggestive is Bloom's fifth principle of reading, namely the recovery of the ironic. For poor old Bloom, surveying an aesthetic and spiritual wasteland, the loss of irony is a terrible thing, since it signifies the death of reading and of our civilisation. Hamlet, western literature's towering literary creation, is for Bloom the master of endless irony, who when he says one thing almost invariably means another. We need to learn how to read Hamlet again.

This is hard for us to take in Britain, since here we are inveterate, nearly pathological, ironists. It is hard to imagine the lustreless literalism of many American academic institutions taking hold here.

It is good to read Bloom in conjunction with Philip Roth's latest novel, The Human Stain. For what is Roth, especially in his Zuckerman novels, but applied Bloom? Roth's The Ghost Writer betrayed the influence of Bloom's The Anxiety of Influence. Roth's latest novel is, in part, a critique of the covens of academic materialism impugned here by Bloom. The same muscular intelligence, the same zest for an intellectual and sensual life prevails in Roth's fiction as in Bloom's new book.

Ultimately the intellectual and the sensual are married in Bloom's notion of reading as a difficult pleasure. He calls this "the reader's Sublime". It is the closest to secular transcendence that we may achieve in this life - it helps us get beyond despair, loss and death. The cultivation of that difficult pleasure, finally, is why we should read.

webTitle: Guardian review: The Justification of Johann Gutenberg by Blake Morrison

fields.headline: Blood and ink
fields.standfirst: Ian Sansom  weighs the cost of genius in Blake Morrison's The Justification of Johann Gutenberg
fields.trailText: Ian Sansom weighs the cost of genius in Blake Morrison's The Justification of Johann Gutenberg
fields.body:
The Justification of Johann Gutenberg
Blake Morrison
Chatto & Windus, £14.99, 224pp
Buy it at BOL

Blake Morrison is troubling. And not merely, or not only, because of his huge facility. His first book - The Movement (1980), an account of Larkin, Amis & co - remains a standard critical history. His Penguin Book of Contemporary British Poetry (1982), which he edited with Andrew Motion, was controversial. His second book of poetry, The Ballad of the Yorkshire Ripper (1984), caused uproar.

Acclaim came with And When Did You Last See Your Father? (1998), and then further acclaim, mixed with a dash of disapprobium, for As If (1998), his account of the Bulger trial. And this is not even to mention the incunabula, the masses of journalism and criticism, the libretto, the play, the book for children - and all of them good of their kind. One is reminded of Max Beerbohm, in his essay "Quia Imperfectum": "A man whose career was glorious without intermission, decade after decade, does surely try our patience."

Now he has written a novel, and according to the dustjacket: "He has been called the most influential man of the last millennium. He launched a communications revolution - and changed the written word for ever. This is his tale, and the story behind his heretical invention." This extraordinary individual is not in fact Blake Morrison, but rather the subject of Morrison's book, Johann Gutenberg, inventor of printing. Like all Morrison's work, and for all its range, The Justification of Johann Gutenberg ultimately focuses on that irreducible spot of unhappiness - that little inky stain - at the heart of the human condition.

Morrison gives us Gutenberg as an old man, bitter, half-blind, ruined, living in exile in Eltville, dictating his memoirs to a young scribe, dreaming of "print-pilgrims" coming to visit him. Gutenberg recalls his parents, his childhood in Mainz, and his schooling. Destined for the church, he gives up his vocation to become a scribe, a coinmaker, a journeyman metalworker, and then a writing master. He falls in love with the beautiful Ennelina, but fails to marry. Unlike Blake Morrison, it takes him some time to settle down to a life of purposefulness.

Gutenberg's ultimate purpose is of course the invention of his printing press with movable type, a complex process involving what Morrison calls, rather magically, a "pentangle of skills". This part of Gutenberg's story is well known, and Morrison himself acknowledges Albert Kapr's scholarly Johann Gutenberg: The Man and the Invention (1996) as an important source for his novel. Morrison is, however, much less interested in Gutenberg's invention than in its human cost. The book's justification lies not in its description of Gutenberg's famous success but in its account of his many private failings.

Morrison's Gutenberg is not a genius, but a fool who sacrifices everything in the pursuit of money, fame, and his own talent. There are numerous illuminating set pieces. A young Gutenberg's first experiment in printing is writing with rat's blood on snow - "I made bold and swirled the rat about, in a circle, so that a decorative red stain, or curlicue, was deposited, like an illuminated letter at the head of a page."

The older Gutenberg is pompous, deceitful, and scheming, the kind of man too busy polishing his anecdotes for the generations to come to really care for those around him. He likes to pretend that his big idea comes to him in a vision of doves: "As I stood with my hand raised, it was as if the dove that perched there spreading its wings had become an open book [...] the grain the dove held in its beak was like a kernel of knowledge seeding itself throughout the world." Even he doesn't believe it. He is very honest, and thoroughly dislikable.

At its best the book ranks with, say, Penelope Fitzgerald's similarly slim and limpid account of German passions and idealism, The Blue Flower (1995), her celebrated last novel about the poet and philosopher Novalis. At the same time there are several of those characteristic gaps, limitations and gaucheries that often seem to bedevil the historical novel.

The research sometimes struggles for its life, like fish thrashing about on the surface of the Rhine. And knowing what we already know of Morrison's interests and obsessions, Gutenberg does perhaps seem to conform rather too easily to that familiar pattern - sensitive middle-class boy with absent father - whose emotional intricacies Morrison has long since etched and perfected. Indeed, with his thick glasses, prejudices and enthusiasms, Gutenberg begins to look uncannily like a wood-cut Philip Larkin - "One of those old-type natural fouled-up guys".

Certainly as with Larkin, and one suspects perhaps even as with a committed littérateur like Blake Morrison, Gutenberg's great sadness reveals itself as the realisation of all the love he must give up in order to achieve his dreams. "Without Ennelina's truth and passion, I was thrown back wholly on inventing. Into the hollow she had left, I poured hot metal; into the silence, words." The Justification of Johann Gutenberg is the story of a life either well spent - or, simply, spent. God only knows if, in the end, it was worth it.

fields.headline: Keep it in the Family
fields.standfirst: Joe Farrell  sees Italian fiction still obsessed with the Sicilian mafia
fields.trailText: Joe Farrell sees Italian fiction still obsessed with the Sicilian mafia
fields.body:
There are many tourist disembarkation points in Italy. Sun 'n' sand tourists can make their way to Rimini or Viareggio, travellers with an interest in the arts will head for Florence or Venice, agri-tourism flourishes in Umbria and culinary tourism in Bologna - but visitors with literary interests should disembark in Sicily.

There are advantages for a writer in inhabiting a troubled society, as shown by Tomasi di Lampedusa's The Leopard, a meditation on Sicily and its history that has been appropriated as a manifesto for inchoate toryism. The line the young rebel speaks to the uncertain Prince - "if we want everything to stay the same, everything must change" - has become the motto of conservatives all over Europe.

The Sicilian tradition has the robust autonomy of Irish literature, and the same willingness to draw nourishment from non-mainstream cultures. This is very much the case with Andrea Camilleri, the Sicilian detective-story writer who has dominated the bestseller lists in Italy in recent years. He writes in a mixture of standard Italian and Sicilian, and - in an explicit act of homage to the Catalan writer Vazquez Montalban - his detective is called Montalbano. Montalbano's investigations are liable to be disturbed by a good restaurant or by a favourite traditional dish cooked by some witness to a crime.

The master of sophisticated detective fiction remains Leonardo Sciascia, whose novels are an extended investigation into what it means to be Sicilian. Sciascia entrusts his investigations to a series of low-ranking police officers, who find themselves crushed between criminals and corrupt servants of the state. Novels like The Day of the Owl or To Each His Own focus on a local mafia in Sicily, but the later Equal Danger (all Carcanet) deals with a new, globalised criminal force that operates in boardrooms and inside ministries.

Claudio Magris, meanwhile, lives at the opposite end of the Italian peninsula from Sicily, but he shows the same attachment to his own place, Trieste. James Joyce lived in Trieste, and there he met up with Italo Svevo, author of Confessions of Zeno. Magris is a writer of some imaginative and intellectual scope. His best book remains Danube, but if that is not suitable reading for an Italian excursion, his more recent Microcosms (Harvill) should pass muster. Both Joyce and Svevo have walk-on parts, but the most representative character is the man who loves Trieste "because he had the impression of being nowhere".

The most "Italian" of writers, in the sense of the one who refuses association with one region, is probably Sebastiano Vassalli, from Novara. Night of the Comet retells the tragic story of the poet, Dino Campana, from Northern Italy, while Vassalli had the courage, or foolhardiness, to choose Sicily as the setting of The Swan (Carcanet), a historical novel dealing with a mafia murder in the 19th century.

There are younger contemporaries who proudly group themselves together under the title The Cannibals, and who appeal, like Irvine Welsh in Britain, to a supposedly anarchic, iconoclastic youth. Enrico Brizzi set the tone with Jack Frusciante Has Left the Band . Simona Vinci does not number herself with the Cannibals, but there is a repulsive violence in A Game We Play (Weidenfeld), which focuses on the sexuality of children.

Those who prefer something gentler will relish Alessandro Baricco, who is beginning to command a following in Britain. His delicate little miniature of a novel, Silk (Harvill), unfolds on the silk trail to China, while Ocean Sea (Hamish Hamilton) is set in an area of the South Seas that would have been familiar to R L Stevenson.

Women writers flourish in a way they have never done before in Italy. The doyenne remains Dacia Maraini, whose Voices (Serpent's Tail) is her only venture into the crime story. Paola Capriolo has a rare knack of mingling sophistication and fantasy, as is clear in Floria Tosca, a deft retelling of Puccini's Tosca, or The Woman Watching, (both Serpent's Tail), the story of a woman in the stalls gazing insistently at an actor on stage.

Michael Dibdin could pass as an Italian writer who writes in English. He acknowledges a debt to Sciascia, and there is a lot to be learned about the seamier side of Italian politics from the investigations of his Aurelio Zen, a Venetian policeman investigating crimes that spring from the overlap between organised crime and disorganised politics. A Long Finish took him to the vineyards of Piedmont, while Blood Rain (both Faber) saw him involved in a mafia affair in Sicily. Which is where we started.

Little Italy

The Italian Institute (39 Belgrave Square, London SW1X 8NX) has a library of 21,000 books, in Italian and English translation. During its September literary season of events, many famous Italian authors (including Dacia Maraini and Alessandro Barrico) will be in London for talks with British authors. In October, Italian and British actors, including Colin Firth, will be giving a series of readings from Italian books. See www.italcultur.org.uk or phone 020-7235 1461 for a programme.

webTitle: Guardian review: That Was Satire That Was by Humphrey Carpenter

fields.headline: The age of ridicule
fields.standfirst: Humphrey Carpenter's That Was Satire That Was charts the erosion of deference in the sixties
fields.trailText: Humphrey Carpenter's That Was Satire That Was charts the erosion of deference in the sixties
fields.body:
That Was Satire That Was
Humphrey Carpenter
Gollancz, £20, 378pp
Buy it at BOL

That loved, vilified and ever more fantasised construct known as "the sixties" is made from many building blocks. In no special order, we can offer such stalwarts as the Wilson government, and most importantly the liberal social engineering conducted by Roy Jenkins, Home Secretary from 1965 to 1967; "Swinging London", whether in the upmarket areas of the King's Road or the tourist traps of Carnaby Street; the "sexual revolution" led by the contraceptive pill; the "underground" counter-culture and the hippies who supported it; the growing appreciation of "recreational" drug-taking; and the emergence of gender politics, both feminist and homosexual.

It was, to attempt an impossible concision, an era in which democratisation was promoted and deference destroyed. The former was achieved through many things - the front-runners are listed above - and while the latter was no single-issue event, a great deal of its popularisation was made possible by a single phenomenon: the "satire boom".

The "boom", as is the way of such fireworks, was relatively short-lived. It began in 1961 with an Oxbridge revue entitled Beyond the Fringe, moved on to a fortnightly magazine called Private Eye and a Soho nightclub called the Establishment, and finally the mass-marketing of the whole thing via a Saturday-night BBC television programme, That Was The Week That Was, which ended in late 1963.

In fact only one of these, the Establishment, made conscious acknowledgment of the concept of "satire". Beyond the Fringe was, in however superior a version, essentially one more undergraduate revue; Private Eye 's immediate rationale was the resurrection of an Oxford rag called Mesopotamia, and the BBC mandarins, while sanctioning TW3 (as it was universally known), emphasised that at no time should it be promoted as "satirical". Its prime lasted barely two years, although the fall-out, especially in TV terms, continued: its overall effects - the healthy destruction of a "deference culture" that had been growing in strength and obduracy for a century - are with us still.

Humphrey Carpenter's book, the first to look at this material since Roger Wilmut's From Fringe to Flying Circus (1982), charts the minutiae of "satire" in great and often fascinating detail. It is an important addition to the oddly short list of written analyses of a period that remains so much a part of recent history. It is as if "the sixties", which lives in the national consciousness primarily as an era of fantasy, is deemed to be best left as such: its facts unexplored, its myths lovingly cultivated.

Although it glances elsewhere, this book remains in essence the history of all four closely interlinked "satirical" creations. Theirs was a small, incestuous world, with the same names appearing in a variety of hats: Peter Cook, of BTF, set up the Establishment and later became principal shareholder of Private Eye. (Later still, his appearances with another ex-BTF star Dudley Moore as "Pete and Dud" were part of the BBC's continuing attempts to keep "satire" alive.)

Richard Ingrams, Christopher Booker and William Rushton, co-creators of Private Eye, would write for TW3. Barry Humphries, who appeared sporadically at the Establishment, penned the Barry McKenzie cartoon for the Eye. And so it went. In none of them, claim the participants, was there any great special mission to change the world - it just seemed to happen that way.

Looking back, reading the BTF scripts, turning the pages of those early Private Eyes, watching the films of TW3, one thing is beyond doubt: they were funny. fields.bodyText: That Was Satire That Was Humphrey Carpenter Gollancz, £20, 378pp Buy it at BOL That loved, vilified and ever more fantasised construct known as "the sixties" is made from many building blocks. The former was achieved through many things - the front-runners are listed above - and while the latter was no single-issue event, a great deal of its popularisation was made possible by a single phenomenon: the "satire boom". The "boom", as is the way of such fireworks, was relatively short-lived. fields.headline: Seeing ears
fields.standfirst: Michael Foot  hails a history of English poetry that combines verse with painting
fields.trailText: Michael Foot hails a history of English poetry that combines verse with painting
fields.body:
English Poetry: 850-1850: The First Thousand Years
Robert Woof, Stephen Hebron, Pamela Woof
Wordsworth Trust, £17.50, 334pp

Talk about the stone that the builders rejected becoming the head of the corner! Once William Hazlitt was whipped away from every respectable Lakeside resort, accused of crimes ranging from rape to preaching red revolution. But in this blessed year 2000, he is promoted to master of ceremonies in an ambitious new history of English poetry published by the Wordsworth Trust to coincide with their summer exhibition.

Based at William Wordsworth's Dove Cottage on the shores of Lake Grasmere, the men and women in charge of the trust have championed - quite uniquely, as I believe - the combined achievements of both poets and painters, each performing an indispensable service to the other. A few, like William Blake, tried their hands at both, and of course he is properly represented in this volume. But long since at Dove Cottage they have known the secret that the eye and the ear may synchronise their discoveries, and maybe change the world in the process.

Wordsworth and Coleridge retain their special relationship, each sustaining the other as they did in life. Especially in the past decade, it has been necessary to commemorate the blissful revolutionary dawn that they once shared. But once the trumpet of revolution had been sounded, a host of other candidates for glory presented themselves, and the deed has been most magnanimously done. One rare insight relocated the true genius of Benjamin Robert Haydon, who had mistakenly thought of himself as the master of panorama, though in fact it is his portraits in paint and words that retain their immortality.

English Poetry, with William Blake on the front and Sir Geoffrey Chaucer with his 29 pilgrims on the back, beats all previous efforts to combine the two arts. Reproduced within these pages, and also on display at the exhibition, are the priceless first editions of the greatest poems, starting with Caedmon, Beowulf and William Langland. But soon enough, Chaucer takes over, with delightful proofs of how all the greatest handed down the tradition from one to the other.

Around the Dove Cottage table, Wordsworth and Dorothy read the Knight's Tale or the Miller's, noting that he was never "insidiously voluptuous". How Chaucer was honoured or bowdlerised is all part of the tale itself. Dorothy took a lenient view in these matters, more generous than she would allow for her own contemporaries.

What the greatest poets said about the other great ones, or even about the lesser breeds, adds a further, persistent charm. Sometimes they could be prophetically or anachronistically wise; sometimes they could fall flat on their faces. Wordsworth and Coleridge, as might be expected from this source, seemed to be offered advantages or protections above their rivals. But readers are always invited to judge for themselves. Consider a few examples.

Wordsworth receives a rebuke from Hazlitt for his treatment of Robert Burns. True enough. The charge was that "thoughtless follies laid him low/ And stained his name". Some others treated these follies more benignly, at their head Byron, who knew that "dirt and Deity" need not be confined in such strictly separate compartments. Robert Burns, as not only the Scots will insist, is even greater than he appears in these pages.

William Blake gets a better show: indeed, with his reproduced engravings, he commands as much space as Shakespeare or Milton, the latter having raised Blake's revolutionary ardour to the highest pitch. However, in his lifetime he was hardly ever appreciated for the right reason. Wordsworth himself said: "There is no doubt this poor man was mad but there is something in the madness of this man which interests me more than the sanity of Lord Byron and Walter Scott."

Which brings me, by a slightly circuitous route, to the thorny question of the madness of Jonathan Swift. Byron is quoted here as to how poets generally might suffer and how Swift in particular had in the end suffered from "lamentable idiocy and madness". The dates inscribed here suggest that it was the death of Swift's Stella almost 20 years earlier that broke his spirit and his command of the language.

No such tragedy was ordained, even by the most wrathful god. The accusation that Swift went mad was an invention of Dr Johnson, long since disproved by all the experts, none of whom published their findings early enough to save Byron from his mistake. No one would have welcomed the revelation more than Byron. More than any other two figures in our literature, he and Swift were kindred spirits. As long as 10 years after Stella's death, Swift wrote what may still qualify as the wittiest poem in the language, "Verses on the Death of Dr Swift" - at least before Byron fashioned his own revolutionary style.

But no reader of this volume need be led astray by such disputes. The great rhythms of English poetry take command as Hazlitt insisted, with Chaucer, Spenser, Shakespeare and Milton at their head. Hazlitt indeed could offer two additions: William Wordsworth, whose original voice he recognised before any other critic, and Jonathan Swift the poet, whom he acclaimed no less than the creator of Gulliver's Travels.

 The exhibition accompanying this book continues at Dove Cottage until October 31.

webTitle: Guardian review: Beauty and the Contemporary Sublime and The Art of the Ridiculous Sublime

fields.headline: A terrible beauty
fields.standfirst: Is science the new sublime?  John Mullan  on the history of wonder, charted in Beauty and the Contemporary Sublime and The Art of the Ridiculous Sublime
fields.trailText: Is science the new sublime? John Mullan on the history of wonder, charted in Beauty and the Contemporary Sublime and The Art of the Ridiculous Sublime
fields.body:
What has "the sublime" to do with us? In common parlance, "sublime" is one of those diminished words (like "fantastic" or "terrific") used to exclaim at anything from the delights of a certain kind of ice cream to the skills of a foreign footballer. It seems, banally, just to mean, "much better than usual". But if we can rescue its older, deeper meanings, "the sublime" catches an experience that we still recognise in a post-modern world, glimpsed in the dizzying reaches of interplanetary space or the vertiginous spirals of the human genome.

In the past, the Alps, the Grand Canyon, Manhattan, the Book of Job, Paradise Lost, and the paintings of Turner have all been called "sublime". Until the 20th century, it was the accepted word for the fascination of all that dwarfs and overwhelms us.

Mountains, for instance. Why do we love them? Because they shrink us and awe us. Stand in front of Turner's huge canvas Snow Storm: Hannibal and His Army Crossing the Alps - perhaps awed yourself by those huge crags and storm clouds looming over tiny soldiers - to get a sense of the sublime's fearful delight. TV programmes presenting cataclysmic highlights from nature (avalanches, tornadoes, cataracts and volcanic eruptions) dimly recall this thrill of the sublime.

In the 18th century, intellectuals rediscovered the classical writer Longinus, who had been writing about the sublime in the first century AD. It seemed that this strange fascination, the delight in what we cannot master, had always existed. A new cult of the sublime was capped with Edmund Burke's Philosophical Enquiry into the Origin of our Ideas of the Sublime and Beautiful (1757). For Burke, the sublime always belongs opposite the "beautiful". Beauty is what we can comprehend; sublimity is what we cannot grasp. Beauty is in proportion; sublimity is in vastness. The beautiful is satisfying; the sublime is stupefying.

Primarily, the sublime was to be found in nature (though rarely in tame English nature). Many a British mountain-seeker went on his travels with Burke in his head. But it could be found in books too. For Burke, the most sublime writer was Milton in Paradise Lost, especially in those hellish passages where "all is dark, uncertain, confused, terrible, and sublime to the last degree". One of literature's most sublime characters was Milton's Satan, fascinating despite one's better instincts (the frightening pleasure of sublimity being apparently amoral).

For the Romantic poets, the sublime was an encounter with the almost infinite powers of the human imagination. In The Prelude, Wordsworth sees Mont Blanc and regrets that the real mountain has taken the place of what he more sublimely imagined. Now the sublime is not in nature, it is in faculties of the individual (or, at least, some individuals). As Coleridge puts it: "I meet, I find the Beautiful - but I give, contribute, or rather attribute the Sublime".

This is also Turner's sublime - the greatest stretch and test of the figurative imagination. Ever since, even if it has faded from literature, it has stayed as an idea in art, especially in American art. 19th-century American painting was dominated by huge landscapes that attempted to catch what Walt Whitman called "that vast Something, stretching out on its own unbounded scale, unconfined" - in other words, America.

This experience was also remembered in the huge abstract paintings of artists like Mark Rothko and Barnett Newman. The latter is one of the main subjects of Jeremy Gilbert-Rolfe's Beauty and the Contemporary Sublime (Allworth Press, £12), which certainly demonstrates that art theorists still hanker after sublimity. Beauty is "frivolous", thinks Gilbert-Rolfe: enjoyable perhaps, but easily fabricated. Beauty is what we get from fashion and design. Theorists of art need something grander: a sublime art of "limitlessness and indeterminacy". For Gilbert-Rolfe, this produces a kind of elevating befuddlement, obliging the earnest student of art to turn to a high priest like himself.

Dizzy post-structuralists like this have a shrunken version of the Romantic sublime. Depressingly, the sublime for them is when our imagination is defeated. Sublimity now describes moments when we recognise that any of our ways of comprehending the world are illusions. For Slavoj Zizek, author of The Art of the Ridiculous Sublime (University of Washington Press, £9.95), this includes our conscious senses of ourselves. Zizek finds the sublime through psychoanalytic theory and the films of David Lynch, which apparently elaborate "the Lacanian sublime", and in which characters pursue "impossible objects of desire".

For the theory men, the sublime is of human manufacture. Gilbert-Rolfe would like us to believe in a "techno-sublime". A geographical idea of limitlessness has given way to a technological one. This is a paradox, for the sublime is precisely what we cannot master, while technology is supposedly what allows us to control nature.

As neither of these theoreticians of sublimity acknowledges, it has for a long time been pure science, not technology, that has given us a sense of the sublime. Now the voids into which we are invited to gaze in amazement are the unimaginably huge ones of Godless space and time.

In some ways all this is not new. Shelley made poetry out of the temporal sublime, most famously in "Ozymandias", where the ancients are makers of huge abandoned ruins, mysterious markers of human smallness. If there is no providence, history can be a vast expanse that mocks our self-regard. And the Victorians were given an idea of time that was even more diminishing, even more sublime. They had geological time, in the span of which any person's life is nearly nothing. Down the tunnel of those millions of years we have since had to gaze, making a Darwinian world possible.

Science, at least as popularised, can be beautiful as well as sublime. The beautiful is science in its shapely reductiveness; the sublime is science in its incomprehensibility. Popularisers of science sometimes seem worried about the imputation of reductiveness, and are often keen to assert that the world still inspires awe after science. Richard Dawkins's last book, Unweaving the Rainbow, was dedicated to showing us that the universe is more "wonderful" with science than without it. It even searched for proof that a mechanically comprehended universe can be poetically inspirational, seizing (unwisely) on James Thomson's ludicrously ecstatic poem in memory of Newton as an example.

As Dawkins did not see, the poetical or artistic sublime is often close to the ridiculous. As the sublime was becoming fashionable, Alexander Pope produced a brilliant guide to this tendency, his "Art of Sinking in Poetry". It was a compendium of the failed sublimities of other poets, many of them contemporaries, and it introduced the word "bathos" to the English language. Those who reach for the sublime can fall on their faces.

We see in Pope's examples, as in some of those 19th-century American landscapes, how scale can become mere bombast, significance mere self-importance. Grandiosity certainly tumbles into the ridiculous in the post-modern aesthetics of Gilbert-Rolfe and Zizek. On this evidence, we have to keep looking for better ways to recover the frightening, necessary delight of knowing our own smallness.

Buy Beauty and the Contemporary Sublime at BOL

 John Mullan is writing a book about anonymity for Faber.

If there is no providence, history can be a vast expanse that mocks our self-regard. And the Victorians were given an idea of time that was even more diminishing, even more sublime. They had geological time, in the span of which any person's life is nearly nothing. Down the tunnel of those millions of years we have since had to gaze, making a Darwinian world possible. Science, at least as popularised, can be beautiful as well as sublime. The beautiful is science in its shapely reductiveness; the sublime is science in its incomprehensibility. Popularisers of science sometimes seem worried about the imputation of reductiveness, and are often keen to assert that the world still inspires awe after science. Richard Dawkins's last book, Unweaving the Rainbow, was dedicated to showing us that the universe is more "wonderful" with science than without it. It even searched for proof that a mechanically comprehended universe can be poetically inspirational, seizing (unwisely) on James Thomson's ludicrously ecstatic poem in memory of Newton as an example. As Dawkins did not see, the poetical or artistic sublime is often close to the ridiculous. As the sublime was becoming fashionable, Alexander Pope produced a brilliant guide to this tendency, his "Art of Sinking in Poetry". It was a compendium of the failed sublimities of other poets, many of them contemporaries, and it introduced the word "bathos" to the English language. Those who reach for the sublime can fall on their faces. We see in Pope's examples, as in some of those 19th-century American landscapes, how scale can become mere bombast, significance mere self-importance. Grandiosity certainly tumbles into the ridiculous in the post-modern aesthetics of Gilbert-Rolfe and Zizek. On this evidence, we have to keep looking for better ways to recover the frightening, necessary delight of knowing our own smallness. Buy Beauty and the Contemporary Sublime at BOL  John Mullan is writing a book about anonymity for Faber.

webTitle: Ex-Welsh minister hopes for English comeback

fields.headline: Ex-Welsh minister hopes for English comeback
fields.standfirst: Special report: devolution in Wales
fields.trailText: Rod Richards, the former Wales Office minister and a Tory member of the Welsh assembly, said yesterday that he hoped to find a safe Westminster seat in England.
fields.body:
Rod Richards, the former Wales Office minister and a Tory member of the Welsh assembly, said yesterday that he hoped to find a safe Westminster seat in England.

He also said that a recent court case, in which he was cleared of punching a 23-year-old woman in the face and breaking her arm, and also a bankruptcy petition that he successfully resisted, would make him a more attractive candidate.

"In a perverse way the experiences of the last 12 months have, I think, made me a better politician - in that I am more able to understand the problems that constituents would come to me with.

"If somebody comes to me and says they have been arrested and charged with something they did not do, I know exactly how they feel because it happened to me. If somebody comes to me and says they've lost their job or their business is going under, I know how they feel. From that point of view I could argue forcefully. That's the kind of representative they want and need - somebody who has scars to show, as opposed to more traditional candidates."

Despite his past, having also been leader of the Welsh Conservatives as well as a Welsh MP, Mr Richards was looking for a seat in England.

"There is no doubt in my mind that, given the devolution policy of this government, there will be two classes of MP: England MPs and then Welsh and Scottish.

"I never did believe in [the government's form of devolution]. Also, politics is about power, the power to change things - and the powers of the assembly are very constrained. It is still Westminster that determines the policy down here."

webTitle: What going to college costs and  how you can pay for it

fields.headline: What going to college costs and  how you can pay for it
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Fees, loans and, grants are a complex area, writes Liz Stuart.
fields.body:
Fees, loans and, grants are a complex area, writes Liz Stuart.

Rules on student funding have already been altered in Scotland, with more changes to come. So just who is entitled to what and when - and how much will the alumni-to-be have to pay for their studies?

If you are English, Welsh or Northern Irish and starting a university course in England, Wales or Northern Ireland this September, you will have to pay £1,050 towards the cost of your course fees, regardless of whether you are going to take up church studies or astrophysics. This effectively means you pay an average of £1 in every £7.50 of the course fee.

This, however, is means tested - if your gross family income is below £17,805 you will pay nothing, and if it is between this and £33,000 you make a contribution on a sliding scale. According to the government, this means around one third of students will pay the full fee, a third pay something and a third pay nothing at all.

Although the days of highly subsidised student life are long gone, loans are available to students with no interest payable until after graduation - known as, unsurprisingly, the student loan. The maximum loan under this arrangement for the coming academic year will be £4,590, for a student living away from home and studying in London. This goes down to £3,725 for students outside London and to just £2,950 for those who opt to live with their parents during the academic year.

Loans must be applied for at least one calender month before the course starts. If you are going to study abroad, different loan levels are available. Repayment will need to start when you earn more than £10,000 a year before tax.

There are some other forms of financial support available on a non-repayable basis, however. If you are a single parent and a student you may claim additional benefit, for instance. If you have dependants - children or a spouse or, if you are over 25, a co-habiting partner - you will also be entitled to benefit. The amount is means tested on the dependant's income.

Hardship loans are also available, although these cannot be relied on as the money is granted at the discretion of the Student Loan Company and the biggest sum is just £500. This is offered to students who have applied for the maximum loan and received at least one instalment. This will also have to be repaid in the future; the same repayment scheme applies as for the standard student loan.

If you have to attend college for longer than the usual term time of 30 weeks you are entitled to an additional payment. This is £45 a week for those living at home, £86 for students living away from home and studying in London and £65 for those away from home outside the capital.

Mature students and young people from disadvantaged backgrounds may also apply for a discretionary access bursary. These are granted by individual universities and do not have to be repaid. The maximum available is £1,000. As each institution will only be able to offer a limited number of these, you should apply as quickly as possible.

Scottish students, meanwhile, are at a distinct advantage to their English and Welsh counterparts. Those who opt to study in their own country can tap into a means-tested loan of up to £3,725 as well as a non-means tested one of up to £1,745 if they are to live in halls or digs or £1,165 if they stay in the parental home. The income threshold for means testing is £17,805. They are also exempt from course fees.

Scottish students who opt to study south of the border are subject to the same loan and fee rules as their English and Welsh counterparts.

"We are delighted that the Scottish executive decided to abolish tuition fees, although we are still concerned about student hardship," says a spokesman from NUS Scotland. Although the overall financing packages for students have increased in line with inflation, the NUS calculates that there will still be a substantial shortfall between money available and the expenses students will face. For the next year the cash gap will be £3,300 for students outside London, rising to £4,000 for those at college in the capital.

According to research by Barclays, graduate debt continues to rise - by 17% last year and by more than 100% since 1994, although, according to NatWest, one in five students are still graduating with no debt at all. The average amount owed to the Stu dent Loan Company, banks, credit card providers and parents is now £4,497 for a person who has just left college. Coupled with a decline in the average graduate salary, this is worrying news for students.

The DfEE publishes a leaflet Financial Support for Higher Education Students in 2000/2001, which is available by calling 0800-731-9133 or see the website www.dfee.gov.uk For the Student Loan Company tel 0800-405010.

fields.headline: Music for communes
fields.standfirst: Incredible String Band Bloomsbury Theatre, London ***
fields.trailText: Incredible String Band Bloomsbury Theatre, London ***
fields.body:
One of the last releases from the Incredible String Band before they fizzled out in 1974 was called No Ruinous Feud. That must have been wishful thinking, because it has taken founder members Robin Williamson and Mike Heron nearly 30 years to pull the band back together.

Anybody unfamiliar with the group's mystique and mythology would have been bewildered by this performance. With the beaming, bearded Williamson acting as a benign master of ceremonies, the new-look five-piece Incredibles pottered erratically around the hinterlands of their back catalogue, like a group of people waking slowly from a deep, enchanted sleep. One thing they had clearly forgotten about was rehearsing, since they made up lumps of this set as they went along, and none too successfully either. Bina, Williamson's wife, had to keep rummaging in her handbag for the band's set list.

Still, it is rather refreshing to witness a performance of such shambling ineptitude (with the honourable exception of Lawson Dando's keyboards). It floated past on such a powerful tide of nostalgic good vibes that it barely mattered what they played or how they played it. At the end of the 60s, the String Band's menu of wispy hippy mysticism and nimble folk-based musicianship won them a quasi-religious following, which is obviously only waiting to be reawakened.

To the unbeliever, much of the material is ripe for ridicule, with its elfin lyrics about magic Christmas trees, painting boxes, ducks on the pond and how each moment is different. However, while Mike Heron's voice seems to have vanished altogether and banjo player Clive Palmer has been stricken with lumbago, Williamson himself offered glimpses of the breadth of his repertoire. He included In My Craft or Sudden Art, with words by Dylan Thomas, prodded the ensemble through Strings in the Earth and Air (lyrics by James Joyce), and made a reasonable stab at some sprightly Scottish folk instrumentals, with Palmer wheezing gamely on the Northumbrian pipes.

For the Smoke Shovelling Song, Williamson invited volunteers on stage to blow whistles and ring bells. I wouldn't be at all surprised if the entire audience has now gone to live on a commune in Wales.
