fields.headline: Ballet goes boisterous
fields.standfirst: Don Quixote Royal Opera House, London ****
fields.trailText: Don Quixote Royal Opera House, London ****
fields.body:
The Kirov's public image is that of a company dedicated to classicism. A company whose symbolic colour is the white of exquisitely posed swan princesses or of ghostly bayaderes. But there is an alternative style of 19th- century ballet at which the Russians also excel: the colourful spectacles in which dance kicks up its legs with the boisterous traditions of the music hall.

None of these are more boisterous than Petipa's comedy Don Quixote, performed here in Gorsky's 1902 version. The work is an unholy mix of farce, folk dance, technical tricks and limpid classicism. The Kirov's dancers breeze through the choreography's technical terrors and never patronise the material.

On Thursday, the tone of the ballet was pitched high and fast by Diana Vishneva as Kitri and Faroukh Ruzimatov as her lover Basil. The latter is a little slow-witted and too self- absorbed to hit every note of raffish, street-smart humour, yet there is enough swagger in his dancing to generate comic energy. He is a glamorous foil to Vishneva, whose brazenly high extensions and fizzing dynamics are made lovable by her pretty arms and huge grin.

As the story careers around its slapstick scenario (the Don is trying to prevent Kitri's father from marrying his daughter to the local fop) the stage is hardly still for a moment. The work's speed is guaranteed to keep boredom at bay, though at times it does threaten to become manic. An overpadded Sergei Konstantinov as Sancho Panza throws away his best jokes in a frenzy of mugged grimaces. Although the whole cast perform with an engaging sense of fun and unselfconscious enjoyment, they could do with an acting coach to polish up their comic timing.

Exceptional, though, is Vladimir Ponomarev as the Don. As angular and attenuated as a Spanish saint, he staggers in hollowed-eyed pursuit after schemes and visions. Through his eyes, we are granted the most singular vision of the whole production: Natalia Sologub dancing the Queen of the Dyrads in the Don's fevered imagination. Sologub possesses an eerily perfect control over her body: the long, singing lines of her movement not only cast a brief lyric spell within the ballet but promise an extraordinary future career.

 Ends tonight. Box office: 020-7304 4000.

fields.headline: Education bill tops £200,000
fields.standfirst:
Jill Papworth advises parents to start saving for those fees now

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Jill Papworth advises parents to start saving for those fees now.
fields.body:
If you want to educate your children privately, or aim to fund them through university, you'd be well advised to face up to the astronomical costs involved and start saving as much as you can afford as early in their lives as possible.

Overall, total costs for a child undergoing primary and secondary private schooling followed by university could top £200,000 say education experts. So, while many people do leave it to the last minute to work out how they'll fund education costs, tending to use an expensive combination of borrowing and pay-as-you-go out of taxed income, forward planning is the key to easing the financial burden.

There are no specific school fees plans and the government axed covenants some years ago. The savings vehicles recommended by independent financial advisers (IFAs) as appropriate for education costs planning include tax-free Individual Savings Accounts (Isas), unit and investment trusts, zero dividend preference shares (zeros), with-profits endowments, National Savings and high- interest term bonds with building societies or banks.

But the mix of vehicles recommended varies widely depending on how far ahead you are planning, how much you have to salt away, your funding targets, attitude to risk and whether or not you can expect to invest inherited lump sums in the future.

According to a Jobs & Money ring-around of IFAs, you are also likely to find that recommendations vary depending on whether your IFA charges for advice on a fee or commission basis. It was noticeable that some who make a living mainly from commis sion are more inclined to favour higher commission-paying vehicles such as endowments, unit trusts and friendly society 10-year bonds in preference to lower commission-paying investment trusts and, particularly, zeros, which pay no commission.

Despite this confusion, it is worth going to an IFA to formulate a long-term, well-balanced investment plan. Specialist IFAs such as Invest for School Fees (part of Willis National) and SFIA Mason & Mason, for example, also make much of their ability to administer plans for clients, ensuring that fee cheques are issued in good time for the start of school terms and regularly monitoring how your investments are performing.

The earlier you start saving the better. One way of getting the ball rolling, if you can afford to, is to start investing your Child Benefit from day one or, perhaps, from when the mother goes back to work and starts earning again.

If you have planned ahead and saved for at least five years before you need to start paying education costs then IFAs are generally agreed that equity-based investments will give you the best return over the long term.

Make use of all tax-free opportunities first, so protect the first £7,000 worth of equity investments in a maxi Isa - each parent has this allowance. Donna Bradshaw of IFAs Fiona Price & Partners says: "Attractive long-term options include low-cost tracker unit trusts such as M&G's and I also like Fidelity's Wealth Builder which is an international fund of (Fidelity) funds which gives very good diversification and which has been performing well."

For planning over the shorter term, Sue Whitbread of fee-based IFAs Chartwell Asset Management says: "Zeros are top of the pile and make ideal investments for building up capital for education purposes."

Zeros are a type of share issued by split capital investment trusts. Unlike normal shares, which aim to pay a regular income (dividend) and appreciate in value, zeros pay out only a predetermined capital sum at a predetermined wind-up date. So you know what you'll be getting back and when. You can invest in a series of different trusts with differing maturity dates to fund staggered education costs.

"One advantage of zeros is that the gain is taxed as a capital gain which can be offset against CGT allowances and zeros can be gifted to a child in a designated account to make use of a child's own CGT allowance, £7,200 per year," Ms Whitbread says.

"Zeros typically yield 7%-9% per annum and while it must be pointed out that the predetermined redemption price is not guaranteed, there has not yet been an instance when a zero has not met its redemption price, so they are fairly low risk."

Given that the longest maturity date on zeros is about nine years, they suit planning over the shorter term. "And over longer periods, well-managed, well diversified equity funds would outperform zeros," says Ms Whitbread who tends to recommend investment trusts over unit trusts because of their lower cost structure.

ISIS publishes a free leaflet on school fees planning which includes a list of specialist advisers. Call 020-7798-1500 for a copy or order via the website at www.isis.org.uk. IFA Promotion is about to publish a free factsheet on school fees and university costs planning. For copies call the IFAP hotline on 0117-9711177 or visit the website at www.ifap.org.uk. The Association of Investment Trust Companies (AITC) publishes free factsheets on investing for children and split capital investment trusts and zeros, available on 0800-707707 or www.itsonline.co.uk. Invest for School Fees 020-7488-8111. Fiona Price & Partners 020-7430-0366. SFIA Mason & Mason 0800-7318707. Chartwell Asset Management 01225-321700.

webTitle: Theatre review: The old pros take their turn

fields.headline: The old pros take their turn
fields.standfirst: A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum Theatre Royal, York *****
fields.trailText: A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum Theatre Royal, York *****
fields.body:
What was that about impoverished regional theatres with no money, no audiences and no sense of ambition? In the period when most provincial playhouses shut up shop for the summer to save a bit of money, the Theatre Royal has opted to splurge on a large cast, full band and big set at the service of a melodious, venerable romp that has been resting on its laurels for far too long now.

A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum, Stephen Sondheim's first solo effort as composer and librettist, has always rather suffered by way of association. First you think of Frankie Howerd, then you think of Up Pompeii, then you think you must have seen it. True, in the course of its madcap plotting it manages to find a place for every cliche in the book, but at least Sondheim went direct to the book that they originally came from.

What is so surprising about A Funny Thing..., apart from the insouciant sophistication of Sondheim's deceptively simple songwriting, is the stamp it bears of its primary influence: Titus Maccius Plautus, the earliest extant Latin comic dramatist. You want to know where mother-in-law jokes and that old gag with the plank came from? You need look no further than Plautus himself.

Nor is it a one-man vehicle, as Frankie Howerd's triumph in the original West End production might have suggested. Martin Barrass is in top form in the taxing toga part of Pseudolus the Slave, and proves that there is more to the role than obsequiously following Frankie. But the real reason for the show's irrepressible buoyancy - and undoubtedly the reason it is attempted so infrequently - is that it demands a wide range of talent from a very substantial cast.

This is not a show you can skimp on, and thankfully director Damian Cruden goes for broke. True, the lengthy cast list offers a constellation of people you probably won't have heard of, but it just shows how unrelated concepts of ability and celebrity can be. Some of the cast, particularly the posse of gymnastic courtesans, are young guns on the way up; but it is the old blokes who make off with most of the honours.

Howard Attfield and Stuart Sherwin, as Senex and Hysterium, prove to be a hilarious pair of old pros in a show where the values of old-proism are paramount. Sherwin's biography informs us that he began his career in weekly rep. Does anyone remember what that was? They may do yet if shows like this continue to buck the trend.

 Until September 2. Box office: 01904 623568.

webTitle: A helping hand for the clueless on campus

fields.headline: A helping hand for the clueless on campus
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Lee Bailey has been advising students on their finance for the past four years, writes Liz Stuart.
fields.body:
Lee Bailey has been advising students on their finance for the past four years, writes Liz Stuart.

He is now based at a University of the West of England NatWest campus branch, set up 27 years ago when the campus was built.

He says the notion that all students are horribly in debt is a myth.

"There are three sorts of people. The first have a precise budget and have saved up to come to university. Around 30% of NatWest banking students leave college with no debt whatsoever, so presumably these are this group.

"Next comes the biggest group. They have a budget, but tend not to stick to it.

"The third, and smallest group - around 5%-10% of students - are people who are really pretty clueless. They think that as long as the ATM continues to give them money, they don't need to think any more about it"

Lee adds, however, that most young people about to go to college grossly underestimate how much they will spend - initial budgets are generally around a third too low. More is being spent on travel and going out than in the past.

While NatWest has no fixed maximum overdraft, the level will be negotiated on an individual basis and, as banks will have one eye on the person's ability to repay, this is not carte blanche for students to borrow £10,000 in their first year.

Mr Bailey says that although the bank will authorise overdrafts over the phone, he prefers that students come to see him, if only to reassure themselves that he has only one head.

"In fact people do seem more comfortable discussing their finances with us, although some still see it as an admission of failure," he says.

webTitle: Train yourself to do without a degree

fields.headline: Train yourself to do without a degree
fields.standfirst:
While graduates enjoy more choice, job security and higher salaries, there are still real prospects for others to gain qualifications and make a career impact. Jessica McCallin sets out the options

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: While graduates enjoy more choice, job security and higher salaries, there are still real prospects for others to gain qualifications and make a career impact. Jessica McCallin sets out the options.
fields.body:
To get a degree or not to get a degree? That will be the question on many a young person's mind this week. Some will have got disappointing A-level results and may be unable to take up a university place unless they re-sit.

Others may be put off by the cost of going to university, while the prospect of yet more study will discourage the exam-weary. And there are always those who, at the tender age of 18, don't know what they want to do with their lives and are putting off thoughts of higher education until they do. Similar thoughts will be running through the minds of the nation's 16-year-olds.

Faced with the choice of staying at school and doing A-levels, leaving to do a vocational course or leaving to get a job, many will, understandably, be confused. But what does the future hold for non-graduates? The short answer is less money.

According to the Higher Education Career's Service Unit university graduates in their early 20s can expect to earn 29% more than their non-graduate peers. As they get older, the wage differential widens. By their early 40s, male graduates will be earning 66% more than men who didn't go to university and women graduates 87% more than their female counterparts.

To put a figure on it: graduates can expect a starting salary averaging £15,500 if they are male and £13,800 if they are female, while non-graduates will get only around £12,000 if they are male and £10,100 if female. By the time they reach their early 40s, male graduates will be taking home around £35,000 a year and female graduates around £25,000, while non-graduates of the same sex can expect salaries of around £20,000 and £14,000 respectively.

You can prosper without a degree, of course. With A-levels in law, English and sociology, Direct Line PR executive Katharine Watson qualified for university, but the prospect did not appeal. It was only when she moved to London from Devon that she found enormous prejudice against non-graduates.

"Some recruitment agencies wouldn't even look at me," she says. "Two and a half years' work experience did not seem to count." When she finally landed a job with Bell Pottinger PR 24-year-old Katharine felt the need to get some qualifications and took a Communications, Advertising and Media certificate through part-time study.

Now "up there with the best of them" in salary terms, she does not regret going straight into the world of work. Her advice to other non-graduate job-seekers: "Don't be fazed. It takes perserverance and there will be knock-backs. Be focused on the area of work you are interested in. You have got to have determination to be successful." Even so, university graduates are much less likely to be unemployed. Spring 2000 figures from the Department for Education and Employment (DfEE) put the unemployment rate for those with first degrees at 2.4%, roughly half the national average of 5.6%.

On top of this, graduates seem to get more holiday time - at least in their early 20s - working around 10.2 months a year as opposed to the 11 months worked by non-graduates. But it's worth remembering that there is far more to further education than a university degree. Vocational A-levels will be launched next month, covering a wide range of subjects including art and design, engineering, information and communications technology and media, arts and entertainment. These will be available through secondary schools and colleges and will be followed by vocational GCSEs in September 2002. National Vocational Qualifications (NVQs), available through further eduction colleges, are another option, usually taken by people who already have some A-Levels.

Offered in a wide variety of subjects, NVQs are designed to develop the knowledge, skills and understanding needed for work in a broad occupational area. They also focus on developing the all-important "employability" skills: the basic keyboarding, presentation and communication skills which companies say are all too lacking among today's youth. If a particular industry or sector appeals to you, an NVQ should give you enough understanding and confidence to get your foot in the door. And while apprenticeships may evoke images of the sweatshop conditions described in a Charles Dickens' novel, modern versions are available in more than 80 sectors including accountancy, air transport, electronic systems, insurance, security and the water industry.

The government has also launched a scheme called Learndirect to promote the concept of lifelong learning. The scheme offers 300 courses on subjects as diverse as keyboarding, business and retail which can be studied over the internet or at a regional Learndirect centre. More details can be found at www.learndirect.co.uk or by phoning 0800-100-900. Your local library and job centre should also be able to help you with finding a course. If money is a problem, individual learning accounts (ILAs) which give you up to £150 to put towards the cost of a course should help. However, evening and part-time courses, especially those offered by local further education colleges can be very good value and it's worth shopping around not only to find the cheapest, but to find the most suitable. It's also worth remembering that many colleges let students pay in instalments, helping to spread the burden.

webTitle: Standard faces fight for its Life yet again

fields.headline: Standard faces fight for its Life yet again
fields.standfirst:
After seeing off one carpetbagger, the Scottish insurer is set to lock horns with two groups wanting conversion. Rupert Jones reports

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: After seeing off one carpetbagger, the Scottish insurer is set to lock horns with two groups wanting conversion. Rupert Jones reports.
fields.body:
Just weeks after sending carpetbagger Fred Woollard packing, Scottish insurance giant Standard Life has found itself under attack again - and this time it's being challenged by not one but two campaign groups calling for it to convert and pay windfalls.

What's more, if this develops into another full-blown battle we could have a real derby on our hands because, unlike the Australia-born, Monaco-based Mr Woollard, these two new foes are both Scottish businessmen (well, one's a Scot through and through, while the other is a Sassenach who's lived in Scotland for the best part of 30 years).

Gordon Hart and Mike Anthony, both long-term Standard Life policyholders, launched separate campaigns this week aimed at forcing the insurer to float on the stock market and hand out windfalls. The two-pronged challenge thrusts the whole debate about Standard Life's future firmly back into the spotlight less than two months after it defeated a conversion attempt led by Mr Woollard.

It was on June 27 that the company announced that only 45.7% of members had voted for demutualisation - far fewer than the 75% needed to secure victory. Mr Hart struck first this week, announcing on Monday he would be mounting a campaign aimed at securing a fresh ballot on demutualisation early next year. First of all, though, he wants some answers to his questions about the way the previous vote was handled.

Mr Hart is the chairman of a group called the Members' Rights Campaign and claims Standard Life's 2.3m member policyholders could receive payouts averaging almost £8,000 apiece if it were to float on the stock market - higher even than Mr Woollard was predicting. Twenty-four hours later, Mr Anthony announced that he would also be donning his battle gear and joining the fray. He has set up an action group called the Standard Life Alliance for Members (SLAM), and is also calling for a special general meeting to be held to vote on convert ing to a public company. Of the two challengers, Mr Hart has the more impressive form - in the past few months he has targeted two other mutual insurers, with some success.

Friends Provident announced in May that it intends to convert to a public company and pay windfalls, just days after coming under attack from the Friends Provident Vote Campaign action group that Mr Hart led. He could be about to add another trophy to his wall as another of his targets, Scottish Provident, has agreed to review its mutual status after being targeted by yet another of his groups, the Scottish Provident Members Alliance Group. With one victory in the bag and another looking a distinct likelihood, Mr Hart, a 50-year-old father-of-two from Hamilton, has suddenly become a figure to be reckoned with in the world of windfall-hunters.

What's more, he has teamed up with another formidable figure, lawyer Jonathan Stone, who has led high-profile campaigns in past years against Burmah Oil and, more recently, Barings, the merchant bank that crashed in 1995. And it's got to be said that his campaign is no amateur affair - his website (www.membersrights.co.uk) is geared up to accept online donations to the "fighting fund," and he has set up a 60p-per-minute telephone information line (0906-601-0061) to boost the coffers.

Mr Hart, a director of a telecoms company, claims Standard Life was economical with the truth in the run-up to the vote and says the board "did not act in the best interests" of members. "We believe Standard Life seriously undervalued and understated its financial strength," he adds. At the height of the battle earlier this year the insurer effectively put a valuation on itself of £12bn and said about 50% of members would receive windfalls of less than £2,500.

These estimates were attacked by many observers as way too low - independent life insurance analyst Ned Cazalet believes the company is worth £16bn and predicted average windfalls of £7,000. Mr Hart says his group estimates the value of the insurer at £18bn, which would give average windfalls of just over £7,800. In order to settle the matter fairly, he says members should be given an "indepen dently audited and impartial" estimate of the windfall they would be likely to receive if the company were to demutualise. This should be followed by an "unbiased referendum" on demutualisation early next year so policyholders can have their say, armed with "the true facts".

If members then vote again for mutuality, a "mutual dividend" should be paid to members from its surplus cash pile to defuse the whole issue. Rather than rushing in with conversion resolutions, he is focusing on securing a valuation of the company. What about Mr Anthony? He is a 47-year-old business consultant who lives and works in Edinburgh but is originally from London. Like Mr Hart, he says he is no carpetbagger - he has been a Standard Life policyholder on and off since 1976 - but he believes Standard Life should demutualise to provide windfalls and subject the board to scrutiny from shareholders.

However, where the two men differ is that Mr Anthony has decided to get straight on with rounding up backers for his set of nine resolutions which include one calling on the insurer "to take steps to demutualise" and another demanding it provides details of likely windfalls for various categories of policyholder. He says he has already got the backing of more than 70 people and has a website at www.a-way-worldwide.com.

Standard Life's rules still allow any resolution to be put forward to a special meeting provided it has 50 eligible supporters, though the company has put some anti-carpetbagging measures in place. The main one is that any policy bought after February 9 this year will not be eligible for a windfall if demutualisation occurs within three years of the date of purchase.

And it's got to be said that his campaign is no amateur affair - his website (www.membersrights.co.uk) is geared up to accept online donations to the "fighting fund," and he has set up a 60p-per-minute telephone information line (0906-601-0061) to boost the coffers. Mr Hart, a director of a telecoms company, claims Standard Life was economical with the truth in the run-up to the vote and says the board "did not act in the best interests" of members. "We believe Standard Life seriously undervalued and understated its financial strength," he adds. At the height of the battle earlier this year the insurer effectively put a valuation on itself of £12bn and said about 50% of members would receive windfalls of less than £2,500. These estimates were attacked by many observers as way too low - independent life insurance analyst Ned Cazalet believes the company is worth £16bn and predicted average windfalls of £7,000. Mr Hart says his group estimates the value of the insurer at £18bn, which would give average windfalls of just over £7,800. In order to settle the matter fairly, he says members should be given an "indepen dently audited and impartial" estimate of the windfall they would be likely to receive if the company were to demutualise. This should be followed by an "unbiased referendum" on demutualisation early next year so policyholders can have their say, armed with "the true facts". If members then vote again for mutuality, a "mutual dividend" should be paid to members from its surplus cash pile to defuse the whole issue. Rather than rushing in with conversion resolutions, he is focusing on securing a valuation of the company. What about Mr Anthony? He is a 47-year-old business consultant who lives and works in Edinburgh but is originally from London. Like Mr Hart, he says he is no carpetbagger - he has been a Standard Life policyholder on and off since 1976 - but he believes Standard Life should demutualise to provide windfalls and subject the board to scrutiny from shareholders. However, where the two men differ is that Mr Anthony has decided to get straight on with rounding up backers for his set of nine resolutions which include one calling on the insurer "to take steps to demutualise" and another demanding it provides details of likely windfalls for various categories of policyholder. He says he has already got the backing of more than 70 people and has a website at www.a-way-worldwide.com. Standard Life's rules still allow any resolution to be put forward to a special meeting provided it has 50 eligible supporters, though the company has put some anti-carpetbagging measures in place. The main one is that any policy bought after February 9 this year will not be eligible for a windfall if demutualisation occurs within three years of the date of purchase.

fields.headline: Little interest at the margin
fields.standfirst:
The vast difference between what banks pay on deposits and what they charge borrowers has yet to come under the spotlight, says Liz Stuart

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The vast difference between what banks pay on deposits and what they charge borrowers has yet to come under the spotlight, says Liz Stuart.
fields.body:
Bank knocking has become as common as politician baiting but unfortunately, even after a government-led inquiry into unfair practices and countless instances of public outcries over branch closures and security breaches, our savings and loans institutions are still failing their customers. Don Cruikshank's March report on the banks showed that neither personal nor small business customers were getting a fair deal.

He pointed, in particular, to excessive ATM charges, market domination of the big four, the slow movement of money between accounts and charging retailers too much for credit card transactions.

But one area which is still attracting scant scrutiny is the savings margin. This is the difference between the amount of interest banks pay on your savings, compared with both bank base rates, and the amount they charge customers for borrowing.

Think about it: it is your money, on which they are paying you as little as 1% (the Woolwich has recently changed the rates on its Prime Gold account, meaning that while rates have increased on small amounts invested, deposit £50,000 with them and you will receive a paltry 1% interest gross) which they are lending to other customers at up to 29%, in the form of an unauthorised overdraft.

This represents a hefty profit for shareholders or boost to mutuals' assets, but is not a good deal for the saver.

You may think this is fair enough - the banks have an infrastructure to operate and shoulder the risk of lending. But this does not excuse the fact that many banks pay very low rates on even substantial sums saved and are failing to increase their savings rates when bank base rates go up.

This effect is compounded with each rate rise, meaning that following last year's six rate increases, the difference between the base rate and the savings rate increases each time.

After the last bank base rate increase of a quarter of a percentage point in February, all the big institutions were quick to raise their mortgage rates by the same amount.

But Halifax, Abbey National, Bradford & Bingley, NatWest, Nationwide and Woolwich made only a small increase to their savings rates for branch customers. Halifax and Abbey National were the most guilty: both increased their mortgage rates by the 0.25%, but the former increased rates on its Liquid Gold account only by an average of 0.04% and the latter upped its Instant Saver 3 account rates by an average of just 0.07%.

Banks have had five months to bring their rates into line, but most have still failed to do so (although, NatWest has since totally revamped some products, such as the First Reserve account on which rates have now been dramatically increased). Their excuse is, that while bank base rates have remained unaltered, then so should theirs.

This argument is a non-starter when they fail to increase the amounts they pay to savers even when there is a base rate rise. Best are Alliance & Leicester, Barclays and Cheltenham & Gloucester. A&L, for instance, increased the savings rates on some accounts by more than the base rate rise - the Access Plus account paid on average 0.29% more than in February.

Even the smaller building societies, which normally can be relied upon to offer the best rates to both borrowers and savers, are often slow to increase their rates because of the expense of doing so.

You should be able to earn at least base rate on your savings. A spokeswoman for financial data provider MoneyFacts says: "Many accounts now actually track base rates and guarantee to do so."

And, as we are now saving almost twice as much as we did just six years ago, we are talking about a lot of money lost in potential interest on savings.

Worryingly, according to Abbey National, around 40% of savers do not know what rate their savings are earning. Fortunately, banks are no longer allowed to let customers' money fester in accounts paying low rates of interest, launched when bank rates were at rock bottom in the past. They are now obliged to transfer the monies automatically into better-paying accounts.

But the message is still to shop around when investing in the first place - there are good rates on offer, although sometimes for a limited period only, and it could pay to look beyond the simple traditional deposit account, although they may lock in your money for a certain period.

webTitle: Questions that get to the Hart of the matter

fields.headline: Questions that get to the Hart of the matter
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Gordon Hart, leader of one of the groups challenging Standard Life, met with the company this week and submitted a list of questions he wanted answers to. Here are some of them, with Standard Life's responses.
fields.body:
Gordon Hart, leader of one of the groups challenging Standard Life, met with the company this week and submitted a list of questions he wanted answers to. Here are some of them, with Standard Life's responses.

Why does Standard Life oppose demutualisation when demutualisation would be good for most, if not all, existing policyholders?

We believe very strongly that mutuality is best for the company and that the change of structure and focus demutualisation would bring would damage the business ... our mutual status allows us to focus exclusively on the interests of the members and policyholders ... although members who have policies which have been running for many years might be net beneficiaries from a demutualisation, this would not necessarily be the case for others. In particular, new policies and increased contributions would not be covered by any ring-fencing agreement [when an insurer demutualises, steps are taken to protect existing policies from future bonus reductions caused by the need to pay dividends to shareholders].

Standard Life based its windfall estimates on an assumed minimum windfall of £250. Why did you pick this number when Scottish Widows had recently chosen £500?

The minimum windfall actually has little impact on the theoretical payout ranges that we presented. A very substantial number of members would receive considerably less than the much-quoted "average" payout (£5,000 to £6,300 depending on the assumption for Standard Life's market value) whether the minimum was £250 or £500 or even more.

Why were the endowment mortgage shortfall letters not sent out until after the June 27 vote [more than 500,000 of Standard Life's endowment policies may not be on target to pay off the mortgage assuming future investment growth of 6% a year]?

We always planned to start is suing reviews by the end of June 2000 and to complete the process by the end of June 2001. This remains our intention. It would have been totally impracticable for us to have advanced the start of this programme because of the volume of questions already being generated by the demutualisation debate.

Why was it not made clear to those persons that in most, if not all, cases the windfall would have solved the potential shortfall?

The issue the board had a duty to explain to members was its belief that the company would serve present and future members better if it stayed mutual. There is no relationship between that issue and current guesses about the future performance of mortgage endowment poli cies - policies which, contrary to widely-held misconceptions, have performed well to date.

What do you estimate to be the likely market capitalisation of Standard Life plc? Fred Woollard estimated £12-£15bn, [life insurance analyst] Ned Cazalet estimated £16bn, others said as much as £20bn.

Standard Life has never put a value on the business. Given the fluctuating values of windfalls on previous demutualisations, it would have been inappropriate and misleading to raise the expectations of members by using the most aggressive valuations proposed by some commentators. We, therefore, decided to use the top and bottom of the range of figures suggested by Mr Woollard.

webTitle: Smile - your bank account no longer works properly

fields.headline: Smile - your bank account no longer works properly
fields.standfirst:
A customer who decided to move his money to an internet bank encountered a raft of financial snarl ups. Rupert Jones reports

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: A customer who decided to move his money to an internet bank encountered a raft of financial snarl ups.
fields.body:
The adverts make it sound so easy. But when Jonathan Morrell decided to move his current account to internet bank Smile he found himself embroiled in a tortuous saga, even receiving "threatening" letters from companies that hadn't got their money because many of his direct debits apparently were not transferred properly.

He is now worried that the affair may have tarnished his credit record.

Smile is one of several banks and building societies taking part in a pilot scheme aimed at making it easier for people to switch banks. Mr Morrell, 30, decided he wanted to move his current account from the Halifax because he was fed-up with the disloyalty charges it imposes for withdrawing money from non-Halifax and HSBC cash machines. A friend told him about Smile, which has no charges for ATM withdrawals and offers a good rate of interest for a current account - 4.75%.

The bank's website certainly makes it all sound pretty painless. "Opening a Smile current account is easy. And if you'd like to switch your existing current account to Smile, we'll make it as quick and trouble-free as possible," it states. You simply give a few details online and it provides you with a set of prepared letters you can print and send out to redirect your existing direct debits, standing orders, salary and any other payments to your new Smile account.

Once you've posted your letters off, your existing bank has 10 working days in which to provide Smile with your details. As soon as Smile receives them, it sends you a copy and you confirm which payments you want to transfer. After that, the switch should take only a few days to complete.

Mr Morrell, a Tyne Tees TV journalist of Whickham, Newcastle upon Tyne, says a date was agreed for the end of June for the transfer of his account to take place. "One or two companies sent me new direct debit mandates which I filled in but, as for the others, I was assured by Smile that those payments would be made without the need to fill out new forms.

"Then the problems began - a phone company hadn't got its money and threatened to suspend the service. A credit card firm hadn't been paid - it demanded immediate payment. My endowment policy hadn't been paid... and on and on it went."

When Mr Morrell first spoke to Smile, he says, staff were helpful at first, telling him that the information could not have got through to the correct departments at the firms concerned.

But one month on, he was still sorting out the problems. "I've just opened a threatening letter from a car finance company. The final payment on a car which I sold a month ago hasn't been made. I thought it was the Halifax's fault, but no - once again it's another Smile cock-up." Mr Morrell says he was angered by Smile's attitude of "it's not our fault". It said that some of the companies it had asked to amend their direct debit instructions to include the new bank details had not done so.

"They should keep a closer eye on what's going on. I've had some nasty letters - it's embarrassing and I'm sure it has not done my creditworthiness any good. I feel as though I've been fobbed off and they haven't lived up to the promises in their publicity."

A spokesman for Smile describes Mr Morrell's experiences as a "one-off". He says that the day after Smile received a letter from Mr Morrell confirming which payments he wanted to transfer over to his Smile account, it sent out all the new direct debit mandates to the companies involved requesting they start to claim their money from the new bank on June 26.

"All that was done and everything seemed to be OK. The problem lies with the third-party companies which are involved. They haven't set their mandates up - some have, but there are quite a lot that haven't," says Smile.

The spokesman adds it has contacted the companies that are still outstanding and asked them to send new direct debit mandates to Mr Morrell to sign. It has also offered him a £15 payment to make up for the problems he has experienced.

"This is a trial system and it has been successful but there will always be isolated cases. We feel the system is better than what was previously there, where the customer had to do it all themselves," says the spokesman.

Smile says its advice to people generally is that, when switching their current accounts, they should keep enough money in their old account to cover the usual payments just in case there is a problem.

Piloting a complicated course

The problems experienced by Jonathan Morrell sum up why many people never get round to changing their bank - they're worried things will go wrong.

But the banks insist that a pilot account-switching scheme is making the whole process easier and less stressful.

More than a dozen banks and building societies are taking part in the "current account transfer scheme" which started last autumn. It aims to enable payments like direct debits and standing orders to be moved seamlessly from a customer's old account to the new one.

The plan is that a fully automated sys tem will be available to all customers by the end of 2001. Until then we will have to make do with the pilot scheme, which the banks say is a big improvement over the old system.

One survey found that 83% of people haven't changed their current account in the past five years and 50% of people have never changed their current account provider.

The new bank contacts your existing bank, which then has 10 days to produce a list of your direct debits and other payments. The new bank contacts the companies and instructs them to amend direct debit instructions and include new bank details. The companies must do this within three days.

However, every bank has to produce details of people's payments within 10 days, whether or not they are taking part. A spokesman for industry body Apacs (Association for Payment Clearing Services) says feedback about the scheme has been good. What may cause problems is that things are having to be sent by letter and information has to be keyed in manually, he says.

webTitle: Survival's the question in university challenge

fields.headline: Survival's the question in university challenge
fields.standfirst:
As the A-level results come out, Liz Stuart considers what's ahead for those bound for the campus -where finding part-time work to stave off a tide of debt is now as important as lectures and partying

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: As the A-level results come out, Liz Stuart considers what's ahead for those bound for the campus -where finding part-time work to stave off a tide of debt is now as important as lectures and partying.
fields.body:
Going to university ought to be about expanding the intellect while learning to be socially independent. Increasingly, it is about scraping together just enough money to live.

For students, the economic decline has been a gradual process. In 1984 the minimum maintenance grant (then £410) was halved and student travel costs reimbursement axed. Two years later, mandatory entitlement to supplementary and unemployment benefits was withdrawn. That same month, housing benefit for those living in hall was chopped, too.

Almost all students questioned by Barcalys Bank this month were in debt. Just 8% were not and the average debt has shot up to £4,339, a startling 25% increase on just 12 months ago. Escalating salaries for graduates in some areas mean that those debts will be paid quickly. The latest tale of super soaraway salaries has it that City law firms are paying as much as £40,000, for example. But that is of little comfort to those starting out in higher education.

Rent accounts for half student expenditure, although this should be put in context; students spend the biggest chunk of their outgoings on going out. The nationwide average rent is £45 a week, ranging from £22 in the Fenham area of Newcastle-upon-Tyne to London where the city-wide mean is £87, according to the National Union of Students.

Unsurprisingly, the majority of students will have to borrow money at some time during their studies. Credit Action, a charity which aims to help people manage their money, says banks and building societies are the good guys, as they charge nothing if borrowing is kept within a certain limit, even if they do try to lure new customers with fool's gold in the form of free CD vouchers.

Next, in order of preference, are the finance houses which charge around 15% on money loaned, followed by store cards at an average of 25%, then licenced money lenders, who, it warns, can charge up to 100%. Loan sharks should be avoided at all costs.

These days, many students find work during term time as well as the vacations. The majority of colleges now have job shops, similar to the job centre, which is separate to the careers or internship offices.

According to Dominic Drane, manager of the student employment office at Anglia Polytechnic University, around three in four students work while they study. And Clair Rees, director of the career service at York University, says college is increasingly becoming a preparation ground for employment with today's students - unlike many of the their 80s and 90s counterparts - acquiring the work-life skills required in the "real world" of work.

Oxford and Cambridge ban their students from finding jobs, but other universities recognise the need to prevent undergraduates being distracted from their studies. Dominic Drane says the average workload for students is 15 hours a week - the limit that is applied at York. The majority of these jobs are in traditional student areas such as bars and restaurants. Most will either receive the minimum wage of £3.60 a hour, or more if work is plentiful.

Mr Drane, who is also head of the National Association of Student Employment Staff, says: "In our area there are plenty of part-time jobs for people who want to work and the wages are accordingly slightly higher. That may not be the case in south Wales, for instance." Some job shops employ the students themselves, just as a recruitment agency would. Anglia's job shop pays an hourly wage of £4.30.

Some manage to find jobs which have a passing relevance to their course or intended career. Liverpool's John Moores University, for instance, coordinates a project with local call centres allowing students to work at the weekend or in the evening so they are not obliged to cut classes.

Virgin is dangling a slightly more attractive carrot by recruiting students as a salesforce for its mobile phones. Although this new legion of workers are dubbed brand managers, even Virgin admits that the workers will find the pay more useful than the work experience gained. The job entails researching mobile phone use among fellow students, auditing local Virgin Mobile retail outlets, liaising with local and student media and - of course - selling Virgin mobiles to fellow students.

Paul Layte, about to enter his final year of a natural science degree at Bath University, says it was not the £150-a-term wage plus free mobile phone which prompted him to answer an advertisement for student ambassadors, but rather the chance to get involved in something different. To date he has sold two phones and organised a competition.

"I am doing management studies as part of my degree and I am interested in marketing; I find putting plans and proposals together comes quite easily. It is also good experience on my CV," he says.

The NUS estimates that 1.5m students will work before starting their course in the autumn. One problem is that, however diligent, many are still uncertain of their tax position - unaware that they could be boosting their income by a third if they knew how to claim back tax and, more specifically, if they knew to ask employers for a P38 (S) form, so tax would not be deducted from the wage packet.

More than 50% of students manage to save an average of £1,680 and parents, accordingly, are being relied on less. In fact, there has been a 22% decrease in parental funding and this year 16% of people going to college received nothing from their parents, against 9% in 1999.

webTitle: Now it's tax and don't spend

fields.headline: Now it's tax and don't spend
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The Treasury's coffers received a record-breaking boost in July as the proceeds of the mobile phone licence auction continued to flow in.
fields.body:
The Treasury's coffers received a record-breaking boost in July as the proceeds of the mobile phone licence auction continued to flow in.

Tax revenues outstripped spending by £8bn last month - the biggest July figure since monthly data started in 1984-85, according to the office for national statistics.

So far this financial year, the government is running a massive £19.4bn surplus on the cash measure of its financial position, compared with a £63m deficit in the corresponding period a year ago.

The healthy state of the books is partly a result of windfall gains from the auction of third generation mobile phone licences, set to net £22.5bn in total for the Treasury. July is also usually a good month for corporation tax receipts.

On the government's preferred measure of the fiscal position, which smooths out lumpy spending and revenue items, the Treasury also recorded a record surplus of £6.6bn in July, giving a surplus for the year so far of £2.33bn, compared to a deficit of £332m a year ago.

Many analysts believe that the chancellor will once again achieve a bigger surplus for the whole year than the Treasury forecast in the March Budget. Mr Brown's forecasts have consistently been on the pessimistic side.

"Inland revenue and customs and excise receipts are overshooting projections by a large margin," said Adam Cole, UK economist at HSBC. "The outcome for the year as a whole is likely to be at least £5bn better than the Treasury's forecasts suggest."

On the spending side, the long awaited surge in departmental spending has yet to materialise. The ONS figures showed that net departmental outlays totalled £23.2bn last month, down from £24.3bn in June. For the year to date, spending is running at £95bn, up from £90.4bn in the same period a year ago.

While the Treasury is storing away a comfortable surplus, consumers appear to be tightening their belts and reining in borrowing as well. New figures from the British Bankers' Association showed that consumer borrowing rose by just £2.6bn, the lowest figure since February. Mortgage lending was also subdued, rising by an underlying £1.9bn, the smallest rise for five months, and one which chimes with other recent evidence that the housing market is slowing down.

The BBA's director-general, Tim Sweeney, said: "Mortgage lending appears to be cooling off after several months of very strong growth."

Separate figures from the Council for Mortgage Lenders, covering building societies as well as banks, showed that first-time borrowers are being priced out of the market. First-time buyers accounted for 43% of purchases in the three months to July, down from 46% in the three months to May.

fields.headline: Accounts you forgot
fields.trailText: Progress is a wonderful thing. If I wanted to change channels on my television I used to have to get up and push a button. Then I got a remote control and could change channels without moving.
fields.body:
Progress is a wonderful thing. If I wanted to change channels on my television I used to have to get up and push a button. Then I got a remote control and could change channels without moving.

Now, with a video recorder and cable television, I have three separate remote controls which sometimes all have to be used together to transmit the desired instruction, using more buttons than you'd find on the back of a Pearly King.

So now, instead of wasting my time with television, I spend it looking down the back of the sofa for the remote that has timed itself to go missing whenever I want to watch something.

All I can find are bits of Barbie outfits abandoned by my daughters, dozens of pens (has anyone ever seen a ballpoint pen actually run out of ink?), fossilised sweets and shoals of coins from foreign holidays.

But to this day I've never shoved my hand down the back of our battered old armchair and pulled out £15bn. This might not entirely surprise you - but you might be interested to know that that's how much money has fallen into the financial system's equivalent of down-the-back-of-the-sofa.

This estimate has been made by the Unclaimed Assets Register, a scheme launched last month to help people track down money to which they think they might be entitled, from pensions, insurance policies, Premium Bonds and National Savings accounts. For a charge of up to £15, you can order a search of a database of unclaimed cash - with one in eight searches reported to yield money.

But even though the register anticipates returning £1m to its rightful owners this year, the largest single amount of unclaimed money is £5bn gathering dust in bank accounts - and this great stack of lost-property cash is not included in the register's searches.

So, how did all this money get left behind? How does a bank account become identified as "dormant"? And if we think we've left a bank account behind somewhere, how would we go about reclaiming our money? Apart from that great enemy of record keeping, death, there are all kinds of disruptions that have parted people from their bank accounts - families breaking up, moving house, losing documents, long-term illness or simply forgetting. It can all mean losing track of cash.

According to the British Bankers Association, an account usually is identified as no longer active if there have been no transactions of any kind for at least a year, after which the bank will write to the customer and then, if there is no reply, wait another couple of months and then, officially, label the account "dormant".

The bank will still keep records of the account and interest will still accumulate, but once an account has been declared dormant there are no more statements or letters sent to what they assume is no longer your current address and your account will no longer be considered as "live".

Even though the account is in the financial deep freezer, the money is still the property of its original owner - or whoever inherited their money where the account holder has died. But you can't walk into the bank after a 20-year absence (if you can find a branch still open) and just expect to walk away with your lost fortune.

If you believe you have a long-lost bank account, you'll be expected to apply to the relevant bank providing proof of identity or evidence of your entitlement to funds from account holders who have died (such as a will).

You'll also be asked to provide any documentation that can link you with the account, such as old statements or proof of a former address. There's a form available from the British Bankers Association or from the bank where you think your money is languishing.

The bank should reply within three months confirming whether your claim to a dormant account is accepted and if there's a dispute, you can apply for an intervention from the Banking Ombudsman.

If you're as organisationally-challenged as I am, (which means I lose every piece of documentation I'm sent) it's reassuring that there are second chances for catching up with lost accounts and insurance policies. We are not all born with filing-cabinet minds and a few changes of address can trash any chance of keeping financial records together.

And on losing things, I'm just dreading the day when I'll have to throw away a television set because I can't remember where I've left the remote control - and if it gets stuck on Kilroy, there's no telling the emotional damage it could cause me.

Email: coughlan_sean@bbc.co.uk

webTitle: Cool operators make hay as net sun shines

fields.headline: Cool operators make hay as net sun shines
fields.standfirst:
Despite the downturn in hi-tech and internet stocks, investment trusts which picked the right targets are big winners. Robin Stoddart reports

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Despite the downturn in hi-tech and internet stocks, investment trusts which picked the right targets are big winners. Robin Stoddart reports.
fields.body:
When the regulatory body for financial services itself says that past performance provides no guide to the future of an investment fund, managers and customers alike may wonder whether they are wasting their time. Comment on the aims and make-up of any unit or investment trust might seem useless.

Yet some special trusts have clearly been winners over recent years. That cannot be said of many of the general life assurance funds that provide the pensions or endowment savings of the average UK investor, because they stuck with old UK shares.

The investment funds that doubled and redoubled in a year or two were mainly those that concentrated on the new software, internet hardware and network communications providers whose ideas promised high returns, if not just yet. Henderson Technology, Finsbury Technology and the other specialists, along with one or two venture capital or smaller investment trust companies and unit funds, made hay with purchases of a relatively small number of stakes in hi-tech companies. JSB and London Bridge Software were the gold nuggets in a handful of funds. ARM, the chip-designer offshoot of Acorn, made fortunes for a rather larger number.

All very well, you might think, but what's the message now? Profits are still there for medium-term investors in technology funds, though many software shares are around half their peak values. A glance at the more entrenched and soberly managed funds, led by 3i, the largest development capital provider in Europe and the newer technology fund offshoots in its stable, shows that finding new growth companies is no random pursuit. Other large development capital and buy-out funds have made millions for hundreds of thousands of mainly US investors. Some are run by investment banks for wealthy private clients and partners.

In the public arena Herald Investment Trust has been one of the best performers over the past five years with twice the growth of the best UK growth or income fund and close to the best of the venture and development capital funds, ahead of 3i itself. It has grown more than fourfold in three years, topping the smaller companies section led by AIM Trust. Listed as international, it is around 60% UK invested. ARM and Sherwood, the insurance software providers, have been outstanding investments. The media section has also provided winners on a global basis, including NRJ, the French radio station operator, and Switzerland's Publigroupe.

The number of holdings is surprisingly long, around 200, with a long list of smaller US companies. Alba, Amstrad and Linx Printing Technologies were among last year's larger holdings, though software is the largest single category, with about a third of the total. Manager Katie Potts pursues a cautious policy and liquidity is sometimes quite high.

Another fund whose manager expressed amazement at the heights some technology issues reached a few months ago is British Empire Securities. It differs from the technology specialists and other growth funds in seeking out value. This is seen not so much in old economy stocks but in investment trusts and holding companies. Lazard's French property interests and holding companies there and in the Fiat empire in Italy have provided lucrative revaluation gains.

So have investment trusts like Lazard Birla India and Gartmore Fledgling, which bought at large discounts and sold at big profits. The shares have made sustained progress but still stand at a large discount on underlying holdings. Manager John Walton will continue to concentrate on special areas of value, eschewing monumental price/earnings valuations. UK and European holdings comprise 60%, excluding cash.

For TR European Growth, which has grown fourfold in five years, selling stakes in small companies that have soared in value is nearly as important as selection. Walford, the Austrian underwear maker, was one such and its disposal before the market turned dull established the reputation of manager Stephen Peak. He has since made millions in Spanish pizza, French media and Swiss consumer goods suppliers. If Europe continues to accelerate its growth, with newer euro countries participating and the currency itself picking up, the fund should keep prospering, though the shares are at a premium on assets.

Outperformance for all three is no rarity; it has come to be expected.

fields.headline: Merger proving mission impossible
fields.standfirst:
Notebook UK and German exchanges dither over deal

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: I f the London and Frankfurt stock exchanges were running for public office, electors could have been forgiven for voting for "neither of the above".
fields.body:
I f the London and Frankfurt stock exchanges were running for public office, electors could have been forgiven for voting for "neither of the above".

The campaign to sell the merger of the two exchanges got off on the wrong foot and never recovered - bogged down on issues ranging from which currency shares would be traded in to whether new listing requirements would be imposed on top German companies when trading in their shares moved to London.

The very considerable efforts to sell the deal as a merger of equals by dividing up the benefits only led to critics in Britain and Germany believing that they were coming off second best.

The mission to explain is still rumbling on. Yesterday Walter Seifert, the head of the Frankfurt exchange, was explaining the workings of the Xetra trading platform to a small team from retail brokers group, Apcims. UBS Warburg, which is now the London Stock Exchange's second largest shareholder, believes more work is needed. Little wonder that London members are still pressing for the merger vote - scheduled for September 14 - to be delayed.

The difficulty facing the voters in each constituency, as it were, is that they cannot vote for "neither of the above". They can either back the deal or give it the boot. If they vote yes to the merger then they will be faced with the very considerable challenges of integration. Explaining the way that would be done has proved tricky enough. Actually doing it will be tougher still.

But rejection would bring its own problems. The vote is not taking place in a vacuum. It is not a result of the boards of the two exchanges suddenly deciding it might be fun to team up. The merger is being driven by the demand for high volume, low-cost cross-border share dealing in Europe via a secure, liquid market.

That demand will not disappear just because London and Frankfurt do not get their joint act together. Paris, Amsterdam and Brussels are pushing through their own Euronext merger. Big investment banks are backing alternative systems for trading cross-border - both at the wholesale and retail levels. If iX, as the merged London-Frankfurt exchange will be known, does not happen then they will put even more effort behind developing alternatives. Rejection would mean, too, that both centres would have to develop their own trading strategies to meet the demand for cross-border dealing.

Neither would find it easy. Euronext would no doubt hold the door open to London. Getting the British exchange on board would be a big coup. But would the London Stock Exchange fancy the idea of selling another merger, or even a more limited form of cooperation, to a membership which has just voted down iX?

Frankfurt's preferred option might be to go it alone and use its Xetra trading platform as a lure to bring in other European exchanges not yet committed to alternative alliances. Milan and Madrid spring to mind, for example.

But both sets of voters would do well to keep in mind that if they do not agree to face the future together they will have to do so as rivals and in a competition in which they are far from being the only players.

Just the spirit

In the global wines and spirits business Diageo, created in 1997 through a merger of Guinness and Grand Metropolitan, is a formidable presence. It has a market share of about 18%. Its competitors all languish below the 10% mark. Naturally enough they are anxious to close the gap.

The reasons are simple - spirits brands require huge marketing budgets. Diageo can afford the sort of blanket advertising needed to make its Johnnie Walker, Baileys and Smirnoff brands household names throughout the world. fields.headline: Mutual scramble hots up
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The scramble to take control of mutual insurance groups Scottish Provident and Equitable Life seems likely to escalate.
fields.body:
The scramble to take control of mutual insurance groups Scottish Provident and Equitable Life seems likely to escalate.

A short list of bidders for Provident is rumoured to have been drawn up, and is thought to include Abbey National and Old Mutual, the South African insurer.

As the candidates for Provident are whittled down advisers to Equitable Life are ready to release the official documentation to those suitors who have expressed an interest.

Abbey National is again expected to be among the interested parties, as is Barclays - 20p stronger at £17.50 - fresh from its takeover of Woolwich.

Equitable's advisers are expected to make it clear to potential suitors that even if they lose the bid, their names will be published in the documentation sent to the insurers' policyholders next year in their vote to end mutuality and sell the business, crippled by a court ruling over guaranteed annuities.

webTitle: Post Office plan to rescue universal bank

fields.headline: Post Office plan to rescue universal bank
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The Post Office is planning to rescue the government's plans for a universal bank with fresh proposals for a new name and logo for the operation.
fields.body:
The Post Office is planning to rescue the government's plans for a universal bank with fresh proposals for a new name and logo for the operation.

The new proposals, due for publication early next month, will also attempt to quell high street banks' fears about the potential cost of setting up the bank.

The Post Office has been working on the crucial business plan, codenamed "project monocracy", since the high street banks claimed that a bank based in local post offices would carry the stigma of a "poor people's bank".

The major banks appear reluctant to participate in the creation of the bank, which they believe could cost them as much as £30m each. The Post Office says the actual figure would be much less than those estimates and points out that under its proposal the government would share the bill.

The bank is the main thrust of the government's aim to protect the 18,500-strong post office network. It is also a key part of the government's strategy to help the "financially excluded" who do not have bank accounts, as well as crucial to achieve its goal of paying social security benefits direct into bank accounts by 2003.

The Post Office has until the start of next month to present its business plan for the new bank.

Basil Larkins, managing director of network banking at the Post Office, described his proposal as "a new thing, a new vehicle, where the costs are shared between government and banks and where we are the distributors and we are remunerated for the work we do. The operation is outsourced to a bank or some other information technology business."

The plan will be based on working with the banks rather than in competition. In addition to being asked to back a universal bank, the banks are also under instruction from the Treasury to have their own no-frills accounts, without credit facilities, for the financially excluded available by the end of October.

Alan Johnson, the Post Office minister, said last night: "The universal bank is the preferred way forward." If the banks agreed to participate in its creation they would be allowed leeway on the October deadline, he said.

While the banks have pledged to reach this target, and some of them have made such accounts available for some time, Mr Larkins expressed concerns that some of the accounts being made available were not "overdraft proof". This might make it difficult for the Post Office to handle any payments out of the accounts.

Even the prospect of money from the goverment for the universal bank appeared to do little last night to appease the major banks. Tim Sweeney, director general of the British Bankers' Association, said: "An unattractive proposal is still an unattractive proposal no matter who's footing the bill, but banks are willing to talk."

The new proposals being put together for the "universal bank" indicate that it may not be a bank in the traditional sense, as it will not make loans because the accounts for the financially excluded are not intended to allow them to fall into debt.

In addition to the universal bank, the Post Office has ambitions for the banks to use its outlets for basic facilities currently conducted in their branches, such as paying in and taking out cash. The Post Office is about to name the company that will provide it with a new computer system, enabling it to connect all post offices with all bank branches, a move that will also allow it to provide up-to-date information on balances.

At the moment, the Post Office provides basic banking facilities for Alliance & Leicester - which owns the formerly Post Office-owned Girobank - Barclays, Lloyds TSB and the Co-operative bank.

fields.headline: Get under the covers
fields.standfirst:
Fewer than one in 10 students have insurance but it can prove a wise and cost-effective move. Liz Stuart reports

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Fewer than one in 10 students have insurance but it can prove a wise and cost-effective move. Liz Stuart reports.
fields.body:
When budgets are tight, spending money on possibilities rather than certainties is a difficult choice. This could be why fewer than 10% of students take out insurance against theft, fire or accidental damage to belongings.

Insurance is hardly a sexy subject, but, according to insurers who specialise in the student market, a claim is made on around one student policy in 10, showing there is need for this kind of cover.

Brian Wright of Saxon Insurance points out that in big cities - which tend to have the highest crime rates - students live in a few areas, making them easy targets for burglars. "Students also have the type of equipment, such as computers and stereos, which can easily be sold on. And it is not unusual to find six students living together, so the burglar has access to all that times six."

One student is burgled every four minutes, and even this, according to insurer Endsleigh, is a conservative figure. Endsleigh, set up in the early 60s in conjunction with the National Union of Students, was the first player in the student market when, according to a spokesman: "The drugs, peace and free-love reputation of students meant they were seen as a risk by traditional insurers." Campus and Saxon are its only student-specialist competitors. All provide basic cover and, for higher premiums, cover for bikes and musical instruments.

Saxon offers the only policy specifically for halls of residence. It also offers a general plan for people living out of halls. The cover is the same: £2,500 worth of goods including computer insurance up to £500, but, because of the lower risk, the halls policy is cheaper at £24 a year against £32.

There is also an online budget version at £15, but the maximum cover is only £1,500. But these are the lowest rates, offered only in low-crime towns. Study in the most expensive cities, such as Manchester, Liverpool or Leeds, and you will pay £76 for the same cover.

Saxon has just three bandwidths, so it may be cheaper for students living in London, as it puts the capital in the cheapest category, with cover starting from £28 a year. For this, personal possessions are covered with no maximum, although there is a limit to £250 for any single item. Computers are covered up to the value of £500.

The Campus policies offered by insurer Student-World, can be bought for the entire three-year period. Students in the most expensive areas will pay £158 for the three years and London dwellers between £117-£122.

Endsleigh splits the country into 10 areas for rating purposes. Most pricey areas include parts of Coventry, Birmingham, Newcastle, Sunderland, Teesside and Wolverhampton, where even the shallowest cover level of £2,000 will cost £96 a year. Students at Brighton, Loughborough and Cambridge will pay the lowest price of £32.50 for £2,500 of cover with Endsleigh.

Before buying a policy it makes sense to check whether your university has a block policy which covers students in its halls and other forms of accommodation. Many do, but where there is no block cover it could make sense to insure your possessions even in this protected environment - two years ago the halls of residence of a major university were razed in a fire.

You may find your parents' home and contents insurance will cover you at your term-time residence. Many policies don't - they are frequently post code specific - and even if they do, it may not be worth breaking a no-claims record. You would have to prove violent entry in the case of theft, whereas the Saxon policy pays out even in "walk-in" cases.

Even parents can take out insurance. Saxon's Unishield policy covers against loss of fees paid if a student should drop out of their course, as well as accident, sickness and unemployment cover. On average, 17% of students fail to complete their studies, rising to 35% on some courses, and parents as well as students can be left with expensive liabilities to the university, banks and Student Loans Company. According to Saxon, the most common reason for early bailing out are sickness, change of mind, sports and motor accidents and pregnancy.

The cautious parent who opts to take out fee, loan and "parent" (that is, accident and sickness) shields would pay from £27.91 a month.

Saxon Insurance Services 01159-676-600; Endsleigh www.endsleigh.co.uk; Campus Insurance or call 0845-330-1408.

webTitle: Sarwan takes the horror out of Headingley

fields.headline: Sarwan takes the horror out of Headingley
fields.trailText: Donna Symmonds Yesterday marked a significant step in the Ramnaresh Sarwan's progress. Not only did he share a crucial 68-run sixth-wicket partnership with Ridley Jacobs but he also displayed his class.
fields.body:
Some say you need a bit of luck. Others claim that, in sport, you make your own good fortune. Either way the 20-year-old West Indian prodigy Ramnaresh Sarwan made the most of what came his way on yesterday's opening day of the fourth Test at Headingley.

With the tourists tottering at 70 for five, and Sarwan on eight, he appeared to enjoy a let-off when an appeal for caught-behind from the glove off Darren Gough's bowling was turned down. By the end of his innings West Indies had reached a competitive 172, with Sarwan stranded on 59, his second half-century in four Tests occupying 82 balls and including nine boundaries.

Sarwan's promise has been evident for some time. Twice he was named the most valuable young player in the Caribbean. At the age of 15 years and 226 days he appeared for Guyana against Barbados, making him the youngest first-class cricketer in West Indian history. And in May this year he became the 10th teenager to play Test cricket for West Indies.

But yesterday marked a significant step in the Guyanese right-hander's progress. Not only did he share a crucial 68-run sixth-wicket partnership with Ridley Jacobs - a West Indian record on this ground - but he also displayed his class. The time he has to play his shots, his range of strokes and his ability to find the gap were all evident.

He caressed several spectacular off-drives and executed, with great precision, the pull. He was a delight throughout and, while he was at the crease, the pitch seemed less treacherous than the efforts of other batsmen had suggested.

He has already won high praise from Sir Garfield Sobers, who said Sarwan reminded him of Sir Vivian Richards and that other superb Guyanese batsman Rohan Kanhai. One can see why. Yesterday he looked certain to be one of the stars of any future West Indian batting line-up. It could be the start of a new era.

If only Courtney Walsh and Curtly Ambrose were able to pass the ball on to performers of such quality. These two magnificent fast bowlers are nearing the end. Walsh was joined by Ambrose yesterday in the rarefied 400 Club, and both were again fabulous, beating the bat repeatedly and giving little away. As usual, however, the change bowlers failed to maintain the standard.

Walsh has witnessed most of the great performances that made Ambrose one of the most feared bowlers of the late 80s and throughout all of the 90s. Upon claiming his 400th victim, the celebrations on the field were both poignant and spontaneous: a huge hug from Walsh and a raised fist by the beanpole Antiguan to the section of the crowd where his family were sitting.

The scenes back in the Caribbean can only be imagined. But the appreciation for his contribution will be as enormous as his input into so many West Indian victories.
