fields.headline: Ambrose pegs England back
fields.standfirst:
David Hopps sees an old foe steal White's thunder with his 400th Test wicket
West Indies 172
England 105 for 5
fields.trailText: David Hopps sees an old foe steal White's thunder with his 400th Test wicket.
fields.body:
Craig White must be wondering whether he actually died and went to heaven on the day he blacked out in that Scarborough sidestreet. How else could he explain five West Indian wickets to his name, the applause ringing around his home ground and the certainty that his England career is finally established? Life was never half as good as this.

Until yesterday, all life had allowed White had been six years in and out of the England side, late call-ups to disconsolate touring parties, and endless carping that he would never make the grade. This was so superior: his best Test figures of five for 57, and West Indies bundled out for 172 in 48.4 overs.

Nasser Hussain can put him right. England's captain knows this is real life: unsympathetically, painfully so. By the close of the first day of the fourth Test at Headingley, England had slumped to 105 for five as their old tormentors, Courtney Walsh and Curtly Ambrose, retaliated on a responsive surface that, if forever repeated, would cause them to abandon retirement plans.

When Ambrose, approaching his most sinister, joined Walsh on 400 Test wickets by having Marcus Trescothick and Michael Atherton caught at slip in his first three overs, he was immediately offered a week's beach holiday by the West Indian team sponsor, Sandals Resorts. For England's sake, he should leave today - and take Courtney with him.

Hussain had been urged by Graham Gooch to play positively, but this was neither the time nor the place. He resisted stubbornly and erratically for almost two hours, needing painkilling tablets and sprays after a blow on the hand by Walsh. His 22 represented his highest Test score of the summer, but there was no sense of release.

At 80 for two, Hussain and Graham Thorpe had designs on batting England to a position of authority. It was not to be. Walsh lolloped in to take three for eight from 28 balls, defeating Hussain and Thorpe with nip-backers, and ending Alec Stewart's bounteous run by having him caught at second slip as he aimed through mid-on. Michael Vaughan, who knows Headingley's devils intimately, remains.

White's arrival as a player of Test standing has been a long time coming. His hair, at 30, is beginning to thin and the collar, as always turned stiffly upwards, now has a mark of resolve where in the past it seemed to act as an extra backbone.

His debut summer against New Zealand was one in which Raymond Illingworth, a grudging chairman of selectors, lauded him as convincingly as Arthur Daley selling a second-hand motor. The Whitemobile, sensing itself oversold, proved an unreliable starter.

Illingworth's mistake was to insist that White should bat at No6, where his technique appeared flimsy. He has now found his niche batting as low as No8, bowling at up to 90mph and showing a growing mastery of reverse swing.

No one relished White's big day more than Darren Gough. The Yorkshire pair took all five morning wickets, and when White led England off, Gough beamed all around him, as if there could be no greater lark than seeing his old mate Chalkie looking embarrassed at all the adulation. "A few years ago, I didn't think people had faith in me," said White. "A central contract meant that people rate me as a cricketer."

West Indies chose to bat first - on the ground where three weeks ago they rolled a second-string Yorkshire side for 126 and 94 - in the belief that the bounce would become more uneven as the match progresses. By Headingley's standards this pitch will not achieve notoriety, but bowlers can expect to have the upper hand throughout.

The first fifty was raised comfortably enough for the loss of only Sherwin Campbell, snared by Gough at the squarer of two gullies. But White then broke the back of the innings with three for six in 17 balls.

There has been no finer sight all summer than Wavell Hinds' extra-cover driving, but he has been bedevilled by ill luck and slack technique, the latter allowing White to nick the inside edge yesterday of an expansive drive.

Brian Lara, offering no shot, was then leg-before as White swung one back from round the wicket, and Jimmy Adams dragged on. Adrian Griffith's horrible cut at Gough was an aberration, and Nixon McLean and Walsh were late gimmes.

Ramnaresh Sarwan, a burgeoning talent, has been accused of mental weakness, but the 20-year-old now averages more than 50 in Tests. His unbeaten 59, the only innings of certainty on this capricious pitch, proved his mettle and the freewheeling post-lunch stand of 68 with Ridley Jacobs plotted the West Indies' escape route.

The 400 club

fields.bodyText: Craig White must be wondering whether he actually died and went to heaven on the day he blacked out in that Scarborough sidestreet. How else could he explain five West Indian wickets to his name, the applause ringing around his home ground and the certainty that his England career is finally established? Life was never half as good as this. Until yesterday, all life had allowed White had been six years in and out of the England side, late call-ups to disconsolate touring parties, and endless carping that he would never make the grade. This was so superior: his best Test figures of five for 57, and West Indies bundled out for 172 in 48.4 overs. Nasser Hussain can put him right. England's captain knows this is real life: unsympathetically, painfully so. By the close of the first day of the fourth Test at Headingley, England had slumped to 105 for five as their old tormentors, Courtney Walsh and Curtly Ambrose, retaliated on a responsive surface that, if forever repeated, would cause them to abandon retirement plans. When Ambrose, approaching his most sinister, joined Walsh on 400 Test wickets by having Marcus Trescothick and Michael Atherton caught at slip in his first three overs, he was immediately offered a week's beach holiday by the West Indian team sponsor, Sandals Resorts. For England's sake, he should leave today - and take Courtney with him. Hussain had been urged by Graham Gooch to play positively, but this was neither the time nor the place. He resisted stubbornly and erratically for almost two hours, needing painkilling tablets and sprays after a blow on the hand by Walsh. His 22 represented his highest Test score of the summer, but there was no sense of release. At 80 for two, Hussain and Graham Thorpe had designs on batting England to a position of authority. It was not to be. Walsh lolloped in to take three for eight from 28 balls, defeating Hussain and Thorpe with nip-backers, and ending Alec Stewart's bounteous run by having him caught at second slip as he aimed through mid-on. Michael Vaughan, who knows Headingley's devils intimately, remains. White's arrival as a player of Test standing has been a long time coming. His hair, at 30, is beginning to thin and the collar, as always turned stiffly upwards, now has a mark of resolve where in the past it seemed to act as an extra backbone. His debut summer against New Zealand was one in which Raymond Illingworth, a grudging chairman of selectors, lauded him as convincingly as Arthur Daley selling a second-hand motor. The Whitemobile, sensing itself oversold, proved an unreliable starter. Illingworth's mistake was to insist that White should bat at No6, where his technique appeared flimsy. He has now found his niche batting as low as No8, bowling at up to 90mph and showing a growing mastery of reverse swing. No one relished White's big day more than Darren Gough. The Yorkshire pair took all five morning wickets, and when White led England off, Gough beamed all around him, as if there could be no greater lark than seeing his old mate Chalkie looking embarrassed at all the adulation. "A few years ago, I didn't think people had faith in me," said White. "A central contract meant that people rate me as a cricketer." West Indies chose to bat first - on the ground where three weeks ago they rolled a second-string Yorkshire side for 126 and 94 - in the belief that the bounce would become more uneven as the match progresses. By Headingley's standards this pitch will not achieve notoriety, but bowlers can expect to have the upper hand throughout. The first fifty was raised comfortably enough for the loss of only Sherwin Campbell, snared by Gough at the squarer of two gullies. But White then broke the back of the innings with three for six in 17 balls. There has been no finer sight all summer than Wavell Hinds' extra-cover driving, but he has been bedevilled by ill luck and slack technique, the latter allowing White to nick the inside edge yesterday of an expansive drive. Brian Lara, offering no shot, was then leg-before as White swung one back from round the wicket, and Jimmy Adams dragged on. Adrian Griffith's horrible cut at Gough was an aberration, and Nixon McLean and Walsh were late gimmes. Ramnaresh Sarwan, a burgeoning talent, has been accused of mental weakness, but the 20-year-old now averages more than 50 in Tests. His unbeaten 59, the only innings of certainty on this capricious pitch, proved his mettle and the freewheeling post-lunch stand of 68 with Ridley Jacobs plotted the West Indies' escape route. fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: Darren Cousins and Paul Taylor, two fellows who could teach Pete Townshend and Roger Daltrey a thing or two about comebacks, sent Sussex stuttering towards defeat at Eastbourne yesterday, allowing Northamptonshire to scent some daylight between themselves and the rest in a Second Division promotion race fast developing into precisely the sort of eye-scratching scrap intended.
fields.body:
Darren Cousins and Paul Taylor, two fellows who could teach Pete Townshend and Roger Daltrey a thing or two about comebacks, sent Sussex stuttering towards defeat at Eastbourne yesterday, allowing Northamptonshire to scent some daylight between themselves and the rest in a Second Division promotion race fast developing into precisely the sort of eye-scratching scrap intended.

Trailing by 43, the leaders were 65 for four before Jeff Cook's second championship century - overshadowing the day's other hundreds by Nottinghamshire's Usman Afzaal and Middlesex's Justin Langer - turned the tide once more: 80 of his 116 came in fours. Set 228, the hosts withered to 13 for six and 25 for seven before Chris Adams finally found an adhesive partner in Nick Wilton.

Amid it all was a slice of history. Among an Englishman's checklist of Herculean tasks, escaping a pigeonhole is up there with breaking out of Colditz, eluding clouds and avoiding Dale Winton. All the more reason, then, to toast the gall of Mark Robinson.

So long the duffer's duffer - he owns the sward's least enviable world record with a dozen successive scoreless innings - the Sussex No11 survived the only ball he received against his old county to take his summer's first-class return to eight innings, eight not outs. Last night Robert Brooke, the eminent statistician, could not find anything to match it. This leopard has patently earned his stripes. Winning this game may be a bit of an ask but still: here's to you, Mr Robinson.

Essex, Northants' closest pursuers, were surprised, after trailing by precisely 150 at Colchester, that Gloucestershire did not enforce the follow-on. "We were conscious of the deteriorating wicket," said the visitors' coach John Bracewell but the match is still open, with the visitors closing on 11 for two and spin holding the key.

Peter Such, who has turned many such locks for Essex and England, rates John Crawley among the best five players of spin in the land, a point the England selectors will be ill-advised to disregard while mulling over the candidates for the impending subcontinental trek.

The Lancashire captain's duel with Kent's Min Patel thus assumed a broader context. Honours went to the left-armer, who dispatched Crawley after the latter had hit 36 out of 42 in boundaries and also sentenced Sourav Ganguly to a duck as the hosts made 236. Hopes of putting Surrey under a semblance of pressure rose anew, however, as Peter Martin and Mike Smethurst replied with four strikes.

Peter Trego plays for Somerset, bats and bowls for the grin of it, is apt to follow a bouncer with a googly, thinks he is pretty much the bee's knees and sends colleagues scurrying for cover when something displeases. Is that reminiscent of anyone? Trego is rousing all sorts of obvious comparisons and his latest effort, 90 off 112 balls for England Under-19s against Sri Lanka, has done nothing to alleviate a burden he appears, fortunately, to relish.

Having secured his team a lead of 206, Trego was sidelined by a side strain but Kabir Ali and Mudhsuden "Monty" Singh Panesar picked up the slack to secure victory. Here's to you, Mr Multi-Ethnicity.

fields.headline: Loyal Ferguson rejoins Everton
fields.trailText: Duncan Ferguson pledged his loyalty once more to Everton yesterday after failing to convince his previous employers Newcastle that his loyalty to them merited a £1m pay-off.
fields.body:
Duncan Ferguson pledged his loyalty once more to Everton yesterday after failing to convince his previous employers Newcastle that his loyalty to them merited a £1m pay-off.

"Everton is in my blood, it always will be," Ferguson proclaimed as he was paraded in the blue shirt he last wore between 1994 and 1998. "I still have my No9 Everton tattoo on my arm, and the fans at Everton are the best in the world."

Unfortunately for Ferguson Everton's No9 shirt is currently in the possession of Kevin Campbell, so the price of loyalty could turn out to be a trip to the tattoo parlour for a retouch, unless the big Scot is about to install himself as Campbell's No1 fan.

The transfer had appeared dead in the water after the former Scotland striker insisted on a loyalty bonus for not having formally requested a move. Newcastle, however, gave the demand short shrift, feeling that 24 Premiership starts in 22 months did not constitute value for money from a man earning £38,000 a week.

Everton have agreed to pay an initial £3.75m with the promise of an additional £1.25m after Ferguson has made around 60 first-team appearances. Already a very wealthy man, Ferguson has secured a five-year contract worth at least £25,000 a week.

"Once it became clear that Newcastle no longer wanted me, there was never any doubt in my mind: I wanted to come back here," Ferguson explained. "Everyone knows how I feel about this club."

Ferguson, 28, dropped his claim for a loyalty bonus from Newcastle only after 11th-hour talks with Everton's deputy chairman Bill Kenwright.

Despite playing little part in Newcastle's pre-season preparations because of an achilles injury, Ferguson has been pencilled in to start against Leeds at Elland Road tomorrow.

Uncertainty over Frank Leboeuf's future heightened yesterday when Chelsea's manager Gianluca Vialli declined publicly to support the Frenchman after meeting the defender for the first time since being strongly criticised by him. Vialli did nothing to dispel speculation that Leboeuf would be sold as he emphasised he will come down hard on anyone who steps out of line.

"I think I get on very well with the players. I have told them that my job is not only to train them but to make sure everybody behaves within the rules and pulls in the same direction. I am trying to implement this and act accordingly."

Only 2,000 seats will be available in Aston Villa's new 13,000-seat stand when John Gregory's side take on Chelsea a week on Sunday after building work fell behind schedule.

Sheffield Wednesday became the first club to be punished under a new ruling yesterday, receiving a £5,000 fine after six of their players were disciplined against Wolves last Saturday.

fields.headline: Tottenham Hotspur
fields.trailText: This summer Spurs have splashed out £11m on Sergei Rebrov, spent another £4m on Ben Thatcher and also snapped up Neil Sullivan. Furthermore, they've had an impeccable pre-season during which they haven't lost a game, and only conceded a solitary goal. So what's the mood like among the Tottenham faithful? Optimistic? Slighty giddy perhaps? Come on man, where have you been?! We're talking about Spurs fans here, the sort of people who could teach a Trotskyist cell a thing or two about permanent revolution.
fields.body:
This summer Spurs have splashed out £11m on Sergei Rebrov, spent another £4m on Ben Thatcher and also snapped up Neil Sullivan. Furthermore, they've had an impeccable pre-season during which they haven't lost a game, and only conceded a solitary goal. So what's the mood like among the Tottenham faithful? Optimistic? Slighty giddy perhaps? Come on man, where have you been?! We're talking about Spurs fans here, the sort of people who could teach a Trotskyist cell a thing or two about permanent revolution.

And revolutionary talk is once again in the air at White Hart Lane, especially after the dumping of David Ginola. Worse still, Spurs fans know deep down that this season won't be all bad. In fact George Graham's side will probably do quite well. It's just that their top seven finish and cup success won't be achieved in the traditional Spurs' sense (i.e. flair, goals and glory) but in the traditional Arsenal sense (i.e. solid defence, workmanlike midfield and lots of lucky 1-0 wins). And that hurts their fans even more.

It's no surprise that Spurs' strength will be their defence. Sullivan is much more solid than Walker, and less prone to severe bouts of flapping (or staying rooted to his line). In addition, after a year together Campbell and Perry should start playing like a partnership and not like they're in some sort of arranged marriage. And they should be well complemented by the excellent Stephen Carr (who developed into one of the best right-backs in the country last year) and the forceful Ben Thatcher.

Up front certainly Spurs certainly have the players to score goals. Rebrov is brilliant, inventive - and, as we'll no doubt get sick of hearing - rated by many in Ukraine as a better player than Andrei Shevchenko. And he will be amply supported by Steffen Iversen.

The only trouble is the support, or rather the lack of it. Because Spurs' midfield is as barren as the Sahara in the summer. Freund holds, Sherwood harrys and - on the flanks Leonardssen and Anderton (when he's not injured) work rather than waltz through defences like the mecurial Ginola once did.

So expect Spurs to be this season's Aston Villa: tough to beat, defensive-minded and - save the odd moment of genius from Rebrov - utterly, utterly boring. But don't be surprised if they challenge for a European place and - with the year ending in one - challenge for a cup or two on the way as well.

webTitle: Comment, Bonnie Smith: the gendered political imagination of the US

fields.headline: Heroines for our times
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: A scholar from India recently mentioned her surprise on arriving in the United States that few people there could imagine a woman president. Her own experience of Britain and India had hardly prepared her for the highly gendered political imagination of the land of opportunity.
fields.body:
A scholar from India recently mentioned her surprise on arriving in the United States that few people there could imagine a woman president. Her own experience of Britain and India had hardly prepared her for the highly gendered political imagination of the land of opportunity. Why weren't those reportedly liberated men and women electing women to high office?

As the current presidential race confirms, in the US, the white male, who is in a minority, alone seems to symbolise what it takes to be a ruler. The case also holds in the large American states. In Texas in 1994, an utterly inexperienced George W Bush easily defeated Ann Richards for the governorship, despite her long record of service and political savvy.

Some might attribute this situation - the closing of ranks around white male leaders whatever their credentials - to misogyny or some other deliberate record of exclusion. And the evidence might even be there for such an inference, but I don't know it. Nor can the obvious satisfaction of US citizens, evident in their endorsement in party caucuses and the voting booth, be so easily explained away.

I look instead to the way political imagination has been built over the past century and more. When asked for models of leadership, students point to Napoleon Bonaparte, George Washington, Winston Churchill and Adolf Hitler. They can discuss the policies of those who loom large in our history texts with real enthusiasm. An occasional woman student will single out Queen Victoria or Margaret Thatcher or Golda Meir.

Such "contributory history" of women is, however, quite out of fashion in all of our curricular debates. For teachers on the political left, studying poor and working women is preferable because they constitute the vast majority and are most representative of women's conditions, whatever the country. Understanding their situation should be the goal of history, not focusing on elite women rulers with whom the poor have nothing in common - and who were in all likelihood profiting in some way from other women's poverty.

The political right has its own reason for omitting great women from the history curriculum: there simply weren't any. According to Christina Hoff Sommers of the American Enterprise Institute, all accounts of so-called "great women" in history are merely "feminist filler". There is simply no reason for women to appear in history books or history teaching. On the small place merited by great or "worthy" women in historical narrative both right and left agree.

Yet history is a place where the political imagination has been nourished. Presidents have been avid readers of history - and some have even written history. Historians, from Lord Macaulay to François Furet and Arthur Schlesinger Jr, have homed in on politicians, both living and dead, as the objects not just of their trade but of their intellectual passion and personal ambition. History, politics and the play of motivating emotions, such as ambition and the craving for place and power, have long worked in unison.

First-wave feminists and activists cultivated their passion for politics by studying the history of great women, whether Joan of Arc, Catherine the Great, or Elizabeth I. As in the case of powerful men, their historical imaginations flourished. That real live woman ruler, Queen Victoria, inspired British activists in ways that are just now being uncovered.

Power, it has been said, is the greatest aphrodisiac, and so it has been for those historians and readers of history who have taken the world's greatest leaders as their love objects as well as their objects of study. Such historical study has been the fundament of both modern leadership and modern citizenship. In fact, the curricula of most schools did not offer history until the advent of representative government in the 19th century. The study of leaders, including dictators and tyrants, has fed the passion for politics.

What will inspire a less highly gendered political imagination in the US? We have worked on the job front, the home front, the health front with some success. But success on the political front has been more elusive. Given the comparatively alienated role of women as political leaders in the US, it may ironically be the force of globalisation and the new conditions of learning that will develop our children's political imaginations. For in much of the rest of the world, models of women's leadership exist, and studying them may stimulate all of us to imagine politics in new ways. In 2084, Big Brother may be sharing the television screen and the history texts.

 Bonnie Smith's The Gender of History is published by Harvard University Press

The political right has its own reason for omitting great women from the history curriculum: there simply weren't any. According to Christina Hoff Sommers of the American Enterprise Institute, all accounts of so-called "great women" in history are merely "feminist filler". There is simply no reason for women to appear in history books or history teaching. On the small place merited by great or "worthy" women in historical narrative both right and left agree. Yet history is a place where the political imagination has been nourished. Presidents have been avid readers of history - and some have even written history. Historians, from Lord Macaulay to François Furet and Arthur Schlesinger Jr, have homed in on politicians, both living and dead, as the objects not just of their trade but of their intellectual passion and personal ambition. History, politics and the play of motivating emotions, such as ambition and the craving for place and power, have long worked in unison. First-wave feminists and activists cultivated their passion for politics by studying the history of great women, whether Joan of Arc, Catherine the Great, or Elizabeth I. As in the case of powerful men, their historical imaginations flourished. That real live woman ruler, Queen Victoria, inspired British activists in ways that are just now being uncovered. Power, it has been said, is the greatest aphrodisiac, and so it has been for those historians and readers of history who have taken the world's greatest leaders as their love objects as well as their objects of study. Such historical study has been the fundament of both modern leadership and modern citizenship. In fact, the curricula of most schools did not offer history until the advent of representative government in the 19th century. The study of leaders, including dictators and tyrants, has fed the passion for politics. What will inspire a less highly gendered political imagination in the US? We have worked on the job front, the home front, the health front with some success. But success on the political front has been more elusive. Given the comparatively alienated role of women as political leaders in the US, it may ironically be the force of globalisation and the new conditions of learning that will develop our children's political imaginations. For in much of the rest of the world, models of women's leadership exist, and studying them may stimulate all of us to imagine politics in new ways. In 2084, Big Brother may be sharing the television screen and the history texts.  Bonnie Smith's The Gender of History is published by Harvard University Press

webTitle: So, where were you when Nasty Nick was kicked out of Big Brother?

fields.headline: So, where were you when Nasty Nick was kicked out of Big Brother?
fields.standfirst:
Yesterday, offices and phones across Britain were buzzing with news: one of the contestants on a Channel 4 game show had been disqualified for cheating. But what made this more remarkable was that the story unfolded on the internet. Mark Lawson on a new kind of 'TV moment'

Special report: Big Brother
Net news
fields.trailText: Yesterday, offices and phones across Britain were buzzing with news: one of the contestants on a Channel 4 game show had been disqualified for cheating. But what made this more remarkable was that the story unfolded on the internet. Mark Lawson on a new kind of 'TV moment'
fields.body:
The playwright Dennis Potter once explained that he had decided to write for TV rather than the theatre because only television offered the possibility of a "common culture": one in which people of all classes and generations experienced the same event simultaneously and talked about it the next morning.

No Potter of today would go into television for that reason. Technological developments in transmission - with programmes in the future to be delivered through computers and telephones - are generally expected to make viewing a fragmented and isolated experience. In this envisaged world in which viewers become their own schedulers, you will watch Friends at 3.30am on a Tuesday if you decide to. Only a dramatic news event - the sudden death of a princess, for example - will unite the audience.

Yesterday, though, the internet - frequently predicted killer of the common culture - offered a shared viewing experience of an unusually powerful kind. In offices - or at least hi-tech, media-friendly offices - employees crouched round computer screens to watch the live web transmission from the house in East London where the surviving seven contestants in Channel 4's house-share elimination game-show Big Brother had rounded on stockbroker Nick Bateman, the series' villain, after discovering evidence of what viewers already knew: that he was breaking the game's rules by playing the contestants off against each other.

Bateman was already established as the stand-out character of Big Brother, a series which has managed to combine compelling voyeurism with genuine psychological revelation. While the rest of the 10 seemed to have calculated that the best way to avoid being voted out of the house was to be pleasant or inoffensive on screen, Nick was duplicitous and scheming. The Sun newspaper - which, like most of the British press, runs at least one story about the programme every day - intensified anti-Nick sentiment among viewers by alleging that he had broken the game rules of total seclusion by hiding a tiny mobile phone in his sponge bag. The claim later became more lurid: the tiny receiver was strapped behind his testicles.

During the early hours of Thursday morning, evidence of Nick's scheming - a pen and paper, which he used to pass illicit notes to housemates - was discovered by the contestants. The suspension of the supposedly 24-hour internet transmission for two hours led to rumours (denied by Channel 4) of a punch-up. But - yesterday lunchtime - Nick faced his fellow residents with a Clintonian explanation for his actions, blaming a large family and employment in the City for his competitive tendencies. Showing once again the sophisticated understanding of the modern media that has marked him out from the others, Bateman is then reported to have negotiated safe passage to a London hotel and asked for sessions with a psychiatrist. He left the house late yesterday afternoon. A show that has become a live factual version of Lord of the Flies had lost its Lord of the Lies.

People in homes and offices unable to receive broadcasts on the internet kept up with developments in the house through email and mobile phones. Technology expected to divide and isolate was unifying people around this media phenomenon of the summer of 2000.

As a significant moment of television, the rumbling of Nick Bateman is most remarkable for being the first of the medium's high spots not actually to have occurred on TV. It is the first television hit in which the scheduled transmission is almost incidental to the effect. Whereas other celebrated moments of shared viewing - the revelation of JR Ewing's assassin in Dallas, the major weddings and deaths in EastEnders and Coronation Street, the big-money moments on Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? - commanded audiences of around 20m, Big Brother has achieved television ratings of only 4m.

But this small impact has thrown up a disproportionate cultural mushroom-cloud of Sun front pages, broadsheet editorial columns, websites and workplace conversations. This is partly because the series has a compelling concept, but mainly because - through the use of the live web transmission - Big Brother is the first TV show to make serious use of the new viewing possibilities. Another significance of yesterday's scenes was that viewers were for almost the first time watching genuinely unedited events: no presenter or director was mediating the coverage. By the time Nick's departure is seen in conventional form - on Friday's edition of Big Brother - it will seem second-hand to many viewers. This is a remarkable change in the nature of what it means to watch TV.

The only drawback to this up-rooting of the couch potato is the one which has always afflicted the internet. Nick's ostracisation could have marked the coming of age of internet broadcasting, but in the event, this was not the case. Like an impotent bridegroom, the worldwide web is always let down at the potentially sweetest moments by the equipment. The infuriating message "web congestion" - which will be familiar to those who tried to download either the Starr report or the Louise Woodward judgment - frequently interrupted coverage as the internet again failed to meet demand.

This provided a second irony for historians of television in yesterday's office huddles. The second most common prediction about the future of television - apart from the one that shared viewing would no longer occur - was perfection of the image. Widescreen and digital TV were expected to allow programming of absolute clarity. Indeed, I remember writing a few years ago in a television column that the future of the medium was immaculate images watched by smaller and smaller individual audiences.

Disproving one half of this bet by becoming talking-point TV, Big Brother - in its web-cam manifestation at least - also knocks down the other half, because the pictures offered are equivalent in quality to the first ever experimental television sets. People huddled excitedly together around a tiny, unreliable image: in a quite unexpected way, the future of television has turned out to mirror its distant past.

As for Big Brother's hold on its audience, the Nick transmissions may represent the peak. Channel 4 has consistently denied that the game is manipulated by the programme-makers in any way. But, if so, their scrupulous honesty has been rewarded by remarkable good luck. What was called for dramatically at this halfway mark of the series is something very like what happened yesterday. It is the point at which a dramatist or screenwriter would have had the group turning against one of their number.

But anyone writing or directing the events would also understand that Nick - as the dramatic engine of the piece - needed to be around for the dénouement. It is traditional to lament the prospect of Hamlet without the prince, but Hamlet without Claudius would be equally problematic as a piece of drama. Melodrama - and Big Brother is melodramatic documentary - needs a villain.

The shaming of Bateman wasn't remotely equivalent in cultural significance to the shooting of Kennedy or the death of Diana, but it marks a stage in the technology of television revelation. JFK died on amateur celluloid. Diana died on live 24-hour television. Nasty Nick was nixed on the net, a day before you'll see it on a set.

Must-see TV: shows that captivated the nation
by Jemima Sissons

Fawlty Towers: The Germans

First broadcast: October 24 1975.

A concussed Basil Fawlty had some difficulty with his German guests.
Fawlty: "Is there something wrong?"
Guest: "Will you stop talking about the war."
"Me? You started it."
"We did not start it."
"Yes you did - you invaded Poland."

Morecambe and Wise Christmas show

First broadcast: December 25 1977.
Viewers: More than 20m.

The yuletide audience gasped as Angela Rippon stepped out from behind her newsdesk and engaged in spectacular high-kicks with Eric and Ernie.

Dallas: Who shot JR?

First broadcast: May 26 1980.
Viewers: 21.6m.

After a summer of bumper stickers, T-shirts and news items, the nation tuned in to find that ex-lover Kristin had pulled the trigger.

Live Aid

First broadcast: July 3 1985.
Viewers: 1.5bn in 160 countries.

Bob Geldof became a TV legend when he implored the audience to: "Give us your fucking money."

Eastenders: The divorce papers

First Broadcast: December 25 1986.
Viewers: 30m.

Christmas in the Old Vic. Den launches into Angie, who has lied about having six months to live: "This [brandishing an envelope], my sweet, is from my solicitor telling you that your husband has filed for a divorce. It also tells you to get a solicitor pretty quick. Happy Christmas, Ange."

Only fools and horses: Del falls through the bar

First broadcast: January 8 1989.
Viewers: 24.3m.

Slapstick perfection. Del attempts to impress the ladies by leaning casually on the bar. The waiter lifts the hatch and he falls through it.

Blackadder goes forth : Goodbyeee

First broadcast: November 2 1989.

Baldrick offers one last gem of wisdom as to the cause of the first world war: "Archie Duke shot an ostrich because he was hungry." Tears were jerked as Blackadder and Baldrick went over the top.

Brookside: The lesbian kiss

First broadcast: January 14 1994.
Viewers: 6m.

Beth and Margaret raise profile, ratings and eyebrows with England's first ever lesbian screen kiss.

The Brit awards

First broadcast: February 19 1996.
Viewers: 11.7m.

Pulp frontman Jarvis Cocker waggles his behind at most of underage Britain as a protest against Michael Jackson.

This life: The last episode

First broadcast: August 7 1997.
Viewers: More than 3.5m.

Rachel has blown the whistle on an affair between Milly and her boss. Milly clobbers her.

fields.headline: Slap and tickle
fields.standfirst: A fan kept from his team, a stripper kept in her clothes, a groom kept from his bride and a man who kept going in a charity shop
fields.trailText: A fan kept from his team, a stripper kept in her clothes, a groom kept from his bride and a man who kept going in a charity shop.
fields.body:
Sex, coats and charity
It was a simple mistake, Richard Alun Roberts told a Denbigh court, that led him to break into a charity shop and engage in sexual intercourse.

Roberts said he entered the shop believing it was his girlfriend's flat. Only after having sex with her did he spot his surroundings, upon which he stole £18.90 from the till and two suede coats.

The prosecution said that Roberts "had sexual intercourse with the female, in the room, and at the conclusion realised it was St Kentigern's charity shop and not a dwelling."

In mitigation, the defence said: "The intention of the visitation was to have a bit of slap and tickle, or sexual intercourse, with the young lady." Alcohol had also played a part.

Roberts - who had previously failed to attend a trial at which he was found guilty in absentia -was placed on probation for a year and ordered to pay £18.90 in compensation to St Kentigern's.
Denbighshire Free Press

Cruellest cut for fan with Tigers in his pants
Hull City football club have issued a savage warning to errant fans by banning one of their most famous supporters from ever attending another match

Clint Leach, a Hull bricklayer, gave a vivid demonstration of his passion for the club in front of millions of TV viewers. Appearing on Blind Date, Mr Leach dropped his trousers to show off his favourite Tigers boxer shorts.

While the club overlooked this affront to public decency, when Mr Leach ran onto the pitch during the last game of the season, against Hartlepool, officials decided it was time to crack down and barred Mr Leach indefinitely.

"It has absolutely destroyed me," said Mr Leach. "Watching the game on Teletext just isn't the same."
Hull Daily Mail

Strip late? No Bristol flashing
Punters at a Bristol strip club were reportedly "flabbergasted" after dancers were banned from taking their clothes off after midnight.

The city council ruled Club Creme could lose its public entertainment licence if full stripteases continue beyond 12 o'clock.

Club Creme's general manager, Gordon Sneddon, said: "At midnight the girls have to keep their tops on. The rules are the rules." But, he admitted, "some people choose to leave".

He affirmed: "There is nothing dirty about what we do. The club already has a strict no-touching policy."

A stripper said: "Bristol is in the dark ages."
Evening Post

I take thee in the name of the law
A former Royal Marine's attempt to keep the peace on his wedding night backfired disastrously as he was hauled off to a cell in Salisbury police station.

After enjoying their reception at Boscombe Recreation Club, Andrew Dobson took his bride Donna and friends to a nearby nightclub, where a scuffle developed between them and a group of off-duty soldiers.

Mr Dobson said: "Donna was then attacked from behind by another girl and part of her wedding dress was ripped off."

While police broke up the fracas, Mr Dobson decided to make a citizen's arrest of his new wife's assailant. Unfortunately, the officers decided to arrest the civic-minded groom for obstruction and only released him after several hours back at the nick.

"I was only let out because it was my wedding night," said Mr Dobson. "When I got back to Amesbury we couldn't find a key to the room, so we ended up spending three hours in the back of my car."
Salisbury Journal

Letter of the week
It would appear that if we all keep quiet and not rock the boat, we can have a new library and concert hall. But in return we have to allow the developers to concrete all over the front garden.
This seems to me like a not so subtle form of blackmail. It's almost a certainty that the new stadium will be built there, putting more traffic on the roads, assuming that fans will still be able to afford the price of admission.
By the way, what became of the millions of pounds from the sale of the town centre?
If there is life up there Jim, it's not as we know it.
D Parsons, Malvern Road
Swindon Evening Advertiser

webTitle: Big Brother's 'Nasty' Nick: I'm no murderer

fields.headline: 'Nasty' Nick: I'm no murderer
fields.trailText: Disgraced Big Brother contestant Nick Bateman proved as adept at handling journalists as scheming against his former housemates as he appeared before the media for the first time this afternoon.
fields.body:
Disgraced Big Brother contestant Nick Bateman proved as adept at handling journalists as scheming against his former housemates as he appeared before the media for the first time this afternoon.

Bateman, appearing at a press conference arranged by Channel 4, which broadcasts Big Brother, neatly avoided being drawn into criticising his fellow contestants who uncovered his underhand tactics that got him evicted from the gameshow house yesterday afternoon. "I would never run down any other contestants in the house," he declared.

When asked how he felt about Craig, who took a prominent role in the confrontation that precipitated his departure from the gameshow-cum-real-life soap, Bateman said: "Craig was doing what anyone else would probably have done in the circumstances. I bear him no grudge." He also said he hoped to see the Big Brother contestants again, adding "human beings have a great capacity for forgiving and forgetting".

Bateman was thrown out of the Big Brother house after the other housemates worked out that he had been trying to influence who they nominated for eviction each week. He admitted talking to other contestants about the nominations and said this had been a "mistake" which he regretted in retrospect.

He denied being a Channel 4 plant, or smuggling a mobile phone into the Big Brother house and said he thought Anna would be the eventual winner of Big Brother's £70,000 prize.

Asked how he felt about being branded the most hated man in the country, Bateman said he thought this was an "extreme" reaction. "I'm just an ordinary guy who took part in a very unusual experiment, under intense scrutiny and pressure," he added.

Bateman also sought to put what he had done into perspective. "I haven't committed a murder. I took part in a gameshow and overtly showed people outside [the Big Brother house] what my game plan was," he said. "I think it's unfair to put a tag around me because I played a game."

As for what people would think of what he had done, Bateman told the assembled journalists: "The public reaction is really up to you guys and how you portray it."

Asked about the experience of living in the Big Brother house under constant surveillance for 34 days, Bateman said: "It was no garden party It wasn't just sitting around in the sun all day and playing cards," as it may have appeared in TV. "It was 24 hours a day under pressure and intense scrutiny."

He added that it had been "a great pleasure" going to the toilet for the first time in weeks without being on camera.

Last night's specially extended hour-long edition of Big Brother drew an average audience of 5.5m between 11pm and midnight - huge numbers for that late in the evening. It also drew the biggest audience share for a Channel 4 show since the TV premier of the film Four Weddings and a Funeral in November 1995.

A spokeswoman for the Big Brother producer, Bazal, dismissed suggestions that Bateman's duplicitous behaviour - including writing names on pieces of paper and showing them to other housemates - should have been detected and dealt with earlier. "It's a gameshow, not a prison - we can't strip-search people," she said. "We took action as soon as we found out [what was going on]."

I bear him no grudge." He also said he hoped to see the Big Brother contestants again, adding "human beings have a great capacity for forgiving and forgetting". Bateman was thrown out of the Big Brother house after the other housemates worked out that he had been trying to influence who they nominated for eviction each week. He admitted talking to other contestants about the nominations and said this had been a "mistake" which he regretted in retrospect. He denied being a Channel 4 plant, or smuggling a mobile phone into the Big Brother house and said he thought Anna would be the eventual winner of Big Brother's £70,000 prize. Asked how he felt about being branded the most hated man in the country, Bateman said he thought this was an "extreme" reaction. "I'm just an ordinary guy who took part in a very unusual experiment, under intense scrutiny and pressure," he added. Bateman also sought to put what he had done into perspective. "I haven't committed a murder. I took part in a gameshow and overtly showed people outside [the Big Brother house] what my game plan was," he said. "I think it's unfair to put a tag around me because I played a game." As for what people would think of what he had done, Bateman told the assembled journalists: "The public reaction is really up to you guys and how you portray it." Asked about the experience of living in the Big Brother house under constant surveillance for 34 days, Bateman said: "It was no garden party It wasn't just sitting around in the sun all day and playing cards," as it may have appeared in TV. "It was 24 hours a day under pressure and intense scrutiny." He added that it had been "a great pleasure" going to the toilet for the first time in weeks without being on camera. Last night's specially extended hour-long edition of Big Brother drew an average audience of 5.5m between 11pm and midnight - huge numbers for that late in the evening. It also drew the biggest audience share for a Channel 4 show since the TV premier of the film Four Weddings and a Funeral in November 1995. A spokeswoman for the Big Brother producer, Bazal, dismissed suggestions that Bateman's duplicitous behaviour - including writing names on pieces of paper and showing them to other housemates - should have been detected and dealt with earlier. "It's a gameshow, not a prison - we can't strip-search people," she said. "We took action as soon as we found out [what was going on]."

webTitle: Gerard Seenan  goes to see whether the isolated Fife town of St Andrews is ready for Prince William

fields.headline: A fresher climate
fields.standfirst:
Prince William's A-level grades (A, B and C ) are good enough to get him into his chosen university. Gerard Seenan goes to see whether the isolated Fife town of St Andrews is ready for him

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Prince William's A-level grades (A, B and C ) are good enough to get him into his chosen university. Gerard Seenan goes to see whether the isolated Fife town of St Andrews is ready for him
fields.body:
Outside the chip shop, the tallest of the three girls - the one with the not-yet-broken-in shoes, gold hooped earrings and, owing to some creative use of peroxide, a vaguely badgerish appearance - is excited. "I can't wait. He's gorgeous," she screams with teenage enthusiasm. "I'd give him one." Her friend, in a barely decent miniskirt, is also thrilled. "God, it'll be great. Imagine getting off with him."

Prince William, second in line to the throne, must be reassured. Should he ever feel the need to tear himself away from essays on the Bauhaus's influence on cubism or symbolism in Botticelli, he will find a warm welcome waiting for him among the battered haddock, chipped potatoes and teenage acne of St Andrews. Not that he is likely to experience such low-rent pleasures. St Andrews, particularly the St Andrews encountered by those of such wealth and breeding as the almost heir apparent, is not that sort of place at all.

The isolated and quietly dignified Fife town is famous for two things: golf and its prolificacy of public-school-educated students. Both are apparent wherever you look. On a clear day it is possible to sit on the beach and gaze on for miles as rich Japanese businessmen and Americans in plus fours happily hack their way round the Old Course, before disappearing in a blaze of flying fairway. In the tat shops in town there are practical golf-themed tea towels (£1.99) and, for the golfer who desires nothing so useful, a themed paperweight (£7.99). All this awaits the man who will be king.

When the telephone rang in the jungle deep in Belize yesterday morning and Prince William's Eton housemaster, Andrew Gailey, crackled down the line the news that the young prince had done rather better in his A-levels than his parents , the prince's attentions must have turned from the Welsh Guard operations he was enduring to St Andrews. In Fife they were certainly thinking about him. The rumour broke on Wednesday - and the tabloids descended. According to yesterday's Sun, it was all undergraduate sex on the fairways and three-in-a-bunker romps at St Andrews. Social anthropology graduate Kev Head, however, told the Guardian he was unconvinced. "It's a bit cold for that," he says. There is, though, plenty of nakedness for Prince William to contemplate.

As befits a university where, reputedly, anything between 40% and 75% of undergraduates - the university does not keep figures - hail from public-school backgrounds, there is a lot of getting your kit off at St Andrews. Members of the rugby team have an annual streak down Market Street. There's also the Kate Kennedy club, founded in 1926, whose nine male members, in between dressing up in women's clothing, commemorate Bishop Kennedy's apparently fetching niece by taking their clothes off and larking about in the - somewhat chilly - North Sea. Yesterday, though, there was none of that.

It was all terribly serious. Prince William had an A in geography, a B in history of art and a C in biology; there was no need for an abuse of royal prerogative on this occasion: he had earned himself a place at Scotland's oldest university. The students' association was instantly animated. As the town, for the first but probably not last time, revelled in more hacks than students - during term they make up 25% of the population - student association president Marcus Booth threw a press conference.

An obviously well-brought-up sort of chap, he was delighted. St Andrews would take Prince William to its beer-soaked bosom. And the British press would no doubt respect his privacy, but if that continental lot tried they would get not a jot of gossip, not even from some cash-strapped fourth year.

"If continental paparazzi come here then I am sure the whole community will close ranks and let them know that their activities are just not on," says Booth. In Ogston's cafe bar, a few students, claiming to be too poor to be able to spend their summer discovering the real Thailand, were distinctly underwhelmed. "What's he studying? History of art. That'll be a doss for him, then," said one, who, perhaps wisely, asked not to be named. Although the four-year MA (Hons) in history of art has a reputation for hardly any lectures but a lot of "library work", the university was yesterday making it clear that academic discipline would be required.

As for the riotous social life, it soon wanes, apparently. "I don't think students here are any worse than anywhere else," says Mike Edwards, assistant manager of Ogston's. "It's difficult to tell who has got money and who hasn't because they all spend above their means. They're all much alike: they get drunk, they get off with each other."

There are plenty of places to get drunk in St Andrews, but there's not a lot else to do. Clubbing is of the type that used to feature on The Hit Man and Her; the students' union is the main focus of social activities. There are, of course, lots of balls. For a man familiar with dressing in the faux Victoriana of Eton, there will probably seem nothing strange in sitting down to dinner in an academic gown. For others, life among the 16th century buildings can get a bit much at times. "This is such a small place and can become claustrophobic," says student Alex Worsick. "At times you have to escape to Dundee to find civilisation - and that's something I never thought I would hear myself say."

But if Dundee has better nightlife than St Andrews, the Fife town is, at least, far prettier. The university is spread around the town, its ancient buildings as much a part of the fabric of St Andrews as the Old Course. Students tend to stay in halls and the prince will have the choice of the original character of St Salvator's or the modern facilities of New Hall on the outskirts of town. Wherever he goes, though, even in the isolation of Fife, there will be those who come hoping to catch a glimpse.

Walking through St Mary's College quadrangle, Ike Goldberg, from Wisconsin, is elated to hear that St Andrews will next year boast a new royal resident. "Your prince is coming here? That would be something to see. Perhaps they could add it to the tour itinerary," he says, only half joking.

webTitle: Plain brown envelope brings message of joy

fields.headline: Plain brown envelope brings message of joy
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Eloise Webster turned pale. The first piece of paper she spotted on opening the brown envelope showed a U. For one awful moment she thought she had failed chemistry.
fields.body:
Eloise Webster turned pale. The first piece of paper she spotted on opening the brown envelope showed a U. For one awful moment she thought she had failed chemistry.

She need not have worried. The unclassified result was an S-level paper she had sat "just for fun". The results that counted confirmed that she was on her way to Cambridge to study natural sciences as a prelude, she hoped, to going into medical research.

"Oh my goodness I got all As," she whispered excitedly as realisation dawned. She turned to hug boyfriend Mark Willis, who gained three As and a B, then grabbed her mobile phone to tell her family the good news.

With top grades in biology, chemistry, maths, further maths and physics, the 18-year-old was among 30 students from Richard Huish college in Taunton, Somerset, to achieve three or more straight As.

Twelve students each gained four As, while Eloise and Natasha Lambert, given a provisional place at Oxford, collected five apiece.

The sixth form college, which includes England rugby coach Andy Robinson and writer Arthur C Clarke among its former pupils, has turned in results above the national average for the past five years. This year the overall pass rate at the college, which has 1,150 pupils in all, has gone up to 95%, with 42% of grades achieved at A or B. Fifteen students, seven of them girls, are on their way to Oxbridge colleges.

Emily Bowie, from Chard wanted an A and two Bs to take up a place to read medicine at Southampton. "It's amazing. I'm ecstatic, I didn't think I'd do it," she beamed, staring at the slip giving straight As in chemistry, biology, physics and maths.

Outside the school hall, where envelopes were still being laid out alphabetically on trestle tables, Ben, her boyfriend of three years, was among those waiting anxiously.

Abby Pow, 18, from Taunton, needed two Bs and a C to do an exercise and sports science course at Exeter University.

Amid scenes of mutual hugging and squeals of joy and, occasionally, disappointment, she opened her envelope with some trepidation. "Oh my God. I think that's OK. I've got to check again. An A in English, I don't know how that happened. I've done it."

Not all were so fortunate.

Before making her way into the hall Naomi Walker had doubted that she had gained the grades she needed in order to study English at Sussex . But she had hoped she had done well enough to get into her second choice university.

Moments later there were tears as she discovered she had probably not done so. Sadly, she went in search of staff who will be on hand in the coming days to guide students like her through the clearing process.

The college vice-principal, Tim Duffen, rejected criticism that the exams were getting easier.

"We don't believe standards are slipping or that things are getting easier, but rather that we are able to crank things up a bit by hard work and by the commitment of students and staff," he said.

fields.headline: Students steer clear of Clearing
fields.trailText: Fewer students are finding university places through clearing this year, according to the Universities and Colleges Admissions Service (UCAS).
fields.body:
Fewer students are finding university places through clearing this year, according to the Universities and Colleges Admissions Service (UCAS).

Mistakes made by the Scottish qualifications authority (SQA) mean that the number of students already accepted is also down.

In 1999, 224,731 students had their places confirmed immediately, while 217,062 have been accepted so far this year. "[It] is largely due to the problems that Scottish applicants have been facing," said an UCAS spokesman.

The SQA admitted today that more than 5,000 students had received inaccurate or incomplete grades last week. Across Britain, 105,773 are still waiting for their chosen university's decision on whether to take them.

"We expect that over the next couple of weeks the number of people getting places will be at least as high as last year," the UCAS spokesman added. He stressed that Scottish students' conditional offers would still be valid until their grades were checked.

SQA chairman David Miller has undertaken not to lower any of the grades Scottish candidates have received so far. He "deeply regretted" the distress caused by the board's errors, he said.

"We have identified every one of these candidates by name and will be working to confirm their final result. No candidate will have their grades revised downwards when we add the missing result data."

He promised to co-operate fully with the inquiry launched by Scottish education minister Sam Galbraith into the cause of the fiasco. "SQA wants to learn from this failureWe owe it to our young people to ensure this never happens again."

fields.headline: Top grades reignite elitism row
fields.standfirst:
Students celebrate record A-level results
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The headteacher at the centre of the row over elitism in university admissions last night renewed his attack on Oxford as his prize pupil achieved five top grades at A-level.
fields.body:
The headteacher at the centre of the row over elitism in university admissions last night renewed his attack on Oxford as his prize pupil achieved five top grades at A-level.

Laura Spence faced photographers at Monkseaton high school, in Whitley Bay, clutching straight As in geography, biology, chemistry, English and general studies. Earlier this year she was rejected by Magdalen College for a place there to read medicine.

Paul Kelley, headteacher at the Tyneside comprehensive, said her results were a vindication of the attack by the chancellor Gordon Brown on Magdalen's decision. Ms Spence will now go to Harvard in the US to read biochemistry.

But on a day when, among the 270,000 students receiving A-level results, there were several examples of extravagant achievement - including by other Oxbridge rejects - Magdalen also claimed its case had been proved.

Anthony Smith, the college president, said the five medical students chosen by the college had exceeded the grades they needed.

Dr Kelley said: "Laura is an exceptional person with exceptional achievements. She has shown great maturity and judgment and we should not lose this calibre of person. The failure of our admissions system is clear and Laura is just one of a whole stream of people who have had problems."

Last night Ms Spence was drinking halves of lager with friends in the town's Foxhunter pub. Harvard had selected her on the basis of its entrance exam - her A-level results were immaterial.

Mr Smith said: "She's done very well and we congratulate her. But the students that have been selected have reached their conditional offers and got results just as good."

Alexa and Kate Shipman, identical twins who studied at St George's school in Harpenden, Hertfordshire, both won 5 As at A-level and an A in AS general studies.

They did not win the place to read medicine at Newnham college, Cambridge, that they wanted, but they accepted the snub with equanimity. Had they been successful, they would have comprised 50% of the subject year group.

About 270,000 students received A-level results yesterday, including Prince William, whose A, B and C grades won him a place at St Andrews.

In a record year for A grades, Northern Ireland students were still well ahead of the rest of the country. One in four - 25.4% of entries achieved an A grade. In Wales, A grades accounted for 20.5% of total entries and the overall pass rate was 93.7%. Last night 192,140 candidates across the country had confirmed their places at university.

webTitle: Following  A-level results, Emma Brockes  wonders where  boys went wrong

fields.headline: Boys in no-man's land
fields.standfirst: It's not just A-levels our boys are doing badly at. They're oversensitive, unhealthy and depressed. On top of all that, the daughter of a US diplomat goes and says they're less sophisticated than American lads.  Emma Brockes  wonders where it all went wrong
fields.trailText: It's not just A-levels our boys are doing badly at. They're oversensitive, unhealthy and depressed. On top of all that, the daughter of a US diplomat goes and says they're less sophisticated than American lads. Emma Brockes wonders where it all went wrong
fields.body:
There was an unpleasant note of alarm in the coverage following yesterday's news that girls have done better than boys in this year's A-levels, but it was, perhaps, mitigated by the fact that this has been a spectacularly bad month for British lads. For any 16-year-old boy in the delicate throes of finding an image for himself, the undernourished, over-sensitive, suicidal and now academically malfunctioning picture of British masculinity may leave him wishing he had been born female.

The A-level bombshell has compounded a run of eight years during which girls have gained more overall passes than boys; and for the first time, girls have achieved more A grades. It follows the publication of statistics revealing that men between the ages of 15-24 are three times more likely to commit suicide than women of the same age.

To add to the gloom, Mary-Catherine Lader, the 15-year-old daughter of the US ambassador to Britain, chose this month to publicly ridicule British boys as "pale and unhealthy looking", and a good deal less sophisticated than their American counterparts.

The most irksome of the theories on why girls have overtaken boys at A-level, and in life generally, is that whenever girls do well in a given field, that field is instantly discredited in the eyes of boys. The "feminisation" of education, in other words the fact that girls are allowed to do well now rather than being held back, is thought by experts to be one of the chief reasons boys don't concentrate in the classroom.

"Keeping them engaged is the challenge of this century," says Adrienne Katz, head of the charity Young Voice which last year interviewed 1,400 male teenagers aged 13-19 in a joint study with Oxford University. The results found that 17% of the boys were anti-school enough not to pass a single exam. "You will get some boys saying, 'Well, education is a girl's thing, why should we be teased to death for trying hard?' More boys are bullied for being good at their school work than for being thick."

"Girls still haven't reached equality," says Dr Ann Buchanan, who is joint author of the Leading Lads report and a university reader at Oxford. "But whereas the boys might have felt that they had a fairly easy playing field in the past, they are having to compete with the girls now."

It is competition corrupted by the lingering belief that a boy who comes second to a girl has not only lost the race, but something much more profound; something that involves his gender and his dignity as a man. With stakes so high, many boys would rather drop out of the game altogether than risk trying and failing. The result is that more boys than girls leave school without qualifications, more are liable to play truant, more are excluded and more end up in remedial groups.

The knock-on effects, only loosely related, are that more men than women are unemployed, more are likely to be made redundant and more become drug addicts. "Our research showed that this type of news about girls' A-level success can make boys go, 'Well, if girls do so much better then why should we bother to try?'" says Katz.

Last year, Susan Faludi followed up her hugely successful tome, Backlash, with Stiffed, a six-year study of American men which explored the now infamous catchphrase, "the crisis in masculinity". This was variously interpreted as an intellectual cover for men fighting to retain their privilege, and a genuine phenomenon causing under-achievement in boys.

Faludi tended towards the latter, concluding that men have been disoriented by the systematic discrediting of values on which they were brought up, namely that if they abided by certain codes of behaviour their dominance at home and in the world would be assured. "If men turned away from softness, play, emotional connection, all the so-called feminine attributes society would reward the traditional man, if not with material wealth and political prominence, then at least with dominion over wife and children. Perhaps this is why, when boys equate reading as something they do with their mummies and football as something they do with their daddies, reading suddenly becomes a waste of time. If it was important, after all, surely daddy handle it? So it continues. At the end of one of the most important weeks of their lives, there will be lots of girls clutching their A-grade A-levels wondering why all the attention is still focused on the boys.

On the streets of London:
the views of three 16-year- olds
Interviews by Merope Mills

Scott Bland

"You don't need any qualifications these days. I've done my GCSEs and I've already had loads of jobs. That's without doing my A-levels. I'm working in a printing company at the moment but I don't know what I want to do when I'm older yet. I don't feel girls are doing better than boys at school. I left school because I hated it, not because I wasn't any good at it. But if I had a problem I don't know who I'd talk to - it depends on what the problem was. I'd probably discuss it with my mates - because I'm closest to them."

Terry Coventry

"Education is important because without it you won't do well in life. But I don't go to school and I haven't done GCSEs or A-levels. I used to work at the market but I got the sack so I'm looking for a job at the moment. I do worry about the future because I don't want to end up like a bum, so I know it's important to get a job and save some money. Some of the girls I know are doing better than the boys but some just waste their lives by smoking all the time. The boys do that too but they can handle it better."

Lee Brigati

"I've done my GCSEs and I'm doing my A-levels at the moment. It's good to have qualifications behind you. But I do think as long as you've got ambitions in life you can do anything you want. If you want it you should go for it. I talk to my mates about any problems I have but there are less boys around me at school - the girls around here are staying in education longer than the boys. They like it more. I think school's a good laugh but I don't do much work there."

webTitle: Nine straight grade As for 'an extraordinary guy'

fields.headline: Nine straight grade As for 'an extraordinary guy'
fields.standfirst: Special report: A-level results 2000
fields.trailText: Thomas Barnet-Lamb of Westminster school in London may have set a British record by leaving with nine A grades at A-level.
fields.body:
Thomas Barnet-Lamb of Westminster school in London may have set a British record by leaving with nine A grades at A-level.

Amid a galaxy of stunning A-level performances, with five A grades almost - but not quite - becoming commonplace, no one shone more brightly than Thomas.

Neither the Department for Education and Employment, the exam boards nor the Qualifications and Curriculum Authority keeps records of individual achievements, but no one can remember anything this impressive before.

Certainly not Thomas's headmaster, Tristram Jones-Parry, who has taught at the school for 27 years and been in charge for two. "I've never known anything like this," he said.

Thomas leaves Westminster school with A grades at A-level in chemistry, economics, electronics, history, maths, pure maths, mechanics, statistics, and physics.

He also has an A in AS-level philosophy, and scholarship level in two Cambridge University Step papers, maths 2 and maths 3. Three of the A-levels were taken last year.

"He's an extraordinary guy in the sense that he bears his brilliance easily," said Mr Jones-Parry.

"He's an extremely good debater, a very good singer. He's inspired other people." Visiting lecturers often had the experience of reconsidering their view after taking a question from Thomas.

Thomas, who is to read maths at Cambridge, moved to Westminster for the sixth form on a scholarship from Culford independent school in Bury St Edmunds.

In greater Manchester, a Ukrainian boy who spoke barely any English when he came to live in the UK five years ago was yesterday celebrating having gained six A-levels at grade A.

Pavel Zubko will take up a place at Cambridge to read natural sciences this autumn, after notching up top passes this year in biology, chemistry, physics, further maths and general studies while a pupil at Sale grammar school. They are on top of an existing A in A-level maths, which he took two years ago.

Yesterday 18-year-old Pavel paid tribute to the teachers at his school. "I had loads of help from all my teachers and I could not have done it without them," he said.

He and his family came to Britain from Kiev in the summer of 1995 when his father took up a research post at Manchester University. After a year at another school, where he gained grade A* at GCSE in maths and grade A in German, he started at Sale grammar school.

Initially Pavel encountered language difficulties, the school said, but he proved himself to be an extremely able student, excelling in mathematics. While studying nine other subjects to GCSE, he largely taught himself A-level maths, with relatively little assistance from staff.

Yesterday the school's deputy head, Dave Wilson, said Pavel was "a thoroughly delightful young man whose unassuming nature has won him many friends among the staff and students at the school.

"He has willingly given up his time to help younger pupils with any problems they have experienced in mathematics and has in effect acted as an additional member of staff the school's mathematics faculty."

Mr Wilson said his pupil's achievement in general studies was a particularly impressive result given that the exam tests the level of general knowledge expected in a typical 18-year-old who has been resident in the UK since birth.

Yesterday morning Pavel had not been able to pass on the good news to his mother, who was in Ukraine, but was looking forward to celebrating in the evening with a few friends. Eventually he would like to follow in the footsteps of his family by becoming a scientist.
