fields.headline: William makes the grade
fields.standfirst:
Prince wins college choice with best royal exam marks in 33 years
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Prince Charles yesterday sent an email of congratulations to Prince William, currently on exercise with the Welsh Guards in the jungles of Belize, after his eldest son was awarded A, B and C grades in his A-levels - good enough to secure his place at St Andrews University.
fields.body:
Prince Charles yesterday sent an email of congratulations to Prince William, currently on exercise with the Welsh Guards in the jungles of Belize, after his eldest son was awarded A, B and C grades in his A-levels - good enough to secure his place at St Andrews University.

The prince, who left Eton last month, was awarded the A for geography, B for history of art and C for biology. The results were conveyed to him by his former housemaster and St Andrews graduate, Andrew Gailey.

After taking a gap year, to be spent partly in Australia, the prince is expected to become the first member of the royal family to study at a Scottish university. He will go up in the autumn of 2001, reading for a four year history of art honours degree. The entry requirements are normally two Bs and a C.

For a young man whose family have Rembrandts, Vermeers, Canalettos and Van Dycks hanging on the walls at home, course work and vacation studies should not pose a problem. The course, described in the university's prospectus as visually stimulating and intellectually challenging, is unlikely to be damned by the chief education inspector as vacuous.

Prince Charles said: "I know how hard William worked to achieve these excellent results and I am very proud that he has done so well."

In a statement from St James's Palace, the prince was said to be "obviously delighted and relieved that he has got into St Andrews" and very much looking forward to becoming a student there.

His grades - added to 10 GCSEs, eight of them As and two Bs, two years ago - appear to be the best achieved by a member of the royal family since they submitted to public examinations 33 years ago when Prince Charles obtained a C in French and a B in history in his A-levels.

The choice of St Andrews, as opposed to Cambridge which members of the royal family have traditionally attended for the past 150 years, was apparently Prince William's own. Edinburgh and Bristol were also considered.

Both his father and uncle Edward read history at Cambridge and both faced accusations of favouritism from contemporaries, something that William should not have to face.

The choice of the oldest Scottish university will certainly ease palace security headaches, situated as it is in a small and intimate coastal town remote from the metropolis. It is also far away from the normal beat of paparazzi and the nearest nightclub is in Dundee.

About 60% of its intake is from state schools. It may be the first time the prince will have met state school contemporaries.

A spokesman for the university said St Andrews would provide a "unique, nourishing and challenging environment" for Prince William.

"We are pleased for him as we are for all successful applicants and look forward to welcoming him to our community," he said.

Alex Salmond, outgoing leader of the Scottish National party and a St Andrews graduate, said the prince would assist the university's international reputation and it was a sensible choice for him to have made.

But he added: "The university will have to reinforce its efforts to make sure Scotland's oldest university is seen as a people's university, not just for the privileged."

How other royals fared:

Prince William has proved himself to be one of the brightest members of the modern royal family, his three good A-levels coming after three A*s, five As and two Bs at GCSE two years ago.

His father, the Prince of Wales, who was the first member of the royal family to sit public examinations, got two A-levels - a B in history and a C in french - after passing five O-Levels (he failed maths). But he had no say in his choice of university. A committee including Harold Wilson, the prime minister, the Archbishop of Canterbury, the Dean of Windsor, the chairman of the committee of university vice-chancellors and Lord Mountbatten chose Cambridge for him, where he got a 2:2.

Prince William's mother, Diana, Princess of Wales, did not take any A-levels and once told a 15-year-old boy that she could not answer a Trivial Pursuit question because she was as thick as a plank.

The Princess Royal obtained an E in geography and D in history in her A-levels in 1968 but she did not go to university.

The Duke of York gained three A-levels in 1979 - in history, english and economics and political science - and in 1982 the Earl of Wessex received two - in english literature and economics and political science, plus an S-Level in history. Buckingham Palace refused to divulge grades attained by princes Andrew and Edward yesterday, saying "the examinations were harder then and the marking different".

Other A level highlights:

Adam Spencer, 10, from Arlesey in Bedfordshire, is likely to be the youngest A-level success. He achieved a grade B in maths after taking adult education courses at Luton sixth form college. "I was actually hoping for an A but I'm very pleased with a B," he said. He intends to go to university at 14 to read maths. Brian Edwards, deputy principal of the college, said they had accepted Adam after other schools refused to take him because of his age.

Sameer Sanghvi, 12, from Finchley, north London, got a grade C in computing from Ryde College, Watford.

Terry Tyacke, 74, extended his world record by passing his 27th A-level exam, scoring an A grade in film studies. He left school at 15 with no qualifications and took his first exam aged 46, to encourage his daughter. "I can't stop, it's like a drug and I am addicted," said Mr Tyacke, of Trowbridge, Wilts.

Tamara Todorovic, a refugee from Bosnia who could not speak English when she arrived in Britain with her family in 1993, has gained three As at A-level. She is leaving Bishop Stopford school in Kettering, Northants, for Warwick University.

German Michael Tyka went to Culford School in Bury St Edmunds, Suffolk, in September 1998, supposedly for a term to brush up his English, but decided to stay on and won 6 A grades at A-level, in maths, biology, chemistry, physics, general studies and German. He will read biochemistry at Imperial college, London.

At Conyers school, a comprehensive in Stockton on Tees, Alan Elder made it into his exam board's top five performers in both maths and further maths. He is going to Cambridge University to read engineering.

Christopher Cummins of Our Lady Sion School in Worthing, Sussex, achieved five grade As at A-level, which he sat when aged 16. His passes were in maths with statistics, pure maths, mechanics, chemistry and physics. He also gained grade 1 in two Cambridge Step papers. Christopher, who also has nine A's at GCSE, plans to take up his place at Trinity College, Cambridge, next year, after a gap year in banking. His school, an independent day school, said his mathematical abilities made him "probably one of the best students in the country in his age range".

Two students from Brockenhurst College in the New Forest - an open access "tertiary" college - gained five grade As at A-level and a distinction at S-level. Matthew Findlay from Hythe and James Kermode from Lymington got the top passes in maths, physics, chemistry, further maths and general studies. Both are taking up places at Cambridge. The college reported record results this year, with 24 students achieving three or more grade As at A-level including eight students with four grade As. In 10 subjects at least half the candidates gained passes at grades A or B.

Students at Kendrick girls' school in Reading were celebrating after winning national plaudits in their subjects. Three girls at the leading grammar school won awards from their examination board for coming in the top five in the country in their subjects. And 17 students at the school, which has consistently topped the league tables, got straight As. Claire Hall, 18, who got three As in sociology, English and religious studies, was ranked by the AQA board within the top five nationally in sociology, along with classmate Jessica Swaile. And Sarah Abram, who came in the top five candidates nationwide in German, got straight As in English literature, sociology and French.

He left school at 15 with no qualifications and took his first exam aged 46, to encourage his daughter. "I can't stop, it's like a drug and I am addicted," said Mr Tyacke, of Trowbridge, Wilts. Tamara Todorovic, a refugee from Bosnia who could not speak English when she arrived in Britain with her family in 1993, has gained three As at A-level. Three girls at the leading grammar school won awards from their examination board for coming in the top five in the country in their subjects. And 17 students at the school, which has consistently topped the league tables, got straight As. Claire Hall, 18, who got three As in sociology, English and religious studies, was ranked by the AQA board within the top five nationally in sociology, along with classmate Jessica Swaile. And Sarah Abram, who came in the top five candidates nationwide in German, got straight As in English literature, sociology and French.

webTitle: Girls help boys' school gain top marks

fields.headline: Girls help boys' school gain top marks
fields.standfirst:
Grammar head reveals secret of bridging the gender gap as pupils nationally celebrate a record year for success

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Even at the top performing single-sex school, the boys relied on a little help from girls to romp home with the best A-level results in the country.
fields.body:
Even at the top performing single-sex school, the boys relied on a little help from girls to romp home with the best A-level results in the country.

For the second year running, Colchester Royal grammar school in Essex got the highest average points score of any state school or college in an analysis by the Guardian, presented in the tables below.

The result came hot on the heels of evidence that girls are outperforming boys at A-level. This year, for the first time, girls got more As than boys - 18.1% compared with 17.5%. Boys also surrendered their traditional superiority in maths and science. Overall, Essex proved to be a top-performing county, with both selective and comprehensive schools doing well.

Colchester Royal grammar school emerged as the highest-performing selective state school in the Guardian's analysis, with an average points score per candidate of 33.98. This is marginally down on last year's 34.6, which was its best result, but still puts it above the top-performing comprehensive schools and colleges.

Ken Jenkinson, its headmaster, said the key to his success in achieving good results for boys was motivation: "The important thing is to have positive relationship with the student. One reason we probably do well is we concentrate on the whole child - extracurricular activities, sport, drama, development.

"We are not just interested in exam result. These exam results tend to be a byproduct of the ethos."

For the first time girls, admitted to the sixth form two years ago, have taken A-levels at the school. The 18 girls kept pace with the 85 boys. "We are delighted with the input the girls have made to the sixth form," said Mr Jenkinson

The school achieved a 99.31% pass rate, and 73.4% of grades were A or B. Twenty-one students obtained four A grades or more, and eight achieved five As.

Nine students were taking places at Oxford or Cambridge, and virtually all would go to university, Mr Jenkinson said. "It's just a combination of teamwork and hard work. Good team, good students, good staff working hard together. We are delighted we have finished top of the table, if that's what we've done."

In second position was the King Edward VI grammar school in nearby Chelmsford with an average points score of 33.67. Again the boys' school takes girls in the sixth form and this year fielded 122 candidates. In its results, 70.8% of grades were As and Bs, and 12 students achieved five A grades. Like many single-sex schools, it remains a boys' school by statute even though it takes a limited number of girls in the final two years.

The state comprehensive with the best A-level results yesterday secured its place at the top of the Guardian's league tables after leapfrogging over about 20 rivals.

The 52 candidates at Tarporley community high school in Cheshire achieved an average points score of 28.76 from results that included 65 grade As, 58 Bs, 40 Cs, 29 Ds and 13 Es. The head, Alan Sieber, hailed "a record year with an average points score equivalent to two As and one B. Students, their parents and staff are delighted by the result of their joint efforts." One student, Rachel Armitage, gained five A grades and an Oxbridge place.

Last year the school had an average points score of 23.1, which put it 24th in the Guardian's tables in a year in which the top comprehensive school scored 25.1.

Tarporley school is proud to call itself a comprehensive but is pragmatic enough to find out what works and put it into practice. It puts pupils into sets by ability in some subjects (maths, modern languages, and science) and teaches all of them together in others.

Hills Road sixth form college in Cambridge retained its place at the head of the Guardian's league for colleges, with 57% of its students gaining A or B grades and an average points score of 28.5 - marginally down on last year's 28.5.

Margaret Ingram, the deputy principal, said the college was delighted with its continued high pass rate. "We have got a very dedicated and committed staff who work extremely hard," she said. "As well as a good academic record we also have a lot of extracurricular activities, which give a stimulating ethos to the college."

Although the children of Cambridge University academics inevitably attend the college, Ms Ingrams said it drew its students from a wide range of backgrounds and made local recruitment a priority. Few Cambridge schools had sixth forms, which inevitably increased its popularity.

About 90% of its intake go on to university, many to Oxbridge. This year's results indicate that 40 pupils are bound for Oxford and a further 25 will go down the road to Cambridge.

fields.headline: RBS dangles a £19 carrot
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Royal Bank of Scotland plans to persuade low income customers of Scottish Power to open one of its no-frills current accounts by promising savings of £19 a year.
fields.body:
Royal Bank of Scotland plans to persuade low income customers of Scottish Power to open one of its no-frills current accounts by promising savings of £19 a year.

The bank hopes the scheme, which is being piloted in parts of Scotland, will be an effective response to the government's demand that accounts for the "financially excluded" be widely marketed.

The Treasury has given the high street banks until the end of October to set up basic bank accounts for the three million people in Britain - mainly low earners - who do not already have them.

Under the trial promotion - which is taking place in Fife, Lanarkashire, and the Borders - Scottish Power customers who pay their electricity and gas bills with cash or through a pre-paid meter will be enticed with leaflets saying that they are missing out on discounts available to customers who pay by direct debit.

The customers will be directed to take the leaflet to the Royal Bank of Scotland, which already has 25,000 customers for its no-frills Key account. The leaflet says the average household could save £19 a year by using direct debit.

At least 15% of Scots do not have bank accounts and are therefore unable to make payments by direct debit - which is one of the main reasons why the government is trying to tackle the issue of providing financial services to them.

The government also wants to pay social security pay ments directly into bank accounts instead of in cash, over post office counters.

As a result it is trying to persuade high street banks to set up a "universal bank" through the post office network, which is under threat from the move to automate social security payments.

Most of the banks have, however, greeted this proposal with scepticism. The alternative the government has offered them is to set up the basic accounts.

No-frills accounts are al ready available from the Royal Bank of Scotland, the Bank of Scotland and Halifax.

Royal Bank's Key account, like other basic accounts, does not allow customers to go into debt but does let them set up direct debits, and provides a card for cash machines.

Royal Bank, which bought NatWest earlier this year, plans to offer a similar account named Step through NatWest by the end of October, and is considering marketing that account through credit unions.

If the pilot scheme proves successful the Royal Bank Key account will be rolled out across Scotland.

A Treasury spokesman welcomed the alliance with Scottish Power. "We want the accounts out there," he said.

fields.headline: Clinton faces fresh inquiry
fields.standfirst:
Gore's big speech eclipsed by return of Lewinsky scandal

The Lewinsky scandal: The issue explained
fields.trailText:
Gore's big speech eclipsed by return of Lewinsky scandal

The Lewinsky scandal: The issue explained
fields.body:
The Monica Lewinsky scandal returned to haunt the Democratic party last night as news of fresh legal moves against Bill Clinton threatened to overshadow Al Gore's presidential nomination acceptance speech at the party convention in Los Angeles.

A leak, which the White House claimed was far from coincidental, revealed that the independent counsel, Robert Ray, who succeeded Kenneth Starr in the job earlier this year, had empanelled a grand jury in Washington to consider prosecuting Mr Clinton when he leaves office in January.

The source said the grand jury had been sitting since July 11 for the sole purpose of considering charges against Mr Clinton arising out of his relationship with Ms Lewinsky and attempts to cover it up.

When Mr Clinton becomes an ordinary citizen on January 20 2001, he may face criminal charges similar to those on which he was impeached and acquitted by Congress last year. Mr Clinton faced two charges from the Senate, of perjury and obstruction of justice. Neither charge reached the required two-thirds majority for conviction.

The White House reacted angrily to the news, which was leaked to the Associated Press news agency and emerged just hours before the vice-president addressed the convention in a speech widely billed as an attempt to break free from the shadow of Mr Clinton.

"The timing of this leak reeks to high heaven," the White House spokesman Jake Siewert said. "Given the record of the office of the independent counsel, the timing is hardly surprising."

Mr Gore's spokesman Chris Lehane said: "Al Gore and Joe Lieberman are going to focus on America's future. Republicans are obsessed with the past."

Even George W Bush's aides criticised the leak. "It's not appropriate for this type of announcement to be made on the day that the vice-president is going to accept the Democ ratic nomination," spokeswoman Karen Hughes said.

In his speech early today, Mr Gore promised a "better, fairer, more prosperous America".

"I stand here tonight as my own man," he said after eight years as vice-president. "I want you to know this," he told an expectant audience. "I've taken on the powerful forces. As president, I'll stand up to them, and I'll stand up for you."

With Mr Clinton nearly 3,000 miles away in the east, Mr Gore left no ploy unused in an effort to persuade US voters to do the one thing they stubbornly refuse to do: to learn to love him the way they continue - in spite of everything - to love Mr Clinton.

Mr Gore's acceptance speech followed days of relentless effort to portray the vice-president as the kind of personality who can fire the anxious party's troubled soul.

Friends and relatives bore witness to the vice-president as a warm, honest, brave and relaxed family man and national leader, setting the scene for a speech which was widely seen as the make-or-break moment in Mr Gore's efforts to prevent Mr Bush from capturing the White House.

Tributes from his wife Tipper and his daughters Karenna and Kristin were interwoven with testimony from figures such as the actor Tommy Lee Jones and the writer David Halberstam, all of them seeking to humanise Mr Gore's defiantly stiff reputation and energise a party which is unmistakably underwhelmed about its chances in November.

Mr Gore and his spin doctors insisted that he wrote most of his speech himself, in an effort to communicate as directly as possible with the party and the nation. "This is a speech that I have written, and I will deserve either the credit or the blame," Mr Gore had said shortly after arriving in Los Angeles on Wednesday.

fields.headline: Premiership Team News
fields.trailText: Charlton v Manchester City
fields.body:
Charlton v Manchester City

Alan Curbishley is waiting on the fitness of £3.75m summer signing Jonatan Johansson. Meanwhile City are waiting to see if Paulo Wanchope recovers from jet-lag after returning from international duty on Thursday. Alfe-Inge Haaland, Shaun Goater, Ian Bishop and Andy Morrison are all missing from Joe Royle's squad with injuries.

Chelsea v West Ham

Christian Panucci is included in the squad for the first time. West Ham are without the injured Ian Pearce and Scott Minto and Trevor Sinclair is suspended.

Coventry v Middlesbrough

New signings Craig Bellamy and David Thompson will make their Coventry debuts and Marc Edworthy and Carlton Palmer are also expected to play after long-term injuries. Middlesbrough include new signings Alen Boksic, Christian Karembeu, Noel Whelan, Joseph-Desire Job, Paul Okon and Mark Crossley in their squad.

Derby v Southampton

Simo Valakari is set to make his debut for Derby as Giorgi Kinkladze and Craig Burley are both sidelined. Southampton striker Marian Pahars is struggling with a thigh problem he picked up playing for his country in midweek and Francis Benali and Matthew Le Tissier are out with leg and calf injuries.

Leeds v Everton

Harry Kewell, Jason Wilcox, Stephen McPhail, Matthew Jones, Alan Maybury and long-term casualty David Batty are all sidelined for Leeds. Everton boss Walter Smith is yet to decide whether to play Duncan Ferguson, but he is expected to give debuts to Alex Nyarko, Paul Gascoigne, Steve Watson and Alessandro Pistone.

Leicester v Aston Villa

Neil Lennon and Gerry Taggart are both doubtful for Leicester after missing Northern Ireland's game against Yugoslavia in midweek. Villa will hand debuts to David Ginola - who will be given a free role - Luc Nilis and Alpay.

Liverpool v Bradford

Skipper Sami Hyypia picked up a groin injury in Finland's 3-1 midweek win over Norway and is a concern and Patrik Berger has a thigh injury and is extremely doubtful. Ashley Ward looks set to take his place alongside Benito Carbone in the Bradford attack and all six of manager Chris Hutchings' acquisitions in the close season - Ward, Carbone, David Hopkin, Dan Petrescu, Peter Atherton and Ian Nolan - should play.

Sunderland v Arsenal

Stefan Schwarz and Gavin McCann are injured and Alex Rae and Don Hutchison are suspended for the visit of Arsenal. Arsene Wenger should give Robert Pires his debut while Lauren will probably start on the bench.

Tottenham v Ipswich

Neil Sullivan has won Tottenham manager George Graham's vote to start the Premiership clash, ahead of Ian Walker. New £11m striker Sergei Rebrov will also make his debut and is almost certain to been partnered up front by Steffen Iversen. John Scales faces a late fitness test on a thigh injury but Hermann Hreidarsson will make his debut for Ipswich.

fields.headline: The Lewinsky scandal
fields.standfirst: The ghost of the Lewinsky scandal has come back to haunt Bill Clinton and US presidential hopeful Al Gore, and at the worst possible time. Derek Brown explains why.
fields.trailText: The ghost of the Lewinsky scandal has come back to haunt Bill Clinton and US presidential hopeful Al Gore, and at the worst possible time. We explain why.
fields.body:
Didn't the US congress draw a line under the Lewinsky affair last year when it acquitted President Clinton of perjury?
The acquittal did not put an end to the persistent inquiries of the independent counsel, Kenneth Starr, and his successor, Robert Ray.

So what new evidence has emerged?
None, so far as we know. The only new development is that Ray has summoned a grand jury in California to consider whether the president should be indicted on criminal charges after he steps down next January. Specifically, it will be looking at possible charges of perjury, arising from Clinton's repeated denials during the Paula Jones sexual harassment case that he had had a relationship with White House junior aide Monica Lewinsky.

Why now?
Ray reportedly empanelled the grand jury as long ago as July 11. News of the move trickled out just as Vice-President Al Gore was formally accepting the Democrat nomination for November's presidential poll.

A little fishy, perhaps?
The White House certainly thinks so. "The timing of this leak reeks to high heaven," said spokesman Jake Siewert.

How damaging for Gore is the new legal move?
It's awful. He is struggling to peg back the substantial poll lead established by the Republican presidential candidate, George W Bush, and to establish himself as a credible candidate for the top job.

How far can Gore go to distance himself from the president?
It's tricky. He can hardly denounce the man he has loyally understudied for eight years, and in any case he needs all the help he can get from America's most formidable politician. It doesn't help that Gore's closest political confidante, Marty Peretz, described Clinton this week as "loathsome".

How has the US media greeted the latest legal shenanigans?
With barely concealed indifference. Even Matt Drudge, the investigative hack whose award-winning website soared to fame at the height of the Lewinsky scandal, is not too concerned about the California grand jury. In any case, he has a rather better story, one about the Clintons spending more than $250m (£160m) on travel in the past three years.

News of the move trickled out just as Vice-President Al Gore was formally accepting the Democrat nomination for November's presidential poll. A little fishy, perhaps? The White House certainly thinks so. "The timing of this leak reeks to high heaven," said spokesman Jake Siewert. How damaging for Gore is the new legal move? It's awful. He is struggling to peg back the substantial poll lead established by the Republican presidential candidate, George W Bush, and to establish himself as a credible candidate for the top job. How far can Gore go to distance himself from the president? It's tricky. He can hardly denounce the man he has loyally understudied for eight years, and in any case he needs all the help he can get from America's most formidable politician. It doesn't help that Gore's closest political confidante, Marty Peretz, described Clinton this week as "loathsome". How has the US media greeted the latest legal shenanigans? With barely concealed indifference. Even Matt Drudge, the investigative hack whose award-winning website soared to fame at the height of the Lewinsky scandal, is not too concerned about the California grand jury. In any case, he has a rather better story, one about the Clintons spending more than $250m (£160m) on travel in the past three years. fields.headline: Here's looking at you, mate
fields.standfirst: You diet together, dye together, compare sizes, swap clothes. But how do best friends really see each other's bodies?  Susannah Conway finds out
fields.trailText: You diet together, dye together, compare sizes, swap clothes. But how do best friends really see each other's bodies? Susannah Conway finds out
fields.body:
Anna Melville-James and Lorrie Sheehy

Anna, 27, is a journalist; her best friend, Lorrie, 34, is a dramatist. They have known each other since they studied together at Cambridge.

Anna

I always look at people's legs - I think I have rugby player's legs but Lorrie has dancer's legs. I know she is heavier at the moment than she wants to be but her personality is loud and exuberant, and whatever body she had would reflect that. She doesn't let her weight hamper her. Fat is not about having extra weight, anyway, it's a frame of mind. And if you're comfortable with your own body, you'll be comfortable with another woman's body by extension.

Lorrie

Anna always looks fantastic, like a 40s film star. She has an amazing back and great arms but we don't really discuss our bodies. If we're going out, we'll compliment each other's hair or clothes instead. I knew Anna when she was larger than she is now and she was always a very attractive personality. I'm 13 stone and to me I look fat: nothing sags yet but it's all getting wider. Even when I was a gymnast and under nine stone, I still thought I was fat.

Sarah Klugman and Anyanna Ndukwe

Best friends Sarah, 29, a project development manager, and Anyanna, 36, a freelance journalist and mother of two, met as mature students.

Sarah

I first saw Anyanna's body properly when I stayed at her house and she was walking around in a vest. She's very muscular - she can lift a child in each hand. After two kids, she has a good tum and I think she likes her body. I've always had a love-hate relationship with mine. From when I was 18, I felt it wasn't doing what it ought to and for years I tried to control it. I need to do more exercise but avoid it because I feel I ought to be happy with my body as it is.

Anyanna

Sarah has a strong body with a sense of power. Her posture is good; there's a feeling of balance in her and I like her long legs. I've always been slim but I was most happy with my body when I was dancing because I was eating and exercising more. I find it odd that women put on weight when they have kids - motherhood has made me leaner because I'm so busy! But a breast uplift is something I might consider in the future because breastfeeding has taken its toll.

Jessica Shepstone and Shelley Sanger

Jessica, 26, is a gossip columnist for an internet site and Shelley, 28, is an illustrator. They have been best friends for six years.

Jessica

I envy the fact that Shelley is smaller-boned than me because while I'm not fat, I'm voluptuous. And when Shelley diets she becomes quite skinny whereas I look just the same. I love Shelley's lips and she's got a cute little nose. I tell her if something she's wearing doesn't suit her but I'm not being nasty - I just want her to look her best. We feel comfortable with each other's bodies. We're used to being naked together, it's not a problem for us.

Shelley

Jessica's got a lovely body and nice pert bosoms, not droopy like mine. I was a 38B when I was a teenager because I had so much puppy fat but then it just fell off. It took me a while to realise I wasn't plump any more. Men think Jessica is quite sexy - I think that's because she's so comfortable with her body and men like that. I feel much more confident about my body now than I used to and in fact our friendship has helped that. It's quite sisterly.

Seth Greenhill and Simon Greenhill

Brothers Seth, 30, a telesales consultant, and Simon, 35, a professional drummer, are the two halves of funk band the Bird Tribe.

Seth

We've got very similar looks and they reflect who we are as people: Simon is the taller older brother, I'm the slightly shorter younger brother. I could be a bit better built - when I was younger I had a body that could be blown away by the wind. I'd maybe consider cutting my hair but as musicians it's a powerful image to have us looking alike. It's been said we are two sides of the same coin - the same but always looking in opposite directions, which is true.

Simon

I like getting older, getting lines - I like the transition from a boyish face to a more masculine one. I like the way doing yoga tones my body, too. I'm the loud one with tattoos and piercings, Seth's the more down-to-earth one - sometimes I think he looks more like his day job than the person he really is. But there are enough differences in our characters and how we put ourselves across to prevent jealousy over image. The competitive stuff comes in our music.

fields.headline: Joining the dots
fields.standfirst: First came emailing and text messaging, then lifestyle sites. Now, finally, the fashion pack is catching on.  Namalee Bolle reports.
fields.trailText: First came emailing and text messaging, then lifestyle sites. Now, finally, the fashion pack is catching on. Namalee Bolle reports.
fields.body:
They may be at the forefront of style but when it comes to technology, many of those involved with fashion were until very recently lagging behind the rest of the net-savvy population. "Only last year I wouldn't even log on to the internet. In fact I didn't even know how to, or care. But I've become quite addicted lately," admitted a transformed stylist friend recently.

So what's changed? First email and text messaging proved that technological advances can be fun. Then a new generation of lifestyle sites, such as handbag.com, net-a-porter.com and charlottestreet.com appeared on the scene. Boo.com, the sportswear retailer, may have been a tad over-ambitious but by the time their financial crisis emerged, the quirky ad campaign had already scored credibility points with the fash pack. As did the fact that Bernault Arnault of LVMH is a shareholder in the company. And lastminute.com's Martha Lane Fox finally rid us of the outdated stereotype of a goggle-eyed computer nerd and replaced it with a young, style-conscious woman with enough cash to clear Bond Street and a name that wouldn't sound out of place heading a fashion house. Technophobia-wise, iMacs magically transformed computers from boring old grey boxes full of wires into luxury "must have" items. "Collect Them All" was the slogan that encouraged dedicated nouveau webbies determined to match that day's outfit to their monitor to do just that.

Once lured into logging on, the catwalk world went dotty about dot.com - after all, there's nothing the fashion world loves like a trend. You may be of the belief that polka dots are just another 50s revival, but it is almost certainly a nod to the net, if one shrouded in retro disguise - remember futurism is out this season.

Even more addictive than dotty dressing, however, are the webzines popping up by the nanosecond. We may have only just started appreciating them but fuk.co.uk (fashion uk) has already been online for five years and was one of the first to start exploiting the internet for its interactive capabilities with its "click and buy" fashion shoots.

Following hot on its kitten heels, though a mere nipper in comparison, fashionfile.com was launched in February. Set up by former model Zane O'Donnell, fashionfile.com has a similar no-nonsense approach to informative features and interviews, but has added a fashion production system designed to aid industry users. According to PR manager Cheryl Gordon: "Fashionfile.com acts as a nonstop portal for everything the industry needs, from viewing model portfolios, choosing photographers and stylists, to finding a location for a shoot, as well as being able to view the designer collections."

The launch of vogue.com planted a long-awaited virtual air kiss and provided the ultimate seal of approval, with the fashion bible saying "it's cool to surf". The ads were anything but subtle; a honey golden torso belonging to some delectable supermod on sexy, accident-inducing billboard posters. Everyone who reads magazines got the message: log on or lose out.

The image epitomises the fashion industry's decision to humanise the internet by making it appear less clinical and more people-friendly. "I think in essence fashion and the web might seem awkward bedfellows, fashion being a very tactile, emotional affair in shopping and a pleasurable fantasy in the context of a magazine. On the other hand, the web still suffers from a dry, bland image. The challenge in creating fashion websites is to make them sexy and fun. The vogue.com ads do this brilliantly; the chic transparency, nipples and, importantly, no model face recast the website, suggesting hot fashion, sexuality, sensuality and feminine allure," says Harriet Quick, Vogue's fashion features editor.

Elle.com, gq.com, nylon.com and wallpaper.com are among the many more who are using the web as an "extra" way to appeal to readers, providing aspects that print media cannot offer: chatboards, movies and constant updates. Want to see what plants are present in Condé Nast's reception? Click on the vogue.com webcam to find out. Scary but true, innovations like these are pulling in the audiences.

Even more frightening for the magazine industry is the possibility that webzines could eventually replace their collectable older sisters. Lee Carter, editor-in-chief of New York cooler-than-thou webzine hintmag.com disagrees. "I don't think the internet will put traditional fashion media out to pasture. There is room for both, but the readers appreciate the immediacy and interactivity sites like Hint have. Plus they're free."

Soon-to-be-launched, London-based thingis.com is all set to rock the socks off the fasherati. Art- directed by design group Tomato, better known for making pop videos and ultra-trendy graphics books, and with contributing writers from Sleazenation, Dazed and Confused, i-D and The Face, the gossip predicts that this is the one to watch. Taking e-commerce to new heights, thingis.com will also sell clothes by young British designers such as Robert Cary Williams, Boudicca and Russell Sage. "We will definitely have the edge over other e-commerce sites," editor James Anderson says. "And we are going to have a gossip section that will be even more salacious than hintmag.com's" (currently number one with the ever talked about libellous column Chic Happens). So get yourself connected and let the web wars commence.

fields.headline: End of an era, End of our tether and End of the waiting
fields.trailText: BLACKBURN OWNER WALKER DIES
fields.body:
BLACKBURN OWNER WALKER DIES

Jack Walker, the steel magnate who funded Blackburn's 1995 title-winning team, has died aged 71 after a long illness.

Walker took control of the club in 1991, when Blackburn were struggling in the old Second Division, but within four years they were Premiership champions. During his first three years, Walker spent £25m on new players, including the £3.5m signing of Alan Shearer from Southampton. He also transformed the ageing Ewood Park ground at a cost of more than £20m.

He was very much a hands-on chairman, regularly phoning his manager and players and travelling to every Rovers game, despite being based in Jersey. "He knew everyone right down to the bag man," said former Rovers defender Tony Gale after hearing the news. "Everyone interested him and Jack was known to everyone. He transformed the place into what it is today. The town and the club owe a great debt to him."

Even when Blackburn returned to the First Division, Walker's commitment to the Rovers cause did not diminish. "You have to get pleasure out of it," he said. "It has put Blackburn back on the up and shown that if you believe in things they can be done. If they don't win then I am bloody miserable on a Sunday."

ADVERTISEMENT: WIN £10,000 AND A TRIP TO THE BRAZILIAN CUP FINAL IN RIO

Think you know about football? Prove it and win with Fantasy League, home of the original fantasy football game. http://www.fantasyleague.com

BORING, BORING BRADFORD

Big transfer news involving Bradford used to be different and exciting. But now they spend so much money, it's just tedious. Spend, spend, spend. That's all Chris Hutchings seems to do! Well, we're sick of it. There's absolutely no way we're going to report the fact that Ashley Ward has completed a £1.5m transfer from Blackburn. Balls to that. Instead, let's give some space to some stuff we'd normally put in the News In Brief.

"Ipswich have just spent £4m on Wimbledon defender Hermann Hreidarsson. The Icelandic international will go straight into the team to face Spurs tomorrow." Heh! Not a mention of how the 29-year-old Ward completed his medical in time before the noon registration deadline. "Australia have confirmed that Leeds United's Harry Kewell, Mark Viduka and Danny Milosevic will be in their squad for next month's Olympic Games in Sydney." See? We don't care that Ward is likely to play alongside Benito Carbone against Liverpool tomorrow. At all.

"The Wales squad to play Belarus in Minsk on September 2 in the World Cup qualifying group five is as follows: P Jones (Southampton), Freestone (Swansea), Barnard (Barnsley), G Roberts (Tranmere), Coleman, Symons, Melville (all Fulham), Page (Watford), Delaney (Aston Villa), Speed (Newcastle), Pembridge (Everton), M Jones (Leeds), Savage (Leicester), Robinson (Charlton), Giggs (Man Utd), Blake (Blackburn), Hartson (Wimbledon), Bellamy (Coventry), Saunders (Bradford), I Roberts (Norwich)." Did you see that? There wasn't even any room for a quote from Geoffrey Richmond. Ha! Ha! Ha!

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"If I am not given the same status Laurent Blanc has enjoyed in the national team over the last four years, by which I mean an automatic place in the side, I will retire. I am totally clear about it. There is absolutely no ambiguity" - He's smooth, he's charming, he's Frank Leboeuf.

LOOK INTO OUR BALLS

This time last season, the Fiver looked into its crystal ball. Inside we found the usual wintertime scene, complete with life-like plastic snowflakes. This in some way explains why our resulting predictions were so far out. We forecast that Leeds would perform poorly (not quite), that Liverpool would take the Premiership by storm (well, almost) and that Dagenham Davor Suker would be chased out of the country by the tabloids (God only knows where we got that from). We also tipped Ruud Gullit to be the first manager out of a job, but that's by the by. Basically, the point is that while you can read this year's predictions, and maybe even enjoy them, it wouldn't be wise to put any money down. So here goes...

THE FIRST MANAGER TO LOSE HIS JOB WILL BE... John Gregory. It's a shocker, we know, but there's nothing we can do about it. You see, once Villa lose their opening three games to Leicester, Chelsea and Liverpool, Gareth Southgate and Ugo Ehiogu will insist on playing crab football for the remainder of the season. Luc Nilis will retire through injury and Greg's 15 defensive midfielders will end up killing each other in a fight to make the first team. By this point Darling Doug Ellis will have no choice but wait another few months and then sack him.

THE SURPRISE HIT OF THE YEAR WILL BE... Tottenham Hotspur. They rely too much on the performance of one man. The fans aren't totally behind the manager. The defence is almost totally populated by ex-Wimbledon players. Steffan Freund prowls the midfield. All in all, from where we're standing, it's not looking good. Fifth place, then.

THE SURPRISE FLOP OF THE YEAR WILL BE... Manchester United. Oh go on. Please.

THE FIRST FOREIGNER TO INCUR TABLOID WRATH (WHO IS NOT FRANK LEBOEUF) WILL BE... Linda Evangelista. This will happen the minute Fabien Barthez has a bad game, as some fat old hack plays cherchez la femme. (cf. Victoria Beckham and hubby)

THE NEW CRAZE WILL BE... Hoping one of the minnows get relegated. Why pretend to like the small clubs? Pick one team from Ipswich, Bradford or Charlton and guffaw loudly as, during the first couple of weeks of the season, they nick a 1-0 win at Anfield or Stamford Bridge. Then get mightily irritated as the goal is repeated every single time they're featured on Football Focus. Laugh like a drain when they get relegated unluckily on the last minute of the last day of the season - you'll never have to see that shoddy goalmouth scramble again!

THE RUMOUR MILL

Henning Berg has expressed an interest in moving to Celtic from Manchester United. "Officially, I haven't heard of any contact by Celtic but there might have been while I've been away [with Norway on international duty]," Berg said. "Celtic are a massive club and I think most players would be interested."

Blackburn are leading the £1m chase for Maccabi Haifa defender Arik Benado.

NEWS IN BRIEF

John Beresford, the Southampton defender, has been forced to quit the game after failing to recover from a serious knee injury. "It's just one of those things that happen in football," said a philosophical Beresford. "It's a weird feeling knowing I will never play again, but I cannot complain as I have had a good career."

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Sky Sports 3: First Division Football - Live: Birmingham v Fulham (7pm)

Grrr! We could tell you a story or two about our run-ins with Trevor Francis

Sky Sports 1: Hold the Back Page (11.30pm)

but leave cuddly old Woolnough alone. We're so close we even shop for hair lacquer together.

British Eurosport: Football (1am)
And anyone interested in Brian's special revitalising shampoo (with a blend of luxury essential oils including maritime pine, anise, verveine and limette) can contact us at the usual address.

Inside we found the usual wintertime scene, complete with life-like plastic snowflakes. This in some way explains why our resulting predictions were so far out. We forecast that Leeds would perform poorly (not quite), that Liverpool would take the Premiership by storm (well, almost) and that Dagenham Davor Suker would be chased out of the country by the tabloids (God only knows where we got that from). We also tipped Ruud Gullit to be the first manager out of a job, but that's by the by. Basically, the point is that while you can read this year's predictions, and maybe even enjoy them, it wouldn't be wise to put any money down. So here goes... THE FIRST MANAGER TO LOSE HIS JOB WILL BE... John Gregory. It's a shocker, we know, but there's nothing we can do about it. You see, once Villa lose their opening three games to Leicester, Chelsea and Liverpool, Gareth Southgate and Ugo Ehiogu will insist on playing crab football for the remainder of the season. Luc Nilis will retire through injury and Greg's 15 defensive midfielders will end up killing each other in a fight to make the first team. By this point Darling Doug Ellis will have no choice but wait another few months and then sack him. THE SURPRISE HIT OF THE YEAR WILL BE... Tottenham Hotspur. They rely too much on the performance of one man. The fans aren't totally behind the manager. The defence is almost totally populated by ex-Wimbledon players. Steffan Freund prowls the midfield. All in all, from where we're standing, it's not looking good. Fifth place, then. THE SURPRISE FLOP OF THE YEAR WILL BE... Manchester United. Oh go on. Please. THE FIRST FOREIGNER TO INCUR TABLOID WRATH (WHO IS NOT FRANK LEBOEUF) WILL BE... Linda Evangelista. This will happen the minute Fabien Barthez has a bad game, as some fat old hack plays cherchez la femme. (cf. Victoria Beckham and hubby) THE NEW CRAZE WILL BE... Hoping one of the minnows get relegated. Why pretend to like the small clubs? Pick one team from Ipswich, Bradford or Charlton and guffaw loudly as, during the first couple of weeks of the season, they nick a 1-0 win at Anfield or Stamford Bridge. Then get mightily irritated as the goal is repeated every single time they're featured on Football Focus. Laugh like a drain when they get relegated unluckily on the last minute of the last day of the season - you'll never have to see that shoddy goalmouth scramble again! THE RUMOUR MILL Henning Berg has expressed an interest in moving to Celtic from Manchester United. "Officially, I haven't heard of any contact by Celtic but there might have been while I've been away [with Norway on international duty]," Berg said. "Celtic are a massive club and I think most players would be interested." Blackburn are leading the £1m chase for Maccabi Haifa defender Arik Benado. NEWS IN BRIEF John Beresford, the Southampton defender, has been forced to quit the game after failing to recover from a serious knee injury. "It's just one of those things that happen in football," said a philosophical Beresford. "It's a weird feeling knowing I will never play again, but I cannot complain as I have had a good career." TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO Sky Sports 3: First Division Football - Live: Birmingham v Fulham (7pm) Grrr! We could tell you a story or two about our run-ins with Trevor Francis Sky Sports 1: Hold the Back Page (11.30pm) but leave cuddly old Woolnough alone. We're so close we even shop for hair lacquer together. British Eurosport: Football (1am) And anyone interested in Brian's special revitalising shampoo (with a blend of luxury essential oils including maritime pine, anise, verveine and limette) can contact us at the usual address.

webTitle: Labour must grasp the nettle and redistribute wealth

fields.headline: Labour must grasp the nettle and redistribute wealth
fields.standfirst: Former civil service chief Sir Peter Kemp casts his eye over our proposals for tackling inequality.
fields.trailText: Sir Peter Kemp: The former civil service chief casts his eye over our proposals for tackling inequality.
fields.body:
The sharing of wealth between workers and non-workers is one of the most contentious issues there is.

A white paper launched by Barbara Castle 30 years ago proposed an overt attack on inequalities with a shift in wealth from the haves to the have-nots. This would work, Mrs Castle said, because the high rate of economic growth meant that the wealthier members of society would not notice the redistributive measures, and also because richer people supported the policy. She was, alas, wrong on both scores.

But the manifesto could grasp this nettle. Economic growth is with us and, with care, looks like it will remain. And in general, the attitudes of the haves are a lot less brutal than they once were.

So the manifesto's proposals have to repeat Ms Castle's aim. Not just repeat it; but lay out precisely how it is to be achieved, including the sharing of responsibility between state and private provision.

Apart from one or two successes, welfare reform has on the whole been one of the great failures of the Labour government's first term.

The government could have increased or reduced the £100bn per annum being spent on welfare reform. In its second term Labour must take a view on this issue. It must also make clearer what its overall policy is.

The manifesto is right to reject universal benefits, but this has to be spelled out. The government did a pretty disastrous job in selling its 75p increase in pensions, and needs to do better.

It must be right to allow more across-the-board money for the poorest members of society, whether they are out of work, disabled or receiving a state pension. And the administrative machinery - assuming that the government can make the computers work - is there to make it happen.

One might have some doubts about resurrecting the earnings-link, but some other formula, beyond simply a prices link, could be devised. Any changes must be sustainable continuity must be promised.

Expanding the Sure Start scheme will be workable and inexpensive. Equally, it would be right both in social terms and for the purposes of administration, to revise the rules of the Social Fund to make grants rather than loans the norm.

The rules need to be simplified and the government should show a thick skin when accused of aiding the inevitable, but hopefully few, "scroungers".

Tackling inequality is where we came in. And it's not just a matter of changes to the benefit system, but much else, including the tax system.

Policy strategists and administrators in the Department of Social Security, the Benefits Agency and the Inland Revenue must work closer together. The manifesto should promise some real thinking here, going beyond the sort of half-baked "task force" ideas we have seen so far.

fields.headline: Flooz flirts with British launch
fields.standfirst:
US gift voucher service talks to Harrods and Tower Records

Net news

Special report: e-finance

Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: Flooz.com, the online gift voucher company, is planning to launch in Britain after talking with some 15 retailers in the UK, including Harrods and Tower Records.
fields.body:
Flooz.com, the online gift voucher company, is planning to launch in Britain after talking with some 15 retailers in the UK, including Harrods and Tower Records.

The planned launch of Flooz.co.uk reflects the continuing ambitions of online payment companies in the US.

A number of firms are fighting a crisis of confidence among e-commerce investors as well as doubts about the viability of their systems to offer payment alternatives to credit cards online.

Flooz.com, launched with an advertising blitz featuring Whoopi Goldberg, who is also a shareholder and one of the sector's best-known names.

The firm markets itself as a virtual gift service at which customers buy "credit" from the website using a credit card and send it to someone else via email. The recipient of the gift, or "stored value" in industry parlance, can spend it with more than 60 online retailers.

British consumers can already shop at a handful of British companies, such as Whittards of Chelsea and Thomas Pink, using credit denominated in pounds rather than dollars. The launch of a British service next year will allow them to use their accounts at many more locations.

Robert Levitan, chief executive of the New York-based company, admits that it has reined in its original international ambitions.

"We were on a faster track and then we decided to stop and take the right partners," he said. "We want to do it properly, and we don't want to be the arrogant Americans who think we know it all."

As well as negotiating with retailers, the company is also talking to distributors and prospective employees. The cost of the entire venture will run into several million dollars.

Analysts are sceptical about the future for online payment systems, in spite of the signs of caution. James van Dyke, a senior analyst at Jupiter Communications, said: "There have been several so-called stored value currencies which have tried to make a go of it over the years - and it has been a tough ride. It's a momentous thing to change payment behaviour."

Mr van Dyke and other analysts refer to a roster of companies forced in the past to retreat from ambitious plans to offer incentive-based, or promotional, currencies.

At the beginning of the internet frenzy companies such as DigiCash, CyberCash and First Virtual Holdings all introduced online incentive-based currencies with limited success.

The internet gold rush encouraged other companies to set up online-based currencies in spite of these failures. Beenz.com already offers an international online currency, while Webcertificates.com, Netcentives.com and MyPoints.com all compete in the same space. Jomono.com is Britain's version of Flooz.com.

"If the goal was to become a standard currency on the internet, none of them have been successful," said Mr van Dyke

The difficulty of establishing a trading currency is not new. The historic nature of incentive programmes was given a new twist last month when Netcentives, a Nasdaq-listed company, teamed up with the Sperry and Hutchinson company, the original purveyor of offline rewards.

S&H Greenpoints.com is the web version of a company which began operations more than 100 years ago before running into financial difficulties during the 1980s.

Mr Levitan, a 38-year-old who also co-founded iVillage, the online site for women, is unfazed by the industry's lack of obvious success to date. "We will succeed if we are the best way to give and receive a gift online," he said.

More than 600,000 people have sent or received Flooz vouchers worth about $5m so far. The private firm, which is still not profitable, is keen to expand its corporate client base, which provides about half of its sales. The idea is for clients such as Cisco Systems and Eastman Kodak to give their employees Flooz credit to spend as an incentive rather than simply putting more money in their wage packet.

Mr Levitan also believes that the companies could work together, as they trade in slightly different currencies. When he talks of Jomono, for example, he says: "They could be a competitor or a partner. It's really too early to tell."

webTitle: New York gears up for 'mouth v magnate'

fields.headline: New York gears up for 'mouth v magnate'
fields.trailText: It has been billed as the mouth versus the magnate. Reverend Al Sharpton, one of America's most vocal black leaders, is on a collision course with media mogul Rupert Murdoch after the businessman swooped on a television network.
fields.body:
It has been billed as the mouth versus the magnate. Reverend Al Sharpton, one of America's most vocal black leaders, is on a collision course with media mogul Rupert Murdoch after the businessman swooped on a television network.

Mr Sharpton believes that the deal, a $5.4bn (£3.6bn) bid for Chris-Craft, would concentrate too much power in Mr Murdoch's hands especially in Mr Sharpton's stomping ground of New York, where the group would own two television stations as well as the New York Post, the daily tabloid newspaper.

Mr Sharpton said he was confident of stopping News Corporation from exerting "undue and undemocratic political influence" in the United States. If it succeeds in the proposed bid for Chris-Craft, News Corp would own 32 television stations in America, making it one of the largest owners in the country.

In New York, no single company should own both a television station and a newspaper in any single market. News Corp won a regulatory waiver when it bought the Post in 1993 because the paper was almost bankrupt. The company has suggested it expects this waiver to be extended.

The black activist leader of the National Action Network called for a meeting with the Federal Communications Commission in Washington this week. He said the regulator should take the opportunity to encourage the non-existent black ownership in New York and Salt Lake City.

"They should use this to work towards their goal of minority ownership."

The FCC declined to comment on the merger yesterday as the deal has not yet been submitted to its offices. The acquisition is expected to provide the first real test of a rule introduced last year to allow duopolies to exist under certain market conditions.

webTitle: Big Brother: Come back Nick, all is forgiven

fields.headline: Come back Nick, all is forgiven
fields.standfirst: As programme-makers line up a replacement for the evicted "Nasty" Nick Bateman, bereft viewer Jason Deans comes up with a few suggestions
fields.trailText: As programme-makers line up a replacement for the evicted "Nasty" Nick Bateman, bereft viewer Jason Deans comes up with a few suggestions.
fields.body:
How on earth can the makers of Channel 4's voyeurfest Big Brother ever fill the void left by the eviction of Nick Bateman? After all, central casting could not have come up with a more compelling mix of JR and Dirty Den than the Big Brother selection process that produced "Nasty" Nick.

Nick begins facing the media music with a press conference in central London this afternoon. But the talk around office water-coolers up and down the land has already turned to the burning question - just who will replace him in the Big Brother house? And what traits should the show's producers be looking for in the new recruit to the real-life TV soap?

The official line is that Nick's replacement will join the other contestants "at some point over the weekend" - though last night Big Brother told Craig that it would be tomorrow. The new arrival at the house of two-way mirrors will be drawn from a reserve list of around 20 people who have been standing by for this eventuality.

The replacement media lab-rat will have to sign a confidentiality agreement promising not to discuss anything that has been going on in the outside world with the Big Brother housemates. The other contestants, in turn, will not be allowed to question the new arrival. But in practice it is difficult to see how the show's producers can police this news blackout.

Big Brother's makers know that the new recruit will be at a disadvantage, joining a close-knit group that has been drawn even close together by the confrontation with Nick. They are also likely to be less popular with the public than the long-term Big Brother inmates, whom viewers have had 35 days to get to know. So the replacement will not be able to vote, or be voted out, in the eviction poll for his or her first week.

Meanwhile, the controversial decision to go ahead with the weekly eviction as planned means that Nichola or Craig will be voted out of the Big Brother house by viewers tonight. The consensus in the Guardian Unlimited office is that Craig is likely to escape Davina McCall's clutches, after the way he acquitted himself during the showdown with Nick yesterday.

When it came to suggestions for Nick's replacement, Steve from Guardian Unlimited's commercial department put himself forward, claiming not have followed Big Brother (impossible to believe for a media type), and because he was "incredibly competitive, but also good at sob stories". He also fancied losing some weight.

Another suggestion was somebody just released from prison, who would not be aware of the media hullabaloo surrounding Big Brother and could slip easily into the role of the show's villain.

Popular potential celebrity recruits to Big Brother house included Changing Rooms' Laurence Llewelyn-Bowen (could help spruce the place up), Ground Force's Charlie Dimmock (good with the garden) and Ben Fogle from Castaway 2000 (useful prior experience, dishy). Steve also suggests the Manchester United captain, Roy Keane. "He's a celebrity, he's mad and he's got some spare time on his hands what with that three-match ban for being sent off in the Charity Shield".

webTitle: Chinese director bows to the censors

fields.headline: Chinese director bows to the censors
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText: The Chinese film Devils on the Doorstep was withdrawn from the Edinburgh film festival last night amid fears of a new climate of censorship in Beijing.
fields.body:
The Chinese film Devils on the Doorstep was withdrawn from the Edinburgh film festival last night amid fears of a new climate of censorship in Beijing.

The spectacular epic, set during the brutal Japanese occupation of northern China during the second world war, won the Grand Prix at Cannes in May. It was shown without the permission of the Chinese authorities.

Jiang, a hugely powerful star in mainland China, was reportedly banned from making films for seven years last month but had tried to ignore the sanction, as he had a previous one for acting in Zhang Yimou's Red Sorghum.

But with shooting due to begin on his new film, The Story of Xu San-Guan the Blood Seller, about a man who sells his blood to survive, it appears that Jiang has been forced to compromise.

Wouter Barendrecht, his European representative, said Jiang was now cutting Devils on the Doorstep. "He has informed us that his new version with be approximately 23 minutes shorter. Unfortunately he is behind schedule due to the sensitive nature of the discussions the producers have been having with the Chinese government."

The statement, released yesterday, is in stark contrast to his defiance of the authorities during Cannes and his fighting talking only weeks ago when he said: "The film shows that people must express their feelings frankly and openly, instead of bottling them up inside while smiling and nodding."

China has been opening up its cinemas to foreign films, with Hollywood's summer blockbusters, The Patriot and The Perfect Storm, showing there this month.

Many observers believe Jiang has been a victim of bureaucrats whose role has been diminished by the new openness.

Their chief objections to the film are that the Japanese are shown to be too powerful and that "turtle fucker" - a Chinese term of abuse - is over-used.

A spokeswoman for the Edinburgh film festival expressed disappointment at the news but was reluctant to comment fearing it would make Jiang's situation more difficult.

fields.headline: Love, etc by Julian Barnes
fields.standfirst: Stuart, Oliver and Gillian still fail to relate to one another 10 years after they were introduced in Talking it Over
fields.trailText: Stuart, Oliver and Gillian still fail to relate to one another 10 years after they were introduced in Talking it Over
fields.body:
Stuart: Hello. We've met before. Remember? I remember you.

Oliver: Oh, I remember you. How very Stuartesque. I can tell you remember me.

Gillian: You may or you may not remember me.

Stuart: Here's the story so far. Gillian and I fell in love, we got married and my best friend, Oliver, stole her off me. He hit her, I went to America, got married, became successful, got divorced (again) and came back to England where I've set up an organic veg business.

Oliver: Rush not to judgment.

Gillian: I knew Stuart was watching, so I made Oliver hit me. To drive Stuart away. It's tough for Oliver now. I'm the one with the job and the money. He's still waiting for things to happen.

Oliver: Guess who phoned last night? Narcoleptic and steatopygous Stuart. Misprise me not, I'm curious. He could also fund my scriptwriting.

Gillian: I just knew Stuart had phoned. Don't ask me how. Did I tell you that Oliver and I rarely have sex these days?

Stuart: I offered to take them out, but they couldn't afford a babysitter. Oliver patronised my choice of wine; Gillian had made a delicious lasagne.

Gillian: I'd forgotten how thoughtful Stuart is. I also burnt the lasagne.

Oliver: It all went swimmingly.

Stuart: My plan is to move them all back into a house I own. And give Oliver a job driving a van.

Gillian: It's the house Stuart and I used to live in.

Stuart: Gillian told me Oliver had a breakdown after his father died.

Gillian: Do you think I'm deliberately evading things? Oliver's become withdrawn again but the house is quite nice and the kids love it.

fields.headline: Southampton
fields.trailText: After a couple of years - alright, ten - of scrabbling around the relegation zone, this could finally be time for Southampton to enjoy a comfortable season in mid-table.
fields.body:
After a couple of years - alright, ten - of scrabbling around the relegation zone, this could finally be time for Southampton to enjoy a comfortable season in mid-table.

OK, so in the current climate it doesn't auger well that they've only spent £1.5m all summer, and that on a player who couldn't even get in the Aston Villa midfield. But an older and wiser Glenn Hoddle knows he doesn't have to splash the cash; by the end of last season, he'd already steadied a perennially rocking ship.

That may come as a surprise to folk who only remember the high-profile humiliations at Newcastle (0-5) and Spurs (2-7), but Hoddle can point to his team's performances at Old Trafford, Stamford Bridge and Anfield - three drawn matches, three moral victories.

Hoddle's tactics played a big part in those games - you couldn't take too much for granted with a defence containing Claus Lundekvam, Francis Benali and Jason Dodd. But a traditionally generous back line may tighten up this year: teenage left-back Wayne Bridge looks like an England international in the making, Dean Richards could walk into most Premiership defences, and Tahar El Khalej has received good notices ever since a nightmare debut at Spurs.

Things look up in midfield as well. Mark Draper will keep the midfield ticking over, which should be the catalyst for James Beattie and Matthew Oakley to finally show what they can do on a regular basis. If the under-rated Jo Tessem keeps turning in the sort of goalscoring performances he did last season, Saints could be very easy on the eye.

And they won't be short of goals either. Marian Pahars, once billed as the poor man's answer to Michael Owen, is now proving to be more dependable than the Liverpool front man. While Owen has spent the last couple of seasons failing to live up to his billing, Pahars is quietly terrorising Premiership defences with his searing pace and level-headed finishing.

His strike partner Kevin Davies will start chipping in as well. A few solid displays in the second half of last season silenced the bellows of laughter generated by the powerful forward's disastrous spell at Ewood Park, and his early promise could be realised this season.

With Uwe Rosler, Hassan Kachloul and Stuart Ripley also up for selection - Patrice Tano, billed as the new Vieira, is one for the future - Hoddle should preside over a solid campaign. If only they had a genius supersub to rely upon when things don't go well...

In: Mark Draper (Aston Villa, £1.5m), Uwe Rosler (Borussia Berlin, free), Patrice Tano (Monaco, free).

Odds: 500-1

Football Unlimited writers' prediction: 13th

fields.headline: The pill: 40 years on
fields.trailText: The contraceptive pill, credited with sparking a sexual revolution and blamed by some for creating a more promiscuous  society, was celebrating its 40th anniversary today.
fields.body:
The contraceptive pill, credited with sparking a sexual revolution and blamed by some for creating a more promiscuous society, was celebrating its 40th anniversary today.

On August 18 1960, women in the US were the first in the world to be able to take Enovid-10, the first make of oral contraception.

The pill was not made available in the UK until the following year, but now more than 3.5m women in this country take it.

A major scare surrounding the pill erupted in 1995, when research suggested that women taking the newest, third-generation oral contraceptives had an increased risk of developing potentially fatal blood clots. Thousands of women instantly stopped taking their pills, and the scare resulted in an extra 20,000 pregnancies and 10,000 abortions over the following nine months.

A spokeswoman for the Family Planning Association said: "The introduction of the pill 40 years ago was a very important step forward for women.

"It gave them the opportunity to control their fertility and make informed choices about their lives.

"Over the years there have been many developments in contraception and today there are 13 different methods available in the UK.

"The pill remains an extremely safe and highly effective method when appropriately prescribed and used."

webTitle: Russian rescue capsule reaches sub, but fails to link up

fields.headline: Russian rescue capsule reaches sub, but fails to link up
fields.trailText: A rescue capsule reached one of the escape hatches on a sunken Russian nuclear submarine for the first time today, but was unable to gain access because it was so badly damaged, a navy official said.
fields.body:
A rescue capsule reached one of the escape hatches on a sunken Russian nuclear submarine for the first time today, but was unable to gain access because it was so badly damaged, a navy official said.

The Russian rescue craft returned to the surface after repeated attempts failed, said navy spokesman Captain Igor Babenko. A larger escape capsule took over and was trying to link up with the hatch, he said.

Four Russian rescue capsules have been trying since Tuesday to reach the 118 men aboard the shattered hulk of the Kursk submarine, lying 108 metres (350 feet) below the surface. Powerful currents and poor visibility have repeatedly beaten the capsules back. The submarine is also leaning at a sharp angle.

One finally managed to reach one of the Kursk's two escape hatches today, but was unable to latch on to it with a special mechanism designed to establish an airtight connection, said Babenko.

The grabbing device could not get hold of the hatch; because it was badly damaged, he said.

The capsules were having better success as the weather in the rescue area improved today, making it easier for them to manoeuvre, navy officers said. But one had to make an emergency ascent after suffering mechanical problems, Russia's RTR television said.

Navy officials said earlier there was no sign of life on the submarine, which went down six days ago during major naval exercises in the Barents Sea.

Underwater inspections of the Kursk show massive damage reaching from the bow to the conning tower, which was much more extensive than earlier thought, officials said.

Deputy Prime Minister Ilya Klebanov, the head of a government commission that reviewed the rescue effort on Thursday, said there was a "terrifying hole on the starboard side of the submarine.

"A rather big part of the crew was in the part of the boat that was hit by the catastrophe that developed at lightning speed," Klebanov told reporters in Murmansk, home of the Russian Northern Fleet.

"There have been no sounds for quite a long time; from within the Kursk," he added.

Both Klebanov and the Navy commander, Admiral Vladimir Kuroyedov, have said that any survivors were expected to run out of oxygen today, but other high-ranking naval officers have given them until next week.

British and Norwegian rescue teams were not expected to reach the site until Saturday at the earliest, after Russia initially resisted accepting western aid. A British navy team with a sophisticated rescue submarine was heading to the area on a ship.

President Vladimir Putin abruptly returned to Moscow earlier today after criticism of his decision to stay on vacation when news of the disaster broke. He said he did not fly to the rescue site because "the arrival of non-specialists and high-ranking officials to the scene of disaster does not help, but usually interferes," the Interfax news agency reported.

Russian officials have not determined how the Kursk got into trouble on August 12. Officials have offered various explanations, including a collision, an internal explosion or even contact with a second world war mine.

Klebanov said evidence suggested the submarine hit an unspecified "huge, heavy object; about 20 metres (66 feet) below surface and plunged to the sea bottom in seconds".

But officials could not explain how a highly sophisticated submarine could crash into a large object. Submarines use radar and other guiding devices that allow them to spot objects many miles away under water.
