webTitle: Why the 'rules' of racism are different for Arabs

fields.headline: Why the 'rules' of racism are different for Arabs
fields.standfirst: Arabs are the only really vicious racial stereotypes still considered acceptable in Hollywood, writes Middle East editor Brian Whitaker
fields.trailText: Arabs are the only really vicious racial stereotypes still considered acceptable in Hollywood, writes Middle East editor Brian Whitaker
fields.body:
"Stop it, you dirty little Arab!" My grandmother always used to say that when I did something disgusting, like picking my nose or flicking food at my younger brother.

It was a long time ago, of course. In those days children were taught rhymes like "Ten Little Nigger Boys" and recited them to admiring aunties.

We have certainly come a long way since then. Oddly, though - and I have noticed this particularly since starting to write about the Middle East for the Guardian - there are people who seem happy to talk about Arabs in terms that they would never use when talking about black people. It doesn't occur to them that this is racist.

Last week, Rules of Engagement, a film about a siege at the American embassy in Yemen, arrived in Britain after earning millions of dollars in the United States. It has been described as the most racist film ever made against Arabs by Hollywood.

The Arab characters - in this case, Yemenis - are, without exception, portrayed as deceitful, bloodthirsty fanatics. The "hero", an American Marines colonel, massacres 83 of them, and the film suggests that this sort of thing is justified for the greater good of America.

Interestingly, though, the heroic colonel is played by a black actor (Samuel L Jackson) who appears totally integrated into American society. Nobody mentions his colour or appears to treat him differently because of it. In that respect only, the film is less racist than many others. Since Rules of Engagement was released, several critics have observed that Arabs are the only really vicious racial stereotypes still considered acceptable in Hollywood.

Possibly these complaints are an over-reaction to what, after all, is a film-maker's fantasy rather than the reality. But perhaps not.

On the day that Rules of Engagement arrived in Britain, the National Transportation Safety Board in Washington issued its first report on the crash of EgyptAir flight 990 off Nantucket last October.

What should have been a methodical, scientific, investigation has turned into a highly charged clash of cultures between Egypt and the USA.

As the plane fell from the sky, the co-pilot repeated an Arabic phrase, "tawakilt 'ala Allah" (I rely on God). This phrase, picked up by the cockpit voice recorder, was leaked to the American media, who variously described it as "a prayer" or a "chant", fuelling the theory that the co-pilot was an Islamic fundamentalist who had deliberately crashed the plane.

The Egyptians were furious and pointed out that the phrase is routinely used by Muslims, not just fundamentalists, when facing difficult situations. They accused the American investigators of making the co-pilot a scapegoat, and being reluctant to explore the possibility of a mechanical failure in the American-built Boeing 767.

It certainly looked like an attempt to fit the co-pilot into Hollywood's current stereotype of the fanatical Arab, but it didn't wash. When the suicide theory began to look improbable, the investigators re-moulded the co-pilot to fit a much earlier Hollywood stereotype played by Rudolph Valentino in the 1920s - the over-sexed Arab.

The FBI came up with statements from staff at the hotel used by EgyptAir crews in New York saying that the co-pilot was noted for sexually harassing chambermaids and had once exposed himself through the hotel window. Again, these allegations were leaked to the press.

This, apparently, was meant to imply that the co-pilot had an unstable personality and should not have been allowed to fly. Questioning the relevance of the FBI statements at a Washington press conference last week, an Egyptian journalist asked whether, if that kind of behaviour made someone unfit to control a plane, it did not also make the US president Bill Clinton unfit to control nuclear weapons.

Nobody seems quite sure why anti-Arab racism is considered acceptable when other forms of racism aren't. Some suggest that the political role played by the west in the Middle East helps to legitimise the stereotypes of popular culture, which in turn reinforce government policies.

But I think attitudes to Islam may also be part of the problem. People in the west often assume that Arabs are Muslims (and sometimes vice versa). Hostility towards Islam - mostly based on ignorance - can mean hostility towards Arabs. So perhaps anti-Arabism is not rooted in racial prejudice but religious prejudice. Either way, it's still prejudice.

Readers who have further explanations or suggestions on this topic are welcome to contact me by email: brian.whitaker@theguardian.com.

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Kidnapped Indian movie star may be released next week, John Peel to make film debut, Dreyfuss shoots from the hip over censorship, comic book bandwagon gathers speed and Scary Movie sequel on the way
fields.body:
 An Indian bandit who kidnapped the movie star Rajkumar 17 days ago is expected to release the film actor next week, according to Yahoo news. Rajkumar, a veteran of 210 films, whose kidnap from a remote farm on July 30 provoked rioting in the streets of southern India, was said to be safe and well and being treated 'like a brother' by Veerappan - India's most wanted outlaw (see our earlier story). Last week, Veerappan issued a list of 10 political demands, including the release of 51 prisoners who are in jail on charges of helping the 56-year-old bandit evade capture for over two decades. A senior government official told reporters on Wednesday: "It [the release] should happen sometime next week... our emissary will go back to the jungles today with our detailed responses to Veerappan's demands."

 John Peel is to make his film acting debut in a movie about a young musician who goes to London to further his career but becomes a witness to murder. Entitled Five Seconds to Spare, the film stars Max Beesley, Ray Winstone and Sean Pertwee The 60-year-old broadcaster said of his role: "I play a grumpy old man who spends his whole life filing records. How on earth they thought of me, I don't know." The film is due for release later this year.

 Richard Dreyfuss has hit back at vice-presidential candidate Joe Lieberman's claim that legal restrictions should be placed on Hollywood because it is a corrupting influence on US citizens. Dreyfuss's response to Lieberman's point that there was too much sex and violence in Hollywood films hardly helped his case: "If anyone was talking about legislating something and restricting Hollywood, I would probably reach for my nearest Colt 45," he retorted.

 After the huge success in the US of The X-Men (released here today), another comic book is set to get some of that big screen magic, according to Variety. Rising Stars is the story of a group of people who assume special powers when a fireball hits their town. MGM have bought the rights for an estimated $1m and original creator J Michael Straczynski is expected to write the script for the film. Talking about the comic he said, "what I tried to do with this story was take all the cliches of comic books and turn them on their heads."

 The surprise US success of the summer - the spoof horror film Scary Movie (released here September 8) - already has a sequel lined up which is to go into production this autumn, according to CHUD website. The hit parody made over $144m domestically - more than seven times its budget of $7m - making it Miramax's highest grossing film ever. The sequel is scheduled to be released in America in May 2001.

webTitle: Barmy Army gets ready for Pakistan

fields.headline: Barmy Army gets ready for Pakistan
fields.standfirst: In the latest instalment of wisden.com's gossip column, Charles de Lisle goes behind the scenes to find out how England's best-known set of fans is preparing for Pakistan, and explains why the county loan system (remember that?) has been a complete flop
fields.trailText: Thirsty Barmies prepare for their first "dry" tour
fields.body:
Thirsty Barmies prepare for their first "dry" tour

England's visit to Pakistan this autumn won't just be their first tour of the country in 13 years. It will also be the first time the Barmy Army has travelled to Asia. England's most passionate and boisterous supporters will be visiting a country which is hardly an obvious destination for them. There will be few of the opportunities to hit the beach, hit the bottle and pair off with local women which have been a major feature of their recent excursions to cheer on England in Australia and South Africa.

Burnham concedes that the organisation will not, this time, have the numbers to make its presence at grounds felt the way it has in Sydney, Cape Town and Barbados. But a "hard core" of 25-30 supporters will be there, at least for some of the three Tests, and will be running through their usual patriotic routines. And how will the Barmy Army manage without alcohol? "I don't know," he replies. "It'll probably be a very quiet tour."

The Barmies, however, are trying to turn the alleged deprivations of a Pakistan tour to their advantage. They have commissioned a special T-shirt for the trip. It originally showed a small cartoon character peaking over a wall, with two bubbles. One said: "What, no booze!" The other asked: "Has anyone seen my mother-in-law?" - a reference to an infamous remark made by Ian Botham. "Pakistan," he declared after returning home early from the 1983-84 tour, "is the kind of place to send your mother-in-law for a month, all expenses paid."

But the host nation had the last word. When Botham, opening for England in the 1992 World Cup final in Melbourne, was given out for nought, he departed to taunts from Pakistan fielders of: "Why don't you send in your mother-in-law now? She couldn't do any worse!"

Bearing in mind the risk of such retaliation, even the Army has now thought better of the planned T-shirt. Burnham and his fellow "generals" have just decided to abandon the mother-in-law reference, and have the T-shirt redesigned solely around the no-booze theme. "We thought the mother-in-law business was quite a funny joke," Burnham said yesterday. "We now realise it's as sensitive an issue in Pakistan as Shakoor Rana."

The U-turn is not the first sign that the Army is at last acquiring a few diplomatic skills: a reference to Rana, the former umpire whose stand-off with England captain Mike Gatting in the Faisalabad Test on the 1987-88 trip was a major reason for the 13-year hiatus, was dropped from the official kit at an early stage. But that festering wound will still be reopened during the tour. "We'll probably have a song about him as we go along," said Burnham. "We'd like to test the water."

Promising young county players suffer as loan system flops

One innovation in this English season of unprecedented change can already be judged a complete flop. The new football-style system allowing counties to loan players to one another has quite failed to catch the imagination. If it had taken off, Devon Malcolm, Northamptonshire's 37-year-old former England bowler, would now be sharing the new ball with Kent's David Master. But, as Bob Carter, Northamptonshire's director of cricket, explains: "We wanted Dev as back-up in case of injury problems."

Not one of the 400-odd registered players has been borrowed by another county, and it's now too late for any such deals to be struck. "We haven't had any takers," confirms the ECB. Carter is blunter: "It hasn't worked, has it?"

The scheme made sense in theory. The idea was that, particularly in the last six or seven weeks of the season, promising players languishing in county second XIs would be given opportunities to sharpen their game in somebody else's first team - maybe that of a club stricken with a run of injuries. "We were very supportive," says a senior official of the Professional Cricketers' Association. "Previously, a young player could fall out of favour halfway through the season - and his season was effectively over."

The new system came with appropriate strings attached: only in exceptional circumstances would players aged 25 or over be allowed to turn out for a rival county; and no player on loan would be allowed to play in the Benson & Hedges Cup or NatWest Trophy if he had already represented his original county in that particular competition.

Loans could also have provided a lifeline for some struggling senior players. Mark Lathwell's precipitous decline from England opener in 1993 to Somerset seconds might have been arrested by a spell with another county; and Lancashire's third spinner, Gary Yates, also enduring the frustration of 2nd XI cricket, might have benefited from a temporary change of county too. Lancashire might also have moved to fill gaps in its one-day seam attack, while Yorkshire might have borrowed a proper spinner.

So what happened? Well, there were some near misses. Kent, having lost strike bowlers Dean Headley and Julian Thompson for the entire season, approached a number of other counties for replacements as far back as May. And Northamptonshire, who refused to loan them Malcolm, failed to persuade anyone to part with an allrounder to replace the injured Kevin Innes. They were also unable to place promising 2nd XI opening bat Alec Swann elsewhere, despite offering him to all first-division counties - Carter wasn't going to have Swann coming good against his own side.

Why has the closest thing the county circuit has ever had to a transfer system been such a damp squib? Reasons given include the counties' innate resistance to change, fear of a sudden injury crisis and reluctance to hand opponents a potential matchwinner on a plate. Another factor is the unusual paucity of "dead" matches as the climax of the new-style season approached (loans could begin no later than July 31). One established county player produces a further explanation: "Counties are reluctant to let go people in whom they've invested a lot of time and money. A player might do well at another club, maybe even sign for them."

Paul Millman, Kent's chief executive, puts it like this: "Conceptually, loans are a brilliant idea, and we're still very supportive. But counties have been nervous, especially in the first season of a two-division championship, about handing over talent they're not sure of, and then finding themselves in trouble. There's a fear factor: when it came to the crunch the counties we had discussions with weren't able to agree."

Millman adds: "Loans may work when people develop confidence in them. It needs someone to break the ice and demonstrate that it doesn't hurt either side." But even the senior PCA official concludes: "I don't think this one's ever really going to fly."

Charles de Lisle is the author, with Christopher Martin-Jenkins, of An Australian Summer: The Story of the 1998/9 Ashes Series (Faber). You can e-mail him at cdelisle@compuserve.com

fields.headline: West Ham United
fields.trailText: Hands up, supporters of other Premiership teams: how many of you would love to have Rio Ferdinand, Frank Lampard, Joe Cole and Michael Carrick in your side? Well, West Ham have got them all. And they also have enough decent players - Di Canio, Stimac, Hislop and Sinclair - to back up their home ground talent as well.
fields.body:
Hands up, supporters of other Premiership teams: how many of you would love to have Rio Ferdinand, Frank Lampard, Joe Cole and Michael Carrick in your side? Well, West Ham have got them all. And they also have enough decent players - Di Canio, Stimac, Hislop and Sinclair - to back up their home ground talent as well.

By rights they should be challenging for a place in the top five this season. In reality they'll probably end up - as they always seem to do - just hovering outside the European places. Which would be a shame, because West Ham play some of the purest and most exciting football in the Premiership.

Unfortunately, they're also one of the most inconsistent sides as well, especially away from home. Because for all the solidity of Stimac, the defensive flair of Ferdinand and the excellent keeping of Hislop, West Ham have an alarming habit of leaking goals. Last season there was the 4-0 home mauling at the hands of Everton and the 7-1 shellacking at Old Trafford to go with some stupefying defeats the year before. How can a defence with so many good players be so porous so often?

During this summer's multi-million pound transfer whirl, the words West and Ham have not been much in evidence, although Harry Redknapp has spent the little money he has wisely. Frederic Kanoute - a £4m buy from Lyon - will add pace to the attack, while Arsenal hand-me-downs Davor Suker and Nigel Winterburn will add panache and experience respectively.

How well Suker and Kanoute link up with di Canio will be a key factor this season. If the mercurial Italian's performances include more goals than histrionics then West Ham will - on their day - be a match for anyone. Whether they'll be able to do it consistently enough to earn an automatic place in Europe, however, is another matter. But if Ferndinand stays, Lampard starts giving it large on the pitch as well as off, and Cole and Carrick begin to live up to their enormous potential, then West Ham will come mighty close.

In: Davor Suker (Arsenal, free), Nigel Winterburn (Arsenal, undisclosed), Frederic Kanoute (Olympiques Lyonnais, £4m), Hayden Fox (Sanfrecce Hiroshima, free).

Out: Paulo Wanchope (Manchester City, £3.65m), Neil Ruddock (Crystal Palace, free), Manny Omoyinmi (Oxford, free), Marc-Vivien Foe (Olympique Lyonnais, £6m), Ian Feuer (Wimbledon, free), Stephen Purches (Bournemouth, free), Samassi Abou (released).

Odds: 150/1

Football Unlimited writers' prediction: 8th

fields.headline: What Lacey thinks
fields.trailText: European contenders
fields.body:
European contenders

1 MANCHESTER UNITED
Position last season: Champions.

A Premiership hat-trick beckons for United whose defence, a problem last season, should be strengthened by the availability of Ronny Johnsen and Wes Brown and revitalised by the presence behind them of Fabien Barthez. Elsewhere no other side can match Sir Alex Ferguson's strength in depth, which is awesome. The show should go on.

In: Fabien Barthez (Monaco £7.8m), Daniel Nardiello (Wolves £200,000).
Out: Danny Higginbotham (Derby £2m), Massimo Taibi (Reggina £2.5m), Jordi Cruyff (released), John Curtis (Blackburn £1.5m), Paul Wheatcroft (Bolton free).

Odds to win title: 8-11
To be relegated: 400-1

2 LIVERPOOL
Position last season: 4th.

This could be the season in which Anfield once more poses a serious threat to Old Trafford. Sami Hyypia and Stephane Henchoz have been joined in defence by Markus Babbel and Bernard Diomede gives Gerard Houllier an extra option in attack. Liverpool became hard to beat last season. Now they may be hard to stop. But will Michael Owen and Robbie Fowler stay fit and in form?

In: Nick Barmby (Everton, £6m), Pegguy Arphexad (Leicester, free), Markus Babbel (Bayern Munich, free), Bernard Diomede (Auxerre, £3m), Gary McAllister (Coventry, free), Robbie Shields (Tallaght, nominal).
Out: David Thompson (Coventry, £2.5m), Bjorn Tore Kvarme (St Etienne, released), Phil Babb (Sporting Lisbon, free), Stig Inge Bjornebye (Blackburn, £300,000), John Boardman (Burnley, free).

Odds to win title: 11-2
To be relegated: 125-1

3 LEEDS UNITED
Position last season: 3rd.

David O'Leary will be seeking to add all-round maturity to the fresh and uninhibited style of football which brought success back to Elland Road last season. Leeds, however, need to get into the habit of winning their big games and the arrival of Mark Viduka from Celtic should give an already sharp attack an even finer cutting edge.

In: Olivier Dacourt (Lens, £7.2m), Mark Viduka (Celtic, £7m).
Out: David Hopkin (Bradford, £2.5m), Martin Hiden (SV Saltzburg, £500,000), Alf-Inge Haaland (Man City, £2.5m), Tommy Knarvik (SK Brann, free).

Odds to win title: 14-1
To be relegated: 66-1

4 ARSENAL
Position last season: 2nd.

Arsenal face an awkward start following the loss of Emmanuel Petit and Marc Overmars to Barcelona. While Arsene Wenger had already signed Lauren Etame Mayer from Real Mallorca and Robert Pires from Marseille he could not have reckoned with losing two-thirds of his left side so abruptly. The fitness of Tony Adams and David Seaman's form may also cause concern.

In: Lauren Etame Mayer (Real Mallorca, £7m), Robert Pires (Marseille, £6m).
Out: Marc Overmars (Barcelona, £25m), Emmanuel Petit (Barcelona, £5m), Nigel Winterburn (West Ham, undisclosed), Davor Suker (West Ham, free), Narada Bernard (Bournemouth, free), David Grondin (Cannes, loan), Jay Bothroyd (Coventry, £1m), Julian Gray (Crystal Palace, undisclosed), Tommy Black (Crystal Palace, undisclosed), Keith Fahey (Aston Villa, free), Brian McGovern (Norwich, loan).

Odds to win title: 9-2
To be relegated: 500-1

5 ASTON VILLA
Position last season: 6th.

The arrival of David Ginola should make Villa Park less of a fun-free zone but John Gregory needs to make a good start if he is to quell noises of discontent from the likes of Ugo Ehiogu and Gareth Southgate. Nevertheless, Dion Dublin's heading ability, with a steady supply of crosses from Ginola, should give the Villa attack more teeth.

In: David Ginola (Tottenham, £3m), Alpay Ozalan (Fenerbahce, £5.6m) Luc Nilis (PSV Eindhoven, free), Thomas Hitzlsperger (Bayern Munich, free), Keith Fahey (Arsenal, free).
Out: Steve Watson (Everton, £2.5m), Mark Draper (Southampton, £1.5m), Benito Carbone (released), Darren Byfield (Walsall, free), Michael Blackwood (Wrexham, free).

Odds to win title: 100-1
To be relegated: 14-1

6 CHELSEA
Position last season: 5th.

Missing out on a Champions League place last time was a costly disappointment for Chelsea. Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink and Eidur Gudjohnsen will add speed and mobility to Gianluca Vialli's attack and with Marcel Desailly deciding to stay at the Bridge the defence remains sound. But unless Chelsea are more consistent they will remain outside the top three.

In: Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink (Atletico Madrid, £15m) Eidur Gudjohnsen (Bolton, £4m), Mario Stanic (Parma, £4.6m), Carlo Cudicini (Castel Di Sangro, undisclosed), Sebastian Kniessel (Eintracht Frankfurt, free).
Out: Chris Sutton (Celtic, £6m), Didier Deschamps (Valencia £3.7m), Dan Petrescu (Bradford, £1m), Neil Clement (West Brom, £200,000), Mikael Forssell (Crystal Palace, loan), Pierlugi Casiraghi (retired).

Odds to win title: 4-1
To be relegated: 100-1

Mid-table security

7 NEWCASTLE UNITED
Position last season: 11th.

Having saved Newcastle from relegation last season Bobby Robson will now set about restoring the sanguine state of affairs which existed under Kevin Keegan. Yet there is still some way to go although Carl Cort looks a useful signing.

In: Carl Cort (Wimbledon, £7m), Daniel Cordone (Racing Club, loan), Christian Bassedas (Velez Sarsfield, £4m), Temuri Ketsbaia (Wolves, £900,000).
Out: Duncan Ferguson (Everton, £3.75m), Alessandro Pistone (Everton, £3m), Steve Howey (Manchester City, £2m), Carl Serrant (Sheffield Utd, loan), Silvio Maric (Porto, undisclosed), Paul Robinson (Wimbledon, undisclosed), David Cunningham (Livingston, free), John Karelse (released), Fumaca (released).

Odds to win title: 66-1
To be relegated: 25-1

8 TOTTENHAM HOTSPUR
Position last season: 10th.

Spurs supporters mourning the departure of David Ginola need to be mollified by signs that Sergei Rebrov will increase the team's scoring potential. Yet the arrival of Neil Sullivan, the excellent Wimbledon goalkeeper, is likely to be equally important in George Graham's quest for the top six while Ben Thatcher will bring a touch of the Crazy Gang to Spurs' defence.

In: Sergei Rebrov (Dynamo Kiev, £11m), Neil Sullivan (Wimbledon, free), Ben Thatcher (Wimbledon, £5m).
Out: David Ginola (Aston Villa, £3m), John Scales (Ipswich, released), Allan Nielsen (Watford, £2.25m), Espen Baardsen (Watford, £1.25m), Peter Crouch (QPR, £60,000).

Odds to win title: 66-1
To be relegated: 16-1

9 WEST HAM UNITED
Position last season: 9th.

Paolo di Canio has invigorated West Ham and with Davor Suker alongside him their attack should prosper this time. Harry Redknapp's side ought to win enough of its games to stay in the top half of the Premier League table although a porous defence may again be a burden.

In: Davor Suker (Arsenal, free), Nigel Winterburn (Arsenal, undisclosed), Frederic Kanoute (Olympiques Lyonnais, £4m), Hayden Fox (Sanfrecce Hiroshima, free).
Out: Paulo Wanchope (Manchester City, £3.65m), Neil Ruddock (Crystal Palace, free), Manny Omoyinmi (Oxford, free), Marc-Vivien Foe (Olympique Lyonnais, £6m), Ian Feuer (Wimbledon, free), Stephen Purches (Bournemouth, free), Samassi Abou (released)

Odds to win title: 150-1
To be relegated: 10-1

10 SUNDERLAND
Position last season: 7th.

Sunderland made a big impact on the Premiership League last season after winning promotion and with Don Hutchison in his midfield Peter Reid will seek to build on the confidence this engendered. But opposing defences will be more wary of Kevin Phillips and Niall Quinn this time and if the partnership is less prolific results may suffer. Nevertheless Sunderland should be secure for a while yet. Summer transfers

In: Don Hutchison (Everton, £2.5m), Tom Peeters (Mechelen, £250,000), John Kennedy (Worksop, £80,000), Jurgen Macho (FC Vienna, free), Julio Arca (Argentinos, £3.5m), Stanislav Varga (Slovan Bratislava, £650,000).
Out: Allan Johnston (Rangers, free), Sam Ainston (Shrewsbury, free), David Duke (Swindon, free), Gerry Harrison (released), Gregg Shannon (released).

Odds to win title: 150-1
To be relegated: 10-1

11 MIDDLESBROUGH
Position last season: 12th.

Christian Karembeu for Paul Gascoigne looks a much better swap now than it would have done a few years back and Bryan Robson will hope to capitalise on the improvement in results he achieved during the latter part of last season. Again the experience of Paul Ince will be crucial and with greater consistency fore and aft Boro should jog along nicely this time.

In: Christian Karembeu (Real Madrid, £2.1m), Paul Okon (Fiorentina, free), Noel Whelan (Coventry, £2m), Joseph-Desire Job (Lens £3m), Alen Boksic (Lazio, £2m), Mark Crossley (Nottingham Forest, free).
Out: Paul Gascoigne (Everton, free), Ben Roberts (Charlton, free).

Odds to win title: 200-1
To be relegated: 10-1

12 SOUTHAMPTON
Position last season: 15th.

The arrival of Glenn Hoddle as manager arrested Southampton's decline last season and may give them a buoyant start this time around. For Hoddle the main problems will lie in improving the efficieny of a defence which still struggles to play as a unit. Kevin Davies and the Moroccans, Tahar El Khalej and Hassan Kachloul, should improve the forward momentum.

In: Mark Draper (Aston Villa, £1.5m), Uwe Rosler (Borussia Berlin, free), Patrice Tano (Monaco, free).

Odds to win title: 150-1
To be relegated: 10-1

13 EVERTON
Position last season: 13th.

The partial revival achieved by Walter Smith at Goodison last season can only be endangered by the loss of John Collins, Don Hutchison and Nick Barmby from the heart of the Everton side. Unless Paul Gascoigne can keep up with the play better than he did at Middlesbrough his arrival will be an irrelevance while up front the fitness of Kevin Campbell may again be a problem.

fields.trailText: Paul MacInnes
fields.byline: Paul MacInnes, Scott Murray and Sean Ingle
fields.body:
Paul MacInnes

£5 on 0 or 1 goals in Leicester v Aston Villa (9/4)

After my scarifying experience during Euro 2000, I believe I can approach this season a tougher, smarter, and most importantly, luckier punter. That's why I'm going to throw my first fiver at a game I can only see developing into a boreathon.

Peter Taylor will not want to start his tenure at Filbert Street with a home defeat, and I don't see Villa possessing enough guile to get past the Foxes' experienced back-line. So, allowing for the odd fluke goal somewhere along the line, I reckon 9/4 represents good value (dunno what that means, but I heard someone say it in a bookies once).

Scott Murray

£5 on a line of three draws: Charlton v Manchester City (9/4); Derby v Southampton (9/4); Sunderland v Arsenal (9/4)

Someone's always going to let you down on the first day of the season. So there's not much point poring over the coupon looking for certs. Well, there probably is, but that's my argument and I'm sticking to it. And so I've popped £5 on the following line of three draws. Don't ask me why, they just look like draws. The cerebral gambler which resides within will have to wait another week.

Sean Ingle

4 x £1.50 trebles and £1 accumulator: Middlesbrough to beat Coventry (2/1), Leeds to draw with Everton (12/5), Blackburn to beat Crewe 4/5 and Sunderland to beat Arsenal (10/11)

A wise old man once said to me: "Never bet big in the first month of the season." And my word, was he right. Because in the early sparring all sorts of crazy things can happen. An average side flukes a win here or there and - oh my God! - they're suddenly top of the tree. Remember Sheffield Wednesday in 1996/7? Conversely a side can stutter and wheeze out of the blocks and it's not until September that they're into their stride. So be cautious early.

I've picked four matches that offer reasonable value. Middlesbrough are overpriced at 2-1 to beat a Coventry side that may time to adjust to life without Robbie Keane, while Leeds, without Harry Kewell, Jason Wilcox and Stephen McPhail could well struggle against Everton - remember they drew 0-0 against Derby in their opening game last year.

Blackburn should be too strong for Crewe, while Sunderland - who will be without Stefan Schwarz, Gavin McCann, Alex Rae and Don Hutchison - will struggle against Arsenal. And by perming the selections, it means that if three out of four come off we still win. Hurrah!

Would you like to bet your life away? Each week for the rest of the season, one lucky punter will have the chance to pit their wits, and Blue Square's cash, against our Football Unlimited pundits. If you think you should have studied Turf Accountancy at University, get in touch at editor@footballunlimited.co.uk.

Come back on Monday, when Blue Square analyst Patrick Murray (no relation) will take our brave betters apart, and advise them on where to improve next weekend. You never know, you might learn something.

fields.headline: A better class of fish
fields.standfirst: Not so long ago, line-caught sea bass was seen as something rather special - now only wreck-caught will do. And scallops? Diver-caught, darling.  Matthew Fort on the fine art of menu one-upmanship
fields.trailText: Not so long ago, line-caught sea bass was seen as something rather special - now only wreck-caught will do. And scallops? Diver-caught, darling. Matthew Fort on the fine art of menu one-upmanship
fields.body:
It was the wreck-caught bit about the bass on the menu that caught my eye. Not merely line-caught or beach-caught or even rock-caught, but wreck-caught. Why, that's extra, extra special, isn't it? Isn't it? One up on diver-caught scallops, wild salmon and free-range chickens. Not that long ago, we would have been happy with a simple line-caught, diver-caught, free-range or wild. These descriptions were designed to reassure the anxious eater of the natural provenance of what was about to appear on our plate, and allay any fear for the environment that might inhibit us from tucking in with a clear conscience.

It is a mark of the sophistication of our awareness that such reassurances should be thought necessary, and of our gullibility that we accept them, and pay the price they necessarily incur. Actually, we pay happily because it suggests that we are getting something special, something different, something better, something classier than the bloke down the road. It's as much to do with inveterate gastro-snobbery, in the unending struggle for cash and cachet, as is it with concern for ecology.

It all began with olive oil. Once there was plain olive oil, and you were lucky if you could find that in the 50s and 60s. Then people began bringing extra virgin olive oil back with them from holidays in the Mediterranean sun, which became the benchmark for culinary class. If you were really smart then it might even be dark green and unfiltered (and uneatable). Then, in 1984/85, disaster struck Italy, the primary supplier. A savagely harsh winter gripped the country, Tuscany in particular, destroying something like a quarter of all olive trees, and reducing oil production by about a third.

Faced with a situation in which they needed to make as much money from fewer olives, the Italians invented the regional olive oil, and then the single estate olive oil. So if you wanted to stay ahead of the game, you couldn't just rely on extra virgin olive oil any more, it had to be the extra virgin olive oil from the San Martino in Prestito estate in Tuscany in the fancy bottle at the fancy price. And you only used that for certain dishes, because its qualities made it suitable only for splashing into the frying pan or rubbing into chicken. For salads, of course, you needed the lighter Ligurian extra virgin olive oil.

Now we are seeing two further refinements in the extra virgin olive oil story, the arrival of single varietal oils - olive oils are usually made with a blend of olives - and, naturally, of organic oils. So, look out for the organic extra virgin olive oil made from the Moraiolo olive from San Martino in Prestito.

The progress of the olive from humble extra to main player is a template for any wannabe foodstuff. Consider the oyster. In the days of Queen Victoria, there was only one oyster, the native ostrea edulis , that was grown in waters all round the coast. The French had crassostrea Portugensis , to which the French gave all sorts of fancy names such as Belon, Cancale, Marennes, and gravette d'Arcachon. Then pollution and disease hit our oyster beds, turning the oyster from universal food to rich man's perk. In 1971 the French introduced the fast-growing, sturdier and therefore cheaper Pacific oyster, an example followed a few years later in Britain, and the oyster came back.

Oyster producers or retailers had recourse to the usual marketeer's ploy when faced with the problem of how to develop the market - create a number of niche brands within it, each invested with a mysterious and usually indefinable quality. The French are brilliant at this, using the geographical variant of the ploy, and apply the principle to all kinds of foods. Hence l'agneau de Sisteron , which is different from l'agneau de Pauillac , which is different from the l'agneau pre-sale de Bretagne . Then there's poulet de Bresse , asperge de Bugey , and jambon de Morvan , not to mention several hundred cheeses and the oysters named above.

We have tried the same thing in Britain. Colchester still has a magic to my ear because it suggests a traditional English oyster, the finest in my view. Then there are oysters from Orford, Helford, Loch Fyne and Galway, mostly Pacifics, but with a few ostrea edulis for good measure. And now peppering fashionable menus is the rock oyster - our old friend the Pacific oyster with a fancy name. Rock has a wreck-caught ring to it which tile-bred, pen-fattened or seabed-sitting, where most oysters are reared, does not, and we will pay happily for that perceived difference.

I won't go as far as to say that there's no difference between these and their less exalted equivalents but I will say that the honorific versions have become invested in a fabulous snobbery which helps justify the cost differential. Wreck-caught sea bass will taste no different from mere line-caught sea bass, but both will be superior to farmed sea bass. Diver-caught sea scallops will differ only from the dredged variety in the lack of environmental damage that their retrieval causes.

As we have become more affluent - which is not the same thing as discerning - so the breadth of food snobbery has grown. There is no vinegar but balsamic. It is not good enough for coffee to be just coffee, but high roast or medium roast, and not just from Costa Rica, Jamaica, Java, Yemen, Colombia or Nicaragua, but Monsoon Malabar, Kenya Peaberry, Pico Duarte or whatever. Pork must be Middle White, beef be Belted Galloway, partridges have grey legs, bacon be dry-cured, flour stone-ground, and tomatoes vine-ripened.

The trouble with this kind of attachment to labels, to the notion of food as fashion accessory, is that there is always a newer, smarter label, another more fashionable fashion, another step in the class ladder.

Take caviar, for example. Those with the highest gastro-aspirations look to caviar to provide the ultimate thrill. We all know, don't we, that there's sevruga, oscietra and beluga, with beluga being generally the best and most expensive because the eggs are the largest. There's something of a debate as to whether Russian or Iranian holds sway in terms of desirability. With Russian production largely in the hands of the Mafia, and a good deal of the stuff available being of dubious provenance, the much more tightly regulated Iranian must seem a more reliable bet.

So we're agreed that fresh, spring Iranian beluga in a 1.8kg tin - the tin in which the caviar is packed immediately after being salted and sorted - at £6,500, is the finest that money can buy. Start saving. But then there's something called "golden caviar" or Almas Diamond, from the incredibly rare albino sturgeon. Once consumed only by the tsars, and later split between Stalin, the Shah of Iran and the chairman of the Russo-Persian Fisheries Company, it is now yours for a measly £7,352 for 500g. Of course, there are those who say it's just a load of one-upmanship.

 The Guzzler will return next week.

fields.headline: Most wanted...
fields.standfirst: ...dice necklace
fields.trailText: ...dice necklace
fields.body:
People like to say the 80s are back but this is really just a euphemism. The truth is that tack is back and, good heavens, aren't we revelling in it? Big gold jewellery, cropped denim trousers, fringed vest tops: we've taken to them all like little children in Halloween costumes.

But not all tack is created equal - 80s tack may have been big this summer but stick with it in autumn and you'll just be plain tacky rather than tacky chic. To stay ahead, check out Kate Moss with her peroxide crop, or the shift towards bleached denim. Yes, the look of the season is Essex tack, much to everyone's secret delight. At last you can break out your shoulderpads again or go for stilettos with jeans.

But the best example of Dagenham Dave chic we've seen is this rather fab dice necklace (£9 from Octopus, mail order 020-7287 4021). Who'd have thought the Ford Escort would become a style icon, but that's just the crazy world of fashion for you. It fits in with the still popular customisation look and is a definite improvement on the currently ubiquitous name-on-a-gold-chain necklace.

Sport this round your neck, with either a half-unbuttoned shirt or a sexy little slipdress, and people will be staring at and playing with your neckwear all evening, which is rarely a bad thing. Far from being old soap on a rope, this is a genius bit of accessorising that is guaranteed to be a conversation piece. Get it before Cat Deeley does.

fields.headline: Most everywhere...
fields.standfirst: ...tartan
fields.trailText: ...tartan
fields.body:
Blame it on Burberry: tartan is the new black. In the 90s we could all hide behind our safe sartorial shields of bland monochrome: black, white and maybe khaki if you were feeling a bit street. Burberry's ubiquitous logo was a nice bit of training tartan for erstwhile minimalists (it may be patterned but it is still - phew! - khaki). But it's a little bit po-faced for the excessive 21st century: we want patterns and we want them bright, loud and to clash like a set of cymbals.

Violently jarring tartan was as inevitable as rain and the designers are loving it. No longer restrained by concerns about decorum, the autumn/ winter catwalks were awash with red, black, yellow and green plaid patterns. Mr All-American Tommy Hilfiger came over all Celtic, while even ultra-trendy Japanese label Comme des Garçons seems to be having a bit of a highland fling this season.

Inevitably this is all beginning to trickle down towards the high street - witness the tartan boot by Faith (£125, tel 0800 289 297 for stockists). Proceed with caution, though: a short tartan skirt might make a nice change from the little black dress, but others could find it a bit too close to schoolgirl chic for comfort.

But let's not beat around the bush here. When it comes to simple word association, there is only one thing that comes to mind when you think of tartan: the Bay City Rollers. So while designers and fashion fiends might like to think they are being oh so unusual, daring and eccentric, the rest of us know that this is just another excuse for them to retread a sepia-tinted memory lane, back down to best-forgotten youthful musical follies.

fields.headline: Pretend you know all about...
fields.standfirst: ...Frostfrench
fields.trailText: ...Frostfrench
fields.body:
Forget the old model-actress-singer dichotomy - that is just too 20th century. Now the formula is model-actress-producer-fashion designer. Think Christy Turlington and her Nuala trainers. Think Denise van Outen and her cheeky clothing at Top Shop. But perhaps the best proponent of this 21st century concept is our own Sadie Frost, one half of the design team Frostfrench.

Frost and best friend Jemima French launched the company in 1999, specialising in sexy lingerie sets. So successful were the naughty knickers that they feature in a British Council underwear exhibition at the Design Museum; this autumn the range has been extended to include scented lingerie.

Frostfrench also produces what Frost calls "clothing with an edge, a sense of humour, clothes that aren't too obviously fashion-conscious". Typical examples are fitted denim skirts with patterned linings and ultra low-slung hotpants, and this season Frostfrench has done it again with Fortune Jeans (around £100, tel 020-7923 7878 for stockists). Available in denim or corduroy, they were, Frost says, inspired by the chocolate bar in Charlie and the Chocolate Factory: under the bright back pocket lies a loud and proud statement, such as "Good Girl" (see above). One can only wonder what Roald Dahl would have made of it all. HF

webTitle: Gibraltar shows teeth in sub dispute

fields.headline: Gibraltar shows teeth in sub dispute
fields.trailText: The government of Gibraltar yesterday clashed for the first time with London over whether a stranded British nuclear submarine moored in the territory's harbour since May can be repaired there.
fields.body:
The government of Gibraltar yesterday clashed for the first time with London over whether a stranded British nuclear submarine moored in the territory's harbour since May can be repaired there.

While international attention has focused on the Russian submarine Kursk lying at the bottom of the Barents sea, HMS Tireless has been in Gibraltar for three months.

The Ministry of Defence wants to repair the submarine in Gibraltar but the local authority, amid continued public opposition, said it was "unable to support the carrying out of the repairs in Gibraltar" because it had been denied a safety report from London.

HMS Tireless was towed into harbour after a leak was found in its cooling system, forcing the shutdown of its reactor.

Environmentalists and the pressure group Greenpeace have opposed repairing the boat in Gibraltar, saying it poses a health and safety risk.

The Gibraltar government said it had been awaiting a safety report from the MoD so that its own independent consultants could assess the risks, but the ministry had refused to hand over the report, it said.

The ministry had also declined to answer public safety questions regarding the boat, the Gibraltar government said.

"The MoD has assured Gibraltar that the repairs pose no risk to the public health. Without access to the report, we are unable to test those assurances," it said.

Reuters

webTitle: Shadow Convention hears how drugs are the new communism

fields.headline: Shadow Convention hears how drugs are the new communism
fields.standfirst: The real debates are taking place outside the Democratic party conference, reports Duncan Campbell in Los Angeles
fields.trailText: Friday, 11.30am: The real debates are taking place outside the Democratic party conference, reports Duncan Campbell in Los Angeles.
fields.body:
He is a Republican governor, a self-made millionaire businessman with 1,000 employees, a married man with two children, a non-drinker, a successful athlete who is planning an expedition to climb Everest. And he supports the legalisation of marijuana.

Gary Johnson, the governor of New Mexico, was among the thousands of people in Los Angeles this week because of the Democratic party convention. It was just one of the many ironies of the week that it should be a Republican who was making some of the most radical political noises.

Johnson addressed the Shadow Convention - the event organised by people who felt that the big issues were not being addressed by the main conventions - in the Patriotic Hall, just a few blocks down from the Staples centre, where the Democrats were holding their event.

Johnson is an interesting man who was never part of the Republican machine and only decided to run for office at the last moment. The fact that he was elected is an indication of the disillusionment many feel with the machine politicians, who have been taught to believe that any talk about loosening the laws on drugs is political suicide.

But to Johnson, the issue is one of life and death. Or rather, quite a few deaths. In a year in the United States, he said, there were 450,000 deaths resulting from nicotine, 150,000 from alcohol, 100,000 from legally prescribed drugs, 5000 from cocaine and heroin and zero from marijuana. The real "bogeymen", he said, were alcohol and tobacco.

He was joined on the stage by another Republican, the would-be California senator, Tom Campbell. He had a similar message about the "war on drugs", and told a clearly amazed audience, used to Republicans talking rather differently, that "soft on drugs has replaced soft on communism". And he quoted Abraham Lincoln, saying that prohibition would do great harm to the cause of temperance because "it makes a crime of that which is not a crime". What was missing from political leaders, he said, was "not brain but spine".

Charlie Rangel, a Democratic congressman who represents the Harlem area of New York City, said that he had recently met Fidel Castro in Cuba. Before his trip he had asked Bill Clinton if he had any message for him. The president had wanted him to ask about the political prisoners there. Rangel had asked him what he should say if Castro asked about all the "political prisoners" in American jails. "They are the poorest people, the people of colour, the people that some people like to imagine don't exist," said Rangel.

So the debate on one of the biggest issues dividing America did take place after all during convention week. But it is taking place in the shadows rather than in the open. President Clinton tried but did not inhale. Vice-President Al Gore tried as a lad but stopped. When George W Bush was, as he puts it, "young and irresponsible, I was young and irresponsible".

The difference is that George W, unlike tens of thousands of young Americans, was not jailed for his irresponsibility. The speakers at the drugs debate in Patriotic Hall may be hoping for change, but it is unlikely that they are holding their breath before they exhale.

webTitle: Search for Harry Potter may be over

fields.headline: Search for Harry Potter may be over
fields.trailText: The search for one of the most discussed and sought after roles in recent years could finally be over - a boy wizard has been found
fields.body:
The search for one of the most discussed and sought after roles in recent years could finally be over - a boy wizard has been found.

According to the American website ain't it cool news, 13-year-old British actor Gabriel Thomson has been picked from thousands of young hopefuls to play the bespectacled wizard in the forthcoming Harry Potter film. An official announcement is apparently due on Monday.

Thomson was last seen on British television playing the young Pip in the BBC adaptation of Great Expectations shown last Christmas. His most recent film role was the lead in the New Line production of The New Adventures of Pinocchio, which was released in 1999.

If this rumour is confirmed, it will end months of speculation and intrigue over who would land this much coveted role (see our earlier stories).

Stephen Spielberg allegedly walked away from the project when author JK Rowling refused to allow him to hire an American child actor to play Harry, and new director Christopher Columbus has also had run-ins with the author over who should play her beloved creation.

fields.headline: Walker loses long illness battle
fields.trailText: Jack Walker, the man who funded Blackburn Rovers' 1995 Premiership title-winning team, has died, aged 70.
fields.body:
Jack Walker, the man who funded Blackburn Rovers' 1995 Premiership title-winning team, has died, aged 70.

Walker was a co-owner of Britain's biggest independent steel manufacturers and ploughed much of the proceeds from the subsequent sale of the company to British Steel into his beloved Rovers.

Although based in Jersey, Rovers owner Walker travelled to every game and was at Anfield on the day the Ewood Park side clinched their first league title for 80 years.

"He knew everyone right down to the bag man," said former Rovers defender Tony Gale. "Everyone interested him and Jack was known to everyone. He transformed the place into what it is today. The town and the club owe a great debt to him."

Blackburn were struggling in the old Second Division when Walker took control of the club in 1991 - but within four years they were Premiership champions. During the first three years he spent £25m on new players, including the £3.5m signing of Alan Shearer from Southampton. The ageing Ewood Park ground, which had not seen success for decades, was also transformed at a cost of more than £20m.

Walker had amassed a personal fortune of £600m from his steel business and last year he was listed as Britain's 30th richest man. In addition to his steel business he built up Jersey European Airways to be worth an estimated £100m.

He lived in a relatively-modest farmhouse overlooking the sea in Jersey, to where he had retreated in tax exile in 1974 with his wife Carol and two sons, and which also housed his office.

But he prided himself on his hands-on approach and flew back to watch the club in almost every game. He was constantly on the telephone to his manager and many of the players and their families.

Walker was born the youngest of three boys whose father was a metal worker at the Leyland motor factory. He left school at the age of 13 to work in a sheet-metal plant. The boys' father, George, founded his own steel business after being retired through ill-health from his job and when he died in 1951.

Walker and brother Fred took over the near-bankrupt firm which had a turnover of a mere £6,000 a year. The business enjoyed ups and downs in a volatile industry but by 1984 the Walkers' purchase of GKN made the firm the biggest of its kind in the land.

Walker had built up the company with a gruelling schedule which saw him start work at 5am. He had resolved not to pay himself more than £10-a-week until the firm's profits topped £100,000 and drove the same old Morris 8 saloon until it ground to a halt.

He resisted several attempts to persuade him to join the Rovers' board because of his business commitments. But after retirement he threw himself wholeheartedly into restoring his home-town team's fortunes with the same resolve he had shown in business.

Blackburn's success at the top was short-lived and although they returned to Division One it did not diminish Walker's commitment to their cause.

"You have to get pleasure out of it," he was quoted as saying. "It has put Blackburn back on the up and shown that if you believe in things they can be done. If they don't win then I am bloody miserable on a Sunday."

webTitle: Gore makes the grade on his big night

fields.headline: Gore makes the grade on his big night
fields.standfirst: The Democrat candidate's crucial speech may have reignited the presidential contest, reports Martin Kettle in Los Angeles
fields.trailText: The Democrat candidate's crucial speech may have reignited the presidential contest, reports Martin Kettle in Los Angeles.
fields.body:
Addicts of American politics will know the lines. Thursday night in Los Angeles was make or break for Al Gore. It was the most important speech of his life. It was the moment when he had to come out of the shadow of Bill Clinton.

Most of the 15,000 journalists who have covered the Democratic convention in Los Angeles, and most of the 15,000 who were at the Republican convention in Philadelphia two weeks earlier, have probably written these lines, or something passably similar. All are agreed that last night in LA had to be a winning night for Gore.

It is worth reminding oneself that the media had an interest in a Gore success last night. With nearly three months still to run and many millions of dollars and hours invested in the coverage, the media desperately needs a proper contest and a bit of excitement. Almost as much as Gore needed a triumph in the Staples Centre last night, in fact.

On the whole, Gore and the media both got what they wanted. Gore delivered the speech that he needed to make and the speech that the Democrats wanted to hear. The response was palpably enthusiastic. The buzz that has been so conspicuously absent for most of the week in the Democratic convention was there at the finish, just when it was most needed.

Like George W Bush two weeks ago, Gore had demonstrably spent an enormous amount of effort trying to get the tone right. That is what speechwriters are for, and they did their job. Gore's speech was as full of policy pledges as had been forecast. It was as focused on "ordinary Americans" as the spinners had predicted. But above all, Gore sounded at ease - "his own man" as he put it in one of the telling lines.

Gore has made some bad speeches during this campaign. Too often, he has seemed to try too hard, to be stiff when he should be relaxed, to be confuse sincerity with shouting, and to have mislaid his sense of humour.

Thursday's nomination acceptance speech was a big improvement on all counts. The balance between explanation and detail was good. The principal goals of the speech were all accomplished. The delivery was right. One almost felt sorry for Gore when he acknowledged his problems, telling the audience that he was sometimes too serious and that he knew he was not the most exciting person in American public life.

The convention organisers had worked hard to ensure a softer, more accessible Al Gore. Speeches from friends like Tommy Lee Jones and David Halberstam, and from family members like his daughters Karenna and Kristin, as well as wife Tipper had set the tone. Gore's task was tougher - to appear warm while setting out some pretty detailed pledges - but he more or less got it right.

The most important theme in Gore's speech was its constant appeal to America's "working families". "My focus is on working families," he said early on. "I will stand with you. I will stand for you." The focal points of his policy agenda - targeted middle and lower income tax changes, guaranteed nursery schooling and tax breaks for student finance - were overwhelmingly aimed at this middle American heartland. After eight years of Clinton policy "triangulation" the Gore agenda is much more recognisably Democratic.

"I'm here to talk seriously about the issues," Gore announced, and was as good as his word. Issues were duly ticked off. Campaign finance reform, further anti-tobacco measures, a daring pledge to keep crime rates falling every year for ten years, a carefully phrased commitment to free trade, but with conditions.

"They're for the powerful. We're for the people," Gore announced. To the demonstrators in the LA streets, still protesting late last night, the words will have seemed hollow. But as a contrast with Bush, and in a sense as a contrast with Clinton also, the Gore speech was undeniably attractive.

It has not been an easy convention for Gore and the Democrats. Bill Clinton dominated the early part, and the president sent a shiver down many Democratic spines once more yesterday after it was revealed that he is being investigated over Monica Lewinsky yet again. But in the end, Gore and Joe Lieberman got it about right. Their pitch was the necessary one in the circumstances. Gore wasn't just not bad, he was actually pretty good. It's a contest again, and that's good news all round.

webTitle: Caddick and Gough shine in the Test of Tests

fields.headline: Caddick and Gough shine in the Test of Tests
fields.trailText: Test matches just don't end at 5pm on the second day, even when it is at Headingley. England just don't win by an innings and 39 runs over West Indies, even when it is the worst Caribbean combination of the modern era. Andy Caddick just doesn't take four wickets in an over, even when the batsmen are befuddled by a quartet of swingers boasting the arc of a Shane Warne leg break. This was the day, even more than Botham's Headingley heroics of '81, that defied all logic.
fields.body:
Test matches just don't end at 5pm on the second day, even when it is at Headingley. England just don't win by an innings and 39 runs over West Indies, even when it is the worst Caribbean combination of the modern era. Andy Caddick just doesn't take four wickets in an over, even when the batsmen are befuddled by a quartet of swingers boasting the arc of a Shane Warne leg break. This was the day, even more than Botham's Headingley heroics of '81, that defied all logic.

England may not win Tests often, but when they do, they do so spectacularly, even freakishly. This, of course, was the biggest freak show of them all - West Indies all out for 61 in 26.2 overs on a pitch that may not have been a Test-class strip, but was certainly no minefield.

But this was a victory with a difference. It was the win of a committed, well-balanced team, rather than the Jekyll-and-Hyde operation that has masqueraded around the world's Test grounds in recent times. England did almost everything right through the entire match - well, both days of it- and have built up steadily since those incredible couple of days at Lord's which now, by comparison, seem almost tame.

By the end, Caddick's figures read 11.2-5-14-5. But Gough was the man who turned the Windies into mice. The ball was a living thing in his hand today: spitting, bouncing, cutting, swinging - positively oozing with venom. Campbell, Griffith and Hinds were all befuddled; Lara completely mesmerised. Gough went to tea with figures of 4 for 12, having set the stage for that final dramatic stanza.

Glenn McGrath confirmed his place among the pantheon of all-time bowling greats four years ago when he worked over Brian Lara so effectively that he became McGrath's bunny. Gough is not yet in McGrath's class, but he is learning fast. Can it really be that, a la Courtney Walsh, as Gough's knees grow older and sorer his bowling gets smarter?

Gough has now dismissed Lara four times out of seven this summer by cramping him for room and refusing to feed his strengths, and even Hansie Cronje would not have bet on the method of the West Indian's demise today. Sticking his chest out, sweeping that periscopic bat high above his head and prodding a pad tentatively forward - plumb lbw - it was almost a complete mirror image of his first-innings downfall.

But if you reckon Caddick and Gough left behind a delectable set of numbers, check out those of Michael Vaughan, a surprise choice as man of the match. In his first 11 completed Test innings, the Yorkshire opener-cum-England No. 6 has been dismissed below 29 just four times - a feat that sounds ordinary enough, but was never managed by Hobbs, Hutton, Hammond, Compton, Cowdrey, May, Graveney, Gooch, Gatting, Lamb, Atherton or Stewart.

Nonetheless, today's 76 was only Vaughan's second Test half-century and, given the tainted surroundings of his first at Centurion last winter, he will have derived enormous satisfaction from it. Resuming at 105 for 5, still 67 behind, nobody would have batted an eyelid had England collapsed in a heap and surrendered any lingering advantage they may have held. Instead, Vaughan and Hick - with a mixture of flair and Australian-like resolve - ensured that the tail well and truly wagged, carrying England to a first-innings lead of 100. Again, the West Indies support bowlers flagged: between them, Walsh and Ambrose had figures of 42.5-12-93-8; King and McLean read 33-7-141-1. Playing seven batsmen may not be the best long-term strategy, but the sensible horses-for-courses policy of England's selectors worked wonders here.

At No. 8 (has he at last found his niche?) Hick was a revelation, square-cutting, cover-driving and thunderously pulling all the West Indies pacemen - even Walsh and Ambrose - with the disdain he usually reserves for county trundlers. With Vaughan and Trescothick (Test average 52.50, thank you very much) surely England's new opening pair of the not-too-distant future, England's batting - for the first time in years - looks in safe hands.

Fittingly, this Test of Tests had an extraordinary conclusion: the sight of Caddick steaming in with six slips and a pocketful of gullies. England fans, who have watched their national side become the laughing stock of world cricket over the past decade, can dare to dream again. Maybe, just maybe, this was no flash in the pan.

fields.headline: X-Men
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about the latest cinematic sensation
fields.trailText: All you need to know about the latest cinematic sensation.
fields.body:
1. Whether the X-Men are goodies or baddies rather depends on your point of view. But God they're ugly.

2. Like them or loathe them, the X-Men film is building up a storm at the US box office, having grossed more than two thirds of its $75m (£50m) costs in its first weekend.

3. The picture, directed by Bryan Singer, opens in Britain today.

4. If you have so far resisted the hype, check out the trailers.

5. Sir Ian McKellen plays the head mutant. He takes it rather seriously.

6. Other stars include Tyler Mane, Patrick Stewart, Ray Park and the wonderful Anna Paquin, who you might remember in the 1993 cult hit The Piano.

7. She's still only 18, dammit.

8. The X-Men are a product of the vivid imagination of Marvel Comics supremo Stan Lee, who has a cameo in the film as a hotdog vendor. The X-Men are a band of mutants led by Professor Xavier (Stewart), who aim to make friends with humans, despite the fact that humans hate and fear them. Their enemies are other more hardline mutants, led by the evil Magneto..

9. The movie's storyline is exceptionally silly, and the US reviews were decidedly mixed. It can't fail.

10. If X-Men isn't your cup of tea, you can always find a more grown-up brew here.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All the rumours rumbled by Tom and Craig and subsequently disqualified for persistent infringement of the rules
fields.trailText: Middlesbrough boss Bryan Robson wants to build his defence around Manchester United duo Henning Berg and David May. The two players would cost £3m apiece.
fields.body:
Middlesbrough boss Bryan Robson wants to build his defence around Manchester United duo Henning Berg and David May. The two players would cost £3m apiece.

Robson may have to make do with May alone, however. Berg has already expressed an interest in moving to Celtic. "Officially, I haven't heard of any contact by Celtic but there might have been while I've been away [with Norway on international duty]," Berg said. "Celtic are a massive club and I think most players would be interested."

Blackburn are leading the £1m chase for Maccabi Haifa defender Arik Benado.

fields.headline: Bomb blast rocks Kosovo's capital
fields.trailText:
An explosion rocked the centre of Pristina Friday,
damaging the offices of Serb, ethnic Albanian and other political parties housed in a
building.
fields.body:
An explosion rocked the centre of Pristina Friday, damaging the offices of Serb, ethnic Albanian and other political parties housed in a building.

There were no immediate reports of major injuries from the blast, but several people sustained lacerations and were in shock.

"It just exploded from the middle of nowhere, and we didn't know what hit us," said Linda Spahiu, her face cut from the blast. Ms Spahiu, who works for the party representing Kosovo's Turkish minority, was in shock and could offer no further details.

The explosion shattered window panes in the vicinity. UN police and NATO peacekeepers cordoned off the area.

Police did not immediately say what caused the explosion, but Bernard Kouchner, Kosovo's chief UN administrator, said it was a bomb, set off by "enemies of democracy."

"A bomb is a very undemocratic means; of expression an opinion, he told reporters at the scene.

fields.headline: Patients' right to know threatened
fields.standfirst:
Cost could scupper plans to disclose medical data
Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: The government is facing growing pressure to rewrite data protection rules which are landing hospitals and GP surgeries with "ridiculously high" copying costs from patients asking for access to their medical records.
fields.body:
The government is facing growing pressure to rewrite data protection rules which are landing hospitals and GP surgeries with "ridiculously high" copying costs from patients asking for access to their medical records.

Doctors are threatening to force a high court test case over rules introduced this year stating that unlimited amounts of patient records - including x-rays which can cost over £20 a plate - should be available for a maximum fee of £50.

The potential bill to the already pressed national health service was described as "alarming" yesterday by one medico-legal practice serving 15 East Anglian hospitals, which is currently resisting a demand to process £2,000-worth of x-ray copying for the £50 fee as "totally unreasonable". The same office had reluctantly photocopied 1,900 pages of patient notes for lawyers at the £50 fee a few days earlier, at a cost of £250 in material and staff time.

"Hospitals are already financially stretched," said Paramjit Samrai, head of the legal unit which is based at Peterborough hospital and handles personal injury claims in-house to reduce NHS costs. "This is threatening to squeeze the budgets even more. There is no way that we want to make it difficult for patients to have access to their records, but there must be common sense.

"We have just told one firm of solicitors that we want to take the issue before a district judge to get a ruling before it all gets out of hand."

Other NHS services are understood to be using an "averaging-out" process, staying within the £50 limit by overcharging some applicants to help meet the high costs forced by others. Additional forms requiring proof of identity and other time-consuming paperwork have been introduced by other hospitals, in spite of a national system introduced under the act.

The situation has also angered personal injury lawyers, who yesterday accused hospitals and GPs of introducing "deterrent" layers of bureaucracy to put off applications for copies of records. Paul Baulen of the Association of Personal Injury Lawyers said one hospital had charged £533 for copies of one patient's records - 10 times the permitted maximum - and others were trying to impose extra charges for x-rays which was against the law.

"Overcharging effectively bars people from gaining access to their own records, which overturns everything the government is trying to encourage through freedom of information," he said. "Until something is done, the people who will suffer are those who have already been injured."

The clash has been developing since the 1998 Data Protection Act came into force in March. The old legislation allowed hospital and doctors to charge a £10 fee for providing a patient's records, with the crucial addition of up to 25p a page photocopying (the civil court rate). This meant that fees rose in proportion to the amount of work required.

The new system imposed the £50 maximum for manual copying, with a £10 limit for computer records and no charge for copies of additions to records requested within 40 days of treatment. It was introduced as part of the government's drive to increase freedom of information, but the majority of record-copying requests stem from personal injury litigation over poor treatment or clinical errors, which is rapidly increasing.

The Department of Health and the Home Office, which oversees data protection law, have both been contacted by NHS trusts appealing for revisions during the law's current transition period, which could see changes when the regulations are reviewed in October next year. But a spokesman for the Department of Health said: "The levels set down are the maximum that should be charged and in many cases patients should be charged less than that."

fields.headline: Kurds claim Turkish bombs killed 38
fields.trailText: Turkish planes have bombed northern Iraq, killing at least 38 civilians and wounding 11, the Kurdistan Democratic party (KDP) said in a statement yesterday.
fields.body:
Turkish planes have bombed northern Iraq, killing at least 38 civilians and wounding 11, the Kurdistan Democratic party (KDP) said in a statement yesterday.

The KDP said the jets attacked an area inside Iraq close to the borders of Turkey and Iran, where Turkish Kurd guerrillas loyal to the imprisoned Kurdistan Workers' party (PKK) leader Abdullah Ocalan have a number of bases.

"On August 15, while Turkish warplanes were pursuing PKK targets, a pasture camp inside Iraqi Kurdistan belonging to Iraqi Kurdish herdsmen and their families fell victim to the Turkish air raid," the KDP said. "As a result 38 civilians were killed, 11 were injured and four are missing."

Turkish military officials said they knew nothing of the incident. "It is out of the question for us to bomb civilians," an army official said.

"Air operations in northern Iraq target the PKK," he said.

The remote mountainous area of northern Iraq, outside Baghdad's control since the end of the Gulf war in 1991, is ruled by Massoud Barzani's KDP and a rival Iraqi Kurdish group.

Ocalan's PKK, fighting for Kurdish self-rule in south-east Turkey, have long used the region as a base to mount cross-border raids, provoking frequent incursions by Turkish forces.

The KDP's peshmerga fighters have regularly cooperated with Turkish troops to fight the PKK.

"We denounce this action which has led to the loss of so many innocent lives," the statement said. "We demand that this incident be thoroughly investigated and that the victims are properly compensated."

The Iraqi Kurdish satellite television channel, Kurdistan TV, showed the wounded, several of them small children, lying on hospital beds in the regional capital, Irbil.

"We were grazing our animals in the summer pastures," said a woman.

"Suddenly the planes flew over, then they flew back again and there were explosions everywhere.

"I don't know what happened then, but everywhere was covered in blood."

"We have nothing to do with the PKK," said another woman. "We don't know why they bombed us, we were just grazing our animals."


Reuters

webTitle: British man wins damages for Nazi attack

fields.headline: British man wins damages for Nazi attack
fields.trailText: A black British construction worker whose life was ruined in a race hate attack by neo-Nazis yesterday won substantial damages from his assailants in the German courts.
fields.body:
A black British construction worker whose life was ruined in a race hate attack by neo-Nazis yesterday won substantial damages from his assailants in the German courts.

Judges sitting in Potsdam near Berlin ruled that Noel Martin from Birmingham should be paid DM500,000 (£170,000) by his attackers. They also ordered that the two men, who left him paralysed from the neck down, should provide him with £335 a month for the rest of his life.

The ruling was delivered against a background of mounting concern in Germany over the prevalence of racial violence, particularly in the east of the country. The latest incident took place yesterday in the town where Mr Martin was attacked. Two teenage neo-Nazis in Mahlow outside Berlin beat up a 28-year-old Angolan man.

Rightwing extremists meanwhile commemorated the anniversary of the death of Rudolf Hess, Adolf Hitler's deputy, who died in prison in 1987. Posters and flyers hailing him as a "martyr to peace" appeared in several parts of the country.

A lawyer for Mr Martin, who was not in court for the verdict, said the chances of his client receiving the money awarded by the court appeared slight. One of his attackers was still serving an eight-year jail term; the other was recently freed. Both men are in their 20s.

Mario Pötter and Sandro Ristau were convicted four years ago of reckless driving and causing grievous bodily harm after hurling a rock at Mr Martin's car during a high-speed chase down a country road. Mr Martin, then 36, swerved into a tree. His passengers, two British friends, escaped with minor injuries.

In a further ruling, the court said the insurers of the stolen car used by the attackers should also pay damages. How much was open to further negotiation.

The British building worker has so far received some £200,000 in victim compensation from the regional authorities, his lawyer said.

Mr Martin, who has taken part in anti-racist campaigns in Germany, suffered a further blow earlier this year when his wife died of cancer.

Events to mark the anniversary of Hess's death have become an annual event. He was officially ruled to have committed suicide, but his family claimed he was murdered and neo-Nazis have latched on to the belief to try to turn him into a martyr.

Police broke up a torchlit procession by some 60 neo-Nazis late on Wednesday in the east German port of Rostock. Three of the marchers were charged with displaying banned symbols.

Posters and leaflets hailing the Nazi leader were found in Rostock and other towns in the Mecklenburg-Vorpommern region on the Baltic. Police detained a 14-year-old youth caught in possession of 1,200 Hess stickers in the eastern town of Jena, in Thuringia. And they confiscated small numbers of similar posters in Baden-Württemberg, Hesse and Lower Saxony in former west Germany.

According to government statistics, 129 xenophobic offences were registered in June, 29 more than in the same month last year. They included attacks which left one person dead and 26 injured.

fields.headline: Pregnant teenagers 'had access to pill'
fields.trailText: Ignorance of contraception or reluctance to go to GPs are not the reasons teenagers get pregnant, according to a study which found that half the teen pregnancies in one region were among girls who had been prescribed the pill.
fields.body:
Ignorance of contraception or reluctance to go to GPs are not the reasons teenagers get pregnant, according to a study which found that half the teen pregnancies in one region were among girls who had been prescribed the pill.

The study, in the British Medical Journal, turns old assumptions on their head. Researchers investigated 240 cases of teenage pregnancy in 14 general practices in the Trent region, and discovered that 71% of the girls had discussed contraception with a nurse or doctor during the previous year, and 50% had been given the pill.

"Access to contraception is essential but it may not be enough to contain our relentless drive to reproduce," Basil Donovan, professor of public health and community medicine at the University of Sydney, writes in the journal.

He suggests that society should be more open-minded about the forms of contraception teenagers are given.

The intrauterine device (coil), he writes, is the world's most commonly used reversible form of contraception and today's tests for coil-related infections can prevent problems women suffered in the past.

"If teenagers could take their fertility control somewhat for granted during the most precarious stage of their sexual careers, then the ability to negotiate other complex aspects of their sexual wellbeing could be enhanced," he writes.

Britain has the highest pregnancy rate in western Europe among 15- to 19-year-olds.
