fields.headline: Millennial malaise bugs Computacenter
fields.standfirst:
Special report: e-finance
Net news
fields.trailText: Computacenter directors yesterday came under renewed pressure to revitalise the computer services firm after they admitted that the millennium bug-induced hangover that forced it to issue a profits warning in June would continue into 2001.
fields.body:
Computacenter directors yesterday came under renewed pressure to revitalise the computer services firm after they admitted that the millennium bug-induced hangover that forced it to issue a profits warning in June would continue into 2001.

The chief executive, Mike Norris, said that while certain divisions were showing signs of recovery the market place as a whole remained tough. "The second half is likely to be substantially better than the first, but it may take until this time next year for normal growth rates to return," he said, as Computacenter shares fell 11% to 380p.

They now stand close to their all-time low, and way off the £15 level at which they traded in February.

Computacenter's troubles reflect a wider malaise among computer hardware and software companies which has forced several to issue profit warnings. Warnings from the likes of Unisys, Compel and EDS in the US that profits will be lower than forecast follow a reluctance among big corporate IT directors to spend on new computers and software.

Dutch firm Getronics yesterday became the latest firm to blame the millennium effect, posting a sharp fall in profits and seeing the price of its shares slump 18%.

Computacenter said that in the six months to June 30, pre-tax profits fell from £40.7m in the comparable period last year to £21.2m. France, Germany and Belgium were the worst-hit regions.

Turnover edged up from £904.8m to £926.7m. Margins fell from 22.6% to 21.2%, with the company expecting them to come under further pressure in the next few months.

Several analysts said they were looking to revise their full-year profit forecasts of around £61m - although Deutsche Bank analyst Ross Jobber said that the shares had probably already bottomed out.

Mr Jobber added that he expected trading to improve in time but given the range of other IT stocks available to traders the Computacenter shares were unlikely to be the first targeted for investment.

Mr Norris said that Computacenter also needed to improve its German business and product margins.

The general order book looks positive, with contracts from BP Amoco and Shell, Mr Norris added, while its e-business divisions were experiencing strong demand from dot.com companies.

Plans to float Biomi, an e-commerce joint venture that allows customers to order office supplies over the web which was the subject of a £2m investment during the period, have been shelved due to poor market conditions.

Computacenter shares trebled between October and February, and the company was looked upon as a major consolidator within its sector. In June it had an £85m offer for smaller rival Compel rejected, and although Computacenter is thought to be still keen to agree a deal it is unlikely to make any move until it has sorted out its own internal trading difficulties.

webTitle: Li deal dashes C&W hope of £5bn to spend

fields.headline: Li deal dashes C&W hope of £5bn to spend
fields.standfirst:
Special report: e-finance
Net news
fields.trailText: Cable & Wireless's hopes of replenishing its bank account with the proceeds of the sale of its Hong Kong subsidiary to the internet startup, Pacific Century CyberWorks, were dashed yesterday.
fields.body:
Cable & Wireless's hopes of replenishing its bank account with the proceeds of the sale of its Hong Kong subsidiary to the internet startup, Pacific Century CyberWorks, were dashed yesterday.

Cable & Wireless has been left with a 20.2% stake in entrepreneur Richard Li's PCCW and only £4.3bn in cash from the sale of its 54% stake in Cable & Wireless HKT.

Graham Wallace, chief executive of Cable & Wireless, said earlier this year he had hoped for a minimum of £5bn cash from the deal as the proceeds had been earmarked to help fund the firm's global roll-out of its data network, web hosting centres and investments in internet service providers.

The cash amount that Cable & Wireless extracted from the deal was based on the offer's structure. PCCW made an all-stock offer of 1.1 PCCW shares for each Cable &Wireless Hong Kong share.

An alternative combined offer of 71.16 cents (47p) of a PCCW share and 92.9 cents cash for each Cable & Wireless HKT share was also put down.

If the 46% minority owners among Cable & Wireless HKT shareholders accepted the all-share offer, Cable & Wireless would have been left with an 11.2% shareholding in PCCW and about £7.1bn in cash.

The maximum Cable & Wireless could end up with under the deal was a 20.9% stake and cash of £3.8bn.

When PCCW made its bid for Cable & Wireless HKT in March, when its stock was riding the euphoria surrounding internet stocks.

Since then, PCCW's shares have tumbled as investors have become sceptical of the earnings and revenue potential of web-based companies.

This meant most of the minority shareholders in Cable & Wireless HKT opted for the cash and share alternative offer by PCCW.

"Given we're not in a bull market, the small shareholders may as well take the cash," said Phil Campbell, analyst at Schroder Salomon Smith Barney. "That's why we assumed the worst case, that Cable & Wireless would get less cash."

Cable & Wireless has already stated its intentions to sell off blocks of its 20.2% shareholding in PCCW. It may be some time before internet stocks return to favour, allowing Cable & Wireless to exit its investment.

Mr Wallace yesterday maintained that Cable & Wireless was happy with the outcome.

"We are extremely pleased with the value that has been realised for our shareholders through this merger," he said.

In 18 months Cable &Wireless has spent £650m transforming itself from a traditional telecoms operator that derived most of its revenue from voice traffic to an organisation that is increasing its investment in data and internet protocol services. Internet protocol is the language that allows computers to share resources across a network.

webTitle: Figures put on Serb killings too high

fields.headline: Figures put on Serb killings too high
fields.standfirst: Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: Nato officials conceded last night that their wartime estimates of the number of Kosovo Albanian civilians massacred by Serb forces might have been too high.
fields.body:
Nato officials conceded last night that their wartime estimates of the number of Kosovo Albanian civilians massacred by Serb forces might have been too high. They were reacting to findings by forensic experts for the International Criminal Tribunal in the Hague who are preparing to complete their work in Kosovo after exhuming about 3,000 bodies.

Not all of the dead can be proved to be victims of murder or execution.

The war crimes teams have dug up 680 corpses this year at 150 sites. Added to the 2,108 found last year, the total is well below the murder estimates, ranging from 10,000 to 100,000, made during the war. Paul Risley, the Hague tribunal's press spokesman, said yesterday: "The final number of bodies uncovered will be less than 10,000 and probably more accurately determined as between two and three thousand."

Nato's intervention against Yugoslavia was prompted by massive Serb offensives against Albanian villages in Kosovo, which caused hundreds of thousands of civilians to hide in forests or flee across the border. There were frequent killings of unarmed civilians.

During the Nato airstrikes, when the Serbs restricted access to Kosovo, there was no way to verify atrocity reports. But Nato officials talked of 100,000 missing men and said at least 10,000 had been killed. Mark Laity, the acting Nato spokesman, said last night: "Nato never said the missing were all dead. The figure we stood by was 10,000. If it's wrong, I'm prepared to put up with a little bit of egg on our face if thousands are alive who were thought to be killed.

He added: "Nato is always going to lose. If there were 100,000 dead we would be criticised for entering Kosovo late. If it's a few thousand, we're criticised because people say there wasn't a crisis."

But Nato officials talked of 100,000 missing men and said at least 10,000 had been killed. Mark Laity, the acting Nato spokesman, said last night: "Nato never said the missing were all dead. The figure we stood by was 10,000. If it's wrong, I'm prepared to put up with a little bit of egg on our face if thousands are alive who were thought to be killed. He added: "Nato is always going to lose. If there were 100,000 dead we would be criticised for entering Kosovo late. If it's a few thousand, we're criticised because people say there wasn't a crisis."

fields.headline: On message
fields.standfirst:
Special report: e-finance
Net news
fields.trailText: • Safety first
fields.body:
 Safety first

Irish telecoms group Eircom has changed the dial-in and email passwords of around 30,000 internet service subscribers after a security breach. Eircom said a hacker had gained access to one of its servers but there was no evidence that any websites had been interfered with.

 Leak

A working version of software being developed by America Online for its new generation of internet-linked devices has leaked out to the worldwide web, the Washington Post reported in its online edition. The Linux-based software - codenamed Gamera - has been available for download on several rogue websites for at least a week. It is being developed by AOL for use in devices such as wireless pads and computers for the kitchen.

 Check-in

Internet search engine and directory Hoojit, founded by former Telinco boss Chris Matthews, is launching an online hotel guide which lets users find accommodation anywhere in Britain within a matter of minutes. Some 20,000 hotels have paid £100 each to sign up to the website.

fields.headline: The washing line of death
fields.standfirst: Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: In ones and twos Kosovo Albanians approach the mortuary at Pristina's main hospital every day and look at the clothes hanging out to dry. Usually they go away frustrated but sometimes they recognise a T-shirt or a pair of trousers and break down in tears. It is proof at last that a husband, father, or son is dead.
fields.body:
In ones and twos Kosovo Albanians approach the mortuary at Pristina's main hospital every day and look at the clothes hanging out to dry. Usually they go away frustrated but sometimes they recognise a T-shirt or a pair of trousers and break down in tears. It is proof at last that a husband, father, or son is dead.

For Detective Superintendent Steve Watts, the head of the British forensic team which has been exhuming bodies on behalf of the war crimes tribunal in the Hague, the scenes have been heart-rending. "By now most bodies are skeletal and there are very sparse dental records in Kosovo. So items of clothing are often the only chance to identify people'" he said.

The exhumers photograph the remains, count the bodies and check for signs of the cause of death. When it comes to identifying people, usually they can do little more than determine the age and sex - except for bits of clothing, which are examined and then washed.

Remarkable

Clothing displays have been organised elsewhere in Kosovo. At the most recent, at the bread factory in Fushe Kosove, grieving families recognised 15% of the articles. "I thought this was a remarkable proportion," said Det Supt Watts.

In the first year of the tribunal's operations in Kosovo, when bodies were fresher, the rate was higher. Roughly two-thirds of the 2,108 bodies exhumed in 1999 were identified.

This year the British team, the largest in the territory, has been concentrating on two sites. It has dug up 180 bodies at a cemetery in Dragodan, a suburb of Pristina. They were found in unmarked pits, and often one hole had two or three bodies in it. "Was it intended to hide the bodies?", Det Supt Watts asked.

At Makoc, near Pristina, the team reopened graves dug by Albanian villagers shortly after the war to give a dignified burial to 61 people who had last been seen when Serb forces separated them from a refugee column. Here the tribunal team's aim was to determine the cause of death. Many had gunshot wounds in the skull, apparently fired at close range.

This year's digging by the British team has produced no evidence of bodies having been burnt. This would be a strong clue to deliberate tampering.

webTitle: Family and stars warm up Gore crowd

fields.headline: Family and stars warm up Gore crowd
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Al Gore used every trick in the political book yesterday in an effort to persuade American voters to do the one thing they stubbornly refuse to do: learn to love him the way they continue to love Bill Clinton.
fields.body:
Al Gore used every trick in the political book yesterday in an effort to persuade American voters to do the one thing they stubbornly refuse to do: learn to love him the way they continue to love Bill Clinton.

Mr Gore's acceptance speech at the Democratic party convention in Los Angeles was expected to provide the climax to days of relentless effort to portray the vice-president as the kind of personality who can fire the anxious party's troubled soul - something the Gore campaign has singularly failed to do so far.

Friends and relations from every stage of Mr Gore's life took to the podium to bear witness to the vice-president as a warm, honest, brave and relaxed family man and national leader, setting the scene for a speech which was widely seen as the make-or-break moment in Mr Gore's efforts to prevent George W Bush from capturing the White House.

Tributes from his wife, Tipper, and his daughters, Karenna and Kristin, were interwoven with testimony from figures such as the actor Tommy Lee Jones and the writer David Halberstam, all of them seeking to humanise Mr Gore's defiantly stiff reputation and energise a party unmistakably underwhelmed about its chances in November.

Mr Gore and his spin doctors insisted that he was writing most of his speech himself, in an effort to communicate directly with the party and the nation. "This is a speech that I have written, and I will deserve either the credit or the blame," Mr Gore said shortly after arriving in Los Angeles on Wednesday.

Wednesday night's convention session provided an early taste of what was in store when the party's vice-presidential candidate, Joe Lieberman, was quickly hustled off the stage, after making a highly effective acceptance speech, to make room for Men in Black star Jones.

Jones told the prime-time television audience that the young Mr Gore "shot pool and watched Star Trek". He recalled Mr Gore's youthful prowess with an air-rifle and joked about his limited cooking skills.

The star was quickly followed by Karenna Schiff, Mr Gore's eldest daughter, who spoke of "the greatest dad in the world" who would take cups of hot chocolate to his children when they camped on the family farm at night.

As Mrs Schiff finished her speech, Mr Gore made a carefully calculated impromptu appearance on the platform to embrace his daughter, wave to the crowd and get himself in the evening news headlines. By tradition, a presidential nominee only makes one appearance at the convention: to deliver his acceptance speech at the close of proceedings.

The biographical blitz shows that the chief problem for the Democrats in translating America's glittering economic and social record during the Clinton-Gore years into success at the ballot box is not the much discussed Clinton factor but the less widely acknowledged Gore factor.

Mr Gore's life story has become the vehicle for the attempted transformation of a campaign still well adrift in the polls, in spite of recent improvements. "The principal communication goal, certainly through the next few weeks, is to get people to know Al Gore better as a person," his senior adviser, Tad Devine, said.

webTitle: Nomura gives up the battle for Hyder

fields.headline: Nomura gives up the battle for Hyder
fields.trailText: The long battle for control of Welsh utility group Hyder ended last night when Japanese investment bank Nomura International decided not to appeal against the takeover panel decision giving victory to the rival bidder, Western Power Distribution.
fields.body:
The long battle for control of Welsh utility group Hyder ended last night when Japanese investment bank Nomura International decided not to appeal against the takeover panel decision giving victory to the rival bidder, Western Power Distribution.

Nomura's managing director, Guy Hands, said the group was disappointed by the outcome but added: "We have decided not to prolong the period of uncertainty for Hyder's stakeholders, particularly the employees, who have been through a great deal over the last few months."

A spokesman for WPD said: "We are pleased certainty has been provided for Hyder shareholders."

The four-month battle came to a chaotic climax at the end of last week after the takeover panel executive imposed a sealed bid procedure in the final stages of the offer period. WPD put in a sealed bid of 365p a share, and though announcement of the offer was made after the deadline, the executive allowed it to stand.

Nomura, which had opposed the imposition of the sealed bid procedure, appealed against the ruling to the full panel earlier this week but was again overruled. It could have continued to seek to overturn the ruling by taking its case to the panel's appeals committee and, ultimately, could have sought a judicial review of the procedings, but last night decided to withdraw.

Although Nomura has decided not to carry on the bid battle, a spokesman said last night that it was too early to say what it would do with the 16.2% stake it had built up in Hyder. The most likely outcome is that it will sell the stake, which would bring it a profit of more than £25m.

The bid terms are more than double the price to which Hyder shares had fallen earlier this year as the group struggled with debts of £1.8bn.

"We continue to believe there is substantial value in Hyder and at least one group of stakeholders, the shareholders, should be pleased that the share price has nearly doubled since our involvement first become public, " said Mr Hands.

Hyder's operations include Welsh Water, the regulated water and waste water business, and South Wales Electricity. WPD plans to add Hyder's electricity distribution business to its own power network in south-west England and will contract out some of Hyder's water services to United Utilities.

webTitle: Sticken submarine crew 'killed in sub blast'

fields.headline: Crew 'killed in sub blast'
fields.standfirst:
Video shows massive damage to stricken vessel
Special report: Russia's stricken submarine
fields.trailText: The Russian authorities yesterday disclosed that the stricken Kursk submarine lying at the bottom of the Barents sea had suffered much greater damage than initially believed, making it highly likely that many of the crew, the vessel's commanding officers and other more senior navy officers died instantly last Saturday.
fields.body:
The Russian authorities yesterday disclosed that the stricken Kursk submarine lying at the bottom of the Barents sea had suffered much greater damage than initially believed, making it highly likely that many of the crew, the vessel's commanding officers and other more senior navy officers died instantly last Saturday.

As hopes faded of bringing out any of the 118 crewmen alive, the defence minister, Igor Sergeyev, revived the first theory advanced for the cause of the disaster - a collision with another vessel.

"The scenario in which the Kursk submarine suffered a collision with another object is now the main one," the defence minister said. "Irrefutable data is already available."

At the northern fleet's main base of Severomorsk outside Murmansk last night, senior navy and government officials were examining five hours of video of the sunken submarine taken earlier in the week by an unmanned observation craft before deciding on their next course of action.

The video shows massive and severe damage to the submarine extending from the nose to the conning tower. "The accident happened so quickly we can say it was like a flash," said Captain Igor Dygalo, the navy spokesman.

A reporter from Russia's state RTR television said the film showed that the Kursk suffered severe damage. "Water flooded the front in a flash and the command centre, I mean the hull, was destroyed in a moment," the correspondent said from a ship on the Barents Sea.

"This is tragic news, when so much water gets into the sub, it is impossible to avoid casualties."

Russian sources said the crash theory focused on the notion that the submarine collided with a surface vessel while trying to come up from the depths. Norwegian experts speculated that the disaster was caused by crew error which sent the submarine careering quickly to the sea bed.

American and Norwegian observation ships detected two blasts at the time of the accident last Saturday, the second much more powerful than the first. Some attributed the explosions to a torpedo blowing up inside the submarine and triggering another explosion.

The Norwegian analysts, Bellona, said the first explosion could have been the thud of the submarine hitting the sea bed which then triggered the more powerful explosion of a pressurised storage tank.

"Nobody knows what caused the accident", a British naval source said, but since the Kursk was very strong, it must have been a "high energy accident".

As a British rescue crew with the LR5 mini sub headed towards the Kursk, the Ministry of Defence said the submarine was so badly damaged that one of its escape hatches was unusable. The LR5 rescue sub would aim for the apparently undamaged hatch at the stern of the vessel.

The craft was lying at an angle of 20 degress, less than earlier suggested. "It could have shifted during the week. It seems to be far more upright, that is good news", the sources said. But underwater currents were extremely strong - and have already severely hampered Russian rescue efforts.

Commander Alan Hoskins of the British rescue team told the BBC his team was trying to remain optimistic. "We hope that we will get there and still find that people have survived," he said.

Tony Blair telephoned the Russian president, Vladimir Putin, from Tuscany to express his concern and to stress that Britain was doing everything possible to assist the operation.

Although the Russian public and media are rapidly losing faith in pronouncements from the top brass,with a wave of resentment and disgust sweeping across Russia at the way the authorities have handled the crisis, the theory that there had been a collision was supported by the fact that the submarine's periscopes were raised.

The retired admiral Eduard Baltin, the former commander of the Black sea fleet, blamed the disaster on bad planning, lack of training and incompetence. "The Kursk is designed for the ocean, not for shallow waters," he said. "Where it was manoeuvring and where it perished is completely wild - strong currents and strong winds. You can't carry out torpedo firing there."

He said the submarine would have been forced to surface to try to identify its torpedo targets, but the 108-metre depth of the sea at that point meant its commanders would not have heard another vessel above.

The vessel's commanding officers would normally be in a section just below the conning tower and experts said their chances of survival were minimal. Other senior navy personnel were on board to observe the war games.

Three days of attempts by Russian rescue capsules to dock with the crippled submarine's escape hatches have yielded no results and the British and Norwegian rescue mission is not expected to reach the site until lunchtime tomorrow, almost exactly a week to the hour since the accident occurred.

"The situation is almost catastrophic," said the prime minister, Mikhail Kasyanov.

The revelations of the massive damage raised fears of radioactive contamination from the two 190-megawatt nuclear reactors which powered the submarine. But Norwegian and Russian authorities said no increase had been detected in radiation levels and that contamination was a long-term problem rather than an immediate one.

The Barents sea, Bellona said, was one of the cleanest in the world and the low levels of radiation detected flowed in on the Gulf stream from Britain's and France's nuclear reprocessing plants at Sellafield and Le Hague.

webTitle: Germany brings surprise end to auction

fields.headline: Germany brings surprise end to auction
fields.trailText: Deutsche Telekom brought the race for German third-generation phone licences to a sudden halt yesterday, but only after the auction raised £31.8bn.
fields.body:
Deutsche Telekom brought the race for German third-generation phone licences to a sudden halt yesterday, but only after the auction raised £31.8bn.

A Deutsche Telekom spokesman said its subsidiary T-Mobil had opted to stop pushing bidding higher to "stop this economic insanity".

It surprised observers who expected the auction to continue until another bidder, possibly Finnish-Spanish consortium 3G, to exit.

Instead the auction ceased after 14 days in its 173rd round with the amounts paid for the six licences ranging between £5.2bn and £5.3bn.

The German government issued the six licences to the six consortiums.

T-Mobil stumped up the highest bid of £5.3bn. The other successful bidders were Vodafone's Mobilfunk, BT's Viag Interkom, France Telecom-backed MobilCom, E-plus which counts Japan's NTT DoCoMo, KPN Mobile and Hutchison Whampoa as major shareholders and 3G, a venture between Telefonica and Sonera.

The government had originally expected the auction would raise only £6.4bn and said it would use all funds raised to pay off debt.

For sale in the auction were 12 blocks of spectrum and four to six licences.

T-Mobil and Mobilfunk had both been vying for three blocks of spectrum each hoping to force out another bidder. Debitel, a subsidiary of Swisscom, was the only consortium to quit the bidding citing the hefty price.

Debts created by the licence auction across Europe are expected to force company mergers, according to Dietrich Ulmer from Viag Interkom's bidding team.

Many saw the prices as too high. The managing director of Deutsche Telekom T-Mobil, Rene Obermann, said: "We were concerned by the escalation in the bidding today, and I am disappointed over the amount we have spent. Today we have reached the pain barrier."

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Digital TV wins over the public
fields.body:
Digital TV wins over the public

Almost one in five British households subscribe to digital television, according to a survey published yesterday by the telecoms regulator, Oftel.

One-third of subscribing households have previously not used analogue cable or satellite services.

The survey shows the key incentive for taking up digital television is the greater choice of channels. Fewer than one in five subscribers use the interactive services such as home shopping and email.

According to the Oftel survey, those who had used the interactive services rated them as speedy, secure and easy to use, with a wide range of available options. Just over 40% of non-users said they were likely to use the shopping services in the future, the regulator said.

Open Plan outsources

Woolwich announced it is outsourcing the processing of applications for its Open Plan current account-cum-mortgage to Ventura. The deal will create 220 jobs in a call centre at Dearne Valley, south Yorkshire.

Biogen says MS is £2bn market

Biogen's chief executive said yesterday that he believes the worldwide market for multiple sclerosis drugs will approach $3bn (£2bn) in value by 2005.

Jim Mullen, president and chief executive officer of the Massachusetts-based biotech company, which makes Avonex, an injectable interferon treatment for MS, earlier yesterday announced an alliance with an Irish biotech company, Elan Corp, to jointly develop another MS drug - Antegren.

He expected that Antegren, a humanised monoclonal antibody, used either in combination with Avonex or alone, would expand the worldwide market by meeting currently unmet needs.

Opec refuses to be rushed

Opec will not make any decision on changing oil production ceilings until the cartel's ministers meet on September 10 in Vienna, according to the newspaper Al-Riyadh, which reflects the official Saudi point of view.

Citing advisers based in Opec's Vienna headquarters, Al-Riyadh said the oil price adjustment mechanism agreed on at an Opec meeting in March will not go into effect before next month's meeting.

"The US anti-trust inquiry is de facto at an end." Last week the European commission demanded further details regarding the proposed merger.

webTitle: Analysis: Kosovo was "a story that has not yet been fully told"

fields.headline: 'Motivated to believe the worst'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: The horror in Kosovo was "a story that has not yet been fully told," the US defence secretary, William Cohen, told American marines on the aircraft carrier Theodore Roosevelt a few days after Nato ended its bombing campaign. "When it is, people all over the world will understand why it was that America believed it had to take action."
fields.body:
The horror in Kosovo was "a story that has not yet been fully told," the US defence secretary, William Cohen, told American marines on the aircraft carrier Theodore Roosevelt a few days after Nato ended its bombing campaign. "When it is, people all over the world will understand why it was that America believed it had to take action."

Flushed with victory after 78 days of air strikes finally led President Slobodan Milosevic to withdraw Yugoslav forces from Kosovo, Mr Cohen was still in combative mood as he visited US units around the Adriatic.

Yet, as new details about the war emerge, Mr Cohen's "untold story" reveals the opposite of what he predicted. The reality of what was going on in Kosovo was less, not more, appalling than Nato claimed.

The International Criminal Tribunal's disclosure that the final toll of bodies dug up in Kosovo would be under 3,000 contrasts starkly with the estimates of mass murder given by Nato while the bombs were falling. Mr Cohen told a CBS interviewer in May that 100,000 men of military age were missing, and "may have been murdered".

David Scheffer, the US envoy for war crimes issues, put the figure even higher. He told reporters at Nato headquarters on May 18 last year that more than 225,000 ethnic Albanian men between the ages of 14 to 59 were unaccounted for.

In fact, the atrocities during the Bosnian war were on a larger scale than Kosovo. Ethnic cleansing accounted for more people in Bosnia, and some 200,000 were murdered. The hyperbole over the atrocities in Kosovo seemed to flow from Nato's need to shore up public support for its bombing, especially when the air strikes failed to secure Mr Milosevic's surrender after the first few days. "It was hard to know what was going on. But we were motivated to believe the worst," recalls Jack Seymour, a former US state department official who works for the non-governmental British American Security Information Council.

Although most Nato allegations of atrocities were covered by caveats that the reports could not be verified, officials knew these reservations were the equivalent of the small print in a contract. Headlines and soundbites were what counted. Nato also had the authority, spurious or otherwise, of data from intelligence.

Brendan Paddy of Amnesty International says: "During the war people were asking us to stand up the figures of deaths and we said we couldn't corroborate them because we had no access to Kosovo. We didn't know to what extent Nato statements were based on military intelligence. If there was intelligence to back it up at the time, it would be useful if Nato would come forward now."

When the war ended, Geoff Hoon, then a junior minister at the Foreign Office, said on June 17 last year that "at least 10,000" Albanian civilians were killed. Five months later the Foreign Office in a memorandum to the House of Commons repeated the phrase, saying it was based "on a variety of intelligence and other sources".

But it continued to make assertions without providing evidence. The memorandum claimed that a "high proportion of bodies will never be recovered, given the degree to which Serb forces, fearing war crimes charges, attempted to destroy bodies". Was this unverifiable statement an alibi to explain the relatively low number of bodies being dug up? The Hague war crimes tribunal itself refuses to give a toll of murdered civilians. It is not its job to come up with a figure, officials say.

Besides the bodies exhumed, the search for a final total would have to include the people reported missing and still unaccounted for. The International Committee for the Red Cross (ICRC), which has a mandate to trace missing people, has received 4,941 requests from families in Kosovo. In 1,573 cases the file was closed, with 199 missing people being confirmed dead and the Serb authorities admitting they were holding 1,374 Albanian men in prisons in Serbia. Of the remaining 3,368 cases some 370 are of people reportedly abducted by the Kosovo Liberation Army or Kosovo Albanian civilians.

Neither the Red Cross or the Hague tribunal can say how many of the missing 3,000 coincide with the bodies unearthed. "Between 60 and 80% of the bodies which the tribunal unearthed last year were identified but they haven't given us the lists of names," says Victoria Romano, the ICRC's protection officer in Pristina, Kosovo. Even if no names on the two lists coincided, this would raise the total of the Serbs' potential victims to a maximum of 6,000, still substantially less than the Foreign Office's "at least 10,000".

fields.headline: Serb killings 'exaggerated' by west
fields.standfirst:
Claims of up to 100,000 ethnic Albanians massacred in Kosovo revised to under 3,000 as exhumations near end

Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: The final toll of civilians confirmed massacred by Yugoslav forces in Kosovo is likely to be under 3,000, far short of the numbers claimed by Nato governments during last year's controversial air strikes on Yugoslavia.
fields.body:
The final toll of civilians confirmed massacred by Yugoslav forces in Kosovo is likely to be under 3,000, far short of the numbers claimed by Nato governments during last year's controversial air strikes on Yugoslavia.

As war crimes experts from Britain and other countries prepare to wind down the exhumation of hundreds of graves in Kosovo on behalf of the UN's International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia in the Hague, officials concede they have not borne out the worst wartime reports. These were given by refugees and repeated by western government spokesmen during the campaign. They talked of indiscriminate killings and as many as 100,000 civilians missing or taken out of refugee columns by the Serbs.

The fact that far fewer Kosovo Albanians were massacred than suggested by Nato will raise sharp questions about the organisation's handling of the media and its information strategy.

However, commentators yesterday stressed that the new details should not obscure the fact that the major war crime in the tribunal's indictment of the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, and four other Serb officials is the ethnic cleansing of Kosovo and forced deportation of hundreds of thousands of people.

"The point is did we successfully pre-empt or not," Mark Laity, the acting Nato spokesman, said last night. "I think the evidence shows we did. We would rather be criticised for overestimating the numbers who died than for failing to pre-empt. Any objective analysis would say there was a clear crisis. There was indiscriminate killing. There were attempts to clear hundreds of thousands of people out of their homes."

When Yugoslav forces withdrew from Kosovo in June last year, Nato spokesmen estimated that the Serbs had killed at least 10,000 civilians. While the bombing was under way William Cohen, the US defence secretary, announced that 100,000 Kosovo Albanian men of military age were missing after being taken from columns of families being deported to Albania and Macedonia. "They may have been murdered," he said. The fear was they might share the fate of the men who were separated from their wives and children and executed when Serb forces overran the town of Srebrenica in Bosnia.

But while some 7,000 Bosnian Muslims died in the week-long Srebrenica massacre in 1995, less than 3,000 Kosovo Albanian murder victims have been discovered in the whole of Kosovo. "The final number of bodies uncovered will be less than 10,000 and probably more accurately determined as between two and three thousand," Paul Risley, the Hague tribunal's press spokesman, said yesterday.

In three months of digging this summer, the tribunal's international forensic experts found 680 bodies at 150 sites. This was in addition to the 2,108 bodies found at 195 sites last year before exhumations were called off because of winter frosts. "By October we expect to have enough evidence to end the exhumations by foreign teams, and they will not be necessary next year," Mr Risley added.

Although the tribunal has received reports of another 350 suspected grave sites, it believes the cost and effort of uncovering them would not be justified. Some suspicious mounds or patches of rough earth in fields where villagers reported a foul stench turned out to contain dead animals or to be empty.

When the tribunal's teams reached Kosovo last summer, shortly after the international peacekeepers, they were given reports of 11,334 people in mass graves, but the results of its exhumations fall well short of that number. In a few cases, such as the Trepca mine where hundreds of bodies were alleged to have been flung down shafts or incinerated, they found nothing at all.

The tribunal's indictment of President Milosevic includes the charge that during Nato's bombing campaign Serb police shot 105 ethnic Albanian men and boys near the village of Mala Krusa in western Kosovo. Witnesses claimed hay was piled on the bodies and set alight. Tribunal experts believe the remains may have been tampered with later, since the bones of only a few people were found.

Motives questioned

The exhumation of less than 3,000 bodies is sure to add fuel to those who say Nato's intervention against Yugoslavia was not "humanitarian" and that it had other motives such as maintaining its credibility in a post-cold war world. Others say Nato's air strikes revealed a grotesque double standard since western governments did nothing when hundreds of thousands were being massacred in Rwanda.

Carla del Ponte, the tribunal's chief prosecutor, told the UN security council: "Our task is not to prepare a complete list of war casualties. Our primary task is to gather evidence relevant to criminal charges."

Evidence of the forced deportation of hundreds of thousands of people was overwhelming before the tribunal gained access to Kosovo but the exhumations are aimed at finding evidence for the charges of mass murder.

"Their benefit is to link forensic evidence to particular units of the police and army operating in particular parts of Kosovo. It wasn't a case of rogue units. The Serbian police state was fully involved," Mr Risley said. But officials will not say how many of the 2,788 bodies exhumed show clear signs of being victims of summary execution such as being shot in the head from close range.

No Nato government has sought to produce a definitive total of murdered ethnic Albanian civilians since the Serb offensives began in March 1998, a year before the bombing. "No one is interested," complained a senior international official in Kosovo involved in helping victims' families. "Nato doesn't want to admit the damage wasn't as extensive as it said. Local Albanian politicians have the same motive. If you don't have the true figure, you can exploit the issue."

webTitle: Things turn nasty for Nick as Big Brother throws him out

fields.headline: Things turn nasty for Nick as Big Brother throws him out
fields.standfirst: Special report: Big Brother
fields.trailText: Weeks of double-dealing caught up with "nasty" Nick Bateman last night when his scheming ways led to eviction from the voyeuristic television game show Big Brother.
fields.body:
Weeks of double-dealing caught up with "nasty" Nick Bateman last night when his scheming ways led to eviction from the voyeuristic television game show Big Brother.

Nick's fellow contestants dragged themselves out of self-absorption for long enough to figure out the truth that to the nation had appeared obvious. After discovering his attempts to manipulate nominations that decide who is thrown out of the show, they confronted him with his crimes. Tension became so high that it almost came to blows, and nervous producers pulled the plug on the show's live webcast.

The link was restored later, in time for fans to watch emotional scenes that rivalled the best of British television for dramatic tension. Nick hit back with claims that his public school and City background had conditioned his competitive instincts.

As it became clear that the former Lloyd's broker was prepared to brazen it out, Channel 4 stepped in to give him the boot for "persistent infringement" of the Big Brother rules.

The winner of Big Brother's £70,000 prize is the last person left in the house after contestants and members of the public have voted the rest out. Nick had been writing notes and showing them to fellow contestants in an attempt to influence their voting intentions. "The rules of Big Brother expressly forbid contestants from talking about nominations and tactical voting," Channel 4 said. His position was untenable.

Because Nick leaves the show outside of the weekly eviction process, his place will be taken by a replacement drawn from a list of back-up candidates. The new contestant's identity has not yet been announced.

The website took 6m hits yesterday, making Big Brother by far the most popular event to have been broadcast on the internet in Britain.

Despite his lack of popularity with viewers, Nick's tactics had proved a success with his housemates. Each week the participants must nominate two of their number for eviction - the public has the final say in a telephone vote - but not once did they pick Nick.

Dr Linda Papadopoulos, the show's counselling psychologist, told the Big Brother website yesterday: "He realised who everyone wanted to be and he allowed them to be just that person when he was with them. He played them."

Such was the scale of his deviousness that rumours spread that he was a Channel 4 mole. The press reported that he had smuggled in a mobile phone, but a search found nothing.

Last night Nick was holed up in a hotel in central London with his family, a psychologist, and minders from the programme, as the events of yesterday were screened in an extended programme on Channel 4. His eviction - and that of Craig or Nichola, depending on the outcome of this week's vote - will be shown on tonight's broadcasts.

webTitle: Martin Woollacott: The lesson of Concorde is that we can't go any faster

fields.headline: The lesson of Concorde is that we can't go any faster
fields.standfirst:
Civilisation rests in the balance between speed and safety
Special report: the Concorde crash
fields.trailText: The world's long romance with speed may finally be ending. Even if Concorde flies again, its antique nature was revealed as soon as the Paris accident made people scratch their heads and ask quite why these odd aircraft were still flying.
fields.body:
The world's long romance with speed may finally be ending. Even if Concorde flies again, its antique nature was revealed as soon as the Paris accident made people scratch their heads and ask quite why these odd aircraft were still flying. Much of the technology that surrounds us has, when we look at it afresh, this Jules Verne quality - solving problems that once seemed important in ways that are ingenious but not necessarily efficient or safe.

The reorientation of science toward the biological and computer frontiers is now an old story, but the 19th-century fascination with motive power has retained a powerful hold on our imaginations and our economies. One of the curious things about the last century is that almost every technological development that actually took place had been imagined and considered in fiction and non-fiction in the years before the first world war.

When these developments actually arrived they were thus already freighted with meaning, and were never simply neutral means to ends. Advances in motive power were for a long while the main way in which progress and national competition in technology were measured. First at sea, then on the railways, then on the roads, in the air and finally in space, more and more rapid movement was seen as an unalloyed good and also, in some hazy way, as a key to a fuller understanding of the world. All kinds of speed were interconnected, forming a transmission belt to a future which people believed would be radically changed.

The early 20th century approach to the revolution in transportation had already parted company from purely practical considerations to imagine what now seem rather tenuous intellectual, political and emotional advantages. HG Wells and Rudyard Kipling, for instance, both imagined world states based on air dictatorships. Space travel, it was implied by its proponents, might in the end allow the whole universe to be completely understood. So intoxicating was this ultimate way in which the growing speed and reach of man-made vehicles could be used that when an unknown rocket buff called Hermann Oberth published his By Rocket to Interplanetary Space in the 1920s, it represented such an escape from the difficulties of the present to the anxious citizens of Weimar Germany that it became a bestseller overnight. Later Fritz Lang transmuted Oberth's propositions into a hit film, The Girl in the Moon.

The destination was important, but sheer velocity was almost always part of the formula. For individual sportsmen, pilots and drivers, speed had the status of a privileged substance to which, in those early days, only a minority had full access. Passengers and spectators participated but in a lesser way. Mechanised speed made men, and a few women, into heroes, and it remains a commodity to which males, in particular, are attracted. The front of the Boys Own annual of half a century ago would typically feature a speeding train in the middle ground, a fast aeroplane above, and a racing car in the foreground. Such icons are still with us.

Disentangling the genuine advantages of speed from its cult aspects has always been a problem, and this was certainly the case in the era in which Concorde was conceived. Land, air and sea speed records had mattered since the 20s in a way inconceivable today and all the advanced nations strove to run faster, swim faster, drive faster, fly faster, and, later, to shoot missiles higher and further than other countries.

This manic race was run on three tracks - of celebrity sport, of competition between civil industries and of military development. All three were littered with casualties, whether it was spectators at Le Mans, Donald Campbell on Coniston Water, or numerous test pilots and astronauts through the years.

Britain was slowing down on all three courses when Concorde came along. Indeed the Concorde project survived in part because Britain had just had to discard three advanced military aircraft programmes and wanted to keep at least one prestige effort going. The other reason, as Harold Wilson explained in his memoirs, was that the agreement with the French was embodied in an international treaty, and they refused even to consider abandoning or postponing the work.

If Britain tried to pull out, Wilson says, we would probably have had to pay half the costs of what would then be developed as a wholly French aeroplane. "Faced with this situation," he noted, "we had little choice but to go on." His lack of enthusiasm suggests that long before Concorde actually flew, some of those responsible for it knew that it was not going to be a practical aircraft, and also that the technical spin-off would be less than advertised. The reason was that speed was such a dominant consideration that everything else had to take second place. The result was an aircraft that was both ahead of its time and behind the times, since the era of small-scale luxury air travel was over.

The preoccupation with speed has always gone hand in hand with a preoccupation with safety, the two standards between them providing a way in which advanced states calibrate the state of civilisation. Increasing speeds have indicated technical progress, while accidents indicate loss of control. The first world lives in constant fear of regression, of losing the scientific and organisational edge that enables it to be both fast and safe. That is one reason why air and sea accidents can attain such mythic status. webTitle: GPs look to their safety in face of assaults and threats

fields.headline: Surgery corrals violent patients
fields.standfirst:
GPs look to their safety in face of assaults and threats

Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: GPs look to their safety in face of assaults and threats
fields.body:
A CCTV camera scans the waiting room, and the spartan consulting room boasts a prominent panic alarm. The furniture is nailed down, to prevent footstools from being used as weapons.

The small surgery is dwarfed by its neighbour - a police station.

The first purpose-built centre catering for patients who persistently assault or intimidate their doctors has opened for business.

It has been built in the grounds of Bitterne police station in Southampton, a £40,000 pilot project which follows a British Medical Association survey last year revealing that 41% of GPs had been assaulted in their surgeries or while on call.

Department of Health figures show that 914 patients were removed from GPs' lists because of violence, or threats of violence, in the 12 months to last October.

Martin Lewis, a Southampton GP involved in setting up the surgery, said abuse from patients was widespread. "We've all been intimidated. I've been intimidated on home visits, and my partner has had a necklace wrenched from her neck in the surgery."

He blamed the violence on "increased expectation" of the health service and impatience to be seen for treatment.

It is hoped that the proximity of a police station will be enough to discourage bad behaviour and give GPs an alternative to simply kicking violent patients off their lists.

"If someone has been aggressive in the past, the fact that we are telling them now that we want to see them at the police unit could be a deterrent. People don't want to be branded with that."

The unit, opened eight weeks ago, is usually unmanned but can be booked by any of the 326 GPs in the Southampton and south-west Hampshire health authority area. Police surgeons can also make use of it.

It has yet to be used and could soon be criticised as an expensive deterrent. Dr Lewis admitted: "Perhaps it will be a white elephant, but we have got to be seen to be doing something."

Superintendent Steven Lawrence of Hampshire police said the initiative stemmed from a wave of violence against doctors a few years ago. In one area of Southampton "doctors were considered vulnerable, and one was quite badly assaulted. It was decided that something needed to be done."

The BMA is keen to see similar "safe havens" opened. Government funding has been made available for them in other health authorities.

Surgeries could be opened either at police stations or on hospital sites under security guard protection.

Simon Fradd, deputy chairman of the BMA's GPs' committee, said: "It is not beneficial to patients or to proper consultation if the doctor feels threatened and at risk."

Last year a poll in the association's News Review found that four in 10 family doctors had been attacked, and 80% had stepped up security.

The News Review quoted a Cardiff GP, Andrew Dearden, who was taken hostage by a patient's family during a home visit, after the patient had taken drugs and become aggressive.

"After I had entered the patient's room, two 6ft male family members blocked the doorway," he said. "They refused to move until I agreed to admit the patient to a hospital psychiatric unit.

"After 45 minutes of negotiation and threatening to call 999 they agreed to let me go."

An Edinburgh GP, who asked not to be named, described being threatened in his surgery by a drug addict brandishing an 8in knife. The doctor used a panic button to call security and the police.

webTitle: Ewen MacAskill: The need for an ethical defence industry

fields.headline: No defence
fields.standfirst:
Our arms sales to dodgy regimes support only 40,000 jobs. They're not worth sullying ourselves for
Special report: Labour's ethical foreign policy
fields.trailText: Our arms sales to dodgy regimes support only 40,000 jobs. They're not worth sullying ourselves for.
fields.body:
After the poor performance of the RAF in both the Gulf and now Kosovo, the wonder is that anyone in the world would want to pay for British arms. And yet they still do. The Ministry of Defence confirmed yesterday that Britain is the world's second biggest exporter of arms, coming in behind the US and ahead of Germany, France and Russia.

Britain was responsible for 22% of arms sales worldwide last year, an astonishingly high share of the market for a relatively small country, especially one whose planes have proved suspect in combat.

The arms industry has done more than anything else to undermine the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, and his promise to introduce an ethical dimension into foreign policy. A foreign minister from another country, reviewing Mr Cook's performance over the past three years, summed it up succinctly: "You can't have an ethical foreign policy and an arms industry."

That foreign minister was wrong. It is possible to conduct both an ethical foreign policy and maintain an arms industry. The bulk of arms sales are non-contentious: it is sales to countries that are non-democratic and have little respect for human rights that create the controversy.

An annual report on arms sales published last month by the MoD, the Foreign Office and the Department of Trade and Industry, showed that the government granted licences for arms sales last year amounting to £900m. Some of the biggest British orders were to non-contentious countries such as Canada (£36m), Germany (£45m), France (£36m), the US (£86m) and Italy (£69m). The British arms industry would not disappear if a curb were placed on contentious countries such as Indonesia, Saudi Arabia, Pakistan and Zimbabwe. Taken together, the dubious countries account for about a third of sales. It is a relatively small figure: certainly not worth the damage caused to Britain's image both at home and overseas.

But the defence industry in this country is a powerful lobby. It argues that if Britain does not sell to those countries, there are plenty of others who will. It also argues that if Britain is seen as too self-righteous about selling to dubious regimes, this will have a negative effect on all British arms exports.

The main argument is the impact on jobs. The MoD estimates that there are 355,000 British jobs dependent on the arms industry and of these, 130,000 depend on arms exports. Stripping out sales to dubious regimes could cost a third of these jobs, about 40,000. That seems a lot and would be hurtful for those involved. But the decline in manufacturing industry over the past two decades has seen huge numbers displaced and absorbed elsewhere.

Much of the defence industry is beginning to diversify anyway into civilian products. The changes have been forced on it by a dramatic decline in arms sales since the end of the cold war and a slump in the Asian markets. The value of arms licences issued by the government in 1993 was £5bn, in 1997 £3.35bn, in 1998 £1.9bn and last year down to £900m.

The decline has meant a more competitive industry and costs becoming marginal. So why does Britain persevere in a dwindling market?

An MoD spokesman said yesterday that arms exports helped offset the cost of developing and producing weapons for British forces. He estimated this amounted to £400m a year of taxpayers' money saved. But this is offset by the huge amounts of taxpayers' money that have gone out in promoting British sales overseas. The MoD has a section (the defence exports services organisation), specially for this purpose, with its own staff overseas. Sales promotion is also part of work of the wide network of British defence attaches who work at embassies round the world.

There are further hidden subsidies for the arms industry. The notorious export credit guarantee department, part of the Department of Trade and Industry, has for years provided money to developing countries to buy British arms. Aid in the past has been used as part of a quid pro quo for arms sales.

Mr Cook feels hard done by over the charges of hypocrisy levelled at him over the ethical dimension to his foreign policy. He has some justification for feeling hurt. At least he has tried. If the Conservatives had been in charge, there would have been no mention of an ethical foreign policy. And if Peter Mandelson or Jack Straw or some other minister replaces Mr Cook at the foreign office after the general election, the chances are the "ethical dimension" will be little heard of again. Mr Cook's problem is that he set a benchmark against which his foreign policy could be judged. He has lost out in arguments with the Ministry of Defence, the Department of Trade and Industry and, decisively, Downing Street.

The powerful defence industry needs to be tackled. Sadly, Mr Cook may turn out to have been the best bet for achieving that change, but to have failed. The chances are Britain will continue proudly to proclaim its place as second biggest arms exporter in the world, regardless of both the ethics and economics.

fields.headline: Doomed benefit card cost £800m
fields.standfirst:
'Fraud proof' system beset by problems will never be used

Special report: welfare reform
fields.trailText: More than £800m has been wasted on a "fraud free" benefit swipe card for 17m claimants which will never be used, parliament's financial watchdog reveals today.
fields.body:
More than £800m has been wasted on a "fraud free" benefit swipe card for 17m claimants which will never be used, parliament's financial watchdog reveals today.

The card, flourished at the 1995 Conservative party conference by Peter Lilley, then social security secretary, was cancelled by his Labour successor, Alastair Darling, last May after ministers were told they were throwing away £15m a month on a system that could never work.

The national audit office said taxpayers have lost £127m; ICL, the computer company that designed the product, £180m; and the Post Office is facing a £571m loss, to cover the debacle.

The card was ordered by the benefits agency and the Post Office as a fraud-proof way of paying out more than 24 benefits to 17m claimants at 20,000 post offices in the United Kingdom. The card, which would have cost £1bn in total, promised to handle 760m payments to claimants a year and save the ministry £100m a year by making benefit fraud impossible.

The auditors reveal that even when the card was commissioned in 1996 civil servants knew it was a high risk project. Papers from the time reveal ICL's card system had "weak authentication procedures and the weakest security proposals", and the company's subsidiary, Pathway, had a "manifest lack of under standing of the management of fraud risk".

Despite misgivings, Whitehall ordered the system before 289 operational problems had been solved because it fitted in with the Tory government's support of private finance initiatives, in which the private sector takes some of the risk.

The card was used to pay child benefit in 10 post offices in Gloucestershire under the Tories. Later Labour extended it to pay child benefit in 205 post offices in the south-west and north-east of England in November 1997.

After 18 months of further negotiations Labour scrapped the project in May last year, deciding to go ahead with the automation of post offices without the new card. Instead benefit payments would be paid direct to bank and post office accounts. The scale of the scandal led Tony Blair to order the Cabinet Office to review the handling of future large scale hi-tech projects by Whitehall.

Sir John Bourn, the comptroller and auditor general, is livid about Whitehall's handling of the project. In today's report he puts the blame on the "organisational myopia" in Whitehall which allowed "fundamental flaws in the design of the management of the scheme".

He also blames rows between the Post Office and the Department of Social Security, which had different priorities in using the card. Social security wanted to curb fraud; the Post Office wanted to expand its business under automation.

"Although in theory projects can be run by two or more organisations, in practice this is a recipe for dispute and delay, which is what happened in this case," Sir John said.

He is critical of "the insufficient work that went into specifying the project and for demonstrations by bidders".

"The result of skimping at the start was vast delay and as it turned out, wasted money."

Sir John, who says that in hi-tech projects "mistakes like this are being made time and time again", calls for sweeping changes, including the appointment of one person in Whitehall, a "risk scrutineer", to take responsibility for each major project.

David Davis, chairman of the House of Commons' public accounts committee, said he hoped the NAO's report would mark a watershed in the way Whitehall managed information technology projects.

"Today's report by the NAO is the latest, and probably worst, example in a long line of public sector IT debacles," said Mr Davis, Conservative MP for Haltemprice and Howden.

Mr Darling welcomed the report: "We cancelled the benefits payment card because it was three years late, costs were escalating and in any event the card would have been obsolete in five years time. It would have been utterly irresponsible to continue with the project.

"The cost of making payments by the card would have been 65p per payment. The cost of making payments by automatic credit transfer is less than 1p per payment. The move to automatic credit transfer from 2003 will virtually eliminate £100m of fraud in benefit payments annually."

David Rendel, Liberal Democrat member of the public accounts committe, said: "The project has been a disaster from start to finish. It has cost the Post Office millions and threatened the future of the post office network ... and the public sector has ended up footing most of the bill."

Computer errors

The passport agency Two years ago thousands of people had to queue outside the agency's London headquarters after a new computer system, developed with the German firm Siemens, to issue passports failed to deliver. The system is now on course but the taxpayer lost £12.5m.

Civil aviation authority Millions of holiday air passengers are facing delays because a £623m air traffic control centre at Swanwick, Hampshire has not opened. The computerised system does not work and will need more modification before it enters service.

Inland revenue Computerisation of the Inland Revenue undertaken by EDS. Cost of the contract is now £2.4bn - £1bn higher than first planned.

Contributions agency Some 172,000 Serps pensioners lost between 1p and £100 a week last year when a computer system developed by Andersen Consulting for 65m national insurance accounts could not handle all the data.

Immigration directorate Thousands of immigration and asylum seekers had to endure hardship and anxiety after a computer system, also designed by Siemens, was not suitable to handle the applications. The result was a backlog of 219,000 cases.

Not everything fails. The £28m Home Office tagging scheme for prisoners has been praised. About 21,000 people have been tagged and in 94% of cases it has worked.

www.nao.gov.uk National Audit Office

webTitle: Captive chimps in Madrid have begun to puree their own fruit and vegetables

fields.headline: Now it's the Naked Chimp
fields.trailText: There is a chimpanzee in Kyoto who can count up to nine. There are chimpanzees who can construct seemingly sophisticated sentences in sign languages.
fields.body:
There is a chimpanzee in Kyoto who can count up to nine. There are chimpanzees who can construct seemingly sophisticated sentences in sign languages.

But until now, no one had observed a chimpanzee behaving as if it had watched an episode of The Naked Chef.

Captive chimps in Madrid have begun to puree their own fruit and vegetables, according to the latest New Scientist, reporting from a meeting of the Animal Behaviour Society in Atlanta, Georgia. Samuel Fernandez-Carriba, a primatologist, reported that a chimp called Linda had arrived at Madrid's Universidad Autonoma zoo in 1992. Her previous owner had removed her teeth to prevent being bitten.

Within a year, her keepers noticed that she ate apples after she had rubbed them on a sharp corner for a short spell. She then licked up the pulp and juice that ran out, and rubbed the apple again.

Six other chimps in the same enclosure began to imitate her. Dr Fernandez-Carriba and colleagues reported that they had spent 450 hours watching the chimps putting their food through their makeshift blender. They used Linda's method - the sharp corner, the 10-second burst - to eat carrots, apples, oranges and lemons. The scientists concluded that they were watching a case of culturally transmitted food transformation. In other words, Ready Steady Cook for primates.

But Dr Fernandez-Carriba added: "These are not cases of transformation of food in the human way. Transformation involves things like heating and grinding."

fields.headline: Freecom.net blues
fields.standfirst:
Special report: e-finance

Net news
fields.trailText: They say revenge is a dish best eaten cold and yesterday Michael Williams, who suddenly resigned as chief executive of Freecom.net on Wednesday, appeared to be putting the old cliche to the test.
fields.body:
They say revenge is a dish best eaten cold and yesterday Michael Williams, who suddenly resigned as chief executive of Freecom.net on Wednesday, appeared to be putting the old cliche to the test.

An official stock exchange statement said the outspoken Mr Williams sold 1m Freecom shares on the day of his departure. Paradoxically, Freecom shares rose 14% after his resignation.

While Freecom maintained the departure was amicable, dealers are not so sure. They point out that Mr Williams had come in for fierce criticism from the City over the handling of the Oneview.net acquisition and the slump in Freecom's share price since March.

With Mr Williams still holding a 2.39% - or 2.4m shares - stake in the company, dealers believe further selling cannot be ruled out. This is likely to affect the shares - down 1p to 56.5p yesterday - in the short term.

webTitle: Judge bars DVD codes from net

fields.headline: Judge bars DVD codes from net
fields.standfirst:
Special report: e-finance

Net news
fields.trailText: A federal judge last night gave the film industry a victory in a high-profile legal case by banning a journalist from republishing software code that unlocks scrambling on DVDs, enabling them to be copied and swapped on the internet.
fields.body:
A federal judge last night gave the film industry a victory in a high-profile legal case by banning a journalist from republishing software code that unlocks scrambling on DVDs, enabling them to be copied and swapped on the internet.

Earlier this year New York US district court judge Lewis Kaplan issued a preliminary injunction banning the defendant Eric Corley, publisher of 2600 (www.2600.org), a top magazine and website of the hacker underground, from posting the code.

The plaintiffs in the legal action, which include Hollywood's biggest studios, Seagram's Universal, MGM and Warner Bros, had sought a permanent injunction.

After several days of testimony in July, Judge Kaplan ordered both sides to submit briefs by August 8, outlining whether computer codes can be considered legally protected forms of speech.

Judge Kaplan yesterday said: "In an era in which the transmission of computer viruses _ can disable systems upon which the nation depends and in which other computer code also is capable of inflicting harm, society must be able to regulate the use and dissemination of code in appropriate circumstance."

The film industry is concerned about widespread piracy resulting from the use of the software to copy movies on DVDs.

 Websites for Nasa and the French national library have been defaced by a hacker who has been angered by attempts to shut down the music sharing start-up, Napster, it emerged yesterday. According to computer website ZDNet News, the hacker - known as Pimpshiz - has exploited a Windows NT bug to target high-profile sites and is about to launch another wave of attacks. The unidentified hacker told the new site that he had defaced five dozen sites in the past two weeks.

fields.headline: Thus rebuts takeover talk
fields.standfirst: Market forces  Neil Hume
fields.trailText: Telecoms company Thus yesterday insisted that it was not involved in takeover talks even as it fired off notices forcing holders of its shares to come clean about their identity.
fields.body:
Telecoms company Thus yesterday insisted that it was not involved in takeover talks even as it fired off notices forcing holders of its shares to come clean about their identity.

Amid persistent speculation of a takeover, Thus is clearly anxious to establish those on its shareholder register.

The company yesterday admitted that it had been sending out the "212" notices which permit it to demand certain information from its shareholders.

After the violent movement in its shares and heavy turnover since its profit warning in late July, it appears that Thus has lost track of its big shareholders.

However, a hostile bid or even a stake-building exercise by a predator seems unlikely, given that Scottish Power - down 16p to 540p - retains a 50.1% stake.

Nevertheless, there clearly is enough anxiety for the company to take the time and trouble to sort who, exactly, is on the register.

Energis , off 22.5p at 496p, along with Cable & Wireless, down 15p to £11.32, and even Colt Communications, 100p weaker at £18.35, have been mentioned as potential suitors as Thus shares fell to an all-time low 118p in the wake of the warning.

But a spokesman for the company said: "Thus is not in takeover talks with anybody at the moment."

Thus shares closed 1p better at 128p as 4.2m shares changed hands.

The FTSE 100's three-session winning streak came to a halt as telecoms sector moved lower following the end of the German third generation mobile phone licence auction.

London's blue-chip gauge of shares closed down 13.8 points at 6,518.2, with Vodafone alone wiping 31 points from the index.

Shares in the telecoms operator, which accounts for around 12% of the FTSE 100's market capitalisation, declined 11.5p to 270p, rattled by the price paid to secure a Germany 3G licence. A cautious research note from Lehman Brothers did not help matters. Although retaining a "buy" rating on the stock, Lehman cut its 2001 forecast for earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortisation by 15% and 10% for 2002. It lowered its target price to 425p from 450p.

Elsewhere in the sector, BT eased 11p to 812p as investors took fright at its spiralling debt mountain.

After taking control of German telecoms group Viag Interkom - via the purchase of Eon's 45% stake - BT's gearing will rise to 190%.

Dealers were also concerned by the fact that Viag placed the highest bid of all for a German 3G licence.

However, oil stocks continued to hold their own, underpinned by the strong crude price and sector rotation. Shell added 14p to 587p, while BP Amoco advanced by some 9.5p to 624.5p.

Financial stocks remained in demand supported by consolidation talk and positive noises from secretive broker Cazenove.

In a review of the sector Cazenove was said to have issued positive recommendations on Barclays , up 55p to £17.30, Royal Bank of Scotland , 22p higher at £13.55p, and Standard Chartered , 29p better at £10.07.

Bid speculation continued to swirl around composite insurer Royal & Sun Alliance , up a further 15p to 505p.

The FTSE 250 ended 19.8 points lower at 6,879.6, with Computacenter the biggest faller. Shares in the computer services firm tumbled 47.5p to 377.5p after it posted weaker than expected interim figures and warned that the hangover which followed increased pre-millennial computer spending would be continued into the second half of the year.

In the smaller company universe, Britax International shed 33p to 101.5p on heavy turnover after the company took a hefty exceptional charge while Teamtalk shot up 14p to 62.5p on speculation of an imminent deal.

fields.headline: At this price?  Photo-Me
fields.trailText: Things have not gone well for would-be internet stock Photo-Me International. Earlier this month the company, a photo-booth operator which hopes to put its snaps on the web, saw a tumble in its share price caused by an accounting dispute that delayed the group's results.
fields.body:
Things have not gone well for would-be internet stock Photo-Me International. Earlier this month the company, a photo-booth operator which hopes to put its snaps on the web, saw a tumble in its share price caused by an accounting dispute that delayed the group's results.

Ernst & Young, Photo-Me's joint auditors, refused to sign off the full-year accounts after a dispute over the inclusion of £4.5m as operating profit in the half-year figures.

Yesterday the company finally published its delayed figures. It reported flat full-year earnings, in line with the recent profit warning or auditor's disagreement.

Full-year pre-tax profits before an exceptional profit of £1.8 m came to £20m, the same as last year. Turnover for the year to April 30 was a fraction above £200m.

Chief executive Serge Crasnianski said yesterday that he was confident of a satisfactory performance in the year ahead. Photo-Me shares closed down 5.5p at 90p. A final dividend of 1.2p was recommended, up from 1.06p last year.

Board changes, which Photo-Me said were related to the changing nature of its business, have been limited so far: former managing director and current non-executive director David Miller resigned yesterday, but further departures are expected.

In truth, Photo-Me's readjustment has been less to do with its recent trials and tribulations - which have seen its price fall from around the £2 mark to nearer £1 - than they have with bloated expectations at the turn of the millennium.

Anticipation of Photo-Me's move into the internet world had boosted its share price to more than £4. Given the good cash-generating heart of the business, Photo-Me is always pretty likely to give a decent return. The revelation that management sold shares at 400p about six months ago would tend to indicate that the share price is not heading that far north again for quite some time to come. At best, this stock is a hold.

webTitle: Archer saga key man injured in crash

fields.headline: Archer saga key man injured in crash
fields.standfirst: Special report: the fall of Archer
fields.trailText: A former friend of Lord Archer, who pledged to testify against the peer if he was charged with perjury, yesterday suffered head injuries in a motorcycle accident.
fields.body:
A former friend of Lord Archer, who pledged to testify against the peer if he was charged with perjury, yesterday suffered head injuries in a motorcycle accident.

Michael Stacpoole was expected to be a key witness if the former Tory vice-chairman is prosecuted for attempting to influence witnesses in a libel trial he brought in 1987 over allegations he slept with a prostitute, Monica Coghlan.

Mr Stacpoole, 62, was injured when a motorcycle he was riding collided with another bike in the resort of Pattaya, Thailand, 95 miles from Bangkok. He was taken to hospital, where he was last night in an intensive care unit.

A confidant of Lord Archer, Mr Stacpoole went to London Victoria railway station to hand Ms Coghlan a package containing £2,000 on behalf of the millionaire novelist.

The crown prosecution service is examining evidence it received last week from a police investigation into the peer. In December Scotland Yard detectives interviewed Mr Stacpoole in Pattaya where he now lives. He claimed to have been paid £40,000 to leave Britain during Lord Archer's libel action against the Daily Star. Lord Archer won £500,000 damages from the newspaper over a story about an alleged relationship with Ms Coghlan. He has denied paying his former friend to leave the country.

A nurse at the Bangkok Pattaya hospital, where Mr Stacpoole is being treated, said he had head injuries and a fractured shoulder and was in a serious condition, but that his life was not in danger. In May Mr Stacpoole was left partially paralysed after suffering a stroke.

In November Lord Archer resigned in disgrace as the Tory candidate in the London mayoral elections and was subsequently expelled from the Conservative party for five years.

Although the CPS has declined to discuss possible charges, it is thought to be considering alleged offences of attempting or conspiring to pervert the course of justice, or of perjury.

The police investigation was sparked by Lord Archer's admission in November that he had asked his then friend Ted Francis to lie for him at the libel trial, giving him a false alibi. In the event, this was never used in court.

The newspaper is now seeking the return of the damages, its costs and interest, estimated to total around £3m.
