fields.headline: 'Safety at risk' in tube sell-off
fields.standfirst:
Leaked memo reveals rail watchdog's concern
Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Safety risks with "potentially serious consequences" have been uncovered in John Prescott's plans to partly privatise the London Underground, less than six months before contracts are due to be signed, a private letter from the government's chief rail inspector has revealed.
fields.body:
Safety risks with "potentially serious consequences" have been uncovered in John Prescott's plans to partly privatise the London Underground, less than six months before contracts are due to be signed, a private letter from the government's chief rail inspector has revealed.

In a memorandum to the company's management last week, which has been passed to the Guardian, the principal rail safety inspector, Stanley Hart, warned of a "growing concern" about safety in the partly sold-off tube system that the deputy prime minister wants to bring in next spring.

Describing himself as frustrated, Mr Hart accused London Underground of overseeing a "breakdown in local management control" in the structures that had been set up for the plans, with "either no proof that the systems work or proof that they are not working".

The disclosure comes at a highly sensitive time for the government, in the run-up to the Labour party conference next month.

Its plans to break up the tube and bring in private companies to run the infrastructure are likely to come under strong attack from trade unionists and party activists.

The catalogue of disasters since the privatisation of British Rail and the admission by the rail inspectorate at the Paddington crash inquiry this year that it had failed to keep a grip on the fragmented private industry have made the issue of safety in the plans for London Underground more sensitive.

Mr Prescott's Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions and the health and safety executive - of which the rail inspectorate is part - yesterday refused to comment on the leaked letter.

But the London mayor, Ken Livingstone, who made opposition to the partial tube sell-off a central plank of his election campaign, seized on the letter as evidence of the dangers of pressing ahead, although he has no legal powers to stop the deals.

"This letter will confirm Londoners' worst fears about the government's public-private partnership scheme and highlights the risk of a Paddington-style crash underground," he said last night.

"The partial sell-off is a threat to the lives of Londoners. The government should heed these warnings and withdraw their dangerous and ill-conceived plans."

The government intends to pass on responsibility for the tube to Mr Livingstone only after it has handed over the infrastructure - accounting for about half the business - to private sector companies on the basis of 30-year contracts.

The network is being split into three parts, and bids are already in for two of them. If the contracts go ahead as planned early next year the structure could be locked in place for a generation.

In his letter, Mr Hart said his inspectorate had "consistently expressed a growing concern that it does not have full confidence" in London Underground's systems being "shadowed" in preparation for break-up and part-privatisation.

It was vital that there was an effective system of ensuring compliance with safety rules, he said. "There is evidence that these criteria are not being met consistently."

A "further disquieting aspect" was the lack of central responsibility in the planned system, when central co-ordination was "essential", he added.

webTitle: Press piles scorn on silent Russian president

fields.headline: Press piles scorn on silent president
fields.standfirst:
Russian journalists flex their newfound muscle

Special report: Russia's stricken submarine
fields.trailText: Russian journalists flex their newfound muscle as Kursk emergency  becomes a PR fiasco for the Kremlin, the government, and the military top brass.
fields.body:
Vladimir Putin yesterday encountered the most sustained barrage of criticism since he became president of Russia, with the country's media mocking his minimal response to the Arctic submarine emergency, pouring scorn on the statements of the government and navy command, and questioning the effectiveness and speed of the Kursk rescue effort.

Since Mr Putin became prime minister a year ago and then president in March, the media have been generally glowing in their treatment of the Kremlin chief, whose spin doctors have been adept at exploiting his telegenic talents.

But the Kursk emergency has fast become a PR fiasco for the Kremlin, the government, and the military top brass.

"Whose honour is drowning in the Barents sea?" ran the frontpage headline in the Kommersant newspaper above a picture of Mr Putin being saluted by a young naval conscript. "There are no political dividends here," the paper said, explaining the president's low profile on the crisis.

"No senior state officials will risk taking responsibility here. Nor will the president."

It then ran a column of how foreign leaders interrupt their holidays and take charge in natural disasters or emergencies. Mr Putin has been on holiday on the Black sea since Saturday.

The secrecy, high-handedness and deliberate misinformation from the authorities are being compared with the Chernobyl disaster of 1986 and its political impact on Mikhail Gorbachev and his policies of glasnost. At the time the kneejerk reaction of the communist regime was to cover up the world's worst nuclear accident.

The Kursk crisis is not on that scale. But the scope and nature of the Russian newspaper coverage highlights the big difference with 1986 - the growing clout of public opinion and its impact on the political process.

The mass-circulation tabloid Komsomolskaya Pravda devoted seven pages to the Kursk yesterday, with a banner headline that asked: "The Kursk sailors fell silent yesterday. Why is the president silent?"

Mr Putin has made only one statement on the Kursk, on Wednesday, and retreated into uncharacteristic silence yesterday. It is highly unusual for an inexperienced politician who built his appeal on action, dynamism, and shows of resolve. He said earlier this year: "The president is responsible for everything."

It took the navy top brass two days to disclose the accident. But if the admirals have since been wilfully misleading the media, Russian journalists have been chasing the story down boldly, locating relatives of the mariners, seeking out experts and retired submarinemen, and grilling officials at every available opportunity.

The relish with which they are exposing this huge blow to Russian prestige underlines the problems any would-be authoritarian leader will have curbing press freedoms.

"Our state machinery has been on the sea-bed for a long time," said a commentary on the front page of Izvestiya yesterday. "Lying and terror, such are the features of Russian government."

What the papers say:

Izvestiya daily, broadly supportive of Putin

"The generals and admirals are ... afraid to tell the truth about their subordinates on the sea bed. They're afraid of losing their jobs. They're afraid of asking the west for help ... so as not to show up their own helplessness."

Kommersant daily, increasingly critical of Putin

"Eveything might have been different if the rescue operation started not on Tuesday but on Saturday when the Kursk sank ... The embargo on the president reacting to the Kursk was set by Vladimir Putin himself."

Segodnya, opposition to Putin

"It's shocking that the Russian government only asked the British for help after the president declared that the situation was critical."

fields.headline: Judgment day for Muirpace broker
fields.standfirst: News Analysis   £32.5m fraud that rocked the wealthy Thompson family
fields.trailText: One of Britain's wealthiest families will be keeping a watchful eye on events unfolding at the Old Bailey today.
fields.body:
One of Britain's wealthiest families will be keeping a watchful eye on events unfolding at the Old Bailey today.

Appearing for sentencing is commodities broker Allan Leonard, an old family friend and employee of the Thompsons, founders of the Hillsdown Holdings combine.

Mr Leonard, from Chislehurst in Kent, has admitted 15 charges of fraud, forgery and false accounting in relation to a £32.5m loss at a derivatives firm controlled by the Thompsons.

The family's diverse business interests have spanned meat packing firms, racecourses, horses, football clubs, fashion and film companies. That portfolio has enabled former Smithfield meat trader David Thompson, 63, and his son Richard, 35, to amass a combined fortune which the Sunday Times' rich list last year estimated at £340m.

Mr Leonard's fraud at Muirpace, the Thompson controlled commodities firm, has hit his former employees hard. According to the Sunday newspaper, it has helped knock back their fortune by around £90m.

The Thompsons were stunned when, two years ago, Mr Leonard confessed that he had run up multimillion-pound losses through a series of unsuccessful trades.

Not only had Mr Leonard been one of their longest serving and most trusted employees, but he had also become a close friend through their shared passion for racehorses. Mr Leonard was well known in racing circles as a punter and an owner.

His biggest claim to fame was that he was joint owner of Top Cees when the gelding won the 1995 Chester Cup.

He and the Thompsons - who own the Chevely Park Stud in Newmarket and owned the 1992 Grand National winner Party Politics -became close.

Mr Leonard also wholly or partly owned horses named Exit to Rio, Creative Account, Mock Trial and No Extradition. "Looking back, perhaps we should have seen the signs," Richard Thompson said. "Subconsciously he was obviously feeling a little guilty."

Mr Leonard's trading at Muirpace blew a hole in both his friendship with the Thompsons and their accounts. Documents that were filed in Companies House for Southfield Trading Group, one of the main Thompson companies, reveal that operating losses increased from £990,717 during the 12 months to October 1997 to £9.25m for the next 18 months. Sales for the same periods were £79.6m compared with £73m.

Southfield's directors write that the losses were "almost entirely attributable to the fraud at Muirpace", and they hope that Southfield will now recover and "give the rest of the group an opportunity to return to profitability".

The Thompsons are still taking advice on whether legal claims can be made in an attempt to recoup the Muirpace losses. Richard Thompson, though, is concentrating on the film business. As chairman of AIM-listed Civilian Content, he is trying to turn what was once a meat-packing business into a successful film production company.

The birth of his new venture has been troubled. Civilian's first film, Gangster Number 1, starring Malcolm McDowell and Saffron Burrows, has recouped just a fraction of its budget at the box office, according to Screen International magazine.

It claims that the movie grossed £325,552 in its first eight weeks - a figure that Civilian insists should be nearer to £500,000.

The film, which had a budget of £4.5m and was largely funded by Channel 4, may be re-released in cinemas.

Mr Thompson is hopeful that the video release and overseas rights could also recoup more of the budget. Several more scripts are under development and Mr Thompson is "cautiously optimistic" about the future.

On July 14, a month after the release of Gangster, he sold 1.24m shares in Civilian. Some shareholders fear it is a sign that he does not have much faith in the business; he insists, though, that he was merely enabling other people to become involved in a company in which it is difficult to buy shares because the stock is so tightly held.

Civilian's strategy change concerned some small shareholders. A small minority expressed reservations at the decision taken in March last year to sell - after a record year of profits -the meat-processing and pet food distribution businesses owned by Whitchurch, as Civilian was known at the time, to a private company owned by Mr Thompson and then move into films.

On May 21 last year Whitchurch, in which Mr Thompson was a substantial shareholder and of which he later became chairman, paid £1m for shareholdings in two film companies held by one of his private firms.

Both companies were less than one month old, and neither had a trading record. Mr Thompson had paid just £7.50 for 75% of one of them only seven days earlier.

The two film companies had several scripts under development and Whitchurch was buying potential, he said. "They owned scripts and ideas, many of them in embryonic form. Valuing them is difficult, not unlike some of these internet companies where you are banking on future growth."

The vast majority of voting shareholders in Whitchurch, where Mr Thompson was chairman and owned around 26%, voted in favour of the deal - agreeing with the board that the film business offered better growth prospects than meat.

Shares in Civilian are trading at 40.5p - below a high of 53p achieved in April - although above the level they sometimes attained in Civilian's days as a meat business.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Three Days Of The Condor | Demon Seed | Cop Land | Atlantic City
fields.body:
Three Days Of The Condor

(Sydney Pollack, 1975)

8pm, Sky Cinema

This superb post-Watergate conspiracy thriller is by some distance the best of the Sydeny Pollack-Robert Redford collaborations (Havana, Out Of Africa and all). Here, Redford plays a history researcher who narrowly misses the seemingly pointless assassination of his colleagues; hunted by icy hitman Max von Sydow, he struggles to uncover the renegade CIA faction that's responsible. Edgy, convoluted and clever, there's also room for a credible affair with Faye Dunaway, with whom Redford seeks refuge.

Demon Seed

(Donald Cammell, 1977)

11.05pm, TCM

Curious sci-fi project from the doomed young co-director of psychedelic gangster movie, Performance. Fortunately it stars Julie Christie, but unfortunately she's playing a woman terrorised by Proteus, a computer that wants to impregnate her with its brainchild. It's a crazy idea that doesn't quite work.

Cop Land
(James Mangold, 1997)

12.05am, Sky Premier

Garrison, New Jersey is inhabited almost exclusively by New York cops. And for gone-to-seed, heavily overweight sheriff Sylvester Stallone, life's easy. But then a murder brings in Internal Affairs man Robert de Niro, who makes it clear that many of these cops are bad apples, Harvey Keitel's top dog in particular. An interesting script that settles for routine heroics.

Atlantic City

(Louis Malle, 1980)

12.45am, Carlton Cinema

Burt Lancaster with a moving depiction of a petty crook who catches a glimpse of the big time. Fascinated by his young waitress neighbour Susan Sarandon, he's soon embroiled in husband Robert Joy's drugs racket. Malle's heartfelt study of people and their dreams is beautiful.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Story Of A Bell | BBC Proms 2000
fields.body:
If you are really looking for the back of beyond, the South Pacific archipelago of Vanuata should fit the bill. Only one of its 82 islands has ever made a worldwide impact - Bali Hai, immortalised by the novelist James Michener. (It's fair to add that the inhabitants of another island quietly invented the hairy art of bungee jumping). Now Alexander Frater has returned to these distant shores accompanied by some ecclesiastical baggage. He tells the story in Story Of A Bell (11.0am, Radio 4).

The Russian violinist Maxim Vengerov returns to BBC Proms 2000 (7.30pm, Radio 3), trailing glory from his appearance there last year. This time he's not only performing as a soloist but directing the English Chamber Orchestra. The evening opens with Vengerov and Paul Barritt combining for Bach's double violin concerto in D. Then comes Mendelssohn's youthful violin concerto in D minor followed after the interval by three Mozart offerings, including his symphony no 29.

fields.headline: Who are you?
fields.standfirst: What the Sky Sports ad says about you
fields.trailText: What the Sky Sports ad says about you
fields.body:
The ad:
We open on a delivery room with a mother lying in bed exhausted but triumphant, holding her new baby. The father is standing beside her, seemingly lost for words. The doctor spots his inability to speak and whispers, "I can help you. Remember when we beat the Germans, remember how that felt... Let it out. It's good to let it out..." With which the new father shrieks, "I'm a dad!" The surgeon then waxes on about how sport can help us express the emotions we would otherwise keep hidden away. "Teach this to your newborn," he urges, as the father (now bursting with emotion) jubilantly screams "1-0!"

The jargon:
This ad, with the tagline "Let the power of sport into your life", is aimed at getting more folk to sign up to Sky Digital by promoting Sky's sports output. But rather than the MTV-style approach of most sports ads (pounding soundtrack, sweating athletes) it shows how sport is a positive force in our lives and can make us all happier and able to communicate more freely.

Personality:
You're a hard-core fan who enjoys watching sport on telly but who hasn't yet signed up to Sky Digital. You could be either male or female: apparently one third of all Premiership season tickets are now sold to women.

Financial status:
Sky's four sports channels cost from around £27 per month, but some bright spark at the agency St Luke's points out that this amounts to just 10 pints of lager a month.

Telling lifestyle detail:
You always go to the pub for the big matches, plus you, um, find it, er, hard to, that is, express your emotions.

Other relevant data:
A recent BBC documentary revealed that testosterone levels actually increase or decrease by as much as 25 per cent when watching sports (depending on whether your team/horse/whatever is winning or losing), so sport really does have an effect on us.

fields.headline: Tales of the unexpected
fields.trailText: Family Century | Big Brother
fields.body:
George Bernard Shaw, like God, was so big you couldn't see him. On one of Shaw's many birthdays, Patrick Campbell found Ayot St Lawrence pulsating with press. One reporter was pushing an X-ray under his door ("Dear Mr Shaw, I've had one break. Please give me another") while a newsreel cameraman hacked a hole in his hedge with shears ("This is where we caught the old goat last year").

Margaret Wheeler, though, got through to Shaw as effortlessly as St Joan deciding to have a quick word with God. They both looked oddly right for the part. Margaret had a boyish bob, a vivid, speaking little face and an undaunted way to her. Shaw, of course, had the beard.

Margaret is the eldest, cleverest member of the Nottingham family, whose lives are slowly unfolding in Family Century (C4). She approached Shaw, like Sheherazade, with a story. Sir Philip Sidney described the trick of it: "...with a tale which holdeth children from play and olde men from the chimney corner." It was the story of a lost child. She said a maternity hospital had mixed up two babies, giving her daughter, Peggy, to another woman, Blanche, and sending her home with a cuckoo child, Valerie.

Shaw did not discount the possibility that she had made it up to take his fancy, but it certainly kept him from the chimney corner. "The serial keeps up its interest though it is too readable to be credible."

It was, however, true. When Margaret described her little daughter ("Her voice, the way she laughed, the dimples coming and going in her cheeks, her small, eager face"), she could have been describing herself. She was incensed, incandescent, implacable. "I decided I was going to sort the Whole Damn Thing Out. I was going to get it Put Right. And I never stopped." That from a woman in her 90s. She must have been a flame-thrower in her 30s.

Shaw found himself cast as Solomon in this drama. He had no children. We only have his word for it that he had been a child. He steadily counselled her to leave well enough alone: "How do Peggy and Valerie feel about it? They are not a packet of sweets to be labelled with certain addresses and delivered by the errand boy. At eight years old they are human beings with likings and dislikings."

Today your head rings "DNA DNA" as if your skull were a bell. Margaret explored all possible tests available in the 40s but Blanche's husband, Fred, distrusted and refused them all.

She was furious with Fred. "I will not be sat upon by a bloke like Fred. Would you? Be sat upon by Fred, I mean?" Shaw, who only did it to annoy because he knew it teased, said Fred seemed to be doing a good job. Margaret replied tartly that, in that case, perhaps he should have her other three children as well. Shaw is like saltwater in the face and Margaret was apt to splutter.

They also wrote about phonetic spelling, why women make better monarchs, the size of George Eliot's feet and why Liszt smelled so dreadful. Her dammed-up intelligence overflowed like a flood plain. She was quite unfazed ("Raspberries to you!") by his fame. He said drily, "Send me the usual 20 pages. I am still interested." She wrote "I am as restless as hell and as miserable as sin. Write me a rude letter and make me laugh."

He encouraged her to write professionally. "Write a book. You can write. Begin with a char. The only way to get rid of housework and mothering is simply not to do it. Either keep servants or leave it undone." Mrs Gaskell was more realistic about female writers: "They cannot get rid of their relations." Margaret's last child had cerebral palsy. She was not going to lose this daughter. She refused to put her in a home and looked after her till she died.

As for Peggy and Valerie, they were told the truth when they were 18 and melted rapturously into the bosoms of their real families, suggesting a complete victory of nature over nurture.

And so they finally heard the country shouting over the fence in the Big Brother (C4) compound. "Watch out! Be careful! He's behind you!" More than 30 years ago Nigel Kneale wrote a staggeringly prescient TV play, The Year Of The Sex Olympics. In it a small group went to live on an island where TV cameras were on them 24 hours a day. It was a round-the-clock peepshow called The Live Life Show. What they did not realise was that one of them was a murderer.

The only way to get rid of housework and mothering is simply not to do it. Either keep servants or leave it undone." Mrs Gaskell was more realistic about female writers: "They cannot get rid of their relations." Margaret's last child had cerebral palsy. She was not going to lose this daughter. She refused to put her in a home and looked after her till she died. As for Peggy and Valerie, they were told the truth when they were 18 and melted rapturously into the bosoms of their real families, suggesting a complete victory of nature over nurture. And so they finally heard the country shouting over the fence in the Big Brother (C4) compound. "Watch out! Be careful! He's behind you!" More than 30 years ago Nigel Kneale wrote a staggeringly prescient TV play, The Year Of The Sex Olympics. In it a small group went to live on an island where TV cameras were on them 24 hours a day. It was a round-the-clock peepshow called The Live Life Show. What they did not realise was that one of them was a murderer.

webTitle: Sub reactors may not be shut down

fields.headline: Reactors may not be shut down
fields.standfirst:
Vessel harbours powerful threat to environment

Special report: Russia's stricken submarine
fields.trailText: There is around 1.2 tonnes of enriched uranium in the twin reactors which powered the submarine Kursk, which is a modern Oscar II class.
fields.body:
There is around 1.2 tonnes of enriched uranium in the twin reactors which powered the submarine Kursk, which is a modern Oscar II class.

Constant monitoring by the Norwegians has found no evidence of a radioactive leak, however, despite the two explosions reported, which must have ruptured the hull. But the massive damage to the bow revealed by five hours of Russian video and the news that the submarine was crippled in a flash increased fears last night that the crew had no time to shut down the reactors.

Kursk has two hulls, which are designed to withstand an impact from an average torpedo. If it was sunk by an explosion in the torpedo compartment then it was probably a very big explosion.

The power output is given as 190 megawatts for each reactor, about the same as one of Britain's older nuclear power stations and a third of the power of Sizewell C in Suffolk, the newest commercial pressurised water reactor.

This is a lot larger than the British Trafalgar class hunter killer submarines which have a single reactor of around 70 megawatts. The Russian submarine is twice as wide at 18 metres, with a similar draft of three metres, and clearly needs much bigger engines to power it through the water.

The fuel core in a Trafalgar class submarine may contain around 220kg of uranium. Each reactor on Kursk is likely to contain around 600kg of uranium, so there will be around 1.2 tonnes on the submarine. Uranium 235 has a half life of 710m years.

When a submarine reactor is shut down a significant amount of heat is still produced by radioactive decay. For this reason there normally has to be a supply of electricity to power the cooling pumps, but these reactors are designed to cool by convection, without the need for power. According to Igor Kudrik, a nuclear researcher at the Norwegian group Bellona, if this system has been disrupted there is a danger of a reactor cracking in the heat, allowing sea water to surge in. This would produce a plume of radioactive water on the current.

A meltdown of the core was less likely. But this heat decay will remain a potential problem for several weeks.

Over a longer period the metalwork which contains the radioactive material will decay, allowing it to be released into the sea.

webTitle: British divers seen as last hope for Russian sub

fields.headline: British divers seen as last hope
fields.standfirst:
United front may have come too late

Special report: Russia's stricken submarine
fields.trailText: Royal Navy and civilian divers are this morning slowly heading up the Norwegian coast with a lingering hope of rescuing some of the 118 Russian sailors trapped on the bed of the Barents Sea.
fields.byline: Richard Norton-Taylor  and  Andrew Osborn  in Brussels
fields.body:
Royal Navy and civilian divers are this morning slowly heading up the Norwegian coast with a lingering hope of rescuing some of the 118 Russian sailors trapped on the bed of the Barents Sea.

It may be too late by the time they arrive, tomorrow afternoon, to carry out what would be an astonishing rescue mission. But it seems to be the last hope. "The Russians recognise we represent the best opportunity for a timely rescue," a Royal Navy submariner said yesterday.

Ministry of Defence officials who have been in touch with the Russian navy since the beginning of the week said yesterday this was not the time for recrimination. As far as the Royal Navy is concerned, this is a humanitarian mission.

Whatever reticence the Russians had has evaporated. "All our questions have been answered," said an MoD official involved in the rescue plans.

Yesterday, the white LR5 rescue vehicle, described by Mike Finney, former commander of a nuclear submarine, as an "underwater helicopter," was lifted on to the Normand Pioneer, chartered by the navy, at the Norwegian port of Trondheim.

Its advantage is that it can operate independently and navigate with pinpoint accuracy. But its top speed is 3 knots. "It will not be easy, ocean currents are a law unto themselves," a navy submariner said.

The plan is for three Russians, including a doctor, to join the LR5's crew in the first attempt to open the escape hatch on the Kursk's stern. The LR5 will also carry oxygen, food, and electric power.

"You cannot tell whether it is too late. No one can tell if they're out of oxygen," Commander David Stanesby said in Trondheim.

A naval spokesman in London added: "If there's anyone inside who can open the hatch we will be very, very excited by that."

If no one does, the LR5 crew will open the hatch, a manoeuvre they have achieved on exercises. If they succeed, 16 Russian sailors will enter the rescue vehicle after passing through an attached decompression chamber. They will be taken to the surface, unloaded, and the LR5 will return to the Kursk, 108 metres down. Each operation will take three to four hours.

In remarkable testimony to the Russian navy's spirit of cooperation, born out of desperation, Commodore David Russell, deputy flag officer submarines, will help to oversee the rescue operation on board the Russian flagship, Peter the Great. He will be accompanied by three other Royal Navy officers, including a Russian speaker.

The Ministry of Defence insisted that chartering the Normand Pioneer was the quickest way to prepare for the rescue mission.

The runway at Murmansk, Russia's northern naval base closest to the Kursk, was not long enough to take the Antonov aircraft which flew the LR5 to Trondheim on Wednesday, according to an MoD official.

Russia's deputy naval chief of staff, Alexander Pobozhy, sidestepped questions about why the LR5 was flown to Norway instead of a Russian airfield. "It was the most optimum option for us," he said after a meeting at Nato headquarters in Brussels. "It was the most acceptable option for us."

Norway is sending 12-15 deep-sea divers, with experience from offshore oil and gas exploration, to assist the British mission.

Admiral Pobozhy said after the Brussels meeting that there could still be many days before oxygen ran out. "From our experience with the Soviet submarine forces, it can be as long as two to three weeks."

The atmosphere at the meeting was described as "very open and expert".

"There was a real spirit of cooperation," said a Nato source.

fields.headline: Nicked! His snaky ways found him out in the end
fields.standfirst: His snaky ways found him out in the end
fields.trailText: The clues were there for all to see. The housemates confined under 24-hour surveillance in Channel 4's runaway summer hit, Big Brother, had ample warning that one of their number, the self-styled "senior City broker" Nick Bateman, was not exactly Mr Nice Guy.
fields.body:
The clues were there for all to see. The housemates confined under 24-hour surveillance in Channel 4's runaway summer hit, Big Brother, had ample warning that one of their number, the self-styled "senior City broker" Nick Bateman, was not exactly Mr Nice Guy.

His right-arm bears a tattoo of a scorpion, the bearer of poison. He lists among his favourite films Kind Hearts and Coronets - the Ealing classic in which a smart young fortune-seeker methodically removes the eight people who stand between him and a fortune. Surely that was the giveaway to Nasty Nick's fiendish plan? Surely the Big Brother inmates should have realised what they were up against: a wily operator who would lie and cheat if that was what it took to win the game?

But no. For more than four weeks, Nick's rivals were trusting and were fooled - until the small hours of yesterday morning, when his scheming and conniving were rumbled. By late afternoon, Mr Bateman's Gordonstoun training came to the fore: he did the decent thing - not by reaching for his revolver, but by offering to walk out of the sealed compound and away from the £70,000 prize. In the end the producers took the decision for him: they gave him the boot.

In store for Nick Bateman is an instant surge of media ignominy, followed closely by its contemporary companion: celebrity. He will be feted and deluged with offers: perhaps a How to Lie column in a men's magazine. For the millions who have become hooked on this show there are two more troubling thoughts. First, how exciting will this show be, now that it has lost its villain? Second, what on earth is happening to us when so many Britons can become addicted to the mundane antics of a few strangers doing nothing for weeks on end? Are we becoming a nation of voyeurs, with no real friends of our own? Or is this perhaps just another case of August syndrome, a silly season fancy that is perfectly harmless. Which is it? You decide.

fields.headline: Sweeping space clean
fields.standfirst:
A laser broom will help beat the problem of orbiting litter

Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: A laser "broom" could be about to sweep space clear of dangerous flying objects. Project Orion - the brainchild of Jonathan Campbell of Nasa's Marshall Space Flight Centre in Huntsville, Alabama - could push fist-sized objects further out into space, or down into the atmosphere where they could burn.
fields.body:
A laser "broom" could be about to sweep space clear of dangerous flying objects. Project Orion - the brainchild of Jonathan Campbell of Nasa's Marshall Space Flight Centre in Huntsville, Alabama - could push fist-sized objects further out into space, or down into the atmosphere where they could burn.

Since 1957, humans have been planting increasing numbers of rocket casings and satellites in permanent orbit. Just to stay in orbit, these travel at at least five miles a second. There have been more than 4,000 launches, leaving 23,000 objects larger than a cricket ball in orbit. More than 100 have collided and broken up into smaller fragments, and the estimate is that there could be between 70,000 and 100,000 objects of between 1cm and 10cm (0.4in to 4in) whirling round the earth.

They include fragments of rocket, broken solar panels, spent satellites, bolts, food bags, compact discs which drifted out of shuttle bays, a camera left behind by an astronaut on a spacewalk, ballpoint pens and even plastic bags full of what Nasa used to delicately call "post-nutritive disposal substances".

And every one of them is travelling at 30,000 kilometres per hour (18,500mph). A hit from any one of them could have catastrophic consequences for any astronaut or instrumentation in the way.

The international space station - already under construction, and soon to grow to the size of a seven-storey building - is shielded, at an extra cost of $5bn (£3.3bn), against flying debris smaller than a centimetre across. Objects larger than 10cm across are routinely radar-tracked by US and European space agency scientists.

But the objects in between are hard to spot and there is a one-in-10 chance that one of them will hit the space station in a 10-year period - and cause at least some damage.

"The result could be much worse, like the difference between a single bullet and a shotgun blast," Mr Marshall told the New Scientist this week.

Space chiefs have been worrying about the "garbage problem" for years. Even very small fragments - and there could be more than 10m fragments smaller than one centimetre within 1,000km of the planet - can cause damage.

The windows of the space shuttle are examined after every flight, and have to be changed at intervals, because they become so pitted by the storm of spacedust, specks of paint and tiny shards of metal now shrouding the planet.

Mir, the Russian space station, has been hit a number of times. A US craft the size of a bus spent nearly six years in low earth orbit, during which time it was hit 20,000 times.

British scientists at Surrey University have designed Snap, a tiny 6kg (13lb) satellite, to target and latch on to dangerous fragments, and fall to earth with them.

But the Americans are looking again at the "star wars" option, of ground and space-based lasers which could lock onto a piece of menacing debris, slow it down and deflect it.

In a test in 2003, the space shuttle will release "simulated debris" that a ground-based laser can "light up". There have already been laboratory tests of the laser broom. "The results are even more promising that we thought," Mr Campbell said.

webTitle: Comment, Gwyn Prins: Focus attention on Russia's nuclear waste crisis

fields.headline: Catastrophe on the cards
fields.standfirst:
The tragedy of the Kursk should focus attention on Russia's nuclear waste crisis

Special report: Russia's stricken submarine
Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: This week, before the horrified gaze of the world, the Kursk has become part of the swelling armada of dead Russian nuclear submarines, most of which are to be found in the ports of the Kola peninsula of north-west Russia.
fields.body:
This week, before the horrified gaze of the world, the Kursk has become part of the swelling armada of dead Russian nuclear submarines, most of which are to be found in the ports of the Kola peninsula of north-west Russia.

If the tragedy focuses attention on Russia's ballooning nuclear waste problem, then some good may yet come of it. What has been lacking has been political will in Russian and abroad. The loss of the Kursk could change that. There is still time - just.

From a radiation point of view, the Kola peninsula is one of the cleanest places in Europe. A bit of strontium 90 from the atmospheric atom bomb test of the 1950s, to be sure - you get that everywhere. On land, there is background radon (as on Dartmoor). In the Barents, Kara and White seas, there is caesium 137, but half of that comes from jolly old Windscale/Sellafield.

But Kola also boasts the greatest latent potential for catastrophic release of radioactivity on the planet. An audit of 1993, ordered by President Boris Yeltsin, opened the issue for scrutiny. Kola is home to huge numbers of operating and defunct reactors.

Between 1954 and 1996, the Soviet Union built 287 nuclear submarines, containing more than 500 reactors. Of these, a minimum of 183 - and perhaps as many as 245 - are now out of service, and at least 120 of those still have fuelled reactors. The Northern Fleet has 142 subs and three battlecruisers (300-plus reactors) in or out of service. Then there are 10 icebreakers and a container ship. In the tally are 16 dumped reactors, including six with unrecovered fuel from nuclear accidents, such as the one that overtook the icebreaker Lenin. To that must now be added the two fuelled reactors of the Kursk.

So Kola has an abundance of spent nuclear fuel from ships needing containment. Then there is the Kola power station. Two of its reactors are judged by the International Atomic Energy Authority to have a 25% likelihood of critical failure in the next 20 years. There is no containment. This, however, is the power station that powers the pumps that cool the shut-down submarine reactors that await decommissioning and disposal. When the electricity company cut the Russian navy off for non-payment a few years ago, marines appeared, submachine guns in hand, to help change its mind. A new Kola nuclear power station is planned.

There is no adequate technical provision to deal with this stuff. The main hope is the Russian reprocessing plant at Mayak, near Chelyabinsk, with western-funded medium-term storage under construction there. However, shortage of special rolling stock restricts the capacity to move material from Kola by rail. A long-term repository is being discussed. The Russians want to put it on the island of Novaya Zemlya - but it is hard to reach and its geology is fractured by previous nuclear tests. Western experts favour a site on Kola, near the stuff. No early agreement is expected.

This situation is a product of the myopia that has been a characteristic of nuclear industries, west and east. They think in straight lines, and then only about the bits that they like, rather than of full-life cycles. Only now, with the armada of dead vessels swelling, is the Rubin Design Bureau, whose gifted engineers helped to build the Soviet submarine fleet (including, very recently, the Oscar design of the Kursk), being asked to un-design them.

Accommodation for spent fuel has been much reduced by accidents. Two storage ponds at the Andreyeva Bay naval facility had to be abandoned in 1982 because poor construction had led to leakage through cracked concrete and failed welds. The storage pool and dry dock at Gremikha failed too, for similar reasons. The Norwegian Bellona Foundation has evidence that drunkenness in the workforce prevented repair. Spent fuel is stored in Northern Fleet service tenders. Four (in Murmansk and Severodvinsk), are over 25 years old and full. With nowhere better to put the stuff, all these old, badly maintained barges are accidents waiting to happen. Spent fuel stands, inadequately shielded, on the quayside.

Like the brooms activated by the sorcerer's apprentice, the block decommissioning of the Soviet fleet is producing increasing volumes of fresh spent fuel. The Russian government plans to decommission 150 submarines by 2007. The present least-bad option is to leave the fuel in reactors on board. But left too long, fuel channels may distort. Defuelling then becomes impossible, so the entire reactors have to be disposed of. Unmaintained, the submarine hulls corrode. Some have sunk at their moorings.

The west wants to help. But at a recent meeting the cost of disposal quoted by the Russians was twice the equivalent western figure. The Russians would like to be paid to clean up; the west is reluctant to hand over cash. People recall the European Union auditors' report on money for safety at nuclear power-stations, which disappeared.

The whole issue is darkened by a cloud from another source - the inveterate culture of secrecy that hangs over Russian military, especially nuclear, matters. Of principal concern today is the case of a former Russian navy captain, Alexander Nikitin. The authorities decided to make an example of him. Put on trial for high treason for revealing information about the Russian navy (information that was actually already known to western researchers from other sources), he was hounded through the courts for years until he was acquitted by the St Petersburg city court last December.

The acquittal was confirmed by the supreme court in April, amid general rejoicing by environmentalists and supporters of free speech. But Victor Cherkesov, a friend of President Vladimir Putin, who was the Petersburg prosecutor and is now governor of north-west Russia, has not given up. The prosecutor's office has appealed against the acquittal and a supreme court hearing is due next month.

Even if his acquittal stands, Nikitin's case will have had dire consequences because of the nature of his defence case. The courts found that at the time of the offence, no law existed which Nikitin had broken: by definition he was innocent. Now there is a law. It works like this, in five Kafkaesque steps: one, there are secret matters not to be revealed; two, they are listed; three, the list itself is secret; four, ignorance is no defence; five, there is no "public interest" defence. As a dissident in the new Russia told me, in future no prudent Russian will dare to speak publicly about any environmental issue except those that are wholly innocuous: perhaps the welfare of sea-birds.

The British government has offered £5m toward the Kola clean up. But any external aid must be targeted primarily at building a comprehensive partnership in which western and Russian engineers and equipment work together. Compromise is unacceptable because the safe management of radioactivity is an activity unlike any other. That a British rescue team was requested, late in the day, to assist with the Kursk, is one glimmering point of optimism that may be seen as the swirling, murky waters close over the disaster.

 Gwyn Prins is principal research fellow at the European Institute of the London School of Economics.

The main hope is the Russian reprocessing plant at Mayak, near Chelyabinsk, with western-funded medium-term storage under construction there. However, shortage of special rolling stock restricts the capacity to move material from Kola by rail. A long-term repository is being discussed. The Russians want to put it on the island of Novaya Zemlya - but it is hard to reach and its geology is fractured by previous nuclear tests. Western experts favour a site on Kola, near the stuff. No early agreement is expected. This situation is a product of the myopia that has been a characteristic of nuclear industries, west and east. They think in straight lines, and then only about the bits that they like, rather than of full-life cycles. Only now, with the armada of dead vessels swelling, is the Rubin Design Bureau, whose gifted engineers helped to build the Soviet submarine fleet (including, very recently, the Oscar design of the Kursk), being asked to un-design them. Accommodation for spent fuel has been much reduced by accidents. Two storage ponds at the Andreyeva Bay naval facility had to be abandoned in 1982 because poor construction had led to leakage through cracked concrete and failed welds. The storage pool and dry dock at Gremikha failed too, for similar reasons. The Norwegian Bellona Foundation has evidence that drunkenness in the workforce prevented repair. Spent fuel is stored in Northern Fleet service tenders. Four (in Murmansk and Severodvinsk), are over 25 years old and full. With nowhere better to put the stuff, all these old, badly maintained barges are accidents waiting to happen. Spent fuel stands, inadequately shielded, on the quayside. Like the brooms activated by the sorcerer's apprentice, the block decommissioning of the Soviet fleet is producing increasing volumes of fresh spent fuel. The Russian government plans to decommission 150 submarines by 2007. The present least-bad option is to leave the fuel in reactors on board. But left too long, fuel channels may distort. Defuelling then becomes impossible, so the entire reactors have to be disposed of. Unmaintained, the submarine hulls corrode. Some have sunk at their moorings. The west wants to help. But at a recent meeting the cost of disposal quoted by the Russians was twice the equivalent western figure. The Russians would like to be paid to clean up; the west is reluctant to hand over cash. People recall the European Union auditors' report on money for safety at nuclear power-stations, which disappeared. The whole issue is darkened by a cloud from another source - the inveterate culture of secrecy that hangs over Russian military, especially nuclear, matters. Of principal concern today is the case of a former Russian navy captain, Alexander Nikitin. The authorities decided to make an example of him. Put on trial for high treason for revealing information about the Russian navy (information that was actually already known to western researchers from other sources), he was hounded through the courts for years until he was acquitted by the St Petersburg city court last December. The acquittal was confirmed by the supreme court in April, amid general rejoicing by environmentalists and supporters of free speech. But Victor Cherkesov, a friend of President Vladimir Putin, who was the Petersburg prosecutor and is now governor of north-west Russia, has not given up. The prosecutor's office has appealed against the acquittal and a supreme court hearing is due next month. Even if his acquittal stands, Nikitin's case will have had dire consequences because of the nature of his defence case. The courts found that at the time of the offence, no law existed which Nikitin had broken: by definition he was innocent. Now there is a law. It works like this, in five Kafkaesque steps: one, there are secret matters not to be revealed; two, they are listed; three, the list itself is secret; four, ignorance is no defence; five, there is no "public interest" defence. As a dissident in the new Russia told me, in future no prudent Russian will dare to speak publicly about any environmental issue except those that are wholly innocuous: perhaps the welfare of sea-birds. The British government has offered £5m toward the Kola clean up. But any external aid must be targeted primarily at building a comprehensive partnership in which western and Russian engineers and equipment work together. Compromise is unacceptable because the safe management of radioactivity is an activity unlike any other. That a British rescue team was requested, late in the day, to assist with the Kursk, is one glimmering point of optimism that may be seen as the swirling, murky waters close over the disaster.  Gwyn Prins is principal research fellow at the European Institute of the London School of Economics. webTitle: Leader: Britain's role in Nato's war with Yugoslavia sparks controversy

fields.headline: New light on Kosovo
fields.standfirst:
But the principle of intervention was right

Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: Britain's role in Nato's war with Yugoslavia sparked more controversy in this country than any other foreign crisis for half a century. Not since Anthony Eden's attack on Egypt in 1956 have passions been so aroused. Leading figures from across the political spectrum took different sides on the issue. The major parties were split. The Guardian shared in the debate and supported the Government's decision to intervene.
fields.body:
Britain's role in Nato's war with Yugoslavia sparked more controversy in this country than any other foreign crisis for half a century. Not since Anthony Eden's attack on Egypt in 1956 have passions been so aroused. Leading figures from across the political spectrum took different sides on the issue. The major parties were split. The Guardian shared in the debate and supported the Government's decision to intervene.

This puts a duty upon us to take especially seriously any criticisms of the campaign, including Nato's conduct, targeting, and efficiency, as well as its governments' negotiating strategy. The effects of the campaign in Serbia and Kosovo as well as the United Nations' performance in the aftermath of the war also deserve close scrutiny, and have had it, in our columns.

During the war we criticised the style of Nato's bombing from high altitude as cowardly. We did not agree with the targeting of bridges, power stations and other infrastructure. Before the bombing started we called for intervention under the political mandate of the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe rather than Nato so as to gain Russian support. We advocated intervention by ground troops and continued to press for it as the bombing dragged on.

This week has brought new revelations. One showed that Britain's bombing was far less accurate than claimed at the time. This followed earlier disclosures that American planes and missiles hit fewer tanks and artillery than the Pentagon said. Today we report that the number of Albanian civilians proved to have been killed by Serb forces was substantially less than western governments said. In the case of the bombing, the charge against Nato is that it lied and covered up. With the exaggerated massacre claims, the charge is more one of misjudgment and manipulation. No one in government could be sure what was happening inside Kosovo when the air strikes were under way.

But instead of advocating caution towards atrocity accounts from traumatised refugees, Nato governments tended to repeat them, to maintain support for the bombing. Excessive optimism about the success of the bombing was matched by excessive pessimism about the horror in Kosovo. The TV pictures of mass deportations were enough to condemn the behaviour of the Serb authorities without governments having to suggest there were Bosnian-style massacres and rape camps. Fears of "another Bosnia" were understandable, but that did not diminish the need to check that they were true.

Yet the sum of all these criticisms does not change the central issue. Was intervention needed? Some of the war's critics talk as though it began with the first Nato bomb. It had been under way for a year, after Serb forces in March 1998 started a rolling series of indiscriminate offensives against Kosovo Albanian civilians and their villages. The United Nations Security Council more than once called on Belgrade to desist.

When President Slobodan Milosevic continued his military repression even after agreeing to accept international observers, action had to be taken. His is not the only government which has defied the UN, but the world's failure to act against other governments does not mean action was wrong or illegitimate in Kosovo. The use of force did not have unanimous Security Council backing, which adds to the contradictions. But massive crimes were being perpetrated in Kosovo. That was why we advocated outside intervention and for all the mistakes and in spite of the lies we continue to believe it was right.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Sick pigs fear at 32 farms
fields.body:
Sick pigs fear at 32 farms

Thirty-two farms and three slaughterhouses were placed under restrictions by the Ministry of Agriculture yesterday after reports of pigs ill with symptoms similar to classical swine fever - although no outbreaks beyond the five in East Anglia have been confirmed.

Seven of the premises are far from the original outbreak. They are in Cheshire, Derbyshire, Lincoln- shire, Lancashire, Sussex, Dorset and the Isle of Wight. Two have links with British Quality Pigs, which supplied piglets which caught the disease.

Boy's body identified

Police yesterday confirmed that the body of a child found in the North sea was that of missing five-year-old Jake Parker, of Wellingborough, Northamptonshire, who vanished while playing on the beach at Brancaster, Norfolk, on Sunday. His body was spotted from a yacht 500 yards off the beach.

Warning after Villa speed case

Safety campaigners yesterday warned of the dangers of speeding after Aston Villa manager John Gregory was banned from driving for 28 days when he admitting driving at 112mph near Mill Hill, north London. Gregory, of Sutton Coldfield, was also fined £540.

The Royal Society for the Prevention of Accidents said the decision by magistrates at Hendon should act as a reminder to motorists to kill their speed and reduce "the carnage on Britain's roads".

Murderers escape

Police were last night hunting for two murderers - James Howey, 38, from Liverpool, and Michael Boyd, 49, from Leeds - missing from Hollesley Bay prison near Woodbridge, Suffolk. Police said both were potentially dangerous.

Chef to face driving charges

Celebrity chef Clarissa Dickson Wright - one of televison's Two Fat Ladies - is to face trial on charges of driving without a licence or insurance after pleading guilty by letter to an additional charge of driving at 95mph in a 70mph zone.

Dickson Wright, 53, of Inveresk, Midlothian, was not present when her case came up at Forfar sheriff court yesterday.

Worker dies in paint vat fall

A contractor cleaning a giant vat of paint at the Fords plant at Southampton, Hampshire, died yesterday after falling in. Other workers pulled him out but paramedics failed to revive him. He was later named as Christopher Derek Shute, 30, of Southampton.

A police spokesman said: "Health and safety officials are carrying out a full investigation along with the police."

Boy, 4, drowns in canal

Kalim Tawaih, aged four, drowned on Wednesday after falling into a canal near his home in Stoke Newington, north London. He had been playing with his six-year-old sister.

webTitle: Jail for conman who posed as doctor

fields.headline: Jail for conman who posed as doctor
fields.trailText: In his long career as a conman Paul Bint has pretended to be many things. He has persuaded his unsuspecting victims that he was a doctor, a lawyer, an earl, a millionaire, and a dancer with the Royal Festival ballet.
fields.body:
In his long career as a conman Paul Bint has pretended to be many things. He has persuaded his unsuspecting victims that he was a doctor, a lawyer, an earl, a millionaire, and a dancer with the Royal Festival ballet.

The reality was somewhat less enchanting: a homeless former hairdresser with the gift of the gab.

His favourite trick was to sneak into hospitals wearing a white coat and stethoscope purporting to be a doctor. He was also fond of masquerading as an aristocrat in order to steal sports cars while out on test drives.

But yesterday Bint's latest fiction earned him a two-year prison sentence after he was convicted at Newcastle crown court of pretending to be a barrister and conning Virgin trains out of free accommodation at the Caledonian hotel in Edinburgh.

On a train between Birmingham and Glasgow this year he said he was a barrister in the Lockerbie trial called Lachlan Campbell-Breedem QC and that his laptop computer containing vital information had been stolen. The train was halted and delayed while an extensive search was carried out by staff.

Because of the delay, he persuaded Virgin trains to put him up at the hotel in Edinburgh for three nights at a cost of £545. To make the story more convincing, he wore a barrister's robes and a wig that he had stolen from Birmingham crown court.

Bint disappeared from the hotel then turned up in Berwick-upon-Tweed, Northumberland, wearing a white coat. He persuaded a taxi driver to take him to a hospital in Newcastle upon Tyne, saying he was a doctor there who was urgently needed for a transplant operation.

A judge once told him: "You are not mentally ill. You have an unfortunate talent which you have used over and over again to persuade others your fantasy world exists."

He was first caught in 1983 when he posed as a doctor, but only after he had arranged x-rays, tended to a man with a collapsed lung and put 12 stitches in another person's head wound. He also tried to trick his way into a heart bypass operation.

In the same year he gatecrashed a party given by Viscount Linley, where he tried to introduce himself to Koo Stark by sending a bottle of Dom Perignon champagne to her table.

Bint has spent a total of 10 years in prison and mental institutions. In July 1993 he was ordered to be detained indefinitely at a psychiatric hospital in York after he pretended to be a doctor at St James's hospital in Leeds.

He was released from hospital the following year and was soon caught at the Royal Preston hospital and Blackburn Royal infirmary pretending to be a locum called Dr Pearce Hanson.

He groped a woman patient and told her: "Trust me, I'm a doctor."

He told the parents of a girl aged 17 who had been injured in a road accident that she would survive. She died six hours later.

He has also been jailed for tricking a car salesman out of a £83,000 Ferrari which he took for a test drive while calling himself the Earl of Arundel.

A Porsche and a Rolls-Royce were spirited away by Bint when he pretended to be an aristocrat.

Last year he changed tack and decided to go "into law". But once again he has found himself on the wrong side of it.

webTitle: Daryl Hannah in West End show of Seven Year Itch

fields.headline: Latest itch
fields.standfirst: Daryl Hannah in West End show
fields.trailText: Daryl Hannah yesterday became the latest Hollywood actress to be lured to the West End, accompanied by the now inevitable hubbub as to whether she will strip on stage.
fields.body:
Daryl Hannah yesterday became the latest Hollywood actress to be lured to the West End, accompanied by the now inevitable hubbub as to whether she will strip on stage.

Hannah, 39, will next month reprise the role made famous by Marilyn Monroe in the film version of the Seven Year Itch.

But Monroe's billowing skirt, the one memorable moment of a forgettable movie, will not be re-enacted on stage, as the scene was added to George Axelrod's original play about a middle-aged New Yorker who fantasises about the girl next door while his wife is away.

Yesterday the play's West End producer, Laurence Myers, insisted he "hadn't brought Daryl over here to be naked on stage", then hinted the play was much "raunchier" than Billy Wilder's 1955 film, and that, if the role demanded it, Hannah would take off her clothes. He had not brought her across the Atlantic to do a "Marilyn Monroe impersonation".

Hannah follows Hollywood's Nicole Kidman and Kathleen Turner, who graced West End debuts with scenes of coy but much-talked-about nudity. She is known for kooky comic roles in Roxanne and Splash, but played a stripper in her latest film. Dancing at the Blue Iguana.

She was persuaded to go on stage by the man who directed Dancing at the Blue Iguana, Oscar-nominated British film-maker Michael Radford, a Bafta winner for White Mischief and Il Postino, who will be making his London debut as the play's director. Myers said of the Seven Year Itch: "The play on which the film was based was a lot raunchier... [though] we are not talking stage orgies.

"This is just a play in the course of which a couple sleep together. I haven't brought her over here to be naked on stage. She's a wonderful comedy actress, but if the play requires her to appear naked, she won't have a problem with that."

The Seven Year Itch will start preview performances at the Queen's Theatre on October 2.

webTitle: Private Lives: I had to be a mother to my little brother - but is it time to stand back?

fields.headline: Private Lives
fields.standfirst: I had to be a mother to my little brother - but is it time to stand back?
fields.trailText: I had to be a mother to my little brother - but is it time to stand back?
fields.body:
Last year my mother died and I moved home to look after my brothers, aged 15 and 18. I was 26. Our father remarried 17 years ago and lives in another city. We thought it best that I move in to see the boys through their education - the younger was in his GCSE year and the elder had just finished A-levels. I, therefore, crossed the bridge from being sister to mother overnight. This summer, my younger brother moved in with our father and is having a terrible time settling in. I'm aware that I shouldn't step on our father's toes now that he is the parent but I have been my brother's mother for a year and feel compelled to help. I feel confused: should I stand back or help my brother?

Be a friend

So many relevant details are missing. In general, the late teenage years are a difficult time to settle into a new family, school or city. To cope with all three without his older brother or schoolmates is asking a great deal of a 16-year-old.

Your brother needs all the support he can get now that the change has been made. Whether you see yourself as a mother or a sister does not matter. He needs a sensible, mature friend. Go and talk to your father and stepmother with your brother, so that everyone knows where they stand. Phone calls, however frequent, are very limited and are open to misunderstanding by all concerned.
C Heritage Suffolk

He still needs you

Help your brother. He can probably speak to you more freely than he can to your father. I know that my own parents are thankful that there has been sibling support for my younger brother who has been going through a difficult time. They are happy to maintain a sympathetic distance and get updates from my sisters and me.

Your father is probably worried about your brother but doesn't know how to approach the situation. Think how hard it is for children, and boys especially, to talk to their parents. Then try and imagine how hard it must be for fathers to talk to their sons.

Your father will probably be relieved if you go and see your brother; you won't be stepping on his toes. You will just be showing concern for your younger, grieving brother. This is normal for a sister, and you have more reason than most to look after him. In the meantime, unless there is a culture of talking in your family (there isn't in mine) your brother will probably just bottle things up and be miserable in silence.
Name and address withheld

Cooperation is the key

I don't think there's any question of "stepping back" from your brother's problems, no matter who he's living with. After a long gap apart, your father has now had the boy living with him for about a year. That's not very long for the youngster to adjust to life away from the only home he knew, with a father he's not that close to, especially when he is no doubt feeling the loss of his sister's care as well as missing his mother.

I expect your dad has his problems, too. A year isn't very long for anyone to grow into being a good enough parent, especially in the fraught relationship between father and adolescent son.

So perhaps one of the answers to the problem is time. But that's not enough. If your father is really concerned for his son, he should get every bit of help available to sort out the boy's troubles - which must include your input, and perhaps family counselling, too.

The fact is that you are still both sister and parent to your brother and it would be perfectly reasonable for you to have some serious talks with your father about the boy and his problems as well as having as much contact with your brother as both of you need. Be confident about this. It is not only your kind heart that is urging you to help your brother; commonsense and humanity are on your side.
A Waite, Norwich

Next week

I am female, aged 19, and a third of the way through a degree at a university a long way from home. My elder brother moved away five years ago. Since then I have lived alone with my mother, who is 48. We moved to a different town when I was 14 and I left behind many friends. However, I have become settled here and made new friends, with whom I love to spend time during the holidays.

Now my mother has fallen in love after being mostly alone for 15 years. I like her new man, a widower 10 years her senior; they obviously make each other happy. But now my mother wants to sell our home and move in with him.

My dilemma is that he lives in a small village a 25-minute drive from where we live now. I would have my own room, but from my point of view it would not be home. I would not feel comfortable about behaving as I'm used to. Coming back from university in the holidays, I would be miles from my friends and would feel very isolated. My mother has asked my opinion on the matter and how I would feel about moving again.

I really do not want to move and feel that my mother should understand my need for a stable home and social life until I finish university. Is my mother being selfish, or am I asking too much?

 Private Lives appears every Friday. Each week we publish a letter to which readers are invited to respond. Replies, giving an account of your personal experience, should reach us by Thursday. Readers are welcome to propose other problems, of around 300 words. To cope with all three without his older brother or schoolmates is asking a great deal of a 16-year-old. Your brother needs all the support he can get now that the change has been made. Whether you see yourself as a mother or a sister does not matter. He needs a sensible, mature friend. Go and talk to your father and stepmother with your brother, so that everyone knows where they stand. Phone calls, however frequent, are very limited and are open to misunderstanding by all concerned. C Heritage Suffolk He still needs you Help your brother. He can probably speak to you more freely than he can to your father. I know that my own parents are thankful that there has been sibling support for my younger brother who has been going through a difficult time. They are happy to maintain a sympathetic distance and get updates from my sisters and me. Your father is probably worried about your brother but doesn't know how to approach the situation. Think how hard it is for children, and boys especially, to talk to their parents. Then try and imagine how hard it must be for fathers to talk to their sons. Your father will probably be relieved if you go and see your brother; you won't be stepping on his toes. You will just be showing concern for your younger, grieving brother. This is normal for a sister, and you have more reason than most to look after him. In the meantime, unless there is a culture of talking in your family (there isn't in mine) your brother will probably just bottle things up and be miserable in silence. Name and address withheld Cooperation is the key I don't think there's any question of "stepping back" from your brother's problems, no matter who he's living with. After a long gap apart, your father has now had the boy living with him for about a year. That's not very long for the youngster to adjust to life away from the only home he knew, with a father he's not that close to, especially when he is no doubt feeling the loss of his sister's care as well as missing his mother. I expect your dad has his problems, too. A year isn't very long for anyone to grow into being a good enough parent, especially in the fraught relationship between father and adolescent son. So perhaps one of the answers to the problem is time. But that's not enough. If your father is really concerned for his son, he should get every bit of help available to sort out the boy's troubles - which must include your input, and perhaps family counselling, too. The fact is that you are still both sister and parent to your brother and it would be perfectly reasonable for you to have some serious talks with your father about the boy and his problems as well as having as much contact with your brother as both of you need. Be confident about this. It is not only your kind heart that is urging you to help your brother; commonsense and humanity are on your side. A Waite, Norwich Next week I am female, aged 19, and a third of the way through a degree at a university a long way from home. My elder brother moved away five years ago. Since then I have lived alone with my mother, who is 48. We moved to a different town when I was 14 and I left behind many friends. However, I have become settled here and made new friends, with whom I love to spend time during the holidays. Now my mother has fallen in love after being mostly alone for 15 years. I like her new man, a widower 10 years her senior; they obviously make each other happy. But now my mother wants to sell our home and move in with him. My dilemma is that he lives in a small village a 25-minute drive from where we live now. I would have my own room, but from my point of view it would not be home. I would not feel comfortable about behaving as I'm used to. Coming back from university in the holidays, I would be miles from my friends and would feel very isolated. My mother has asked my opinion on the matter and how I would feel about moving again. I really do not want to move and feel that my mother should understand my need for a stable home and social life until I finish university. Is my mother being selfish, or am I asking too much?  Private Lives appears every Friday. Each week we publish a letter to which readers are invited to respond. Replies, giving an account of your personal experience, should reach us by Thursday. Readers are welcome to propose other problems, of around 300 words. fields.headline: No: 1702
fields.standfirst: French
fields.trailText: French
fields.body:
Les Britanniques? Ils sont commes les Bourbons: ils n'ont rien appris, ni rien oublié.
Nope, didn't get a word of that.

Ah, les Britanniques! J'en ai marre de leur splendide isolement! C'est affreux!
If you're trying to be insulting, you're going to have to say it in a language that I understand.

Il paraît que les jeunes Britanniques ne veulent pas apprendre le français. En plus, ils ne s'intéressent pas aux autres langues étrangères. En fait, l'isolement de la Grande Bretagne s'intensifie. Ecoutez-moi, les rosbifs: vous n' êtes pas vraiment des Européens. Pas du tout!
I've always liked you French, you know, what with your open fruit tarts and your beers in dinky bottles. It's just a shame about your personal hygiene and the fact you haven't won a significant military engagement since Austerlitz. And that you speak French rather than a language us Brits can understand. English, for instance.

J'en ai ras le bol de votre racisme! Ras le bol!
No, didn't get that either, although the accompanying hand gesture looked rather rude. Perhaps you're a little upset that young Britons are less likely to study French than they used to be. Figures released by British examination boards yesterday showed that A-level French entries fell by nearly 3,000, or 13.5%, to 18,221 . . .

Ah, oui. Il paraît que les étudiants britanniques préfèrent apprendre l'allemand.
Now don't interrupt... while applications to study A-level German fell by only 1,000 to 8,692.

Enfin, vous avez raison. Monsieur David Hart, secrétaire général d'un syndicat de professeurs britannique, a dit hier: "The significant drop in modern language entries is evidence of a European isolationist attitude."
Finally! I understood that bit.

Do say:
"Ce qui n'est pas clair n'est pas français."

Don't say:
"French is the patois of Europe; English is the language of the world."

webTitle: Rebecca Mead on August in New York

fields.headline: City deep in the jaws of gloom
fields.standfirst: On August in New York
fields.trailText: On August in New York
fields.body:
Have you ever noticed, a friend of mine asked the other day, how in August, just when New Yorkers are heading to the beach, the Discovery channel starts showing endless reruns of documentaries about sharks? The programmers are aware, my friend went on, that nothing grabs the attention quite so well as gloom and alarmism, particularly when it's sunny outside. Our darker natures know that the apparent cheeriness of things is not to be trusted.

The allure of gloom was also my friend's explanation for the surprise appearance on the current New York Times bestseller list of From Dawn to Decadence, a massive survey of 500 years of western culture by Jacques Barzun, a 92-year-old former professor at Columbia University. There is much that could be said about From Dawn to Decadence, which is jostling for space on the list with The Day John Died, about JFK Jr, and something called Life on the Other Side, a psychic's tour of the afterlife which is, strangely, in the non-fiction category.

One of the most important things to be said about the Barzun book is that it is nearly 900 pages long and costs $36, neither of which would be typical leading indicators for bestsellerdom. But, my friend's argument would go, the unprecedented growth of the US economy and the current mind-boggling advances in technology and medicine all pave the way perfectly for a jeremiad such as this. Reading a book with a title such as From Dawn to Decadence in these boom times is the literary equivalent of scaring yourself silly by watching TV programmes which warn that while the calm blue ocean may look inviting, you are liable to lose a leg if you dive in. The experience is perversely thrilling but ultimately unconvincing. Gloom is hardly the mood most commonly associated with the US, particularly in convention season, when cheerleader-like peppiness and the unironic wearing of silly hats is the order of the day.

Pessimism-as-worldview did get a boost this week after a report presented at the American Psychological Association's annual meeting suggested that there are advantages to negative thinking. (If you anticipate the worst, you just might figure out ways to avoid it, or so the argument goes. Or you might never get out of bed again.)

Even so, gloom is likelier in the US to be taken as a condiment rather than the main dish. At the movies this weekend, the biggest audiences were for Hollow Man, which is the latest take on the Invisible Man story so can hardly be considered Bergmanesque angst; and Nutty Professor II: The Klumps, which features broad toilet humour and a randy grandmother and is thereby coded as the opposite of gloomy.

The gloomiest new release of the week was Autumn in New York, which features Richard Gere as a 48-year-old Manhattan restaurateur and womaniser who falls for Winona Ryder, a 22-year-old with a fatal heart condition.

The movie fails for many reasons, among them the deluded notion of the Gere character that what the average 22-year-old woman wants from an older man is commitment; anyone who has actually been a 22-year-old woman will remember that what she wants is to be taken out to expensive dinners and to spend the night somewhere other than the apartment she shares with four room-mates.

When I saw Autumn in New York one afternoon last week, there were about six other people in the audience; maybe everyone else was at home reading Jacques Barzun. When a work such as Barzun's takes off, cynics always suggest that while the book may be being sold, there is no guarantee that it is being read. But that seems an unfair presumption.

While to be educated in Britain means to have read deeply in one subject while being ignorant in all others, US undergraduates read widely if not in much depth: the sweeping survey of history is thus a form with which Americans are extremely comfortable. Furthermore, self-improvement has been a basic value in this country since the time of the pilgrims, so the notion of spending a summer engaged in what amounts to a western-civilisation refresher course makes a lot of sense. Besides, what else is there to do on the beach in August? Watch the waves and wonder whether there are sharks beneath the surface?

 Rebecca Mead is a staff writer at the New Yorker. Shane Watson is away.
