fields.headline: Back to the future
fields.standfirst: It's not easy making TV programmes about buildings: they're big, they don't move around and they never have fights with each other. But as Channel 4 launch The Shock Of The Old, a reappraisal of celebrated architecture,  Jonathan Glancey feels cautiously optimistic
fields.trailText: It's not easy making TV programmes about buildings: they're big, they don't move around and they never have fights with each other. But as Channel 4 launch The Shock Of The Old, a reappraisal of celebrated architecture, Jonathan Glancey feels cautiously optimistic
fields.body:
It wouldn't work today. A lovely old duffer in a Viyella shirt, tweed jacket and wobbly hat pottering about six small English towns with a camera crew in tow and speaking quietly of their simple virtues. No, not the camera crew's, the buildings'. Nice bit of pargetting here, a rather natty example of hood-moulding there. Cosy clapboarding. Soft Flemish bond brickwork. Gables. Crockets. Twisting chimneys. Nothing clever in the commentary, no puns, no Wildean witticisms. No apposite aperçus. Nary an "innit"; just a lacing of old-fashioned charm, natural good manners and loosely bridled class.

That was Alec Clifton-Taylor and his Six English Towns series, made for the BBC quite some years ago. I still think these programmes are some of the best made on architecture, buildings and places, because I learned so much from them, liked their lack of pretension, their quiet passion and Clifton-Taylor's great ability as a communicator. No wilful obfuscation, yet absolutely no dumbing down. Learning worn lightly by a kind, grandfatherly figure. And no need, at least as far as I could tell, for stylists and make-up artists.

Architecture is a notoriously difficult subject to get across on television. Always has been. The problem is simply stated. Buildings are big and don't move. Because of this, successive generations of producers have exhausted just about every trick in their technical repertory. Dramatic camera angles, melodramatic music, a presenter staring wistfully up into a dome, and, erm, more dramatic camera angles. What they tend to lack are strong storylines, memorable characters and the very human dimension that makes buildings come alive.

Architects, to be unkind for a sentence, tend to enjoy buildings best when there are no annoying humans to spoil them. Inside every architect, you can't help thinking, is the spirit of Professor Otto Silenus, the chilling young man who rebuilds the Beste-Chetwynde house in Evelyn Waugh's delicious Decline And Fall (1926). Silenus, whose only previous work had been a rejected design for a bubble-gum factory somewhere in eastern Europe, was on a mission to rid the human element from architecture. Only reluctantly did he agree to provide a stair to link the severely proportioned floors of the new house. This was delicious, spot-on satire. Mere humans should not be allowed to mar architecture.

Piers Gough, a likable architect with bird's nest hair, booming delivery and big, colourful glasses, spends the best part of The Shock Of The Old, a six-part series for C4, providing the human element. Gough is presented as what we call a "character"; he knows his stuff, from Roman to hi-tech British buildings, but wraps it up in a few too many dreadful puns and groaning jokes. These work well in conversation - Gough is an intelligent and witty man - but feel awkward on screen. Bring back Alec Clifton-Taylor, or even that paragon of no-nonsense delivery, Professor Nikolaus Pevsner. Or go to a broad church of an audience.

Quaint to watch at the beginning of the 21st century, John Betjeman and his producers knew how to tell stories about the people who made and occupied buildings. Today, for the most part, a heavy duty falls on the presenter who has to perform like an experienced actor - the professional TV pundit who stresses too many of the wrong words, looks knowingly into the camera lens and appears to be reading with a singular lack of passion from the autocue. Clifton-Taylor and Betjeman were watchable to viewers outside the TV industry because they acted parts they had written for themselves on and off the box for many years. Nobody could play John Betjeman, the nation's battered teddy bear, better than JB himself.

It is possible to make a TV documentary, if not perhaps a series about architecture without a presenter, but then the buildings' supporting cast must be very strong or their stories gripping. The best contemporary architectural documentary-maker is Rebecca Frayn. Frayn cannot be hurried. Her programmes are precisely cut and polished gems, seemingly reverential yet shot through with fox-like cunning. The film she made for C4 about minimalist houses, and their architects and clients, a couple of years back was magnificent: architecture stripped bare on a psychiatrist's couch. This was one of the saddest, yet most beautifully made TV films I've ever seen, wealthy people and earnest professionals colluding to design and build an architecture that was somehow meant to clear away emotional unrest and over-attachment to physical things; yet, rarely has one seen such an intensity of restless materialists. Gripping.

The other thing an architecture programme can do, although few manage it, is to pursue a line of real argument: a polemic, in other words. This is rare because to argue about architecture in Britain is tantamount to the same thing as causing offence. Architects do not like to be criticised. When I began to write for the Architectural Review, the garrulous historian Gavin Stamp told me in stentorian terms that the only thing I needed to remember was that the "only good architect was a dead one". You could say what you liked about them then, even be objective.

The Shock Of The Old is being sold as a controversy. Gough, says C4, "sets out to remind audiences of just how modern and radical buildings were in their day, stripping away the centuries of familiarity, enabling us to see their startling boldness". No shock there then, after all, although computer graphics, even if a little crude compared to the subtlety of the buildings they attempt to depict, are used to good effect right from the start of the series. And here is some real advance in architecture as it is shown on TV. Once Gough has got the dreadful puns out of his system in the opening sequences of "Romans@britannia.co.uk", it's intriguing to hear him describe the great victory arch the Romans built at Dover as a gateway to Watling Street, and thus colonised Britannia. We get to see the arch and, yes, it must have looked as shocking in its way as operatic shopping malls, built on a Roman scale, which Gough takes us to see. I liked, too, the comparison he makes between medieval cathedrals, shown here in computer-generated former glory, and the new IMAX theatre at Waterloo. Medieval cathedrals were, in a way, the Sensurround cinema or colour TV of their day.

But what is truly controversial about The Shock Of The New is Gough's keen appreciation of some truly shocking postmodern buildings, many of which should only be visited wearing a pair of Jonathan Meades' dark glasses. Or Alec Clifton-Taylor's Viyella shirt, tweed jacket and battered hat. Can we have a repeat of Six English Towns now?

 The Shock Of The Old, Sunday, 8pm, C4

webTitle: Commons to pay £5m to building firm

fields.headline: Commons to pay £5m to building firm
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: The House of Commons has agreed to pay £5.2m in compensation to a building company discriminated against during construction of a new office block for MPs.
fields.body:
The House of Commons has agreed to pay £5.2m in compensation to a building company discriminated against during construction of a new office block for MPs.

The Anglo-American firm Harmon Facades (UK) Ltd lost out on a contract to provide bronze cladding for the £231m Portcullis House despite a bid £2m less than that of the successful bidder.

The four-year case was one of the more embarrassing episodes involving the complex opposite Big Ben, which has come under fire for its cost.

Last October the high court ruled that the Commons had breached European and UK law by awarding the £34m cladding contract to the Anglo-German company Seele-Avis. Judge Humphrey Lloyd also ruled that the Commons had committed "misfeasance in public office" when an official later falsified the reasons for the contract not being awarded to Harmon.

The Commons had claimed that Harmon should not have won the contract because it was forced into liquidation two years later. The judge ruled that winning the deal would have prevented this.

Parliament was ordered to pay Harmon £1.85m in interim damages and a final award of not less than £3.7m.

The Liberal Democrat MP Archy Kirkwood, representing the House of Commons commission, said in a statement that the payout was "very substantially less" than that claimed by Harmon.

Parliament was ordered to pay Harmon £1.85m in interim damages and a final award of not less than £3.7m. The Liberal Democrat MP Archy Kirkwood, representing the House of Commons commission, said in a statement that the payout was "very substantially less" than that claimed by Harmon.

webTitle: Computer to score chance of criminals re-offending

fields.headline: Computer to score chance of criminals re-offending
fields.trailText: Every offender in Britain is to be given a computer-generated score that will tell the courts before they are sentenced how likely they are to re-offend and what danger they pose to the public, under a controversial plan to be introduced next year.
fields.body:
Every offender in Britain is to be given a computer-generated score that will tell the courts before they are sentenced how likely they are to re-offend and what danger they pose to the public, under a controversial plan to be introduced next year.

The chief inspector of probation, Sir Graham Smith, said yesterday he understood that the introduction of Oasys - the offender assessment system - would not be universally welcomed, particularly by defence lawyers. But, he said, it would mean for the first time that the courts and probation and prison services had a consistent way of judging the likelihood that a convicted offender would strike again.

Last night the Law Society and probation officers voiced "deep concern" that it would lead to sentences based not on what a criminal had done, but on who he was or what he was likely to do. The punishment would no longer fit the crime, but the criminal. It would also decide whether a defendant should be freed on bail.

The system, developed by the Home Office, gives an offender a computerised score based on factors like unemployment, literacy, family circumstances, lifestyle, history, who they mixed with and their educational background, as well as on the criminal's attitude to his or her offence. A computer would analyse the results and produce a score to enable an experienced probation officer to predict how likely the person was to re-offend.

It is not expected the reports would contain a raw figure suggesting, for instance, that a particular burglar had a 90% likelihood of committing the crime again. Rather, the courts would be told whether there was a high, medium or low risk that particular criminals would re-offend, and how dangerous their crimes were likely to be.

Sir Graham Smith said that Oasys would not replace the judgment and gut instincts of probation officers, but would allow their reports, on which the courts based their sentencing, to be less subjective. "We have to be more consistent. We have relied too much on nous, instinct and feel," he said. "It will ensure the offender gets the right sentence and onto the right 'what works' programme to tackle his offending behaviour."

More than 600,000 probation reports are written each year and used not only to decide the sentence, but also the courses criminals should be required to take and when to release them on parole or on home detention curfew.

Pilot schemes are under way and the scheme is expected to be introduced nationally next year. "There are going to be people who say they don't like it. There are going to be human rights issues, but we are not going to say 'this particular person will definitely commit a crime.' We are going to say that all these factors are going to have some kind of impact," said Sir Graham.

webTitle: Last-ditch pleas to save teenage killer from electric chair

fields.headline: Last-ditch pleas to save teenage killer from electric chair
fields.trailText: At 7pm next Thursday the state of Georgia is likely to set another grisly record in the history of capital punishment in America when Alexander Williams, now aged 32, will become the fifth child offender to be executed in the US this year - more than in any year since six minors were put to death in 1954.
fields.body:
At 7pm next Thursday the state of Georgia is likely to set another grisly record in the history of capital punishment in America when Alexander Williams, now aged 32, will become the fifth child offender to be executed in the US this year - more than in any year since six minors were put to death in 1954.

Amnesty International, which issued an "urgent action" appeal for clemency yesterday, said that Iran, Nigeria, Saudi Arabia, Pakistan and Congo were the only other countries to execute juvenile offenders in the past 10 years. But the US tops the list with 14 executions.

In 1986, at the age of 17, Williams abducted 16-year-old Aleta Carol Bunch from a shopping centre in Augusta. He was arrested eight days later. His information led to her body in a remote, wooded area outside the town. She had been robbed, raped and shot.

On Tuesday the pardons board will hear pleas for clemency, including one from Rosalynn Carter, the wife of the former US president.

In a letter to the board Williams - who has been diagnosed as a paranoid schizophrenic - admitted his guilt for the first time and said: "I am asking the people of Georgia to show compassion toward me, something that at 17 I regret was outside my own power of humanity."

The lawyers also plan to take the case to the Georgia supreme court and, possibly, the US supreme court. A lawyer familiar with the case told the Guardian that the grounds would be that under the Georgia constitution the execution of a juvenile constitutes cruel and unusual punishment; and that it would be illegal under a raft of international law which the US has ratified.

Amnesty's report on the case says that Williams failed to get proper representation. The lawyer at his trial did not bring forward evidence about his long history of physical and mental abuse by his family, particularly from his mother. In 1990 the lawyer was formally removed from representing indigent defendants because of his inadequate performance.

Attempts in the appeal court to get a new sentencing hearing on the grounds of poor legal support also failed, by two votes to one.

Amnesty urged Georgia last night to "offer an example of progressive human rights leadership" by granting clemency, but Aleta Bunch's mother, Carolyn, said of Williams's personal plea: "It doesn't change my mind - he should still get the death penalty."

webTitle: Yugoslavia taken to task over two Britons

fields.headline: Yugoslavia taken to task over two Britons
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: The British foreign office minister Keith Vaz yesterday urged Yugoslavia to charge or release the two Britons arrested on suspicion of being terrorists after meeting the families of the two men in London.
fields.body:
The British foreign office minister Keith Vaz yesterday urged Yugoslavia to charge or release the two Britons arrested on suspicion of being terrorists after meeting the families of the two men in London.

In Belgrade, four Dutchmen who were arrested just before the two Britons were detained denied all allegations of a plot to assassinate the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic.

The two Britons, Detective Sergeant Adrian Prangnell, 41, and PC John Yore, 31, who were working for the UN in Kosovo helping to train the Kosovan police force, were arrested with two Canadians at an army checkpoint in Montenegro on August 1. The incident is not related to the charges against the Dutchmen.

Mr Vaz called in the head of the Yugoslav interests section in London, Rade Drobac, yesterday for the third time since the Britons' arrests and accused Yugoslavia of being in breach of various international conventions.

Both detainees were safe and well but remained in solitary confinement. Consular access had been permitted on Wednesday and a further visit was planned for today.

Mr Vaz said: "We are still deeply concerned at the failure of the Yugoslav authorities to comply with the international conventions."

The Yugoslav army, which claims the Britons had military hardware and detonators and appeared to be trained for sabotage, said that it wanted the men prosecuted. There has as yet been no confirmation from the Yugoslav justice system.

But Britain has dismissed the Yugoslav army's version and said that the men were in Montenegro on holiday. They had a copy of the SAS survival handbook, which is available in bookshops, and the amount of explosive equipment amounted to just over £30-worth, belonging to the Canadians, who worked in the construction industry.

Mr Vaz said the government was "very concerned" that the two men had not been allowed a private meeting with Robert Gordon, the British representative in Belgrade. "There is always someone there from the authorities, watching and listening to what's being said. This is totally unacceptable," he said.

Lawyers for the four Dutchmen said yesterday that their clients had rejected the charges against them. Ivan Jankovic, speaking after meeting his client, Godfred de Rie, in Belgrade's central prison, said: "All four of them have expressly and explicitly denied the charges against them."

Mr de Rie is accused of leading a terrorist group which intended to kidnap or kill Mr Milosevic. The other three detainees were accused of being members of the group.

Lawyers for the men said that their clients showed no visible signs of beatings, but when asked if Mr de Rie had been beaten, Mr Jankovic said: "I have reason to believe so."

He said he had told Mr de Rie that he believed that all statements, including those on video, had been given under duress and could not be used in court.

Mr Jankovic, who is also defending the two Canadians, said that 11 knives shown on television and said to have been found in the possession of the Dutch, were not as formidable as they looked, given that one man was a knife collector and another a manufacturer of special knives.

Toma Fila, who represents Bas van Schaik, said the case was "overblown" and believed it would take on a more subdued tone after the September 24 presidential elections.

fields.headline: International news in brief
fields.trailText: 38 dead after Turkish air raids
fields.body:
38 dead after Turkish air raids

Turkish warplanes on a mission to destroy Kurdish guerrilla bases have bombed northern Iraq, killing at least 38 civilians and wounding a further 11, a local Iraqi Kurdish party revealed yesterday.

The wounded, described as herdsmen and nomads, were reportedly taken to a hospital on Tuesday in the regional capital, Irbil. Turkish military officials have denied knowledge of the incident. Earlier reports had put the total number of deaths at 33. Reuters, Ankara

France's roads claim 116 lives

More than 100 people died on France's roads during the long holiday weekend, according to transport officials.

The officials said 1,393 accidents occurred between Friday and Tuesday last week, resulting in 116 deaths and 2,004 injuries - 14% fewer accidents and 18% fewer injuries than in 1995, when the holiday period was also five days long. AP, Paris

Three killed by mines in Bosnia

Three people, including a Swiss mine expert, were killed yesterday while trying to remove the bodies of two fishermen killed earlier this week in a minefield near the Bosnian town of Rogatica, about 25 miles east of Sarajevo, the UN said.

While their full identities were not known, a Bosnian Serb member of the demining team and a local policeman were thought to be the other victims. A local translator was also said to be seriously injured in the blast. Reuters, Sarajevo

Freed dancers head home

Seven European women who were forced into prostitution after travelling to Cambodia to work as dancers in a hotel's nightclub departed for home yesterday after an arduous three-week ordeal.

The five Romanian and two Moldovan women told human rights workers in the capital that their passports had been confiscated after they landed and that they had been forced by the hotel's Canadian owner to provide sex to Cambodian, Chinese and Thai businessmen. Reuters, Phnom Penh

webTitle: Attack dampens hope of Corsica accord

fields.headline: Attack dampens hope of Corsica accord
fields.trailText: A rocket was fired at the office of a French government representative in Corsica early yesterday, dealing another blow to government-sponsored efforts to bring peace to the Mediterranean island.
fields.body:
A rocket was fired at the office of a French government representative in Corsica early yesterday, dealing another blow to government-sponsored efforts to bring peace to the Mediterranean island.

Police said the attack caused no injuries and only minimal damage to the building. But the incident, attributed to separatist guerrillas, is the second challenge in as many weeks to far-reaching plans by the French prime minister, Lionel Jospin, to offer Corsica an unprecedented degree of self rule in exchange for an end to a quarter-century of bloodshed.

Last week Jean-Michel Rossi, a reformed Corsican nationalist, was shot dead outside a cafe in upper Corsica along with his bodyguard. Their heavily armed killers remain at large.

The rocket attack took place as Mr Jospin, whose plan for Corsica has been criticised by the conservative opposition and members of his coalition as rewarding violence, said in a magazine article published yesterday that Corsicans must respect the rule of law if devolution is to go ahead.

But while the political wings of the main Corsican national ist parties have voiced support for the accords, their underground military groups have yet to show themselves capable of uniting to agree on the need for peace.

The plans, if passed by the French parliament, would transfer responsibility for issues such as culture, education and infrastructure to the Corsican assembly, which would also have the power to modify laws passed in Paris.

If all went well, a future French government would then revise the French constitution in 2003 or 2004, introducing proportional representation and creating a single political and administrative body for Corsica with limited law-making powers.

In his article, published in Le Nouvel Observateur, Mr Jospin admitted there was resistance in France to granting Corsicans legislative power, but argued that the mood may change if lasting peace returns and Corsicans make good use of their new powers.

"But if the Corsican state of mind does not change, if the island's elected representatives do not assume their responsibilities, if the violence continues, any revision of the constitution would be risky if not unjustified," he said.

fields.headline: Restoration praise
fields.standfirst: Northumberland
fields.trailText: Northumberland
fields.body:
You can count on the Women's Institute to lay on an invigorating trip. Last week we visited Chillingham Castle to see the wonderful restoration of this Borders pile which has been in possession of the Grey family since the 1900's. As a child I remember seeing its crumbling turrets spiking the racing sky as we piled out of the ancient Morris minor and gaped enthralled at this marvellous hoary, tottering building, the spirit of Border frays oozing from its very moss.

I went along with the WI to see the restoration undertaken by Sir Humphry Wakefield over the last 20 years. When restoration started, the castle was virtually roofless with almost a ton of pigeon droppings on each floor. During the second world war, soldiers were billeted here and were so cold that they stripped panelling off the walls to keep the fires burning. "After extensive rot had been removed, 16 roofs had to be replaced," Sir Humphry told me. "But underneath the rotted Victorian and Georgian plasterwork we found medieval splendour. Great open fireplaces, passages and windows and one walled-up Tudor chimney containing over 100 documents and the oldest writ in Northumberland, dating from 1540."

From one of the turreted stairways in the south wall of the castle I looked out of a casement window onto the beautifully restored Italian garden with lawns, clipped hedges of box and yew and the longest herbaceous border in the north of England. In medieval days, the garden had been a "tilt yard" and on a platform at the west end wall, ladies sat to watch their knights jousting. Now there are rose beds and neat hedges.

Sir Humphry admits that restoration of the castle had been a Herculean task and, at the start, the resident ghosts had been hostile. "They didn't like being disturbed," he confided. "But once I became constructive they realised the ambience was positive and came on to my side." Scenes from the film Elizabeth were filmed at Chillingham and when the cast were working in full costume, extra figures of that era were noticed in the crowd scenes. "They were our ghosts mingling," explained Sir Humphry.

fields.headline: Neo-Nazis mark death of 'martyr' Hess
fields.trailText: Posters and leaflets hailing Rudolf Hess as a "martyr of peace" appeared around Germany on the 13th anniversary of his death yesterday amid national concern over the far-right movement.
fields.body:
Posters and leaflets hailing Rudolf Hess as a "martyr of peace" appeared around Germany on the 13th anniversary of his death yesterday amid national concern over the far-right movement.

Police broke up a torchlit procession by some 60 neo-Nazis late on Wednesday in the east German port of Rostock. Three of the marchers were charged with displaying symbols with banned racist or Nazi content.

Hess, Adolf Hitler's deputy, committed suicide in Spandau prison, Berlin, in 1987. He continues to exert a fascination for Germany's small band of neo-Nazis, who believe (as does his family) that he was murdered by his British military captors.

Posters and leaflets were found in Rostock and towns across the state of Mecklenburg-Vorpommern. Police detained a 14-year-old youth caught in possession of 1,200 Hess stickers in the eastern town of Jena.

Police also confiscated small numbers of similar posters in Baden-Württemberg, Hesse and Lower Saxony states in the former West Germany, generally perceived to have less of a problem with the far right than the east.

No incidents were reported at his grave in the Bavarian town of Wunsiedel.

On Wednesday, a Berlin court upheld a decision by city officials to reject a request by a neo-Nazi for permission to stage a march on Saturday to mark Hess's death.

The court said that such a march would be "unbearable" for the general public in the light of recent violence against foreigners.

fields.headline: Concorde families to sue for £180m
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Concorde crash
fields.trailText: German lawyers acting for the families of victims of the Air France Concorde that crashed last month with the loss of 113 lives plan to sue the French national carrier for more than £183m, it was reported yesterday.
fields.body:
German lawyers acting for the families of victims of the Air France Concorde that crashed last month with the loss of 113 lives plan to sue the French national carrier for more than £183m, it was reported yesterday.

Most of the 103 passengers on the doomed flight, which plunged into a hotel in the small town of Gonesse on July 25 less than two minutes after takeoff, were German tourists on their way to join a luxury cruise ship in New York.

Lawyers in Mönchengladbach said they believed that a suit for negligence would have "every chance of success".

French and British government officials, together with representatives from the Civil Aviation Authority and its French equivalent, the DGAC, met in London to discuss how to get Concorde back in the air following the decision on Wednesday by both countries to suspend the jet's airworthiness certificate.

"Both sides share the same determination to work together to find a solution to put Concorde safely back into service," a British government spokesman said after the meeting. The two governments would spell out their plans on Friday, he added.

Concorde was grounded after investigators concluded that the Paris catastrophe was caused by a single tyre burst, a relatively common occurrence that should never down an airliner.

Investigators believe the tyre was shredded by a stray piece of metal on the runway. Large chunks of rubber then flew up into the left wing, puncturing a fuel tank and triggering the disastrous fire and dual engine failure that led to the crash.

webTitle: 'Relatives' pin their hopes on war's last PoW

fields.headline: 'Relatives' pin their hopes on war's last PoW
fields.trailText: One week after his return to Hungary, the man believed to be the last prisoner from world war two is in great demand by would-be relatives.
fields.body:
One week after his return to Hungary, the man believed to be the last prisoner from world war two is in great demand by would-be relatives.

Andras Tamas, 75, is staying at the National Psychiatric Institute in Budapest, directed by Dr Andras Veer. The institute has been inundated with appeals by possible relatives wanting a chance to meet him, to find out if he is a missing member from their own families.

Mr Tamas is sharing a room with a 35-year-old man with whom he spends much of his day chatting. No more concrete details are known about him, other than his name and birthplace, Turoszentmarton, now called Martin, in central Slovakia.

Before Mr Tamas's return, Dr Veer had drawn up a shortlist of four families from several hundred who contacted him. Since then, new families have approached the institute at a rate of two or three a day.

Mrs Ferenc Tamas, from Bodrogkisfalud in eastern Hungary sounds tired on the telephone.

She believes Mr Tamas is her husband's father's brother - one of six young men who went away to the war from this small village which now has 1,000 inhabitants. She has a fading photograph of them, each holding their call-up papers. The war memorial in the village includes the name Andras Tamas among those who perished.

Erzsebet Koller, from the village of Beloiannisz, east of Budapest, is another hopeful. She believes Mr Tamas could be her father.

She was there at the airport to meet him, and managed to give him a red carnation. She breaks down as she speaks of his homecoming, and the three minutes she was allowed with him the next day, at the institute - taken there by a Russian television channel.

Mr Tamas showed no recognition of her. "There are so many of us claiming him now," she said despairingly, "I don't know who they're going to give him to."

She, and all the other "relatives" have been told to be patient. Dr Veer wants more details of his past to come from Mr Tamas himself, not those who hope he is really theirs.

Doctors have concentrated on his physical rehabilitation this week. A prosthesis to replace his right leg, amputated three years ago, is expected to be fitted today. The main work on his memory is expected to begin next week.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: • A spectacularly unfunny email from Charles Kennedy's office does the rounds. The document, received from Lib Dem councillor Gavin Stollar and sent on from the computer of press person Daisy Sampson, contains a joke so incorrect it might only find a market in the Alabama of the 1950s. Suffice it to say, it involves a black man, his posh white girlfriend and her appalled father - and it turns, in the way of such jokes, on a stereotypical feature of black male anatomy, and larded with pidgin English. Very plastic sandals and beards.
fields.body:
 A spectacularly unfunny email from Charles Kennedy's office does the rounds. The document, received from Lib Dem councillor Gavin Stollar and sent on from the computer of press person Daisy Sampson, contains a joke so incorrect it might only find a market in the Alabama of the 1950s. Suffice it to say, it involves a black man, his posh white girlfriend and her appalled father - and it turns, in the way of such jokes, on a stereotypical feature of black male anatomy, and larded with pidgin English. Very plastic sandals and beards.

"I'm happy to take the irony route, yes," says Daisy, asked if spreading the joke is a pastiche of this long outmoded racial stereotype. And rumours of Bernard Manning's booking as a warm-up act for Charlie Kennedy's big leadership speech at the Lib Dem conference next month remain unconfirmed.

 On similar territory, we return to our Book of the Month. Having explained at the start of Under No Illusion (Blake Publishing) why the word "nigger" is not offensive, my friend Paul Daniels makes another coded bid to succeed Gurbux Singh at the Commission for Racial Equality when he tells of a night in Bombay with the lovely Debbie McGee. The couple went to "a nice restaurant", he writes; "the lamb came in a pastry-covered pot with the bones sticking out of the pastry... The smell was not good and... the meat tasted like it smelt. I didn't eat too much of it." Oh dear.

The next morning Paul's guide explained. "You ordered lamb but they did not have any lamb. They served you dog but the real problem is it was not a young dog." How extraordinarily credible that is of a top Bombay restaurant.

 Sad news from the world of tourist attractions. Irene Jamieson rings from St Albans to recommend the Tomato Museum on Guernsey - but alas, alas and thrice alas, it transpires that it closed about two years ago. According to Neville in the Guernsey tourist information office, the reason - and this is the crazy bit - was that it did not attract enough visitors and, er, went to seed. Neville remembers it only as "all right", and recalls the tomato wine served there as "not very pleasant". "One man got a £600 fine for pouring what he called 'disgusting liquid' over their electronic till."

 I am captivated by a Daily Express article, "Robbed - in the place I feel safest", in which editor Rizla Rosie Boycott describes how, at her country place, she allowed a con-man claiming to have run out of petrol to nick her Audi. There is so much here to enjoy, but my favourite bit is Rosie trotting off obediently to the garden when the man asked if she had any lawnmower fluid. For his car. How many times have I begged her to take more tobacco with it? She wouldn't listen, and this is the result. Poor show.

 Optimism grows regarding the recapture of Gerald Kaufman. Gerald was snatched in central London on Sunday by terrorist splinter group Real GAF (Judy Garland Appreciation Front), whose demands are for lower dress-circle prices at West End musicals. Yesterday, however, with cautious optimism, Scotland Yard negotiators said cash has become the key issue... and if the Real GAF is prepared to raise its offer, there is every chance we'll take him back again.

 I am profoundly depressed to learn of the hypocritical and craven expulsion of Nick from Big Brother. Still, it's not all gloom for the junior insurance broker. At least his career prospects look good. Duplicitous, treacherous, neurotic, deceitful and pretty much amoral - I think we can all guess what's next. Taxi to Fleet Street, Mr Nicholas Bateman, taxi to Fleet Street...

 Terrible scenes last Tuesday week at the Covent Gardent branch of fashion chain Monsoon. The store was closed - and we are really not making this up - because of flooding.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: A reader complained in Letters, page 19, July 19, that Barclaycard had authorised a £1,500 credit limit for her son, a university student, 21. The family now agrees, after a complaint by Barclaycard, that the card was a NatWest Visa. (Her son notes, however, that when he switched to Barclaycard soon afterwards, he was given an opening limit of £1,500.)

The family now agrees, after a complaint by Barclaycard, that the card was a NatWest Visa. (Her son notes, however, that when he switched to Barclaycard soon afterwards, he was given an opening limit of £1,500.)

Angela Rippon was said (page 4, G2, August 14) to have stepped from behind her newsreader's desk to dance on the Morecambe and Wise Christmas show in 1978. It was 1976.

In the East Sussex section of our Heritage Open Days guide for areas outside London (August 12), the website for the Brunswick Square house, Hove, should have read www.regency-town-house.org.uk

A piece on digital broadcasting, Media Guardian, page 48, August 14, said News Corp's pay-TV operations reached "60% of the world's population, or 85m homes". Such domestic overcrowding is explained by the fact that the phrase should have read "60% of the world's pay-TV population ..."

Sport's cricket round-up on page 30 yesterday said that batting for Glamorgan against Nottinghamshire, "Steve James and Matthew Maynard both hit Sunset Strips - 77 to those too young to recall the splendours of Efrem Zimbalist Jr and Ed 'Cookie' Burns." The TV character's name was Kookie.

A health article on page 8, G2, August 15, declared that many women found their breasts "little more than a source of tortuous pain". Collins gives that word's meanings as: twisting or winding; devious or cunning; intricate. If wanted in the phrase above, the word should have been torturous.

fields.headline: Examining the entrails
fields.trailText: So the annual denigration of school students' achievements has begun once again (Record A-level pass rates lead to row over standards, August 17). For some years now schools have been exhorted to raise standards and we've responded to this request.
fields.body:
So the annual denigration of school students' achievements has begun once again (Record A-level pass rates lead to row over standards, August 17). For some years now schools have been exhorted to raise standards and we've responded to this request. In the school of which I am chair of governors we have made particular progress in sixth-form work through, among other things, improved monitoring and use of predictive instruments; improved management; the appointment of an excellent head of sixth form; and the hard work of our teachers. Why is it so difficult to believe that we have simply been successful in doing what we were asked to do?

Rev Michael Camp
Hadlow, Kent
mmcamp@zetnet.co.uk

 I am reading at 8am that A-level results are suffering from "endemic grade inflation". My daughter will get her results at 10.30am. How valuable will she think her results are? Of course, the comment comes from Ruth Lea, policy director at the Institute of Directors, who regularly defends endemic pay inflation for...er...directors. When will she and the overpaid, generally useless people she represents get off our children's and teachers' backs?

Mick Gosling
London
mgosling@stokenew. demon.co.uk

 Of course the percentage of A-level passes is rising, because since the introduction of league tables many schools and colleges actively discourage students expected to fail from sitting the exams. Therefore the statistics say little about standards.

Gail Seery
Grantham, Lincs
GailSeery@aol.com

 One of the major factors in the year-by-year improvements in A-level results is the pressure of market forces on the examining groups. The examining bodies compete fiercely each year for a finite group of customers (the schools) and their interests lie in keeping these customers happy. Woe betide any examining body which announced falling success rates. Small improvements keep schools in the fold and defections to other groups to a minimum.

DJ Gillan
Knutsford, Cheshire

 If girls did substantially better than boys this year, presumably in past years boys did better than girls. Did the National Association of Head Teachers have any concern about that? Or did they just regard boys outperforming girls as part of the normal course of things? If girls do better than boys because boys buy into a laddish culture that says it is not cool to be clever, but then in later life boys do better than girls, surely concern is wasted on boys? They get ahead because they live in a male-dominated culture. That's something the NAHT should be concerned about. But they're probably mostly boys.

Jane Carnall
Reading
hj.carnall@virgin.net

 Isn't it interesting? When boys were outperforming girls in exams it was because the boys were cleverer. Now that girls are outperforming boys, it is because boys are underperforming.

Debbie Burton
Manchester

 Many boys hesitate to be seen working hard at school in case they be accused of being queer by their peers. Another reason for the repeal of section 28?

Bernard Ratigan
Paul Wishart
Loughborough, Leicestershire

 It is very clear that girls are taking easy subjects and avoiding the subjects generally accepted as "difficult".

Neil Hornby
Sevenoaks, Kent

fields.headline: Rich and privileged
fields.trailText: If Concorde does not fly again (Leader, August 16), it will not be "doubly tragic".
fields.body:
If Concorde does not fly again (Leader, August 16), it will not be "doubly tragic". Concorde is the most polluting passenger aircraft, whose raison d'etre has been to transport the over-rich and over-privileged from one unreality to another. I delight in its grounding.
Adam Tickell
Netley Abbey, Hants

 Tim Luckhurst may have a point about deficiencies in some aspects of Scottish education (Comment, August 16). But my experience (as a non-Scot) over the past 15 years in interviewing people for jobs requiring excellent literacy skills has been that most Scottish-educated candidates far outclass their competitors in their ability to read and write literate English.
Don Keller
London

 You report that in Los Angeles there has been a day of marches in protest at "corporate greed" (Democrat convention, August 16). Why the quotation marks?
Rev John James
Churchill, Somerset

 Your obituary of Lord Scarsdale (August 16) shows he was a true Curzon. Under the family's coat-of-arms, at Keddleston Hall, is the motto "What Curzon Has Curzon Holds". None of your fancy French or Latin, and no pious pretence of serving God or man.
Les Russon
Worksop, Notts

 Lord Scarsdale's family only "stretches back 900 years". Mine (and that of almost everyone I know) goes back much further than that.
Antony Scott
Bristol

 It is depressing, though no real surprise, to find when it comes to infantile sniggerings about Mars bars (Letters, August 16 and 17), Guardian-reading men are no different to their Sun-reading counterparts. Aren't there any sexually mature men out there?
Jean Hewson
Berkhamsted, Herts

fields.headline: Social fund critics reply
fields.trailText: Angela Eagle's defence of the social fund fails to answer three basic questions (Letters, August 17).
fields.body:
Angela Eagle's defence of the social fund fails to answer three basic questions (Letters, August 17). First, given the government's claims about winning the battle against poverty, why was there a huge increase in the number of people needing to make budgeting loan applications to the social fund? Second, what does it say about benefit levels that the DSS rejected 360,000 applications because applicants were "too poor" to repay? And third, what does the government think happens to those who are rejected? It commands "work from those who can" and allegedly offers "security for those who cannot". Not much sign of security here.

Steve Webb MP
Liberal Democrat social security spokesman

 The response of Angela Eagle to Malcolm Dean's criticisms of the social fund is bland in the extreme. She does not discuss the point that applications from poor people for loans are increasing at the very time New Labour is boasting of tackling poverty. She fails to consider what happens to those whose applications are rejected. And she ignores the accusation that, in opposition, Labour condemned social fund loans and called for their replacement by grants.

Bob Holman
Glasgow

 As a someone who exists on incapacity benefit because of renal failure since birth, I applied for a budgeting loan of £210, on the advice of the benefits agency, only to be told that I was not entitled to one as I was not on jobseeker's allowance or income support. I don't want to keep the money or to make a fortune speculating on international currency. I just want a loan to get my Mini through its MoT, so I can get to hospital for dialysis and to Hull University to study. So much for New Labour's philosophy of empowerment.

Mark Hallam
Hull

 Social assistance benefit rates in this country were always alleged to be sufficient for food, clothing, fuel and other basic necessities. Because this made replacement of expensive durables difficult, the system used to include a "single-payment" grant scheme. But in 1988, the then government decreed that in future benefit rates would be enough to repay loans for essential items, even though benefits were not to be increased. Angela Eagle ducks this issue. A system of grants should be restored until benefits are high enough to permit claimants to repay loans for necessities without suffering hardship.

Geoff Fimister
Child Poverty Action Group

Second, what does it say about benefit levels that the DSS rejected 360,000 applications because applicants were "too poor" to repay? And third, what does the government think happens to those who are rejected? It commands "work from those who can" and allegedly offers "security for those who cannot". Not much sign of security here. Steve Webb MP Liberal Democrat social security spokesman  The response of Angela Eagle to Malcolm Dean's criticisms of the social fund is bland in the extreme. She does not discuss the point that applications from poor people for loans are increasing at the very time New Labour is boasting of tackling poverty. She fails to consider what happens to those whose applications are rejected. And she ignores the accusation that, in opposition, Labour condemned social fund loans and called for their replacement by grants. Bob Holman Glasgow  As a someone who exists on incapacity benefit because of renal failure since birth, I applied for a budgeting loan of £210, on the advice of the benefits agency, only to be told that I was not entitled to one as I was not on jobseeker's allowance or income support. I don't want to keep the money or to make a fortune speculating on international currency. I just want a loan to get my Mini through its MoT, so I can get to hospital for dialysis and to Hull University to study. So much for New Labour's philosophy of empowerment. Mark Hallam Hull  Social assistance benefit rates in this country were always alleged to be sufficient for food, clothing, fuel and other basic necessities. Because this made replacement of expensive durables difficult, the system used to include a "single-payment" grant scheme. But in 1988, the then government decreed that in future benefit rates would be enough to repay loans for essential items, even though benefits were not to be increased. Angela Eagle ducks this issue. A system of grants should be restored until benefits are high enough to permit claimants to repay loans for necessities without suffering hardship. Geoff Fimister Child Poverty Action Group

webTitle: Letters: More fishing in troubled waters

fields.headline: More fishing in troubled waters
fields.trailText: In presenting cod-farming as the future of fish-farming and a "possible solution" to the crisis in world fish stocks (Changing the face of fish farming, August 16), you have not done your homework properly.
fields.body:
 In presenting cod-farming as the future of fish-farming and a "possible solution" to the crisis in world fish stocks (Changing the face of fish farming, August 16), you have not done your homework properly.

Farming cod, which like salmon are carnivores at the top of the food chain, is inherently unsustainable and will only compound the crisis in world fisheries. The voracious appetite of fish-farming has already seen its use of the world's fish meal rise from 10% in 1988 to 33% in 1997.

Recent research by Rosamond Naylor shows that farming carnivorous species requires large inputs of wild fish for feed. She calculates that such farming "uses two to five times more fish protein, in the form of fish meal, to feed the farmed species than is supplied by the farmed product".

In fact, the figure for cod, halibut, sole, sea bass, haddock and tuna (all of which are now farmed) is 5.16. Feeding five tonnes of wild fish to produce less than one tonne of farmed fish simply does not add up in anyone's books.
Don Staniford
Friends of the Earth Scotland
don.staniford@virgin.net

 There is one proven way of sustainable fishing, and that is to set up marine reserves where no fishing is allowed at all. This allows breeding stocks to be established, which then spill out into fishing waters once stocks are replenished, and requires little effort.
Noel Carter
Newcastle upon Tyne

 In Senegal and the Gambia eight years ago, I saw the pirogues come in with ladyfish three feet long, which were wrapped in palm leaves with lime and chilli to roast over a fire (Fishing for the future, August 14). One or two would feed the whole village. The woven nets had a wide mesh you could put your spread hand through, so immature fish were never caught. It was an sustainable way of life that had gone on for thousands of years.
Alison Prince
Whiting Bay, Isle of Arran

 In Brittany at Concarneau there is a fine Museum of Fishing with a display area on "conservation". It tells how to salt and can fish - of course.
Alan Pyle
Crewkerne, Somerset

webTitle: Analysis: Another age of the train?

fields.headline: Another age of the train?
fields.standfirst:
John Prescott gave a huge boost to the railways. But doubts about operating costs, franchises and Railtrack's performance remain

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: John Prescott gave a huge boost to the railways. But doubts about operating costs, franchises and Railtrack's performance remain
fields.body:
When, in British Rail days, Jimmy Savile used to tell us that this was the age of the train, not many were convinced. The British people's love of trains did not extend to using them. Railways were in a long decline that continued well into the 90s. But since 1995, the number of passenger journeys has increased by nearly 30% and the railways are now carrying more people than at any time since the second world war.

The Conservatives would have us believe that this growth is due to privatisation. But the analysis that underpins the government's 10-year transport plan would suggest otherwise. A new forecasting model, developed by the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions, suggests that the increase in passenger numbers can be explained mainly by factors outside the industry's control: strong economic growth and rising road traffic congestion.

Privatisation made fortunes for a few but passengers have seen few benefits. The performance of Railtrack and the train operating companies has been little better, and in some cases worse, than British Rail. The main elements of the government's strategy are falling into place. It has created a new Strategic Rail Authority (SRA) with a remit to develop the network, and appointed a new rail regulator, Tom Winsor. At present the SRA exists in "shadow" form with powers inherited from Office of Passenger Rail Franchising and the British Railways Board. It will gain extra powers when the transport bill completes its passage through parliament.

Railways were the clear winners from the government's spending review and the 10-year transport plan. Over the next three years public spending on railways will increase by 125% in real terms compared to an 18% real-terms increase in spending on trunk roads and motorways. The transport plan commits a total of £60bn to the railways over the next 10 years. Nearly half the money, £26bn, will come from the public sector in operating subsidies and capital grants. The rest will be made up from a mixture of fare revenue and private finance, the latter being backed by future income from fares and an extra £3.5bn of direct revenue support from the public purse.

But should taxpayers get more for their money: a stake in the industry? In part, this question was answered in the announcement of the first two new passenger franchises, a 20-year replacement franchise for Chiltern Railways, which runs trains between London and the West Midlands, and a two-year extension to the Midland Main Line franchise. Besides new investment in trains and track and better performance, operators will be expected to enter profit-sharing agreements with the SRA.

In the next 18 months, the SRA intends to replace all the short-term franchises with fewer, longer-term franchises along similar lines: more investment, higher standards of service and profit-sharing. The franchise map will be redrawn and the total number of passenger franchises reduced from 25 to 22. Not all is plain sailing. With Chiltern and Midland Main Line, the incumbent operators put in the winning bids. The replacement for Connex South Central, also in the first tranche, has been held up by the incumbent operator's unwillingness to give up the franchise before it expires in 2003.

But the question of whether the public sector should also acquire not just a share in the profits but also a stake in the ownership of the industry and in particular in Railtrack, the monopoly owner of the infrastructure, remains. The idea of a public sector equity stake in Railtrack in return for government grant was put forward by Labour in opposition. Today, some 90% of Railtrack's income comes in the form of payments made by the passenger and freight operators for use of the infrastructure. But the SRA now holds the purse strings to £4bn of capital grants for renewals, including the upgrading of the west coast main line, and a £7bn rail modernisation fund for expansion of the network.

The SRA will publish a detailed strategy for the development of the rail network later this year. It will set out the principles of investment support and describe the forms of funding that will be made available. One possible option is that direct payments to Railtrack could be made in return for a share in the ownership of the network. The alternative, that Railtrack's shareholders make a capital gain from taxpayers' money that they have not earned, would seem perverse.

There is also the question of whether Railtrack should lose its monopoly on infrastructure projects. Sir Alistair Morton, the chairman of the SRA, is particularly concerned about Railtrack's ability to finance and manage all network enhancements. He has been encouraging Railtrack to enter into joint ventures with the train operating companies.

Research commissioned by the Institute for Public Policy Research suggests that such joint ventures could have an important, if limited, role in setting a benchmark for Railtrack's performance. Railtrack has an improving record on managing the existing network and is responsible for fewer delays and cancellations than the train operating companies. But its management of major infrastructure projects, such as the west coast main line, leaves much to be desired.

In the spending review and 10-year transport plan, John Prescott has delivered a huge win for railways. Now it is time for the industry to deliver in return.

 Tony Grayling is a transport specialist at the Institute for Public Policy Research. t.grayling@ippr.org.uk

fields.headline: The evolution of cloning
fields.trailText: Ian Gibson perpetuates two myths (A vote for cloning, August 15). First, my predecessor as Bishop of Oxford, Samuel Wilberforce, was not against evolution as such. He believed that the evidence then adduced for evolution was not conclusive - a view shared by a good number of scientists at the time. Secondly, historians of science remark on how quickly the thoughtful Christian public accepted the theory of evolution. The persistence of creationist views among fundamentalists should not blind us to the rapidity with which Christians adjusted to a new way of thinking of God's action in the world.
fields.body:
Ian Gibson perpetuates two myths (A vote for cloning, August 15). First, my predecessor as Bishop of Oxford, Samuel Wilberforce, was not against evolution as such. He believed that the evidence then adduced for evolution was not conclusive - a view shared by a good number of scientists at the time. Secondly, historians of science remark on how quickly the thoughtful Christian public accepted the theory of evolution. The persistence of creationist views among fundamentalists should not blind us to the rapidity with which Christians adjusted to a new way of thinking of God's action in the world.

Rt Rev Richard Harries
Bishop of Oxford

A few weeks ago, the company that created Dolly announced that its cloning experiments were to end, having consistently produced deformities rather than healthy animals. Now we hear from a government report that the same techniques may be used on human embryos to make healthy replacement tissue to cure human ailments (MPs to get free vote on embryo cures, August 17). Has there been a great unreported leap forward that transforms techniques too unreliable for animals into ones safe for us? Arguing about the merits of pro-life and pro-science positions seems academic if the science isn't up to scratch.

Karen Hurley
London

fields.headline: UK fall-out
fields.trailText: Yes, the Russians have appalling disregard for the environment, with their fleets of rotting nuclear submarines and casual dumping of radioactive materials (Scientists fear nuclear meltdown, August 17). But remember HMS Tireless. This British nuclear-powered submarine, having broken down and leaked radioactive coolant across the Mediterranean, has been sitting in Gibraltar dockyard for three months. Local alarm and anger is met with bland statements from our Ministry of Defence, devoid of information about what has gone wrong and what the dangers are. Shouldn't nuclear glasnost begin at home?

webTitle: TV and radio 'licence to print money'

fields.headline: TV and radio 'licence to print money'
fields.trailText: The route to broadcast riches is through children's entertainment: Anne Wood, the creator of the Teletubbies, was yesterday named the wealthiest woman in television.
fields.body:
The route to broadcast riches is through children's entertainment: Anne Wood, the creator of the Teletubbies, was yesterday named the wealthiest woman in television.

According to the first "rich list" of the television and radio industry, Ms Wood and her family were valued at £150m, second only to the chairman of the GWR radio group, Sir Peter Michael, who is worth £175m.

The list was drawn up for Broadcast magazine by the Sunday Times Rich List compiler, Philip Beresford.

It also shows that performers who have set up their own companies - such as Chris Evans, Noel Edmonds and Kirsty Wark - have enjoyed considerable success. Evans is worth £80m: his already considerable assets were boosted when he sold his stake in Ginger Media Group to Scottish Media Group in January for £75m. He is eighth in the list.

The BBC's director general, Greg Dyke, is estimated to be worth £15m, putting him joint 38th, and the comedian Jennifer Saunders is worth £10m, and comes in at joint 48th.

Mr Beresford said the list showed that the independent television production sector was now the "sexiest" part of the media industry.

"It seems to be a licence to print money, as was said about the early days of ITV. Content is king, and if you can produce something good, ... you're in business."

Media stars who do not have their own production companies were not included in the list."That's why the Chris Tarrants and the Cilla Blacks did not make it," Mr Beresford said.

The list also revealed that comedy is a sure road to riches. As well as Saunders, Rowan Atkinson, Jasper Carrott, Adrian Edmonson, Jennifer Saunders, Griff Rhys Jones and Mel Smith all feature.

Atkinson, star of the Blackadder series, is worth £40m with his production company Tiger Television, and comes 18th. Talkback Productions has made Rhys Jones and Smith each worth £20m.

Carrott, owner of the media company Complete Communications, is worth £32m and comes 22nd.

fields.headline: Punk idol rallies LA protesters
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The Kennedys have been everywhere throughout the Democratic convention so it should be no surprise that one of the biggest cheers on a long day of street protests in Los Angeles should be for Jello Biafra, the singer and writer who rose to fame with the 1980s hardcore punk band, Dead Kennedys.
fields.body:
The Kennedys have been everywhere throughout the Democratic convention so it should be no surprise that one of the biggest cheers on a long day of street protests in Los Angeles should be for Jello Biafra, the singer and writer who rose to fame with the 1980s hardcore punk band, Dead Kennedys.

Addressing the crowd in Pershing Square, surrounded by hundreds of police, Biafra told demonstrators that "corporate power is the new Vietnam".

The gathering came at the end of a day of arrests and marches and the firing of rubber bullets on a crowd outside the centre where the convention is being held.

The police declared unlawful assemblies for the second time this week to disperse protesters who had gathered on the issues of police brutality and the death penalty.

So far 192 people have been arrested, 59 for felonies and 133 for misdemeanors.

"Do you want to be part of history or do you want to watch it on television?" asked Biafra who is in dispute with former members of his group because he refused to allow Levis to use a Dead Kennedys song for a commercial.

"Above all, don't give up, don't turn into yuppies like the last generation!" He urged people to vote for the Green party candidate, Ralph Nader.

The day started with 30 people being arrested outside Rampart police station, which is at the centre of a corruption scandal involving officers dealing in and planting drugs, shooting unarmed gang members and fabricating evidence.

A larger march of around 4,000 people then rallied outside the LAPD's headquarters to protest about people killed by police.

A lorry with the names of 2,000 who had been killed throughout the US was at the centre of a march which nearly boiled over after a masked anarchist set fire to the American flag.

webTitle: The blonde marauders who help Al squirm with a purpose

fields.headline: The blonde marauders who help Al squirm with a purpose
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: You know how it is at the end of the Christmas holidays? You love your family. And you've loved seeing them day after biliously festive day. But now, just once, could you stay in bed and watch the last BBC2 Fred Astaire movie in peace? Now, just once, could the front-door bell not ring?
fields.body:
You know how it is at the end of the Christmas holidays? You love your family. And you've loved seeing them day after biliously festive day. But now, just once, could you stay in bed and watch the last BBC2 Fred Astaire movie in peace? Now, just once, could the front-door bell not ring?

My friends, that is not the American way. Ring out wild bells! Here they come again, the Democratic marauders. Eight-year-old blonde scraps of gap-toothed sweetness reading poems about "rainbows in a smog-filled sky". And your own nearest and dearest, bent on that most grisly of tasks: making you seem like a caring, sharing, electable human being. Please welcome ... President Ebenezer Scrooge.

Thus Karenna Gore Schiff, Al's eldest and politically cutest, tosses her inevitably blonde hair, and insists on telling the world how once upon a time in a freezing Tennessee winter, she and her best little friend Eliza built an igloo in the back garden and insisted on sleeping out in it. And they were so cold. And then out came dad with the hot chocolate.

Thus Hadassah Lieberman, suddenly called by God and the Democratic national committee to be a political wife, must testify in public about "the love of my life, my regular Joe" - with a passion for "family, faith, neighbourhood, congregation and community" you could pour over hot pancakes.

Thus Joe himself is obliged to remember his granny from eastern Europe who came to America and found her Christian neighbours wishing her "Good Sabbath, Mrs Manger" as she went off to the synagogue every Saturday. And his dad, "who lived in an orphanage and drove a bakery truck". And his mom, "who is here tonight - mom, I love you". And, of course, Big Al - the epitome of "family and faith, a father and now a grandfather. When my daughter was six, after spending time with Al, she looked at me and she said: 'He MUST be a daddy'".

Thus Tommy Lee Jones is summoned from the set of some new disaster movie to remember his years sharing a room with Al at Harvard and tell us how Tipper will still "sit on Al's lap and smooch".

Tipper must do her podium stuff. And Al - the maker of breakfast toast, the bearer of hot chocolate, the would-be commander-in-chief - must squirm through the whole routine again.

Squirm (as the Republicans would say) with a purpose. This (as the script does say) "is the party of principles, not personalities": which, being interpreted, means it's got sacks full of policies, but Albert Gore Junior for a candidate.

webTitle: Safety checks weaken suicide theory of EgyptAir crash

fields.headline: Safety checks weaken suicide theory of EgyptAir crash
fields.standfirst: Special report: EgyptAir flight 990 crash
fields.trailText: Egypt yesterday claimed vindication in the latest round of the politically charged investigation into the crash of EgyptAir flight 990, which plunged into the sea off Massachusetts last October, killing 217 people.
fields.byline: Khaled Dawoud  in Cairo and  Brian Whitaker
fields.body:
Egypt yesterday claimed vindication in the latest round of the politically charged investigation into the crash of EgyptAir flight 990, which plunged into the sea off Massachusetts last October, killing 217 people.

American investigators believe that the 59-year-old co-pilot, Gamil al-Batouti, deliberately pushed the aircraft into a fatal dive when the captain left the controls to go to the toilet.

But yesterday Mohammed Fahim Rayan, EgyptAir's chairman, said he was "99% sure" that a technical problem, not a suicidal pilot, had caused the Boeing 767 to crash.

Earlier this week, Boeing urged all airlines flying the wide-bodied 767 to make special checks on the bell cranks - mechanical links from the hydraulic controls that help to move the elevator flaps on the tail.

Boeing denied any connection with the crash investigation, but EgyptAir was delighted. "This is exactly what we've been talking about," said Captain Shaker Kelada, the airline's safety chief.

Bell cranks retrieved from the wreckage of flight 990 were found to have rivets sheared in opposite directions, which EgyptAir says may indicate that the elevators - controlling the up and down attitude of the plane - jammed.

"We have seen at least two similar complaints from the Boeing's 767 elevators by Air Canada and Air Mexico," Walid Murad, head of the Egyptian Pilots' Federation, said.

Egypt has always rejected the suicide theory, suggesting that investigators latched on to the theory to exonerate Boeing from any part in the disaster.

A series of leaks to the American press during the early stages of the investigation sought to portray Batouti as an Islamic fundamentalist. When that was disproved, subsequent leaks portrayed him as an unbalanced sex maniac who harassed women in hotels.

Although the American national transportation safety board (NTSB) has not yet reached a conclusion about the cause, last Friday it released the first 1,665 pages of documents relating to the crash - including the first full transcripts from the cockpit voice recorder.

Far from confirming the suicide theory, the transcript shows Batouti cooperating with the captain after his hasty return to the cockpit in an effort to save the plane.

Twenty-eight minutes into the flight, and two minutes before the crash, with Batouti in charge in the cockpit, there are sounds described as a thunk and a click. The voice recorder then captures three syllables of non-Arabic speech. Four of the 10 people involved in the transcription believe they heard words similar to "control it"; one thought it might be "hydraulic"; five say it is unintelligible.

Immediately after this, Batouti says faintly: " tawakilt ala Allah " (I rely on God) - a phrase he repeats 10 times before the recording breaks off.

The American suicide theory was based on the fact that Batouti uttered this phrase, routinely used by Egyptians facing difficult situations, before the autopilot was disengaged and the engines shut off.

There is also nothing in the transcript to support earlier American claims that the captain, Ahmed Mahmoud al-Habashi, and Batouti fought for control of the plane.

In the transcript, Batouti asks: "What's happening?" but there is no suggestion that Batouti has done something wrong or is not working to save the plane.

Leaks from the investigation earlier also suggested that Batouti switched off the engines to prevent Habashi pulling the plane out of its dive. But the Egyptian Pilots' Association says the crew were following standard procedure in order to slow the aircraft's speed. In the transcript, Habashi orders Batouti: "Shut the engines". Batouti replies: "It's shut".

In the space of 40 seconds, the plane descended from 33,000ft to 16,000ft before the voice recorder cut off.

On the basis of radar observations, US investigators say that it later climbed to 24,000 feet before finally dropping into the sea. The Egyptian Pilots' Association claims this is another error.

Ali Murad, the association's deputy secretary general, says: "If the engines were switched off during the dive, how did the plane manage to climb up to 24,000 feet again? What was seen at 24,000 feet were remains of the plane which fell more slowly than the main part."

Before the NTSB's release of documents, the American paper USA Today published leaks from an FBI investigation in which security staff at the New York hotel used by EgyptAir crews alleged that there had been complaints about Batouti exposing himself from behind a window, and that he had harassed chambermaids. None of these incidents was reported to police at the time, and there were statements from other hotel workers describing Batouti as a pleasant man who caused no trouble.

To the co-pilot's nephew, Walid Batouti, the latest leaks "all confirm the conspiracy being made against Batouti and EgyptAir".

webTitle: Developer's plans to turn Blackpool into Las Vegas

fields.headline: Las Vegas in Lancashire
fields.standfirst: Blackpool developer's plan for casino hotels
fields.trailText: A leisure firm is hoping to turn Blackpool from a kiss-me-kwik seaside resort into the British Las Vegas.
fields.body:
A leisure firm is hoping to turn Blackpool from a kiss-me-kwik seaside resort into the British Las Vegas.

The Lancashire resort may be more reminiscent of saucy postcards, fish and chips and trams but all this could change if Leisure Parcs, owner of the Blackpool Tower, is allowed to build six huge casino hotels at a cost of £1bn, together with a conference centre and 3,000 seat theatre.

The proposal has been submitted to the gambling review body, but would require a change of legislation. Last night the minister for tourism, Janet Anderson, described the proposal as exciting, and said that, like all Britain's resorts, Blackpool had to adapt to the indoor leisure needs of the new century.

The casino hotels, with up to 12,000 slot machines, would stretch along the seafront from the Winter Gardens, with the hope of eventually attracting 30m visitors a year.

Marc Etches, managing director of Leisure Parcs, said yesterday that the casinos could be a catalyst for economic regeneration of the area.

"In Blackpool we have a conundrum," he said. "It is very successful, with 12m visitors every year, but has the 12th lowest gross domestic product in the country and the third lowest in the north-west. It has some very difficult social and economic problems.

"To turn things around, we have to be as bold and ambitious with a concrete vision for the town. That vision means persuading the government to change gambling legislation to allow resorts like Blackpool to have casino hotels."

Mr Etches did not liken his scheme to the famed gambling resort in Nevada, but cited the experience of Atlantic City, near New York, which reversed its decline by building four casinos in the late 1970s and today had 34m visitors bringing in £4bn a year.

Leisure Parcs has owned the tower, the town's three piers and the Winter Gardens since 1998.

webTitle: Retailers fail to attract shoppers in spite of record discounting

fields.headline: Gloomy summer shows up in sales
fields.standfirst: Retailers fail to attract shoppers in spite of record discounting
fields.trailText: Record discounting on Britain's high streets throughout the summer failed to lure in shoppers, official figures showed yesterday.
fields.body:
Record discounting on Britain's high streets throughout the summer failed to lure in shoppers, official figures showed yesterday.

Stripping out price changes, retail sales volumes remained flat in July - according to the office for national statistics - while the amount retailers took through their tills actually fell.

"This year's summer sales were something of a damp squib - particularly in clothing and footwear, where record price cuts failed to shift any more volumes than usual," said Geoffrey Dicks, a UK economist at the Royal Bank of Scotland.

Even the impact of the fourth Harry Potter novel, the fastest selling book in publishing history, was not enough to lift the sale figures - although several retailing chains reported to the ONS that it was the only bright spot in an otherwise gloomy month.

The strongest growth in July came in the non-store retailing and repair sector at 1.8%, the ONS said. The sector comprises mail order and door to door sales, repair services and market stalls.

Clothing and footwear shops and food stores had the worst sales figures last month, recording a 0.2% and a 0.4% drop in volume terms.

Weaker than expected sales data will help calm fears at the Bank of England that private spending coupled with the chancellor's boost to public spending would increase demand and push up inflation.

"It's a very encouraging number. We've still got GDP figures next week though, so it's still finely balanced, but today's numbers will be encouraging for the rate outlook," said Fraser Coutts, an economist with 4Cast.

Other analysts said the underlying picture showed that consumers' spending remained robust.

Weather-related factors are also believed to have put off shoppers in July, although the growth of large shopping malls means that consumers are less likely to be deterred by a bit of rain.

"Stripping away the most volatile component, food, sales were more upbeat," said Michael Hume, UK economist at Lehman Brothers.

"Consequently, these figures are unlikely to prompt a rethink on the outlook for consumer spending on the MPC. We still see rates being hiked by 25 basis points in September," he added.

The ONS reported that the three-month on three-month growth rate, usually a more stable guide to the trend than the monthly figures, jumped to 0.9% in the three months to July from 0.4% in the three months to June.

However, ONS statisticians cautioned that this was partly a result of January's millennium-fuelled sales boom dropping out of the three-month comparative data.
