fields.headline: Formidable Lieberman woos independents
fields.standfirst:
Democratic convention Vice-presidential candidate moves up a league and boosts Gore's campaign
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Joseph Lieberman faced down the doubters and made a powerful pitch to independent voters in his speech to the Democratic convention in Los Angeles on Wednesday. In so doing, Al Gore's running mate indicated he could be the man to unlock the 2000 US presidential election for the Democrats.
fields.body:
Joseph Lieberman faced down the doubters and made a powerful pitch to independent voters in his speech to the Democratic convention in Los Angeles on Wednesday. In so doing, Al Gore's running mate indicated he could be the man to unlock the 2000 US presidential election for the Democrats.

Less than two weeks ago, Mr Lieberman was a relatively obscure, generally conservative Democratic senator, known to the public mainly as a prominent critic of Bill Clinton during the impeachment crisis, and known to the Washington press corps mainly as an honest and interesting, but marginal, figure within his party.

Yet thousands of delegates in the Staples Centre greeted the little man from Connecticut - "my Joey", as his wife, Hadassah, introduced him - as a conquering hero, as he delivered a smart, upbeat and generally well-judged acceptance speech.

He entered to the music from Chariots of Fire, greeted the audience with an improbable clenched-fist salute and started his speech with a Jewish mother-in-law joke. But in contrast to his campaign appearances last week, Mr Lieberman dwelled only lightly on religious themes or the significance of his selection to American Jews and immigrants.

It was a speech that set out to do four things: introduce the still largely unknown Mr Lieberman to a wider national audience; help promote Al Gore's generally lack-lustre public image; win the enthusiastic support of the black American electorate, a crucial Democratic base; and reach out to independent and undecided voters who need reasons to cast their ballots for the Gore-Lieberman ticket.

"Let me just speak to those of you at home who haven't made up your mind if you want to build on our prosperity," Mr Lieberman said, before highlighting bipartisanship and political reform as two key areas appealing to independents. "I respectfully say to you that Al Gore and I are the guys who are ready to do the job," the vice-presidential candidate said.

At various points in his speech, Mr Lieberman praised Republican leaders such as Ronald Reagan and John McCain. He stressed his senate reputation as an "across-the-aisle" legislator, who had worked with Republicans in the past and who was happy to do so again.

"Our opponents are decent and likeable men," he said. "I am pleased to call many in their party my friends."

In the coming election, this appeal to the centre and to independents will clearly be one of Mr Lieberman's responsibilities.

The senator's quirky and unconventional voting record has raised some questions - especially among black leaders - about whether he will win over their support.

In two warm-up speeches, Congressmen Robert Menendez, a Latino from New Jersey, and the formidable John Lewis of Georgia, a black man, fought to promote Mr Lieberman's anti-racist record.

Meanwhile, Mr Lieberman went out of his way to restate his support for affirmative action, as he had done earlier at a meeting with the congressional black caucus.

Mr Lewis reminded the convention that the young Mr Lieberman had travelled to America's deep south to help register black voters during the toughest years of the civil rights campaigns of the 1960s.

Mr Lewis called him: "My friend and my brother."

The impact that the man from Connecticut has made on the polls in just a few days has been good for the Democrats, and yesterday's speech has established him quickly as a formidable player in the political big league.

If Mr Gore loses in November, Mr Lieberman could be an early favourite for the Democratic nomination in 2004, an unlikely thought even two weeks ago.

All aboard the Democrat bandwagon:

The day's 'next president but one' tip California Governor Gray Davis, who has established a high profile during the week, presented President Clinton with a (fake) Oscar during a fund-raising party at Paramount Studios

Most miffed organisation The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences which does not like replicas of its carefully protected Oscar being handed out to just anyone

Comedian Bill Maher "Hollywood loves this Gore-Lieberman ticket. I know this because today three studios green-lighted projects about a robot that teams up with a rabbi"

Jon Corzine, the Democratic Senate candidate for New Jersey "We live in a time of tremendous prosperity, a time when Democrats have transformed record deficits into record surpluses. It is our duty to use this prosperity to address the unmet needs of the American people"

Newly welcome and honoured guests at the feast American Indians are now among the biggest political backers of candidates in areas where they are establishing casinos. There are 75 American Indian delegates at the convention, a new record

Publication with biggest big-name turnout for a party George, the political mag founded by the late John F Kennedy Jr. Ben Affleck, Chelsea Clinton, George Clooney, Samuel L Jackson, Goldie Hawn and William Baldwin attended

fields.headline: McCain facing new cancer battle
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Senator John McCain was consulting doctors in Arizona yesterday after revealing that he has suffered a recurrence of the most dangerous form of skin cancer.
fields.body:
Senator John McCain was consulting doctors in Arizona yesterday after revealing that he has suffered a recurrence of the most dangerous form of skin cancer.

The Arizona senator's office announced that doctors had found two spots of melanoma, on his left arm and left temple. He underwent an operation in 1993 to remove an earlier melanoma from his shoulder. Since then, friends say, he has had check-ups every three months. The latest tests were taken earlier this month.

The former contender for the Republican presidential nomination has cancelled most of his immediate public engagements, though he intends to honour a commitment to appear in Ohio on Sunday on behalf of a colleague.

fields.headline: Buoyant P&O aims for £1.5bn float
fields.trailText: A £1.5bn stock market flotation of P&O Nedlloyd is being planned as booming world trade volumes trigger a massive turnaround in profitability at the Anglo-Dutch container ship operator.
fields.body:
A £1.5bn stock market flotation of P&O Nedlloyd is being planned as booming world trade volumes trigger a massive turnaround in profitability at the Anglo-Dutch container ship operator.

P&O Nedlloyd - which in May parted with its managing director Tim Harris in acrimonious circumstances - produced second-quarter pre-tax profits of $28m (£19m), compared with a $32m loss during the same period last year.

The overall number of containers moved rose from 706,000 to 762,000.

The move back to profitability came even though there was a 100% increase in fuel costs because of rising oil prices. The company said its cost-cutting programme was on course to produce savings of $100m by the end of this year and nearly double that by the end of 2001.

A spokesman at the P&O group headquarters in London said a stock market listing was now "very much on the agenda" after earlier hopes were dashed by the firm's poor performance.

Mr Harris is thought to have left the firm after arguments with P&O chairman Lord Sterling over the inability of P&O Nedlloyd to turn itself around more quickly.

The latest results are the best from the company since Britain's P&O and Royal Nedlloyd of Holland agreed to pool their liner shipping resources in 1997.

New managing director Robert Woods said the future looked equally bright.

"The industry overall is in much better shape because the overcapacity that dogged us has balanced out.

"Further rate improvements are being achieved, and we expect a significant increase in profits for 2000."

A strong American economy and the recovery in Asia have played the most significant role. China has been particularly strong, but both imports and exports from Europe to Asia have grown.

Mr Woods said that even if American growth slowed down as expected, there was every reason to feel confident about container volumes.

The company bought Farrell Lines in early July and is seeking further consolidation.

P&O Nedlloyd has also been making money out of its small terminal operations arm, which has facilities in New York and Antwerp as well as Colombo. It is developing a new terminal in Rotterdam.

Meanwhile, a 30-year high freight market in almost all sections of the shipping sector means that P&O might be willing to go for an early float of its ABC bulk carrier arm, which pulled back from a listing in Oslo six weeks ago.

ABC operates Capesize bulk carriers of around 100,000 deadweight tonnes which have been enjoying a doubling of freight rates.

P&O admits it is now looking at London as well as Oslo for a future ABC stock market float. It pulled the plug on an original flotation because the financial appetite of the small but significant Norwegian shipping market had been exhausted by a series of similar moves just ahead of it, the company said.

A third part of the P&O empire is now definitely set for a New York listing this autumn. Falling stock market values for quoted cruise ship rivals led some analysts earlier to question whether the P&O Princess listing would proceed.

P&O shares have been rising steadily, and ended the day up 17.5p at 618.5p.

P&O has been through a rapid transformation in recent years selling off its construction business and shedding its conglomerate status in a bid to win back investor sentiment.

It has been partially successful, but some have questioned whether the rump of P&O will have a future as an independent company.

fields.headline: Cordiant admits to merger approach
fields.trailText: Cordiant Communications, the marketing group which owns the Bates advertising network, yesterday admitted to holding informal negotiations with putative buyer True North of the US, but cautioned that no discussions were taking place.
fields.body:
Cordiant Communications, the marketing group which owns the Bates advertising network, yesterday admitted to holding informal negotiations with putative buyer True North of the US, but cautioned that no discussions were taking place.

Cordiant, one of the few remaining independent advertising groups, has been a perennial takeover target since demerging from Saatchi & Saatchi in 1997 but is making itself an increasingly expensive morsel.

Earlier this month it sealed the £392m acquisition of Lighthouse Global, a US branding and public relations business which has propelled the group into the world's top 10. "We're always talking to people in the industry," said Michael Bungey, Cordiant's chief executive. "The nature of our business means that Cordiant has always been considered a takeover target. There are many more companies than True North who are interested in us."

Cordiant produced a 66% increase in pre-tax profits to £17.8m in the first six months of the year, comfortably beating the City's expectations. Revenues reached £208m, 34% higher than the same period in 1999. Cordiant shares were unchanged at 347p.

The market has undergone a period of consolidation which has already seen Saatchi & Saatchi fall to Publicis of France. WPP is the process of acquiring Young & Rubicam.

Mr Bungey said the business would continue to make bolt-on acquisitions.

webTitle: Days numbered for BT investor confidence

fields.headline: Days numbered for BT investor confidence
fields.standfirst: Telecoms' debt burden
fields.trailText: BT's acquisition of another 45% of Germany's Viag Interkom is hardly the biggest deal ever to hit the telecoms sector. The purchase price would not even buy one of the German third-generation mobile phone licences just auctioned.
fields.body:
BT's acquisition of another 45% of Germany's Viag Interkom is hardly the biggest deal ever to hit the telecoms sector. The purchase price would not even buy one of the German third-generation mobile phone licences just auctioned. Yet the deal has thrust BT's biggest headaches firmly into the spotlight: the size of its debt, what the company intends to do to address the issue - and how quickly.

Not too much should be read into yesterday's fall in BT'S share price. The whole European telecoms sector has been spooked by the size of the poker game played out in Mainz for the pot of 3G licences. Yesterday, shares in the Dutch telecoms group KPN hit a low for the year; Deutsche Telekom and France Telecom ran into a depression, too.

The mood will scarcely have been lifted by the outcome of the German auction. Berlin has squeezed pretty well every last pfennig out of the process, but the outcome means that there will be six competitors in the market to provide services based on 3G capability, rather than five.

That aside, BT's debt burden is formidable. On its own calculations, gearing could hit 190% - a cool £30bn - in the first half of next year after the company forks out for the licence Viag has won in the 3G round.

The company affects to be unconcerned, although others, including the rating agencies, may prove less insouciant. True enough, BT does have some scope to stop the debt ballooning to such proportions. It could, for example, float Cellnet, Yell, Openworld, Concert, even part of Viag. Any or all of those would not only cut the debt burden but would also be likely to enhance the share price as it would make "sum of the parts" valuations much easier.

The Viag acquisition, coupled with the purchase of Esat in Ireland and the increase in the Telfort stake in Holland to 100%, gives BT's European strategy a coherent look which will be enhanced if it can get its name on a - thankfully fixed price - French 3G licence through its global reach.

It is true, too, that while many analysts are pessimistic about the length of time it will take all the 3G licence holders to make returns on their investments, the mobile phone market retains an almost breathtaking capacity to expand. Figures yesterday from Iceland and Finland, for example, show mobile phone market penetration rates topping 70% at the end of June. That is for the future. BT's immediate priority must be to show that not only does it have the potential to get the debt down but that it has a convincing timetable for doing so. Investor patience with the BT's management must be finite.

Oil refinements

Opec president Ali Rodriguez offered little comfort to the world's oil markets yesterday. Oil prices in New York climbed above $32 a barrel after Mr Rodriguez - who is also the Venezuelan oil minister - indicated that Opec would wait until its next meeting, almost a month away, before deciding on whether or not to open the supply tap further, even though the price is now well above Opec's $22 to $28 a barrel target range.

But although on the surface Opec seems to have a whip hand because of the tightness of the market, it is in something of a bind of its own.

Mr Rodriguez hinted at the dilemma when he suggested that while producers wanted "advantageous prices", the level should not affect the economies of consuming countries.

If he is as concerned as his remarks suggest, he is right to be so. An oil price riding above $30 is bound to increase pressure to use less energy and to act as a brake on economic growth.

It may also stimulate the oil industry - which restructured to cope with a $10 a barrel price - to open up exploration and development and bring more production on stream.

Opec has other problems, one of which is in maintaining its unity. If Opec members did agree to pump more oil, the extra supply would have to come from the Gulf - notably Saudi Arabia. Most other members are at full stretch and so could not compensate from a lower price by pumping more oil.

The US is already working away at the cracks. Earlier this week energy secretary Bill Richardson was openly critical of some Opec members - not least Venezuela, which he accused of talking up the oil price - but was markedly complimentary about the behaviour of the Saudi authorities.

Mr Rodrigues argues that it is not Opec that is forcing up prices. Rather, he blames a shortage of refined product because of low refinery activity and the results of the continuing informal price adjustment mechanism agreed earlier this summer.

Such arguments are doing little to reassure the market, however. Mr Rodrigues and his colleagues will need to come up with something rather more substantial at the cartel's meeting on September 10 - if not before.

fields.headline: New economy leads pension changes
fields.trailText: Leading companies are continuing to move away from offering traditional final salary pension schemes - viewed by many as the best type of arrangement for workers - and it is the "new economy" companies that are leading the change, research shows.
fields.body:
Leading companies are continuing to move away from offering traditional final salary pension schemes - viewed by many as the best type of arrangement for workers - and it is the "new economy" companies that are leading the change, research shows.

Ten FTSE 100 companies now offer money purchase schemes exclusively - all of them in the technology, media and telecoms sector - while a further seven have closed their final salary schemes to new staff, according to the survey from consulting actuary firm Lane Clark & Peacock.

A third of FTSE 100 companies now offer money purchase arrangements - also known as defined contribution schemes - to at least some of their staff, despite many experts believing that final salary schemes offer workers a better deal because they guarantee a certain level of pension benefits at retirement.

Money purchase schemes - where the value of the pension is determined by how much is put in and investment performance on the markets - offer no such guarantees.

"We expect that the trend to defined contribution will continue - already ICI has announced its decision to close its final salary scheme to new entrants," said Richard Abramson, a partner at Lane Clark & Peacock.

Employers are often using the change as an excuse to reduce their pension costs, but he added: "The down side is increased uncertainty and volatility for the employee, who is far less able to bear the risks of stock market fluctuations than large companies."

The 10 FTSE 100 companies offering only money purchase arrangements include firms such as ARM Holdings, BSkyB, Energis, Logica, Misys, Reuters and Telewest.

The survey also criticised some companies - including Abbey National and BP Amoco - for disclosing "inadequate" information about pension and redundancy costs in their accounts, based on its study of the workings of the SSAP 24 accounting standard.

webTitle: Boarding call: Virgin puts Railtrack on notice

fields.headline: Boarding call: Virgin puts Railtrack on notice
fields.trailText: Sir Richard Branson's rail company, Virgin Trains, yesterday put on hold plans to sue Railtrack over delays to west coast services despite continuing problems.
fields.body:
Sir Richard Branson's rail company, Virgin Trains, yesterday put on hold plans to sue Railtrack over delays to west coast services despite continuing problems.

But the rail company, 49% owned by Stagecoach, warned it would still be seeking damages unless Railtrack made further improvements in its performance within 28 days. A spokesman for Virgin said: "It has been slightly better since we served notice on them a month ago, but they are still on probation and a lot more work needs to be done by them for us to finally withdraw our plans."

Virgin has been bearing the brunt of disruption as Railtrack proceeds with a £5.8bn west coast line improvement programme. In the latest incident contractors working for Railtrack cut a 650 watt electric cable at Euston station on Wednesday night, closing down signals and forcing Virgin to halt train operations for three hours.

Railtrack apologised last night, saying there had been some improvements but admitting major service disruptions.

The company said the contractor at the heart of the Euston incident had been put on notice and new procedures were being put in place. Robin Gisby, director of network development for Railtrack, said: "This is the most complicated engineering project undertaken on Britain's railways and our performance to date has been inconsistent. We apologise."

Meanwhile Connex failed to make the shortlist for the South West Trains franchise. It has come in for particular criticism on its commuter service in south-east England and failed to make the grade for the South West Trains franchise against Stagecoach, FirstGroup and Sea Containers subsidiary GNER.

fields.headline: Boots halts European roll-out
fields.trailText: Boots has been forced to scrap plans to expand in mainland Europe after a decision to shut 17 stores in Holland. Instead the retail group will concentrate its store openings in the far east and south-east Asia.
fields.body:
Boots has been forced to scrap plans to expand in mainland Europe after a decision to shut 17 stores in Holland. Instead the retail group will concentrate its store openings in the far east and south-east Asia.

The company said there was strong demand for Boots' own brands in the Netherlands but sales and profits had failed to meet targets.

It will write off £14m after selling the units to Dutch drug chain Etos - part of Royal Ahold, the country's largest retail group - which will in future sell Boots brands at its 412 stores in Holland.

Boots claimed the move was merely a local setback and dismissed suggestions that it was a blow to its overseas strategy. A quick exit underlined a newfound determination to concentrate on shareholder value.

Deputy chairman David Thompson said: "The partnership with Etos provides a clean exit from our retail operation while at the same time opening the way for sales of key ranges across the whole of Holland."

He admitted that Boots' combined healthy and beauty format did not fit with the characteristics of the Dutch retail market, and could not therefore become a template for other European countries.

Analysts were divided about the significance of the failure. One, who declined to be named, said: "This is an important setback because it undermines Boots' strategy of becoming the lead player as deregulation eventually rolls out across Europe."

But Nick Bubb, retail analyst with SG Securities and a "bull" regarding the value of Boots shares, described it as "a bit of a rebuff", but added that negative factors were eradicated by the speed with which the company had acted to shut its retail operation down.

"It has certainly cut its losses quicker than it would have done in the past," he said.

Boots went into Holland in 1997, a year after the government decided to allow corporate pharmacies access to the market. The rest of Europe was expected to follow the Dutch model, but has not.

Boots shares were steady, ending the day up 2p at 499p.

fields.headline: Letters
fields.trailText: John Heath-Stubbs writes: As a poet in his own right, the Ibsen and Strindberg authority Michael Meyer (Obituary, August 7) produced well-crafted studies of personal relations.
fields.body:
John Heath-Stubbs writes: As a poet in his own right, the Ibsen and Strindberg authority Michael Meyer (Obituary, August 7) produced well-crafted studies of personal relations. The Eight Oxford Poets that he and Sidney Keyes assembled in print in 1941 were sometimes labelled "neo-romantic", in contrast to the more socially and politically engaged writers of the time.

The most notable of the eight was Keith Douglas, while Drummond Allison has attracted renewed interest since the 1994 edition of his Collected Poems. In addition to Meyer, Keyes, Gordon Swaine and myself, the group contained two future clerics - JA Shaw and the Old Testament scholar Roy Porter.

However, one Oxford name conspicuous by its absence was that of Philip Larkin. He claimed forever after to be deeply offended by his exclusion, though it has to be said that the poems he submitted to Meyer were even earlier than his collection, The North Ship, which he subsequently disowned.

Eight Oxford Poets marked an attempt to break new ground at a dark moment for the world (as did the three anthologies produced by the quite separate New Apocalypse group); its foreword pointed to the feeling common to the eight that "we cannot save ourselves without some form of spiritual readjustment". The collection received the encouragement of Herbert Read, poetry editor at George Routledge & Sons, but its appearance depended on the thoroughly characteristic enterprise of Michael Meyer.

Bryan Breed writes: The excellent obituary by William Frankel of Freddy Bloom (July 22) said that she ran the Youth Book Club for a year from 1945. In fact, it was from 1950, when Ginny, a frequent and energetic visitor to its offices, was already four years old.

RH Clubb writes: Your obituary of Professor Ferdy Woodward (July 20) states that he was one of the "select band of Royal Navy ordinary seamen to be awarded prize money". In fact, prize money was awarded to all naval personnel who served in the war. I served on a cruiser of the 10th cruiser squadron and received prize money of £4.50.

The Eight Oxford Poets that he and Sidney Keyes assembled in print in 1941 were sometimes labelled "neo-romantic", in contrast to the more socially and politically engaged writers of the time. The most notable of the eight was Keith Douglas, while Drummond Allison has attracted renewed interest since the 1994 edition of his Collected Poems. In addition to Meyer, Keyes, Gordon Swaine and myself, the group contained two future clerics - JA Shaw and the Old Testament scholar Roy Porter. However, one Oxford name conspicuous by its absence was that of Philip Larkin. He claimed forever after to be deeply offended by his exclusion, though it has to be said that the poems he submitted to Meyer were even earlier than his collection, The North Ship, which he subsequently disowned. Eight Oxford Poets marked an attempt to break new ground at a dark moment for the world (as did the three anthologies produced by the quite separate New Apocalypse group); its foreword pointed to the feeling common to the eight that "we cannot save ourselves without some form of spiritual readjustment". The collection received the encouragement of Herbert Read, poetry editor at George Routledge & Sons, but its appearance depended on the thoroughly characteristic enterprise of Michael Meyer. Bryan Breed writes: The excellent obituary by William Frankel of Freddy Bloom (July 22) said that she ran the Youth Book Club for a year from 1945. In fact, it was from 1950, when Ginny, a frequent and energetic visitor to its offices, was already four years old. RH Clubb writes: Your obituary of Professor Ferdy Woodward (July 20) states that he was one of the "select band of Royal Navy ordinary seamen to be awarded prize money". In fact, prize money was awarded to all naval personnel who served in the war. I served on a cruiser of the 10th cruiser squadron and received prize money of £4.50.

fields.headline: Sir Antony Duff
fields.standfirst: After a life in diplomacy and intelligence, he devoted himself to the homeless
fields.trailText: Sir Antony Duff, who has died aged 80, was the epitome of the wise public servant on whom Whitehall's ship of state has traditionally relied. The irony is that Margaret Thatcher, in her early years as prime minister, also relied on him, an experience he did not entirely enjoy.
fields.body:
Sir Antony Duff, who has died aged 80, was the epitome of the wise public servant on whom Whitehall's ship of state has traditionally relied. The irony is that Margaret Thatcher, in her early years as prime minister, also relied on him, an experience he did not entirely enjoy.

Twice she persuaded him to forego retirement, first when she asked him to take over the role of security and intelligence coordinator in the Cabinet Office, and subsequently when she persuaded him to clear out the Augean stables of MI5. When finally retired, he spent years working on behalf of London's homeless. Earlier, he had served as ambassador and diplomat in many countries, culminating in a crucial role organising Zimbawe's independence in 1979.

Duff's background was naval; his father was an admiral, and he was educated at the Royal Naval College, Dartmouth. He had a distinguished record as a sub-mariner in the second world war, the start of a career which, in the words of one Guardian writer - in an article prompted by one of the rare occasions when Duff's name surfaced in public - achieved the difficult trick of staying submerged during much of its long public service.

It was this trait, when he was a 24-year-old submarine commander, that earned Duff a place in naval legend, after an ingenious escape off Norway during the second world war. Disabled by German destroyers, its diving planes stuck in a nose-dive mode, his submarine, Stubborn, floundered at twice its maximum operating depth.

Duff kept the descending craft stable by shifting the crew around as human ballast. When this technique failed to dislodge the boat from the seabed, where it was under bombardment from depth charges, he diverted breathing air into the main compressor, catapulting them all to the surface and safety. His achievement was recognised by a DSO.

But his eyes had been damaged in the action and, after the war, he abandoned his hopes of a naval career to join the Foreign Office, serving in Cairo, Paris, Bonn, Kuala Lumpur, and as ambassador to Nepal in 1964. He became high commissioner in Kenya at a time when the Rhodesia crisis was poisoning relations with other African commonwealth countries. In 1975, he was brought back to London as head of the Foreign Office's Africa department.

Duff was about to retire at a crucial period in the Zimbabwean independence negotiations at Lancaster House, which at last brought agreement in 1979. His long experience and calmness persuaded Mrs Thatcher to appoint him to the post of deputy governor in Salisbury (now Harare), under Christopher Soames. While Duff was credited with doing much of the backroom work, and bringing the white Rhodesian military commander, Peter Wallis, to heel, he was also said to have backed the moderate Bishop Abel Muzorewa in the British effort to keep the principal guerrilla leader, Robert Mugabe, out of power.

Elections were finally held in March 1980, and Zimbabwean independence came the following month. Soames and Duff returned to Britain, and Duff retired from the diplomatic service after 34 years. But he was at once appointed to coordinate the activities of the security and intelligence agencies, MI5, MI6 and GCHQ, the government communications headquarters at Cheltenham.

Occasionally, an unforeseen event might provoke real debate within the joint intelligence committee (JIC), of which Duff was a member, both as coordinator and, later, as director general of MI5. Mikhail Gorbachev's rise to power in the 1980s was such a case. Duff and Sir Derek Boorman, chief of defence intelligence, took the view that the Soviet leader's proposals for internal reform and deep cuts in missile stocks seemed genuine. Sir Percy Cradock, then chairman of the JIC, disagreed. As far as he was concerned, Moscow was still aiming at communist domination of the world - and he won the argument in committee.

In 1985, the affair of Michael Bettaney, the young MI5 officer caught trying to pass secrets to the Soviet embassy in London, led to a scathing attack on MI5's top management by the security commission. Cathy Massiter resigned from MI5 to disclose how the agency had monitored trade union leaders and dissenting groups - including CND and the National Council for Civil Liberties - because it regarded them as "subversives".

At the age of 65, Duff accepted the unenviable task of trying to shake MI5 up, replacing Sir John Jones, the first director general to have spent his career in the agency's F branch, responsible for domestic subversion. He steered the organisation towards combating more relevant targets, including Northern Irish terrorism.

He began to open up MI5 to discreet contacts with the media, and persuaded Mrs Thatcher to appoint an independent ombudsman to investigate complaints by secret service employees. When, in 1987, she stopped BBC Radio 4 from broadcasting My Country Right Or Wrong, a series about democractic accountability in the security and intelligence services, Duff told his staff there was nothing in the programmes to worry about.

However, his role - and his previous career as an outsider - was resented by older members of the MI5 hierarchy. The younger generation of security service officers, including many women, also believed that, while he recognised the problem, Duff failed to get rid of the unpopular, male-dominated, old guard.

Douglas Hurd, then home secretary, conceded during a Commons debate at the end of 1986 - provoked by the Peter Wright Spycatcher trial in Australia - that an internal complaints procedure, recommended by the security commission, had still not been introduced.

Mrs Thatcher's futile attempts to stop the publication of Wright's memoirs did nothing for MI5's reputation, and were probably not appreciated by Duff, who did not give evidence in the Australian courts. But the Spycatcher saga prompted another internal Whitehall inquiry, also headed by Duff, into allegations that a faction within MI5 had sought to discredit the then Labour prime minister, Harold Wilson, back in the mid-1970s. Mrs Thatcher told MPs that Duff found "no evidence of any truth" in the allegations, although at least one former senior official, who was embroiled in the whole affair, has said since that he was not even questioned.

By 1987, Duff had had enough of Whitehall intrigue and retired for the third and last time. He then turned to a most unusual activity for a former senior diplomat, and started work at a day-centre for the homeless, making and serving tea. Known simply as Tony Duff, he devoted the next five years of his life to being a member of the board of London's Homeless Network.

Duff was knighted in 1980. He married Pauline Sword in 1944. They had a son, two daughters and a stepson.

 Arthur Antony Duff, diplomat, intelligence officer and worker for the homeless, born February 25 1920; died August 13 2000

fields.headline: Lancelot Ware
fields.standfirst: Super-intelligent barrister who founded Mensa
fields.trailText: Dr Lancelot Ware, who has died aged 85, was credited with conceiving and setting up Mensa, the contentious organisation for people with high IQs. But there are those who insist that the idea was already well advanced in the mind of his rival, Roland Berrill, when the two met by accident on a train in the mid-1940s.
fields.body:
Dr Lancelot Ware, who has died aged 85, was credited with conceiving and setting up Mensa, the contentious organisation for people with high IQs. But there are those who insist that the idea was already well advanced in the mind of his rival, Roland Berrill, when the two met by accident on a train in the mid-1940s.

That first contact says something about the mindset of some Mensa buffs. Ware, a postgraduate Oxford student with receding chin and intense manner, was going home to Godalming on holidays. He was in a first-class compartment because his parents were wealthy, and was reading a volume of Hansard.

Berrill, a 50 year-old bearded Australian, had a private fortune, but had failed to get into Oxford. For a while, he watched Ware reading but, when the train reached Woking, he could keep silent no more. "Young man, is that Hansard you are reading?" asked the super-intelligent Berrill. "Obviously," replied the super-intelligent Ware. "You can see the name at the top." And he went on reading.

Critics of Mensa might see, in that brief conversation, the essence of many of the organisation's future problems - the clumsy attempt at human contact brushed off gracelessly by an assertion of superior cleverness. But both men, it turned out, were more interested in organising the cerebrally clever than the astute or emotionally literate: before the train reached Godalming, Berrill had told Ware about his brother at Oxford, and his own failure to get there; about his efforts to form a movement to persuade men to wear brighter coloured clothes, and, in particular, about his passion for intelligence testing.

A lawyer by training, Berrill was, at this stage, chiefly interested in measuring intelligence by phrenology, the study of bumps and recesses on the head. Ware argued that intelligence tests were a more scientific way forward. He had made such tests as a medical researcher during the war, and had been influenced by the work of Sir Cyril Burt, who had concluded that intelligence might have a racial basis. (Burt, of course, became a hate figure of the left and was exposed as a faker.) Before they parted, Ware invited Berrill to Oxford to discuss their ideas further.

The fact that Ware gave Berrill himself some intelligence tests at his lodgings - and pronounced his new friend to be in the top 1% of those he had examined - perhaps indicated that he was not as unworldly as he may have appeared. Berrill reportedly burst into tears, sobbing that it was the first time anyone had ever pronounced him good at anything.

Soon, Berrill's coffers, as well as his tear ducts, were opened. Their baby, Mensa, was born in 1946, its aim being to assess people's high intelligence and inquire into what things such people had in common.

Whatever the truth about the balance of influence between the two men, it is certain that Ware was a co-founder. He remained an idiosyncratic figure, often at odds with the organisation, and whose interest in it waxed and waned, according to whether he agreed with the current leadership or not. He always used the title Dr, which was based on a PhD rather than any medical qualification.

Victor Serebriakoff, an international honorary president of Mensa, remembered asking everyone at one meeting to define themselves in terms of class. All those who considered themselves working class were to raise their hands, then those who thought they were middle class, and, finally, those who regarded themselves as upper class. The only hand that went up for the upper class call was Ware's.

Serebriakoff reflected: "Personally, I think that he and Berrill felt they had formed Mensa to re-justify the aristocracy, but when they looked at the members coming in, it didn't turn out to be like that at all."

Nonetheless, Mensa's attempts to broaden its social base often had inconclusive, sometimes tragic, results. In 1974, Wilf Middleton, an RAF corporal with an IQ of 160-plus (the Mensa minimum was 148), became the organisation's first blue-collar chairman. Within months, he had left the RAF pleading victimisation, quit a job with an amusements firm as a protest against the exploitation of the workers - and committed suicide. A truly intelligent man would never, of course, have got himself into such a tragic situation.

Ware's faith was more long-lasting, though periodically dented by officers he did not agree with. As early as the 1950s, when Mensa had only 150 members - and Berrill pulled out, disillusioned and dying shortly afterwards - Ware left as well. But he rejoined in the 1960s, and helped British Mensa, the forerunner of branches in many countries, to expand into a membership of thousands.

Certainly, his professional activities showed a more practical grip than that of many Mensa members. After Steyning grammar school and the Royal College of Science, where he got his BSc and PhD, and Lincoln College, Oxford, where he got an MA, he became a lecturer in biochemistry at St Thomas's hospital medical school, from 1941 to 1946. He was called to the bar in 1949, specialising, until his retirement in 1987, in cases involving international trademarks and intellectual property.

At one time, he was chairman of the Conservative Graduate Association, and a governor of Imperial College, the London School of Economics, St Olave's and St Saviour's Foundation, Wye Agricultural College and Weybridge Technical College. From 1949 to 1955, he was a Surrey county councillor, after which he became a London County Council alderman until 1961. His hobbies were field sports, real tennis, rackets and chess, and he was made an OBE in 1987. When he was 65, he married Joan Francesca Rae, who survives him.

As if to clinch the Mensa question, in 1967, on the organisation's 30th anniversary, a commemorative plaque was unveiled outside Ware's former lodgings in Oxford. In 1982, he was declared the official fons et origo Mensae .

 Lancelot Lionel Ware, barrister and co-founder of Mensa, born June 5 1915; died August 15 2000

webTitle: John Waters and Cecil B Demented

fields.headline: Still Waters run deeply muddy
fields.trailText: Still Waters run deeply muddy
fields.body:
It's a truth insufficiently acknowledged that the great heroes of our youth will usually betray us before their hair turns grey, and it's been as true of the Hollywood baby-boomers as it has of any other generation. Sooner or later they all take a seat on the board and acquiesce to the defamation of all their youthful ideals, once so militantly held, now so quietly surrendered.

Directors who once waged a campaign of parricide against their cinematic forebears are now grown fat and slow, seduced by big money and bad cinema. The New Hollywood of the 1970s has become the Old Guard of today.

Scorsese, the prime mover of American cinema's last two decades, is currently trapped in a holding pattern of paralysed respectability that resembles Hitchcock's final years - Kundun was his Topaz, Bringing Out The Dead his Torn Curtain. Francis Ford Coppola hasn't made a memorable movie since Apocalypse Now. Robert Altman is in his final downhill slide. William Friedkin, Brian De Palma, Arthur Penn, Bob Rafelson, Peter Bogdanovich - all of them, and countless others from that great flowering of American cinema, have taken the money and run from anything resembling risk or controversy.

Only one director of their generation has kept the faith through the years. Since I first read his imperishable autobiography Shock Value nearly 20 years ago, John Waters has proved an infallible guide to life and movies. Since then he's never, ever let me down, and his latest movie, Cecil B Demented, is as splendidly insane as anything he's made.

Shock Value just about saved my life when I first read it in my late teens. I knew I was in safe hands when I read the first lines: "To me, bad taste is what entertainment is all about. If someone vomits watching one of my movies, it's like getting a standing ovation." Before then I didn't know anyone who could see the funny side of mass murder, sexual deviancy, 300lb transvestites, "chicken-fucking", trailer-parks and really terrible movies.

Waters helped me realise there were a lot of us out there, tired, huddled, yearning to be freaks. Since I lived about 50 miles from Baltimore in those days (when Barry Levinson's Diner was also doing the rounds), I was often able to drive to the source of all trashy knowledge, "the hairdo capital of the world".

I saw Pink Flamingos on July 4 1981, at the beautiful Charles cinema (where Steve Guttenberg and Tim Daly see The Seventh Seal in Diner: "I bin to Atlantic City 100 times and I ain't never seen Death walkin' on the beach"), and my sister and I saw some great horror double-bills in Baltimore grindhouses at the tail end of the Midnight Movie boom that video snuffed out. Night Of The Living Dead and Eraserhead? Oh to be young and shockable again!

My first copy of Shock Value was soon adorned with the signatures of Waters, his superstar grandma Edith "the Egg-Lady" Massey, the late great Divine, and Mink Stole (who, weirdly enough, now lives two blocks from me), the heart of his Dreamland repertory company. When the book was stolen in California in the mid-80s I was absolutely heartbroken.

Until a fellow Waters maniac felt my pain and gave me his copy. It's in front of me now, and I'm as touched as I always am when I read my friend's inscription on the flyleaf: "Hey Asshole! Divine isn't the filthiest person alive_ YOU ARE!" He further commends me for my "last few months of arduous 'method' filthing", though I haven't a clue what this refers to, since I've long repressed all memories of the 1980s for the sake of my mental health. Just below these kind words are new signatures from Waters and Mink, but Divine and Edie are long gone, so I'll never replace those.

Since 1988's Hairspray, Waters been embraced by the mini-studios, but never co-opted. He's never lost his thrilling ability to skewer cant and pomposity, and his worldview is now shared by millions of moviegoers who loathe the dominant cinema of saccharine reassurance and bullshit happy endings. Apart from Simpsons creator Matt Groening, no one else has managed to change so drastically the way we look at our popular culture.

Cecil B Demented (Stephen Dorff) is a lovable sociopath who redefines the meaning of those shopworn terms "outlaw film-maker" and "guerrilla cinema". He and his outcast teenage acolytes - "The Sprocket Holes" - embark on a campaign of cinematic terrorism by kidnapping bitchy movie star Honey Whitlock (Melanie Griffith gamely standing in for Divine) and forcing her to act in their schlock-epic Raving Beauty.

Soon enough Honey develops a severe dose of the Stockholm Syndrome and comes to love her captors, much as Patricia Hearst did with the Symbionese Liberation Army in the 1970s (Hearst herself plays the appalled mother of one of the gang). Demented's poster is a spoof of the old Baader Meinhof/Red Army Faction logo, with a camera replacing the machine gun, and the movie vibrates with a gleeful, vandalistic hatred for mainstream cinema.

Although he's as insane as most of Waters' characters, I can't disagree with a word the jodhpur-clad, riding crop-flexing Cecil says: "I am a prophet against profit!"; "I am Cecil B Demented, the enemy of family film! Family's just another word for censorship!"; or "Your Hollywood system stole our sex and co-opted our violence, and now there's nothing left to us!"

And lest we think Waters is some scatological buffoon, it should be noted that Cecil is the most cine-literate movie I've seen in years. Waters namechecks or quotes the New York underground of the early 60s, Hong Kong chop-socky, hardcore pornography, Otto Preminger, Fassbinder, Sirk, Herschell Gordon Lewis, Kenneth Anger, Sams Peckinpah and Fuller, and producer William Castle. And one theatre-manager utters the words: "What? Pasolini's playing - and we sold no tickets?"

fields.bodyText: It's a truth insufficiently acknowledged that the great heroes of our youth will usually betray us before their hair turns grey, and it's been as true of the Hollywood baby-boomers as it has of any other generation. Sooner or later they all take a seat on the board and acquiesce to the defamation of all their youthful ideals, once so militantly held, now so quietly surrendered. Directors who once waged a campaign of parricide against their cinematic forebears are now grown fat and slow, seduced by big money and bad cinema. The New Hollywood of the 1970s has become the Old Guard of today. Scorsese, the prime mover of American cinema's last two decades, is currently trapped in a holding pattern of paralysed respectability that resembles Hitchcock's final years - Kundun was his Topaz, Bringing Out The Dead his Torn Curtain. Francis Ford Coppola hasn't made a memorable movie since Apocalypse Now. Robert Altman is in his final downhill slide. William Friedkin, Brian De Palma, Arthur Penn, Bob Rafelson, Peter Bogdanovich - all of them, and countless others from that great flowering of American cinema, have taken the money and run from anything resembling risk or controversy. Only one director of their generation has kept the faith through the years. Since I first read his imperishable autobiography Shock Value nearly 20 years ago, John Waters has proved an infallible guide to life and movies. Since then he's never, ever let me down, and his latest movie, Cecil B Demented, is as splendidly insane as anything he's made. Shock Value just about saved my life when I first read it in my late teens. I knew I was in safe hands when I read the first lines: "To me, bad taste is what entertainment is all about. If someone vomits watching one of my movies, it's like getting a standing ovation." Before then I didn't know anyone who could see the funny side of mass murder, sexual deviancy, 300lb transvestites, "chicken-fucking", trailer-parks and really terrible movies. Waters helped me realise there were a lot of us out there, tired, huddled, yearning to be freaks. Since I lived about 50 miles from Baltimore in those days (when Barry Levinson's Diner was also doing the rounds), I was often able to drive to the source of all trashy knowledge, "the hairdo capital of the world". I saw Pink Flamingos on July 4 1981, at the beautiful Charles cinema (where Steve Guttenberg and Tim Daly see The Seventh Seal in Diner: "I bin to Atlantic City 100 times and I ain't never seen Death walkin' on the beach"), and my sister and I saw some great horror double-bills in Baltimore grindhouses at the tail end of the Midnight Movie boom that video snuffed out. Night Of The Living Dead and Eraserhead? Oh to be young and shockable again! My first copy of Shock Value was soon adorned with the signatures of Waters, his superstar grandma Edith "the Egg-Lady" Massey, the late great Divine, and Mink Stole (who, weirdly enough, now lives two blocks from me), the heart of his Dreamland repertory company. When the book was stolen in California in the mid-80s I was absolutely heartbroken. Until a fellow Waters maniac felt my pain and gave me his copy. It's in front of me now, and I'm as touched as I always am when I read my friend's inscription on the flyleaf: "Hey Asshole! Divine isn't the filthiest person alive_ YOU ARE!" He further commends me for my "last few months of arduous 'method' filthing", though I haven't a clue what this refers to, since I've long repressed all memories of the 1980s for the sake of my mental health. Just below these kind words are new signatures from Waters and Mink, but Divine and Edie are long gone, so I'll never replace those. Since 1988's Hairspray, Waters been embraced by the mini-studios, but never co-opted. He's never lost his thrilling ability to skewer cant and pomposity, and his worldview is now shared by millions of moviegoers who loathe the dominant cinema of saccharine reassurance and bullshit happy endings. Apart from Simpsons creator Matt Groening, no one else has managed to change so drastically the way we look at our popular culture. Cecil B Demented (Stephen Dorff) is a lovable sociopath who redefines the meaning of those shopworn terms "outlaw film-maker" and "guerrilla cinema". He and his outcast teenage acolytes - "The Sprocket Holes" - embark on a campaign of cinematic terrorism by kidnapping bitchy movie star Honey Whitlock (Melanie Griffith gamely standing in for Divine) and forcing her to act in their schlock-epic Raving Beauty. Soon enough Honey develops a severe dose of the Stockholm Syndrome and comes to love her captors, much as Patricia Hearst did with the Symbionese Liberation Army in the 1970s (Hearst herself plays the appalled mother of one of the gang). Demented's poster is a spoof of the old Baader Meinhof/Red Army Faction logo, with a camera replacing the machine gun, and the movie vibrates with a gleeful, vandalistic hatred for mainstream cinema. Although he's as insane as most of Waters' characters, I can't disagree with a word the jodhpur-clad, riding crop-flexing Cecil says: "I am a prophet against profit!"; "I am Cecil B Demented, the enemy of family film! Family's just another word for censorship!"; or "Your Hollywood system stole our sex and co-opted our violence, and now there's nothing left to us!" And lest we think Waters is some scatological buffoon, it should be noted that Cecil is the most cine-literate movie I've seen in years. Waters namechecks or quotes the New York underground of the early 60s, Hong Kong chop-socky, hardcore pornography, Otto Preminger, Fassbinder, Sirk, Herschell Gordon Lewis, Kenneth Anger, Sams Peckinpah and Fuller, and producer William Castle. And one theatre-manager utters the words: "What? Pasolini's playing - and we sold no tickets?" But it wouldn't be John Waters without some plain old filth, like this speech by porn star Cherish (Alicia Witt): "When I was 10 my whole family fucked me under the Christmas tree. As I heard my grandpa shout 'Jingle Balls!' I cried out, 'O Santa, why hast thou forsaken me!' " Movie of the month, director of my dreams. Burn, Hollywood, burn!

fields.headline: Meet the new Audrey Hepburn
fields.standfirst: She's Dutch and she's a former model turned movie actress. So who does Famke Janssen remind you of?
fields.trailText: She's Dutch and she's a former model turned movie actress. So who does Famke Janssen remind you of?
fields.body:
When you're a 5ft 11in ex-model who made her mark as a seductive assassin in GoldenEye, a rather particular Hollywood route might seem inevitable. Famke Janssen, however, has failed - or succeeded, depending on which way you look at it - to fulfil the expected role.

She has starred in a number of indie films but could hardly be described as alternative; she has added glamour to box office blockbusters but doesn't play the same character in vehicles tailored to her requirements. She's an actress, in other words, making the most of what comes along - but most actresses don't look like supermodels, and even fewer supermodels could ever be true actresses.

Her latest film brings these disparate elements together. X-Men is a special-effects-drenched blizzard of a movie that uses its premise - a group of mutant superheroes who must learn to use their special powers for good while dealing with the fear they inspire from normal humans - as an allegory for prejudice. It is smart and exciting, but based as it is on the comic book of the same name, and given the track record of comic-based films, it could have been a dangerous choice for a woman keen to establish herself as a proper actress.

"But you take into consideration that Bryan Singer is the director and you eliminate some of that risk," says Janssen of her decision to play the part of Dr Jean Grey, the mutant learning to hone her telekenic skills under the tutelage of Professor Xavier, the X-Men's shiny-pated mentor. Singer made his mark with the indie hit The Usual Suspects, which attracted Janssen to the project. "I'm a firm believer in taking risks in life, because you'll never get anywhere unless you do, and the more risk involved the greater the outcome - or the worse, but you never know so you've got to go for it.

"Comic books have been done in a very over the top, unreal manner in the past, but given my knowledge of comics - and I'm not a fan of them at all - it's actually a dark, alienated world. That's never been brought to the screen before, but that's exactly what most readers of The X-Men are interested in, because they're so often outsiders in one way or another too. And so I thought that if Bryan Singer could bring any of that tone and darkness and realism to the X-Men, that would make a great movie. And it did."

Janssen was actually born in Holland, and came from Amsterdam to work as a model in the US in her early 20s. In some respects, she's a modern version of Audrey Hepburn - another Dutch model who broke into Hollywood. She gave up modelling to study at Columbia University, and struggled to find acting jobs for four years after graduating before landing the female lead in GoldenEye, as Xenia Onatopp, the Russian assassin and nemesis to Pierce Brosnan's 007.

Since then she has wavered between bids for indie credibility (City of Industry, Woody Allen's Celebrity) and mainstream horror (Deep Rising, House On Haunted Hill); critical successes (The Faculty) and all-round embarrassments (Circus). She's now 35 and a jobbing actress: not so high-profile that she can call the shots like Hollywood's half-dozen leading ladies, but respected enough to work with some very good directors.

"With a lot of studio movies, you can't really base your decision to be involved or not on a script, because there are a lot of things that are left in flux. Working on a film for six months, you never know what scenes they're going to keep, so you have no idea on what the outcome will be."

The first consideration in Janssen's career-path decison-making is always the director. "Working with Woody Allen on Celebrity was a milestone for me because he's such a hero of mine, and I've always preferred working on character-driven projects, but I have to say, a movie like The Faculty I did because the director was Robert Rodriguez and he's a great film-maker.

"It doesn't matter what the genre is. I'd never condemn horror, for example; one of my favourite directors of all time is Stanley Kubrick, and he made The Shining. How much input the director has and who he is is the most important thing. With all the unknowns going on, you want to give yourself up to someone who knows what he's doing. I'll probably go back and forth doing different movies, and I've just worked with a first time director [on Love & Sex] because I loved the script so much, but at this point in my career working with great directors is probably the major goal."

Janssen underlines a fact that rarely gets talked about: that a decision to work on a certain movie is partly based on what that working experience is going to be like. X-Men involved six months of shooting on location in Canada, after all.

"It's always different. Woody Allen, for example, is not one to praise anybody, and he can be very critical. He can come out with something with a remark which makes you go: 'Ow. OK, I get it, I suck.' He's brutally honest at times, and at other times he doesn't speak, and he doesn't let you know what else is going on in the film. Robert Altman, on the other hand, who I worked with on The Gingerbread Man, is the director who indulges actors. He'll let them improvise and do take after take. I couldn't say which is the better experience - it's all interesting."

The trappings of fame do, of course, have to take a back seat when you're going to travel down such a winding road. Before receiving the star treatment on the X-Men, Janssen had just shot Love & Sex, a micro-budgeted romantic comedy by Valerie Breiman which gave the actress her first starring role, as a magazine writer who has to prove that she can write a good article about relationships and in order to do so trawls through her history of disastrous ones.

"It was hysterical and I loved working on it, and with Jon Favreau, who stars as the woman's long-term boyfriend. That was one of my best experiences. There were 21 days to shoot Love & Sex, and six months for the X-Men. So I was doing a movie where we shot five or six scenes a day, and because I have to play all different ages it was constant make-up changes, wardrobe changes, hair changes, with never a quiet moment and pages and pages of dialogue to do.

"Then all of a sudden I arrived in Toronto, and I was sitting around, saying, 'What are we doing? Shouldn't we be working?' I'd be called in at five in the morning, spend two hours having hair and make-up done, and then they'd say, 'Actually, we've decided to shoot another scene. We'll come back to you'. It just felt like it took forever to get anything accomplished. On Love & Sex I got in trouble if I went to the bathroom."

Janssen has chosen to live in New York over LA, emphasises that quality of life is more important than career profile, and hasn't fallen for the celebrity life - "I don't care for all that stuff, if you want to do good work it doesn't matter where you stay or what you sleep on" - but she's still a movie star as well as an actress, and has to play the part.

"It's a completely different role which you just don't realise belongs to the job. You wake up in the morning and do interviews for the whole day, then you get on a plane and you don't even know where or when you're meant to sleep. It means a lot of travelling, and a lot of talking about yourself. After a while you feel: can't we talk about something else?"

Janssen likes her role as Dr Jean Grey. "She's a very normal person. The thing that I liked is this sense of control that all the X-Men have to have. When you have these special powers you'd better be able to control them well or a lot of things can go wrong. And she's just not that good at it yet. They're all superheroes, but they have flaws."

Perfectly groomed Hollywood stars can make mistakes too, after all. Anyone who has seen Circus would have to agree that one thing Famke Janssen doesn't share with her character is a gift for ESP. "I know. Like I said, sometimes you just don't know. You can say, the next time it won't happen, but it probably will. You've got to take risks."

 X-Men is released today. Love & Sex is released September 29.

fields.headline: Video roundup
fields.standfirst: A Room for Romeo Brass | The Beach | House on Haunted Hill
fields.trailText: A Room for Romeo Brass | The Beach | House on Haunted Hill
fields.body:
A Room for Romeo Brass
Rental
Alliance Atlantis Cert 15
****

Shane Meadows juggles charming comedy with dark and dangerous deeds in another memorable small-scale and very British drama. It's distinctly different from its fine predecessor, TwentyFourSeven but has clear thematic links: hopeless fathers, striving surrogate dads, and desperate wooing scenes are already identifiable as key Meadows topics and this film, which lacks the visual poetic quality of its predecessor and is more thematically unpredictable, makes its director even more clearly his generation's heir to the downtrodden realism and defiant humour of Leigh, Loach and Blair.

Sadly he seems to be the only one in England right now: it's a heavy burden he wears lightly. The central characters here are the eponymous Romeo, a chubby black kid who manages to eat a bag of chips meant for three in a nicely-timed gag over the opening credits, "Knocks", his best friend and next-door neighbour and Morell, the eccentric misfit who wins the boys' friendship after saving them from being beaten up and desperately wants a date with Romeo's sister, Ladine.

The plot, and its sometimes shocking lurches from humour to out-of-control violence, takes place against the backdrop of poverty, frustration and desperately dull housing estate life - if you've seen his short films as well as the features, Meadows's Nottingham already seems almost as familiar as Alan Bennett's Leeds.

Its unknown cast all acquit themselves well but Paddy Considine as the complicated Morell, owner of many fantasies and the world's worst shellsuit, is particularly outstanding in a difficult part. It's unsettling in a similar way to Mike Leigh's 1981 housing-estate drama Meantime and boasts an eclectic and carefully chosen soundtrack (Beck, Fairport Convention, JJ Cale). A rare film about shifting relationships and, despite that sleeve, absolutely not pants at all.

The Beach
Rental and DVD
Fox Cert 15
**

Nice scenery, shame about the film. Substantially changed from Alex Garland's sand and stimulants bestseller, The Beach re-emerges as a Leo vehicle which might please the fan club (he's barely ever offscreen and gets a few sex scenes) but won't do a lot for the rest of us. It's stuffed with bland philosophy of life stuff, intoned as though it's deep wisdom and banal conversations and oddly for Danny Boyle and co, whose soundtrack was a key selling point for Trainspotting, a strangely old-fashioned, very Hollywood score (All Saints's more appropriate Pure Shores makes only a brief appearance.)

The Beach has an uncertain tone throughout and its relationships are as unconvincing as its shark attack. The basic story is still not bad - holidaying Yank is handed map by strange new friend (mad Robert Carlyle, the most fun in the film) and sets off to find a "paradise island". But once its Treasure Island meets Lord of the Flies plot takes a sharp turn right into Apocalypse Now territory, it's hard to stay interested.

Still, it has a few trademark Boyle camera zooms and it's not the unmitigated disaster of the team's last film, A Life Less Ordinary, whose cinematic bellyflop probably prevented the Boyle/ Hodge/ MacDonald team from installing their usual lead actor, Ewan McGregor, though DiCaprio's perennial 25-going-on-16 look suits the film's naive teen sensibility.

House on Haunted Hill
Rental and DVD (£19.99)
Warner Cert 15
**

The trickiest part of remaking a gimmicky William Castle horror is that the suave sliminess of his lead actor, Vincent Price, is no longer available. This pacy update gets around it by giving the pencil-thin moustache to the excellent Geoffrey Rush and calling him "Mr Price". It seems more affectionate tribute than rip-off. Cue grand guignol with characters running round dank corridors with torches and an effects budget beyond Mr Castle's dreams. Pretty mechanical stuff but much better than the recent re-make of The Haunting.

fields.headline: Doing the loco motion
fields.standfirst: Patrice Chéreau spent 14 days on a train racing between Paris and Mulhouse to make his latest film. The French director of La Reine Margot tells Peter Lennon why
fields.trailText: Patrice Chéreau spent 14 days on a train racing between Paris and Mulhouse to make his latest film. The French director of La Reine Margot tells Peter Lennon why
fields.body:
When Patrice Chéreau wanted to display human nature at its most intense, self-absorbed, tormented and vindictive, he hired a couple of carriages from French railways, packed his characters in and sent them shuttling backwards and forwards between Paris and Mulhouse. Unlike Murder on the Orient Express, the assaults (emotional only) took place in real travelling conditions.

Using natural light, the camera operator was jammed into the corridor; the microphone was on Chéreau's shoulder, the continuity girl crouched behind his legs and when the camera had to do a 180 pan, everyone had to duck. "We did it because of the landscape and the movement of the train," Chéreau explained. "You cannot really fabricate the movement of a train in a studio - the actors and the camera moving at the same time. We needed to have the real energy of that journey.

"We would arrive at Mulhouse a couple of hours later, uncouple the carriages, have a meal, then link the carriages to a train going back to Paris and arrive back by 6pm. We did it for 14 days. Since we did the journey so often, we knew at exactly what minute the tunnels would come." I pondered the notion of trains so punctual you could set your tunnels by them.

Those Who Love Me Can Take the Train, the latest film by the French director best known as writer-director of the blood-soaked historical epic La Reine Margot, tells of a group of mourners who travel to Limoges (the real four-hour journey was inconveniently long for shooting) to the funeral of their mutual friend, Jean-Baptiste, a manipulative, homosexual artist.

The story is inspired by the real experience of Chéreau's film editor when she went to the funeral of the gay, manipulative, documentary film-maker, François Reichenbach seven years ago. The title is the phrase with which he summoned friends to his funeral. But woven into this is Chéreau's painful, ambivalent tribute to his father.

"My father was a very good, but not very successful, painter in Angers, where I was born," Chéreau said. "His name was also Jean-Baptiste. He was completely different, but he was also a difficult man. My father was not a such a nice person. Nobody is asked to be a nice person; it is completely uninteresting to be a nice person. He chose Limoges for the second half of the story because the train journey had to be a long one, requiring effort. It turned out to be a suitable destination. Limoges is reputed to have the largest cemetery in Europe: 185,000 residents. The town has only 200,000 live ones. Chéreau chose the unguarded moments of bereavement to access the complex relationships of his characters (played by Pascal Greggory, Valeria Bruni Tedeschi, and Jean-Louis Trintignant). Most of the relationships are homosexual; one character is transsexual.

Was the story also based partly on Chéreau's own experiences? "You draw on your own gay experience," Chéreau said. "But I try not to make a gay film. I can say that I am interested in gay experiences in the sense that everything in gay life is not exactly heterosexual. But I am interested in the similarities, not in the differences. I am impressed by the fact that when you love someone, suddenly you have exactly the same problems as heterosexuals."

Chéreau is essentially a man of the theatre, where he has been a star since his 20s (he is now 55) although he has done dangerous bungee jumps with his career, like suddenly taking off to run the Piccolo theatre in Milan, putting on productions such as Lulu and Pandora's Box.

A year later he was appointed co-director (with Roger Planchon) of the Thétre National Populaire. Then in 1976 he did a freefall into Bayreuth, accepting an offer to put on Wagner's Ring. With the cast in tuxedos and one of the props a New York fire escape, there was a predictable scandal. But his musical director, Pierre Boulez, stood by him and he repeated the offence for two more years.

"I have been confronted by challenges all the time," he said. "At 27, I was in Italy working in a foreign language. Then there was Bayreuth. I think I have a real taste for challenges. That is the most important thing for me - to learn what I don't know already."

He has the build and character for it; short, sturdy and determined (he bulldozed his recently acquired English through our interview). But when he took the risk of actually playing Napoleon, in Youssef Chahine's Adieu Bonaparte in Egypt, he, like the original, came a cropper. He admits he is "an awful actor".

"I have no pleasure in being in front of the camera," he said. This did not prevent him taking the role of General Montcalm in Michael Mann's Last of the Mohicans. But it carried a bonus. Isabella Adjani was with Daniel Day-Lewis at the time and was a frequent visitor to the set. He seized the opportunity to recruit her for La Reine Margot, his furiously energetic rendering of the malevolent intrigue which led to the St Bartholomew's Day Massacre of Huguenots in Paris in 1572.

It was a witches' brew of sex, butchery and extravagant pageantry which won him an international reputation. But to achieve the right level of malignancy, he had to spice Dumas's swashbuckling romance with the venom of his own 1972 production of Marlowe's The Massacre at Paris.

It was not until 1974 that he first tackled the cinema. A consistent criticism of his work is that it shows its theatrical orgins, but his response is defiant: "I was not born into the cinema as many French directors were, so it was a big challenge for me. But my theatre background gives me another point of view. I am happy to keep that distance".

This first film was La Chair de l'orchidée, a thriller derived from a muddled novel by James Hadley Chase, author of No Orchids for Miss Blandish. "When we signed the contract," Chéreau said, "I was shocked to discover that he was a completely fake American. He was a Swiss named René Raymond." [He was actually English-born.] "I also wondered why I had such a terrible time adapting the book. Then looking at American thrillers, I realised that his were not real books at all, just compilations of cliches from American thrillers."

Chéreau did not improve matters by making it probably the wettest film in history: most of the time the characters are standing cringing under a downpour or rolling in the mud. The imperious Edwige Feuillère of the Comédie Française refused to get out of her car; she acted from the dry back seat. "Why all the rain?" I asked. He shrugged. "I wrote: 'It was raining' all the time. I don't know why, I was very young."

A later effort, L'Homme Blessé (The Wounded Man, 1983), freely adapted from Jean Genet's The Thief but based on his own anguished adolescence, was a more substantial work. "It was about this young guy of 18 discovering the world of boys. Part of the film is about adolescence and when you are doing a film about adolescence you have to look into your own life. You remember how terribly sad and confusing this time is; you don't see any escape."

La Reine Margot, made in 1994, was a departure, if only because of the level of violence. "I hate violence in real life," he said. "But the world is in a continuous confrontation with violence. We began the script of Margot with the death of Ayatollah Khomeini in Iran and finished shooting in the middle of Yugoslavia. La Reine Margot was full of that religious violence. But I am also fascinated by the violence of sentiments; the violence of love, the difficulty of love, the violence of family relationships."

His latest bungee jump is to make a film in English. "For me that is the last challenge in my life: to film in a language I had not spoken before with English actors." He was very taken by Hanif Kureishi's Love in a Blue Time and Intimacy (which will be its title), and with Kureishi wrote a script drawn from both books. "I wanted to make the film in the place where he wrote them".

He started taking English lessons last year and from February to April he was shooting at the Elephant and Castle, Battersea and Brixton, with Mark Rylance, Timothy Spall and Marianne Faithfull. "I really like being a European director," he said. "Doing theatre in Italian, opera in German, and now English." He loves London but finds "huge differences" in the approach to working. "The English crew work very hard," he said, "but they are not interested at all in what you are doing as a director and not interested at all in French films."

"You are turning your back on Europe." he said, reproachfully.

 Those Who Love Me Can Take the Train is released today.

fields.headline: Pip Karmel
fields.trailText: Pip Karmel
fields.body:
What was the first film you saw? Run Wild Run Free. The final scene, in which the mute boy crawls through the mud to save the horse and pleads with it not to die by speaking for the first time, is an absolute killer!

What's your favourite film and why? The Red Balloon. A great example of storytelling without dialogue.

When did you last walk out of a cinema and why? Three months ago - the film has to be good when you're nine months pregnant. What Dreams May Come featured Robin Williams and a special effects department gone wild.

What was the most erotic moment in a film? The pre-sex scene between William Hurt and Kathleen Turner in Body Heat. Very potent chemistry.

What's the most annoying habit in a cinema? Running commentaries on the film.

When did you last hide under your seat in a cinema? I'm not at all keen on screen violence and particularly hate mafia films. I spend a lot of time watching the face of the person next to me to gauge when it's safe to look back at the screen.

When was the last time you cried in a cinema? When was the last time I didn't!

What's your favourite line of dialogue? "We have a sick rabbit also" from Local Hero.

Which actor would you like to be? Sean Penn, Daniel Day-Lewis or John Cusack.

Which actress? Miranda Richardson, Susan Sarandon, Annette Bening or Juliette Binoche.

You've written and directed stories about women who question their past. Is this subject of personal interest to you? I did go through it but they're generally about people reflecting on what might have been, which spoils their present lives.

Is the boom of Hollywood production companies working in Australia over? Regrettably, no. Big studios use Australia because it's cheap, but Hollywood films overshadow the local industry. We have great light, crews, actors and support. But financing is tough and it's difficult casting - we lose so many people to the UK and US.

 Pip Karmel is director of Me Myself I, released today.
