webTitle: Jackie Chan is at last big in Hollywood

fields.headline: The main Chan
fields.standfirst: After 20 years of death-defying stunts and innumerable broken bones, Jackie Chan is at last big in Hollywood
fields.trailText: After 20 years of death-defying stunts and innumerable broken bones, Jackie Chan is at last big in Hollywood
fields.body:
Jackie Chan, introduced as the world's "biggest and bestest movie star" grins as SM:TV presenter Cat Deeley whizzes questions light as frisbees at him. In between getting her to feel the hole in his skull, punctured when a stunt went near-fatally wrong, and laughing over his fear of horses, he relates how his parents nearly sold him at birth for £120.

The kids in the audience wish he was still dancing jelly-legged beside Spices Posh, Baby and Sporty, and wonder when the next basket of sweets is coming round. Soon he will be the man with the prizes at spoof game show The Spice is Right, making the production crew laugh with his cheeky display of nail-painting kits and toy karaoke machines. He's known throughout the world as an invincible martial arts action hero. The incongruity is delicious.

But then, maybe Chan's irrepressible appearance on the Saturday morning kids TV programme SM:TV isn't that strange. He has, after all, spent the past two decades playing up to the camera as bumbling figures remarkably skilled in acrobatics and kung fu, becoming Asia'a number one celebrity and winning an MTV lifetime achievement award in 1995 in the process. His films exude an infectious good humour, a characteristic he cultivated 22 years ago to escape being called the new Bruce Lee and establish himself as the ultimate martial arts actor. It works: you simply can't imagine the glowering Lee brandishing a spice rack on kids TV.

That afternoon, Chan visits Leicester Square to talk at a screening of his new film, Shanghai Noon, an ebullient number set in 1880s Nevada that sees Chan fighting cowboys and Indians to rescue a damsel in distress. Although Chan has made innumerable films (one list sets the figure at around 80), this is the first time he has received a Leicester Square premiere.

But this is no glitzy red-carpet affair: the afternoon has been organised by Chan's UK fan club to raise money for Sarah Stevenson, a member of Britain's tae kwon do team at the forthcoming Olympics, and the atmosphere is muted. Certainly no one in London's nearby Chinatown seems to know that Chan is here. After the film finishes there's no spectacular party, but a quiet photo session in Planet Hollywood with 100 of Chan's respectful fans. The closest Chan gets to glamour is when Melanie C bursts into his dressing room at the TV studio to ask for his autograph.

Strange, perhaps, because the desire to be a huge star fuels everything he does. It's because he longs to be hero-worshipped that his longtime manager, a dapper man in floaty Hawaiian shirt called Willie (confusingly, his surname is also Chan), is unable to think of a bone that Chan hasn't broken in the cause of fame. It's because he has long been consumed with frustration at being able to walk from New York to LA with no one but the proprietors of Chinese restaurants batting an eyelid that Chan has spent the last 20 years trying to break the American market, efforts that are finally being repaid.

It has taken enormous tenacity for Chan to overcome the conservatism and racism endemic in Hollywood. He first attempted the move in 1980, but he had only achieved prominence in Asia two years earlier, with the kung fu comedies Snake in the Eagle's Shadow and Drunken Master, and Hollywood couldn't give a flying frog about him.

He appeared in The Cannonball Run, and experienced two dismal flops with The Big Brawl (1980, directed by Robert "Enter the Dragon" Clouse), and cop flick The Protector (1985) - he later complained that Hollywood was only interested in him playing Japanese bad guys. He turned down such roles because "Asian people would kill me!" In between, he made the pirate film Project A (1983), widely acknowledged as one of his greatest.

Chan wasn't acknowledged by Hollywood, however, until a re-edited, dubbed version of Rumble in the Bronx, directed by Stanley Tong, became a box office hit in 1996, grossing over $30m. After 16 years of trying, Chan had, as far as the US mainstream was concerned, arrived.

As Frederic Dannen points out in Hong Kong Babylon, Chan's sudden popularity wasn't an isolated event. The film that preceded Rumble in the Bronx as the top movie in the US was John Woo's Broken Arrow. Woo had come to Hollywood in 1994 to direct the Jean-Claude Van Damme vehicle Hard Target, at a time when Quentin Tarantino was still ubiquitous and volubly praising the excellence of Hong Kong cinema (it's rumoured that Tarantino personally ensured that Chan won his MTV award).

But whereas films such as Broken Arrow and Mission: Impossible 2 could have been directed by practically anyone with a flair for explosives, there isn't anyone in Hollywood doing what Chan does best: creating exhilarating, perilous stunts and fight sequences that redefine the boundaries of martial arts cinema.

The fact that Chan does every stunt, fall, punch, kick and somersault himself sets him apart from any action hero you care to mention. He developed his terrifying capacity to absorb pain during his decade as a ward at the Peking Opera School, where he learned acrobatics, martial arts, singing, mime and acting, worked for 19 hours each day and was severely beaten for the slightest misdemeanour. (Crying when beaten was on the list of transgressions.) Although he was a child actor while still at school, his career really kicked off in the early 70s when he became a stunt man, notably on Fist of Fury. (Bruce Lee was said to be impressed when he accidentally bashed Chan on the temple and the teenager didn't stop acting.)

From stuntman, Chan progressed to action choreographer and in 1979, at the age of 25, he made his directorial debut with the formula action flick Fearless Hyena. Starring as a young man undergoing gruelling but entertaining kung fu training, Chan incorporated in the film some superb set pieces that required him to dodge spears and balance on ceramic bowls. From there it was a short skip to hanging from a speeding bus by an umbrella (Police Story, 1985) and bouncing on to the top of a hot air balloon (Armour of God, 1986).

Like most American action directors, Chan builds his films around a few inventive vignettes. He'll open with a big chase and progress through a few fights and breathtaking stunts to a final combination sequence that can last anything up to 20 minutes and usually pays scant regard to the dictates of dramatic coherence. In Chan's eyes, the more pyrotechnic this last scenario, the better: Drunken Master 2 involves firebreathing and a bed of hot coals; Police Story 2 ends with a fireworks factory exploding. However, it's the (slightly) more traditional kung fu scenes, in which Chan fights using whatever household objects cross his path, that really light up the screen.

In some cases the fight choreography is so remarkable it redeems an otherwise abysmal film: Mr Nice Guy, for instance, is atrocious until the elaborate game of hide and seek in a warehouse, during which Chan sends one of his adversaries spinning in a cement mixer. In coming up with such scenes, Chan takes much of his inspiration from slapstick cinema. His heroes are Buster Keaton and Harold Lloyd, and his films constantly quote their more outlandish feats (most notably, Project A steals the clock hand scene from Lloyd's Safety Last, and Project A 2 the collapsing wall from Keaton's Steamboat Bill Jr).

The violence in Chan's films is paradoxically both cartoonish and all-too-real; the films invariably end with outtakes showing Chan in great pain as each stunt goes wrong. There's an element of masochism to his film-making: he willingly puts himself in danger for the sake of thrilling his fans.

This can even take him to the point of death. Fourteen years ago, when filming Armour of God, he plunged 40 feet after turning mid-stunt so the camera could see it was really him, smashed his head on a rock and went into a coma. In a sense, it's the part and parcel of the Hong Kong film industry, which doesn't have the budget for safety. But the fact is, the heartstopping danger is the secret of Chan's success; it makes his films so watchable despite their deficiencies in plotting and script.

Of course, the last hurdle between Chan and Hollywood was the English language. In one of the weirdest quirks of Hong Kong cinema, films are often recorded without sound and dubbed later; sometimes actors who have executed their own stunts don't bother to record their own lines.

Chan, however, couldn't expect his western audiences to keep tolerating the inept translations and poor-quality dubbing that make the English language versions of his films unintentionally risible. Despite being nearly illiterate - the result of receiving only an hour's conventional schooling per day as a child - he started learning English in 1980 and he's now a good speaker who just lacks confidence. The first outtake of Mr Nice Guy, his first fully English-language film, doesn't see Chan cracking a bone or nearly castrating himself, but Chan stumbling over his lines.

Rush Hour, directed by Brett Ratner and Chan's first major US success (grossing well over $100m), hit on a solution: pairing Chan with a fast-talking, wisecracking comedian - in this case squeaky-voiced Chris Tucker, whose mouth is as dexterous as Chan's flailing limbs. Tom Dey, the director of Shanghai Noon, repeats the formula, and a daffy Owen Wilson appears as Chan's garrulous comic foil. The banter between the pair is winning, and Chan even begins parodying his difficulty with English: his character is called Chon Wang, only the way he pronounces it, it sounds like John Wayne.

It's a good gag, but it's still the barroom brawl, Chan's ability to defeat three men brandishing guns using only a rope and a horseshoe, and his barehanded conquest of some bad Indians that redeem what might otherwise be mere fluffy pastiche.

You wonder, though, how much longer Chan can keep this up. At the age of 46, and with the near-death experiences piling up, his body is surely begging for a rest. As we wait for the screening of Shanghai Noon to begin, I ask him why he still does these stunts. "I think I should retire, because American action movie so good, they can make everybody become a superhero," he admits. "In Hollywood I can film with special effect. But Hollywood said no. They said, 'Why you have to learn special effect? Because right now in Hollywood everybody learn from you. What we want is something different. We want Jackie Chan style. We follow your rule.' So now I have to do my own stunts." Hollywood, it seems, outwits him yet.

Jackie Chan: five of the best

Drunken Master 2
Jackie takes a dip in a bed of hot coals

Project A 2
Jackie races a collapsing wall

Police Story
Jackie slides down a string of fairy lights

Rumble in the Bronx
Jackie does battle with a hovercraft

Rush Hour
Jackie takes on Chris Tucker's mouth

 Shanghai Noon is released next Friday.

It's because he has long been consumed with frustration at being able to walk from New York to LA with no one but the proprietors of Chinese restaurants batting an eyelid that Chan has spent the last 20 years trying to break the American market, efforts that are finally being repaid. It has taken enormous tenacity for Chan to overcome the conservatism and racism endemic in Hollywood. He first attempted the move in 1980, but he had only achieved prominence in Asia two years earlier, with the kung fu comedies Snake in the Eagle's Shadow and Drunken Master, and Hollywood couldn't give a flying frog about him. He appeared in The Cannonball Run, and experienced two dismal flops with The Big Brawl (1980, directed by Robert "Enter the Dragon" Clouse), and cop flick The Protector (1985) - he later complained that Hollywood was only interested in him playing Japanese bad guys. He turned down such roles because "Asian people would kill me!" In between, he made the pirate film Project A (1983), widely acknowledged as one of his greatest. Chan wasn't acknowledged by Hollywood, however, until a re-edited, dubbed version of Rumble in the Bronx, directed by Stanley Tong, became a box office hit in 1996, grossing over $30m. After 16 years of trying, Chan had, as far as the US mainstream was concerned, arrived. As Frederic Dannen points out in Hong Kong Babylon, Chan's sudden popularity wasn't an isolated event. The film that preceded Rumble in the Bronx as the top movie in the US was John Woo's Broken Arrow. Woo had come to Hollywood in 1994 to direct the Jean-Claude Van Damme vehicle Hard Target, at a time when Quentin Tarantino was still ubiquitous and volubly praising the excellence of Hong Kong cinema (it's rumoured that Tarantino personally ensured that Chan won his MTV award). But whereas films such as Broken Arrow and Mission: Impossible 2 could have been directed by practically anyone with a flair for explosives, there isn't anyone in Hollywood doing what Chan does best: creating exhilarating, perilous stunts and fight sequences that redefine the boundaries of martial arts cinema. The fact that Chan does every stunt, fall, punch, kick and somersault himself sets him apart from any action hero you care to mention. He developed his terrifying capacity to absorb pain during his decade as a ward at the Peking Opera School, where he learned acrobatics, martial arts, singing, mime and acting, worked for 19 hours each day and was severely beaten for the slightest misdemeanour. (Crying when beaten was on the list of transgressions.) Although he was a child actor while still at school, his career really kicked off in the early 70s when he became a stunt man, notably on Fist of Fury. (Bruce Lee was said to be impressed when he accidentally bashed Chan on the temple and the teenager didn't stop acting.) From stuntman, Chan progressed to action choreographer and in 1979, at the age of 25, he made his directorial debut with the formula action flick Fearless Hyena. Starring as a young man undergoing gruelling but entertaining kung fu training, Chan incorporated in the film some superb set pieces that required him to dodge spears and balance on ceramic bowls. From there it was a short skip to hanging from a speeding bus by an umbrella (Police Story, 1985) and bouncing on to the top of a hot air balloon (Armour of God, 1986). Like most American action directors, Chan builds his films around a few inventive vignettes. He'll open with a big chase and progress through a few fights and breathtaking stunts to a final combination sequence that can last anything up to 20 minutes and usually pays scant regard to the dictates of dramatic coherence. In Chan's eyes, the more pyrotechnic this last scenario, the better: Drunken Master 2 involves firebreathing and a bed of hot coals; Police Story 2 ends with a fireworks factory exploding. However, it's the (slightly) more traditional kung fu scenes, in which Chan fights using whatever household objects cross his path, that really light up the screen. In some cases the fight choreography is so remarkable it redeems an otherwise abysmal film: Mr Nice Guy, for instance, is atrocious until the elaborate game of hide and seek in a warehouse, during which Chan sends one of his adversaries spinning in a cement mixer. In coming up with such scenes, Chan takes much of his inspiration from slapstick cinema. His heroes are Buster Keaton and Harold Lloyd, and his films constantly quote their more outlandish feats (most notably, Project A steals the clock hand scene from Lloyd's Safety Last, and Project A 2 the collapsing wall from Keaton's Steamboat Bill Jr). The violence in Chan's films is paradoxically both cartoonish and all-too-real; the films invariably end with outtakes showing Chan in great pain as each stunt goes wrong. There's an element of masochism to his film-making: he willingly puts himself in danger for the sake of thrilling his fans. This can even take him to the point of death. Fourteen years ago, when filming Armour of God, he plunged 40 feet after turning mid-stunt so the camera could see it was really him, smashed his head on a rock and went into a coma. In a sense, it's the part and parcel of the Hong Kong film industry, which doesn't have the budget for safety. But the fact is, the heartstopping danger is the secret of Chan's success; it makes his films so watchable despite their deficiencies in plotting and script. Of course, the last hurdle between Chan and Hollywood was the English language. In one of the weirdest quirks of Hong Kong cinema, films are often recorded without sound and dubbed later; sometimes actors who have executed their own stunts don't bother to record their own lines. Chan, however, couldn't expect his western audiences to keep tolerating the inept translations and poor-quality dubbing that make the English language versions of his films unintentionally risible. Despite being nearly illiterate - the result of receiving only an hour's conventional schooling per day as a child - he started learning English in 1980 and he's now a good speaker who just lacks confidence. The first outtake of Mr Nice Guy, his first fully English-language film, doesn't see Chan cracking a bone or nearly castrating himself, but Chan stumbling over his lines. Rush Hour, directed by Brett Ratner and Chan's first major US success (grossing well over $100m), hit on a solution: pairing Chan with a fast-talking, wisecracking comedian - in this case squeaky-voiced Chris Tucker, whose mouth is as dexterous as Chan's flailing limbs. Tom Dey, the director of Shanghai Noon, repeats the formula, and a daffy Owen Wilson appears as Chan's garrulous comic foil. The banter between the pair is winning, and Chan even begins parodying his difficulty with English: his character is called Chon Wang, only the way he pronounces it, it sounds like John Wayne. It's a good gag, but it's still the barroom brawl, Chan's ability to defeat three men brandishing guns using only a rope and a horseshoe, and his barehanded conquest of some bad Indians that redeem what might otherwise be mere fluffy pastiche. You wonder, though, how much longer Chan can keep this up. At the age of 46, and with the near-death experiences piling up, his body is surely begging for a rest. As we wait for the screening of Shanghai Noon to begin, I ask him why he still does these stunts. "I think I should retire, because American action movie so good, they can make everybody become a superhero," he admits. "In Hollywood I can film with special effect. But Hollywood said no. They said, 'Why you have to learn special effect? Because right now in Hollywood everybody learn from you. What we want is something different. We want Jackie Chan style. We follow your rule.' So now I have to do my own stunts." Hollywood, it seems, outwits him yet. Jackie Chan: five of the best Drunken Master 2 Jackie takes a dip in a bed of hot coals Project A 2 Jackie races a collapsing wall Police Story Jackie slides down a string of fairy lights Rumble in the Bronx Jackie does battle with a hovercraft Rush Hour Jackie takes on Chris Tucker's mouth  Shanghai Noon is released next Friday.

fields.headline: England in wonderland
fields.standfirst:
West Indies 172 and 61
England 272
England win by an innings and 39 runs
fields.trailText:
West Indies 172 and 61
England 272
England win by an innings and 39 runs.
fields.body:
Ah, Test cricket, the endless time for contemplation, the imperceptible battle for supremacy over five long days. That was how it used to be. Now, as anybody on this ground could testify, there is not even time to breathe.

With three-day Tests disturbingly becoming the norm, England yesterday went one better and achieved the unthinkable: they routed the West Indies within two days, only the second time a Test since the war has finished so quickly.

The West Indies were banished for 61 in only 26.2 overs, and such is the frailty of their batting that it was their lowest total against England for all of a month, since they capitulated for 54 in two more deliveries at Lord's. The winning margin, an innings and 39 runs, was England's first innings victory since 1966 against a side that, in the interim, has crushed them repeatedly.

This was feverish, chaotic cricket, on an indifferent but far from malevolent surface, and to the ecstasy of the Leeds crowd, it was led at nearly every turn by Yorkshire players. After Craig White's five wickets on the first day, came the finest innings of Michael Vaughan's brief Test career, a composed 76 on a sunny morning whencomposure was a rare gift, and worthy of the man-of-the-match award. Michael Atherton's successor lies in waiting.

Then came a finale of staggering immediacy. Darren Gough, swinging the ball into the left-handers at speed, dismissed a trio of them - Adrian Griffith, Wavell Hinds and Brian Lara - in his first three overs. Andrew Caddick, switched with devastating effect to the Rugby Stand End after tea, demolished most of the rest with four wickets in an over, leaving this emotionless man wheeling around the outfield in astonishment.

Nasser Hussain, the captain of an England side now 2-1 up with one to play, with their first series win against the West Indies for 31 years in sight, said: "It has been an incredible two days and has been incredibly hard on the mind because things were happening so quickly that you could never feel you had won the game.

"The pitch was poor yesterday. But the reason we bowled them out for 61 today was down to high-quality swing bowling. The key was to get wickets with the new ball."

England got all 10. Griffith and Hinds both fell to their first ball, both induckers, with Griffith's stumps splayed and Hinds struck on the back leg. Lara, after an excessive delay, barely jammed down on the hat-trick ball, but he went in Gough's next over, offering no shot to the Yorkshireman and falling leg before for the second time in the match. Both decisions were borderline.

Dominic Cork then struck Jimmy Adams on the finger, which caused a lengthy enough stoppage for him to lose form while being treated; he dragged his next ball on to the stumps. Half the side dispatched by tea, and Yorkshire faces were jubilant.

Caddick had bowled without luck from the Kirkstall Lane End. Switched uphill after tea, he produced the most magical over of his Test career. The West Indies had recently lost four wickets in an over to Wasim Akram at Lahore. Now they made a habit of it. Ridley Jacobs was lbw to Caddick's first ball, inswingers with his third and fourth balls bowled Nixon McLean and Curtly Ambrose, and Reon King (who barely survived another hat-trick attempt) was bowled by the last. Courtney Walsh's wicket sparked a pitch invasion.

From their overnight 105 for five, only optimists anticipated that England would salvage even the slimmest of first-innings leads. For them to add another 167 at a rate of four runs an over belonged in the realms of fantasy.

The only thing that can be predicted about the Headingley pitch is its utter unpredictability. Throughout the morning it looked on benignly while Vaughan progressed with scholarly intent. Graeme Hick, too, making his 10th England comeback at the unlikely position of No8, made light of the pitch's malevolent reputation with a series of controlled square drives.

Mediocre pitches are rightly blamed for wrecking batting techniques, but both Vaughan and Hick, at Worcestershire, have learned not to imagine devils in every delivery. They attacked judiciously, and ran enterprisingly. Vaughan exchanged the strike as if it was a gesture of politeness as much as a tactical necessity.

Hick's departure, drawn forward by Adams and stumped by Jacobs, and a duck for Craig White, pushing indeterminately at McLean, suggested that England's frolic would soon end.

An accidental beamer, first ball, from McLean (a slower ball that went wrong) left Cork at his most maniacal. A duck should have been his fate, too, but Hinds comically came too far in for a skier at square leg and Adams fumbled a run out when Cork irrationally went walkabout. So blessed, England's lower orders added virtually another fifty, Vaughan's finest international knock ending to Ambrose and the second new ball. The West Indies' spirit had been broken.

Shortest Test innings in England (all against England), in overs:

12.3 overs South Africa, Edgbaston, 1924

17 India, Lord's, 1974

22.3* Australia, Lord's, 1896

26* Australia, The Oval, 1896

21.4 India, Old Trafford, 1952

23 Australia, Edgbaston, 1902

26.1 South Africa, Lord's, 1912

26.2 West Indies, Headingley, 2000

* denotes five-ball overs

fields.headline: Oh, Noh... Japan has the horrors again
fields.standfirst: Pete Tombs on a spirited comeback for scary cinema in the land of Godzilla
fields.trailText: Pete Tombs on a spirited comeback for scary cinema in the land of Godzilla
fields.body:
The scariest scenes in the hit Japanese horror movie Ring are also the simplest: a sinister young girl brushing her long black hair in a mirror; the mouth of a well surrounded by trees; waves breaking on a night-time beach; a TV set popping into life in an empty room. Just as The Blair Witch Project electrified western filmgoers with its low tech/high terror approach, so Ring and its sequels are setting audience records across the far east by returning to one of the staples of Asian cinema - the ghost story.

When cinema came to Japan 100 years ago, it drew on the repertoire of the popular kabuki drama. Many of these plays were ghost stories. The most famous, Yotsuya Kaidan, a tale of spectral revenge meted out to a treacherous husband, has been adapted for the screen more than 25 times. Its ghost is an archetypal image of Japanese horror cinema: a wronged woman, hungry for revenge. She seems to float towards her victim, long black hair trailing behind her, face white as ashes.

These spooky stories got a big boost after the war when samurai dramas, the other great staple of Japanese cinema, were banned by the allied forces for political reasons. The 50s saw a positive torrent of ghost films. The big studios, Toei, Daiei and Shintoho incorporated spectral cats, vengeful females and haunted swamps into their scenarios with a single-minded dedication to thrill and chill.

These low-budget shockers made regular appearances in cinemas during the months of July and August, the time of O-Bon, the festival of the dead. Their purpose was twofold: to put patrons in a suitably respectful frame of mind, and to cool them down with a few well-placed shivers.

By the end of the decade, the genre had pretty much run out of steam. One challenge to the pre-eminence of the ghost film was the 1954 release of Godzilla. The film's subsequent success, both at home and abroad, led to a lot of energy being pumped into making similar monster movies. Films about yakuza gangsters also became popular and sex completed the package. Spooky, white-faced ghost ladies had lost their box-office appeal.

From the mid-60s, new-wave horrors like Hell Screen, Onibaba and Hellish Love began to exploit the sexual freedoms newly available to film-makers. Two of the most significant of these controversial shockers - Masumura's Moju and Tanaka Noboru's The Watcher in the Attic - were based on stories by Edogawa Rampo, Japan's foremost writer of tales of terror, whose work continues to provide fruitful pickings.

His writing combines tight plotting with deviant psychopathology, an irresistible combination for film-makers. Moving even farther out than Rampo, the extreme edge of late 60s commercial cinema produced gruesome sex-horror hybrids like The Joys of Torture and Violated Angels. These films, and many more like them, pushed the boat about as far as it could go in terms of artful sadism, while remaining just inside the bounds of Japan's strict censorship codes.

A healthy counterpoint was provided by a cluster of films that attempted to integrate traditional Japanese myths with the monster movie techniques spawned by the success of Godzilla. Maijin, released in 1966, was the first of a trilogy of movies featuring a huge stone statue that can be summoned to aid the oppressed, but tends to be more difficult to send back to sleep.

In 1968, the same production team delivered another horror extravaganza based around traditional Japanese stories: Yokai Hyaku Monogatari, or One Hundred Ghost Stories. The conceit here is a pair of painted screens that come alive, allowing the mythical monsters painted on them to spill over into the real world. The first to manifest itself is an umbrella ghost, a bizarre, one-legged creature with a long tongue. An army of faceless men and a giant laughing head soon follow. Other creatures resemble masks from old Noh plays, along with fire-snorting demons, a pumpkin-headed goblin, lanky-limbed demons with huge stomachs and a woman with an incredible extending neck.

Films like One Hundred Ghost Stories and the Maijin series were fun, but the expense of such productions was prohibitive. As the big five studio system began to collapse in the early 70s, independent companies prospered, turning out work that, at its best, was edgy and experimental, drawing inspiration from pop music, underground movies and, above all, adult manga. These cheaply produced comics are one of the most popular forms of entertainment in Japan. Their design style is self-consciously cinematic, with close-ups, travelling shots and widescreen action all being suggested on the page. Their readers are used to provocative, adult themes.

One of the big manga successes of the mid-70s was Tenshi no Harawata (Angel Guts), written by Takashi Ishii. Starting in 1977, this violent and sexually explicit title was brought to the screen in a series of seven films helmed by some of Japan's top directors. Each episode features a woman, always called Nami, who investigates a violent mystery that seems to implicate her in ways that are never entirely clear. In every case, as the mystery seems about to be solved, it moves one step away, revealing a new set of imponderables. This mirage-like approach to plot and clues became a common feature of much contemporary Japanese horror, including Ring and its sequels.

In 1988, Ishii and Angel Guts director Toshiharu Ikeda began work on a series of films that contain some of the most disturbing images of modern Japanese horror. Shiryo no Wana (usually translated as Evil Dead Trap) begins with a late-night TV hostess (again called Nami) being sent a snuff movie tape, apparently showing her own torture and death. With three female colleagues and a male director she sets off to the location where the video was shot. The team end up in an abandoned government research station. One by one they are bumped off in exceptionally grizzly and devious ways until only Nami survives. The ending shifts the film into entirely unexpected and deeply disturbing territory. It's impossible to describe but unforgettable.

The best recent Japanese horror films focus around women. This was acknowledged by the makers of Ring when they changed the book's male lead into a female investigative journalist. A startling addition to this "feminist" strand of horror is Kiyoshi Kurosawa's 1989 film Sweet Home. This is a masterpiece of movie-making and it's a crying shame that so few in the west have seen it.

More female protagonists and more manga influence can be found in the other main strand of contemporary Japanese horror - the high-school film. House, from 1977, was an early and very quirky entry into the field. Eko Eko Azaraku (Wizard of Darkness) is a more standard example of the genre. A new girl, the mysterious Misa, discovers that her school is the centre of a series of five strange killings - a bloody pentagram. Apparently possessed of magic powers, Misa sets about unravelling the mystery. The 1995 film went on to spawn several sequels and a TV series, as well as being a clear influence on Buffy the Vampire Slayer.

The traffic is not one way, of course, and 80s and 90s Japanese horror films bear the unmistakable stamp of western influence. Dario Argento, David Cronenberg and George Romero are frequently alluded to and TV series like The X-Files and Twin Peaks have also left their mark. The need to decipher cryptic clues, secret messages hidden in stones, strange cults and a cursed videotape form the raw material of recent films like Angel Dust, Organ, Cure, Hypnosis and Ring. However, the films remain highly unpredictable. As ever in Japanese art, the western influence has been absorbed and mutated, turning into something rich, strange and unmistakably Japanese.

Inspired by a series of bestselling books and a TV show, Ring has beaten Hollywood at local box offices and is today released in the UK. An American remake is also planned. Japanese horror is at a creative peak. The variety and energy of its output is astonishing. Films like Shinya Tsukamoto's Gemini (another Rampo adaptation), Higuchinsky's Spiral and Takashi Miike's Audition are rewriting the rules as to how far and fast the genre can be stretched. If the success of Ring does nothing else, let's hope it finally awakens interest in the west to this treasure trove of great cinema.

 Ring is released today. Hellish Love and Watcher in the Attic are available on DVD and VHS from Pagan Films.

House, from 1977, was an early and very quirky entry into the field. Eko Eko Azaraku (Wizard of Darkness) is a more standard example of the genre. A new girl, the mysterious Misa, discovers that her school is the centre of a series of five strange killings - a bloody pentagram. Apparently possessed of magic powers, Misa sets about unravelling the mystery. The 1995 film went on to spawn several sequels and a TV series, as well as being a clear influence on Buffy the Vampire Slayer. The traffic is not one way, of course, and 80s and 90s Japanese horror films bear the unmistakable stamp of western influence. Dario Argento, David Cronenberg and George Romero are frequently alluded to and TV series like The X-Files and Twin Peaks have also left their mark. The need to decipher cryptic clues, secret messages hidden in stones, strange cults and a cursed videotape form the raw material of recent films like Angel Dust, Organ, Cure, Hypnosis and Ring. However, the films remain highly unpredictable. As ever in Japanese art, the western influence has been absorbed and mutated, turning into something rich, strange and unmistakably Japanese. Inspired by a series of bestselling books and a TV show, Ring has beaten Hollywood at local box offices and is today released in the UK. An American remake is also planned. Japanese horror is at a creative peak. The variety and energy of its output is astonishing. Films like Shinya Tsukamoto's Gemini (another Rampo adaptation), Higuchinsky's Spiral and Takashi Miike's Audition are rewriting the rules as to how far and fast the genre can be stretched. If the success of Ring does nothing else, let's hope it finally awakens interest in the west to this treasure trove of great cinema.  Ring is released today. Hellish Love and Watcher in the Attic are available on DVD and VHS from Pagan Films.

fields.headline: Animal tests are 'science, not torture'
fields.standfirst: Workers at the HLS testing laboratory, besieged by anti-vivisectionists, ask why the government that demands the tests will not defend them
fields.trailText: Workers at the HLS testing laboratory, besieged by anti-vivisectionists, ask why the government that demands the tests will not defend them.
fields.body:
Until recently, when it became a bit of a handful and they gave it away, Frank Bonner and his family had a pet dog - a beagle. Nothing unusual about that. Except that Dr Bonner is the head of science and technology at Cambridgeshire-based Huntingdon Life Sciences, which for the sake of commercial research conducts experiments on, and then kills, around 750 beagles a year. The pet, however, was not one of these.

Its breed, said Dr Bonner, was "pure and utter coincidence". But at the end of the working day, Dr Bonner and HSDL's hundreds of scientists, technicians and administrators emerge from behind their shiny razor wire, run the gauntlet of anti-vivisectionists shouting abuse, and go home to their pets.

In all, HLS gets through about 75,000 animals a year: 87% mice and rats, 8% fish, 3% birds, 1% dogs, 0.6% monkeys, and smaller numbers of other animals, including cats.

Animal rights campaigners, who have made HLS the target of one of their most successful campaigns, are unlikely ever to be persuaded that these people love animals. But they insist they do.

"To listen to some people outside, it's as if we love nothing better than torturing animals, as if we get up in the mornings rubbing our hands and saying 'Oh goody, we're going to torture animals today'," said one HLS scientist, who, like most staff, spoke on condition of anonymity.

"We are working with animals, carrying out procedures on them, experimenting on them - but we play with them, too. In the end, of course, you give the animals a terminal injection and hold them while they are put to sleep."

The real hypocrites

The scientists went on: "To me, it's much better having people that love animals and care for animals carrying out these procedures (which government and society thinks are necessary) than people who are callous towards them."

To the animal rights movement, led in this cause by SHAC, for Stop Huntingdon Animal Cruelty, this is hypocrisy. In their view, no real animal lover would have anything to do with animal experiments. They maintain that the shocking 1997 undercover video of dogs being abused by HLS workers was not, as the company said, an isolated incident, rendered impossible by changed procedures, but a true glimpse of what still happens inside.

To the beleaguered HLS staff, who said they were as shocked and sickened by what was revealed on the video as the wider public, society, and government, were the real hypocrites.

Society wanted the cures promised by the biotech revolution. Government wanted to make sure the new treatments were safe, and enforced laws that demanded every new medicine be tested on rodents and a non-rodent species before it was given to humans. Yet, HLS staff complained, the government had failed to speak out publicly in their defence since they came under attack from animal rights activists.

The campaign to shut HLS down, which has persuaded institutional and individual investors, including the Labour party, to sell shares in the firm, has its darker side. In May, unknown persons set fire to four cars belonging to HLS employees. "All the attacks took place in the same village, within five minutes of each other," said Huntingdon's managing director, Brian Cass. "It's really, really lucky nobody was injured."

Two months earlier, in an attack not previously made public, another staff member had his car torched. He was away at the time, and his wife was alone in their home in a Yorkshire hamlet. "The first thing she knew about it was when the tyres exploded. She rushed downstairs and all she could see was a sheet of flame," said the HLS worker.

Another HLS employee said he and his wife had received mail threatening to kill them and their children. "We had packages delivered tricked up to look like bombs," he said. "We've had to call the bomb squad three times. We've had windows smashed, and 30 people outside the house during my son's first birthday party shouting and screaming abuse.

"I've been a member of the Labour party for many years. I've been very disappointed by their attitude. It's not been 'we don't like what you do'. It's been 'we completely understand what you do, we support you, but don't expect us to support you in public'. One MP said they didn't feel able to support us in public because they feared an attack on their constituency office. From an elected MP, I find that cowardly."

The Home Office minister Mike O'Brien visited HLS recently, and the government may take legal steps to give animal researchers better protection. But figures released yesterday exposed the dilemma for a government that wants to be seen as both animal-friendly and science-friendly.

Although the overall number of animal experiments fell slightly, the race to use the new genetics to develop drugs showed in a leap in use of GM lab mice and bigger animals like monkeys, cats and dogs. Dog experiments went up 20%, to 8,185.

In Huntingdon's massive dog house, which has space for almost 1,200 dogs but this week had about 480, the young beagles live in long, bare, brightly lit concrete rooms, divided up into roofless steel pens.

They each get 4.5 square metres of space. They are exercised each day in the long aisle between the pens. For much of the day, gates are opened between the pens and the dogs get to pair off for play. Sometimes staff play with the animals; there are plastic toys in the sawdust on the floor.

After a period of acclimatisation, the dogs are fed medicines and other substances under test - often in the same tablet form, with the same sort of dose, that humans might take. At the end of the study, the beagles are killed and autopsies are done to see what effect the drugs have had on their inner organs.

Society's decision

This week, 17 substances were being tested on the dogs: six anti-cancer drugs, four to treat heart disease, three designed to treat diseases of the central nervous system including one for Parkinson's disease, two for diabetes, one for lung disease, and one for a veterinary medicine.

HLS staff said they would like to see all medicines, from paracetamol to the most obscure and costly new drug, carry the label: Tested on animals. "People would suddenly realise how much of their everyday life was dependent on this," said one scientist. "It would make people more aware of why we do the work we do."

"Can you remember the last time a government minister, or one of the regulators who demands these tests, stood up and said that the government insists animal testing is carried out?" asked Mr Cass.

"People like us are at the sharp end, bearing the brunt of attacks and public attention. All of our work is for government requirements, and we feel the government should acknowledge that.

"Society has to make the decision. If we want to see new drugs being introduced, but don't want to see animals used for tests, then we have to accept a high degree of risk that things won't work out."

Not all of HLS's work is for UK government medicine requirements. Some is for overseas companies trying to satisfy their regulators; some for weedkillers and fertilisers; some for food additives. One test last year was for a company which wanted to replace long-standing synthetic preservatives in food with a "natural" alternative.

Anti-vivisectionists pointed to such experiments as examples of unnecessary testing. Even new drugs, they argued, could be checked in the test tube and by computer modelling. HLS scientists countered that the technology, while improving, was not yet ready.

"I can foresee a time when it will not be necessary to do these studies," said an HLS researcher. "In a few decades, it may well be that animal experimentation will go away forever. The difficulty is that at the moment, the non-animal tests are not robust enough, or acceptable to governments, to prove new medicines are safe."

fields.headline: The best Senate scene
fields.standfirst: X-Men
fields.trailText: X-Men
fields.body:
The near-future. Jean Grey (Famke Janssen) is addressing the US Senate; a mutant herself, she is attempting to defend them to Senator Robert Kelly (Bruce Davison), who is poised to introduce a bill calling for a national mutant register. Kelly rises to his feet.

"Three words, Miss Grey - are mutants dangerous?"

"I'm afraid that's an unfair question," Grey replies. "After all, the wrong person behind the wheel of a car can be dangerous..."

"Well, we license people to drive."

"Yes, but not to live , Senator. It is a fact that mutants who have revealed themselves have been met with fear, hostility - even violence. To force mutants to expose themselves..."

"Expose themselves? What is it the mutant community has to hide, I wonder, that makes them so afraid to identify themselves?"

"I didn't say they were hiding..."

The senator produces a piece of paper on which he claims are the names of every mutant in the US.

"A girl in Illinois who can walk through walls - now what's to stop her walking into a bank vault, or into the White House, or into their houses?"

He gestures at the other senators.

"There's even rumours of mutants so powerful they can enter our minds, taking away our free will. Ladies and gentlemen, mutants are very real... and they are among us! We must know who they are and, above all, what they can do!"

The senators erupt in wild applause.

See also: Mr Smith Goes To Washington, Gladiator, Star Wars

Don't see also: Timecop

Pointless trivia: X-Men director Bryan Singer's production company is named Bad Hat Harry after a line in his favourite film, Jaws

fields.headline: A most X-cellent adventure
fields.standfirst: At last, a summer blockbuster that lives up to its name, writes Peter Bradshaw
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: It is a delirious, ambiguous fantasy of empowerment which speaks for and to the angry, the enraged, the dispossessed, the geeky and the uncool
fields.body:
At last. Finally. After the terrible famine of summer blockbusters worth the name. After the entertainment drought that was Tom Cruise discharging his mission statement in Sydney, Australia - that well-known centre of international excitement. After handing over our miserable enjoyment ration coupon in return for George Clooney shouting and wearing a big jumper on the high seas. After all this, at last, a proper summer film is here. Better late than never.

X-Men is the live-action version of the bizarre mutant anti-heroes of the Stan Lee comic strip, directed by Bryan Singer, and it is preposterous and sinister and enjoyable.

X-Men are the mutants of our planet earth in the not-too-distant future, an oppressed and harassed minority which a reactionary political establishment wishes to register and marginalise out of existence. The X-Men have got this way, not through the time-honoured Marvel comics convention of the nuclear or radiation accident, the kind of fateful event that befell Peter Parker or studious Dr Bruce Banner; but on account of the general workings of "evolution".

The mutants are not subject to any debilitating physical dysfunction or unsightly disfigurement. By and large it means they are very good-looking and able to do fantastically cool stuff like channelling lightning bolts and making claws come out of their hands.

But there is a serious ideological rift within the mutants. There is a liberal wing, led by Professor Xavier (Patrick Stewart) a telepath who believes in rapprochement with ordinary humans, despite the fact that humans hate and fear them.

On his side are Storm (Halle Berry) who makes her eyes go white and harnesses lightning bolts, and Cyclops (James Marsden) who can omit optic blasts through his wraparound Ray-Bans. (Cyclops's powers are a bit rubbish, really - if he loses his Ray-Bans behind the sofa, he is stuffed.) And there is Dr Jean Grey, who has telekinetic powers. She does not have an X-Men name. Perhaps she is weighing up a provisional shortlist.

Ranged against Prof Xavier's enlightened posse are the radical wing led by Magneto - sometimes wearing a snugly-fitting helmet, sometimes not - played by the superb Ian McKellen. They are, if you will, Real X-Men or Continuity X-Men, who believe that any peace process with humans is futile. Ordinary human folk, those vanilla mammals, will only ever want to destroy mutants, so they must be annihilated, or rather themselves turned en masse into mutants by a single nuclear blast from a new weapon Magneto is developing in his magnificent lair.

On Magneto's team are Mystique (Rebecca Romijn-Stamos), who is completely blue and can transform herself into any person. And there's a couple of lower-rank supporting-class X-Men: Sabretooth (Tyler Mane) a grunting, shambling monster, and Toad (Ray Park) who is basically an ugly bloke with a long tongue.

Magneto and Professor Xavier are at war, and their immediate bone of contention is the recruitment of a couple of likely new candidates. Rogue (Anna Paquin) is a lovely, confused young woman who destroys anyone she touches. Then there is Wolverine (Hugh Jackman), someone of awesome strength, healing powers, with the ability to make great steel claws spring out of his hands. Wolverine has the most extraordinary hair of all the X-Men, teased up into two peaks at the back of the head, like horns.

When we first see Wolverine, he is earning a modest crust on the Ultimate Fighting Circuit of northern Canada. Lounging against the corner of the fighting cage, he takes on all-comers, and gives them what can only be described as a right spanking, though unsportingly neglecting to reveal his genetic advantages. It is Wolverine, handsome, macho, hairy-but-not-too-hairy, who is the star of the show, instinctively on Professor Xavier's side, though amusingly detached from his organisation, and nursing a major horn for the lovely Dr Jean Grey, lovable impetuous X-Man that he is.

Singer devises for the X-Men some entertaining action sequences, and fight scenarios, the hi-tech slapstick is shrewdly pitched short of the explicit violent level to keep the picture within its teen target range. There is a funny scene in which Magneto, bristling with contempt for homo sapiens, flips over a couple of police cars, and makes the cops' weaponry float out of their hands and start shooting at the terrified officers of the law.

But the really extraordinary sequence comes at the very beginning, a moment of sheer audacity, which if managed with any less deadpan bravado would certainly be offensive. And even as it is, it is right out there on an edge of provocation undreamt of by other mainstream Hollywood movies.

Singer devises an opening scene set in Poland, 1944, with terrified Jews being herded up behind barbed wire by Nazis; a young boy is separated from his parents and with a howl of anguish sends some Nazi goons sprawling and bends the gates open with sheer brainwaves. Which X-Man will this victim of history grow up to be in modern America? Suffice to say, the final showdown is in Ellis Island, through which he passed in 1949, and this is the location for the X-Man's toweringly sarcastic denunciation of the US as a cradle of pluralism and tolerance.

Singer's X-Men is the flip-side of happy, confident, multicultural America; this is an America at unease with itself. It is a delirious, ambiguous fantasy of empowerment which speaks for and to the angry, the enraged, the dispossessed, the geeky and the uncool. It has that aspect of darkness which Singer brought to The Usual Suspects and Apt Pupil, which also interestingly brought rumours and memories of Nazism into modern America. And it is a pleasure to see those old RSC players, Stewart and McKellen, who 20 years ago were giving us their Oberon and Macbeth at Stratford, given such mighty, meaty roles on the big screen.
